text:
Who doesn't love voodoo??? Where else can you find a doughnut with your favorite cereal or candy on it? The downtown location is small and parking is always hard to come by, but if you park in Chinatown and are willing to walk a couple blocks to get there then it's no biggie.

The only downside to voodoo is probably the staff. I've never gotten a friendly vibe from any of them, which is probably just because they are always so incredibly busy in there.

To showcase some of their more interesting doughnuts, all of which I have tried and loved:

Old Dirty Bastard - a raised doughnut with chocolate topping, crushed oreos and peanut butter drizzle

Bacon Maple Bar - yes... it's real bacon. Your standard maple bar with two lovely, crispy and fresh strips of bacon on top. Get over the weird and get with the bacon... this is amazing

Cock n Balls - this is your basic raised doughnut with chocolate topping.... cream-filled, of course! They will even put custom writing on top if you want. It's like $5 and could feel a family of four. Go for it!

Then, there are various raised and cake/frosted doughnuts with toppings such as oreos, Captain Crunch, Cocoa Puffs, Rice Crispies, pixie stix, bubble gum, marshmallows, and yes.... even Tang.

One big word to the wise.... they only take CASH... so come prepared. Prices per doughnut range from about $1 each to $5, and I think a dozen is around $15 if you pick them out yourself. I highly recommend this every time you are in Portland.

They are located next door to a porno theater and across the street from a strip join on the edge of china town. Probably not so savory for children and I wouldn't feel comfortable walking around there alone as a single woman, but with a friend or two I say go for it! Right off bus route 20.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Portland landmark must visit for any foodie. Some of my favoirtes are maple bar with bacon, the ol dirty bastard and the tex ass. Bring cash no plastic here cash money only
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I went here last week while in Portland for the very first time. I was told by many people that Voodoo Doughnuts is a requirement while visiting. My friend and I stopped in around dinnertime on a weekday and, to our surprise, there were only about 10 people in line. I had expected much worse--these sort of places always seem to involve long waits. The shop itself was tiny but serves its purpose well... the process was very efficient, and there were a lot of entertaining decorations to look at.

I purchased two doughnuts: a crueller with chocolate icing and "the loop" (I don't really even like Fruit Loops, but this was an impulse purchase). Upon getting back to our hotel, I ate (or ate MOST of) the massive "loop" doughnut. It was good, but a bit much for me. I had the crueller the next morning and enjoyed that much more--it was very flaky and the chocolate icing was rich without being overly sweet. 

As a bonus, the staff members were very outgoing and friendly!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Bravo, Voodoo Doughnut, for such creativity and supplying the drunken clientele with late-night next-day-regretting snacks.  

The decor, staff and doughnut options (Blazer Blunt, anyone?) are so Portland.  The maple bacon draws in the most attention and deservedly so.  I used to think I only liked this place because I was so wasted that any unhealthy food sounded good as long as it was served quickly, but I've enjoyed these doughnuts in sobriety as well.

Only get the fruit powdered ones (Mango Tango, Grape Ape) if you're craving the super-sweet.  The cereal topped treats are great, if you like that particular cereal, that is.

Thank you, Voodoo for my Blazer Blunt, the titters over the Cock and Balls, giving my friend his Mango Tango and just for being there for Portland.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I had a lot of fun at this place mainly taking pictures of the donuts. I got the classic voodoo doll donut and it was probably the coolest looking donut I've gotten. text:
24 hour donut shop, AND they're not stale when you pick up a few in the middle of the night?! Yesss! This shop is the definition of Portland - complete with hipsters and smokers alike standing around outside. Voodoo is a tiny little shop so don't be surprised if there's a line extending outside the door. It goes by super fast unless you're stuck behind an indecisive donut eater. Voodoo is conveniently located next to a big alley filled with tables and plenty of seating if you want to eat your donut right away. 

They do have a ton of options here, might as well get at least a dozen! All of their flavors are listed on a chalkboard on the wall, but some of the uniquely named ones don't have descriptions, so you might just have to wing it. There's a rotating donut case too if you want to decide by looks instead of description. I didn't want anything crazy but nothing boring either, so I went with the Portland cream donut, nicely described as "Portland's official doughnut." Sounds good to me...and it was! It's chocolate glazed and inside there's a custard-type of cream... it almost reminded me of a Boston Cream Pie. The donut tasted dense and fresh, no wimpy grocery store donuts here. I also tasted my boyfriend's Voodoo donut and the Mango Tango donut. The Voodoo donut is more for its looks - since they decorate it just like a Voodoo doll. Tasty, but it's basically just a chocolate frosted donut. The Mango Tango donut was really good though - packed with mango flavored jelly and topped with a thick glaze. That was probably my favorite of the three, since it was the most unique... you rarely see a Mango donut at your neighborhood donut store! And we didn't eat it until the next night, and it tasted just as good.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Eh, it's basically a stop for tourists to come and take a food-selfie. The lines are often completely ridiculous and no where near worth it for the quality of the donuts they have. Granted a couple of them are fairly decent quality and taste-wise, but a majority of them are more for entertainment or novelty purposes rather than for flavor. I would rather go to a place that has really good donuts than to wait in line for an hour to get a penis shaped donut or a donut covered in stale fruit loops.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Probably wouldn't come back to this tourist spot. The hugely popular Voodoo Doughnut was crowded and a bit dirty. There are better donut shops in Portland. Give them all a try. No need to buy a dozen at each stop.

Note: I felt like my Voodoo Doll donut may have had traces of nuts. I had a slight reaction after a small bite.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: It was a nice rainy day in Portland and the line was out the door. They were nice enough to pass out some coffee and donuts to those of us waiting. What great donuts, awesome experience and service to go with it

text:
The line is hilarious.  It's so long, you'd think all these people are waiting to get into a hot nightclub but no, we're all waiting for our Voodoo Doughnuts!  Don't worry though - the line actually goes by pretty fast and it's well, well, WELL worth the wait!

I was most shocked by how GOOD the prices are at this place.  As such a hyped up, must-see Portland attraction, I expected the prices to be overpriced but they weren't.  I don't remember the exact prices, but there were many doughnuts that only cost around a dollar each.

I ordered a "Voodoo Doll," which was great!  It's a doughnut shaped like a little voodoo doll, with a little pretzel stick you use to poke at it and see the jelly filling ooze out.  I also ordered a Portland Cream which was amazing, and a glazed French Crueller, also good.

I'd give this place SIX stars if I could!  BTW, remember to bring cash.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
When in Portland...

Vegan donuts = Win

We got lucky and visited when there was really no line. We had the namesake Voodoo doll donut and the chocolate/Oreo/PB donut. They were both delicious, decadent and fun. 

The creative decorations and flavor combinations make this place worth visiting again!

It's a small shop and I can imagine it must be kind of crazy when the lines are long, but the employees were really friendly and pleasant. The only downsides are the kind of shady area with people begging and having to pay for parking.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Yea- wow- majorly cool and majorly good. we enjoyed... Only in Portland...You guys rock!

text: Ok, we went here because of the enormous amount of reviews. The location is downtown near the waterfront and chinatown, the titles of the doughnuts are catchy but the flavors mask the doughnut taste. If you have ever had a malasada, voodoo doughnuts are no match. You should try it to blend in with everyone else or to be the favor of a party but not try it because you are a cop and want to taste the best donut Portland has to offer.

text: I have tried voodoo both times I've been to Portland, there's always a long line but it moves pretty fast. Things are little crazy in there so both times I've asked for a dozen that they pick. The second time the girl at the counter was not friendly, I asked for an extra maple bacon, and she gave me one, then she have me about eight donuts that are essentially the same just with different stale cereal toppings. Stale sugar doughnuts with fruit loops, Oreos, fruity pebbles, sprinkles, all stale. They make a decent cake doughnut, try blueberry if that's your thing, and they have pretty good vegan doughnuts. Otter than that I don't think I'll be back.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I had to see what all the hype was about. The line was out the door but it went fairly quickly. After reading all the reviews about the rude employees that don't seem to like customers who ask questions, I felt a little intimidated.  If they don't like the questions, I'm not sure why they don't post menus explaining each donut and what they contain. Seems like if you're going to have customers waiting in a long line out  the door, you would post a descriptive menu on the window to read while you wait. I took my chances and just ordered 3 varieties. The Portland cream, plain glaze, and another one that had rice crispees and peanut butter on top. Sound gross but I asked her for something with peanut butter and that's what I got. The Portland cream was definitely the favorite and very good. The rest were just ok. I will take a hot crispy cream glaze donut any day over these. I'm glad I tried them but I don't need to go back!   
BTW I didn't feel the employees were rude, not overly friendly or welcoming but then again, I don't think I would either dealing with nonstop crowds!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Definitely have to go just for the experience of Voodoo but the doughnuts aren't the best I have ever had and you will wait in line forever! But once you get through the line you will have your pink box and a one of a kind Portland experience. - Make sure to bring cash!!! they don't accept CCs. 
** if you can get the doughnut fresh out of the oven when they are still just a bit warm they are much better!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Took a quick little trip to Portland for a birthday celebration and our first stop there was Voodoo Donuts!

My boyfriend has always wanted to try the maple bar with bacon on top and I was open to trying anything they had.  So as our second choice we got an Old Dirty Bastard.  We tried the maple bar first and we were both amazed with how good it was!  We talked about how it's kind of a novelty type of place and that it doesn't have to be good to sell donuts because, well, they're just so unique.  However this was so tasty!  The maple wasn't too sweet and the bacon was the perfect crispness and saltiness to just make it all work.  It was sublime.  
Next was the ODB and that was HEAVEN!  A raised donut with chocolate frosting covered with oreos and drizzled with peanut butter!!!  So good and what a sugar shock!!!  It was worth it though, I desperately needed a glass of milk with it though!!

So two thumbs up from me on this place.  It's a novelty shop, but has really tasty donuts to boot!  Now I say to thee, divide and conquer!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:

Also, the doughnuts are actually good. Don't be turned away by all the bells and whistles they pile on.

text:
Stopped in on my way back home from Portland and ordered a chocolate donut with crushed butterfinger topping.  Best donut ever.

A pair of down-on-their-luck panhandler dudes camped outside said hello to me on my way in, which I must have just ignored.  On my way out, one of the dudes stood up and petulantly muttered "when someone says hello to you, you should say hello back!", and then stormed off down the block indignantly.

My GF and I just laughed it off.  We're from a city south of Portland that is infamous for it's abundant homeless population, and no, we don't feel obligated to greet every panhandler we see with a smile and warm hello.

I guess we're just assholes that way.  :)
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Passed through Portland and me and my friends had to stop to get some donuts. I was planning on getting a dozen but I felt totally rushed even tho it wasn't busy at all. The donuts are in a spinning case with no labels so you just gotta guess. The bathroom door had a sign that said 'out of order' but I saw a girl coming out of it so maybe it was just a lie? I asked the cashiers where the closest bathroom was and they replied 'I don't know I'm not from around here.' I couldn't tell if they were messing with me but I had to PEE. anyways when entering I had to step over a homeless junkie who was obviously having withdrawals. The donut was okay I guess. I've been to psycho donuts in San Jose and those are waaaay better and they don't rush you.

text:
I had one day in Portland, so we decided to stop by Voodoo.  Look, they're good donuts.  But I really enjoyed the regular donuts over most of the creative/weird ones.  Grape Ape?  Disgusting.  No one in my family wanted to finish that thing.

The wait wasn't really that bad.  We had done the research; we knew it was going to be busy.  It was maybe only 20 minutes for us.

Definitely just went to try it, but I've had better donuts.  I don't regret the visit though; definitely interesting.

text:
I loved the fun, variety and creativity of the different kinds of donuts. There's Voodoo and Blue Star, and I think one should try both because they're different.  

Voodoo has your kitschy, pop-culture kind of donuts (e.g. with toppings like Tang, grape Kool-aid, various crushed candy bars, cookies and supernaturally-colored childhood breakfast cereals)... and others veering towards the creepy side (e.g. the famous voodoo doll stabbed with a pretzel and pentagram-sporting "diabolus rex").  Check out the flavors on their website...they even have vegan and gluten-free donuts!

My hubby got the larger crushed-Oreo covered "dirt" donut, and I got the smaller, innocent-looking "Mexican hot chocolate" chocolate cake donut, dusted in chili-sugar.  And the price was so right... 2 donuts and a coffee for around $5!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: They're OK.  Nothing great.  The different topping on the donuts are pretty interesting.  Just not too appealing to me.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Man...this place is hyped! I have had dozens and dozens of people tell me that Voodoo is amazing, and have seen the pink boxes around town. Hell, I even saw people on the plane coming from Portland with boxes! It is on television, celebrities have endorsed it...sheesh, how else could this place be advertised? Jesus coming down from heaven and personally blessing the place? Jokes aside, I decided to see what the hype was about...and found out that it's just that, hype. 

After waiting over fifteen minutes (only three people in front of me. But the hipster clerk wouldn't let anyone else pay until a customer used the ATM to get cash), I finally ordered my two doughnuts (bacon maple bar, and regular maple bar), and payed almost five bucks(!) for the two. Now that should have payed for two doughnuts, plus coffee at any other place, but I figured that the doughnuts should be good enough, right? Not quite.

Simply put, the doughnuts were nasty. The bacon tasted old, and the icing was way, way too sweet. To the point where I felt like vomiting afterwards. I couldn't even finish the second doughnut, because the sweetness was just killer. Some of you may think I am a wuss...but come on, try it yourself and see. I'd like to see you choke down two of the maple bars. And if you do...join the forces of Wilford Brimley in fighting diabeetus. 

As mentioned earlier, the smarmy hipster clerk just pissed me off. She had this air of superiority around her, like if she didn't exist, the whole place would fall apart. There was another hipster behind the counter, who did not open up a second register to help out the long line, and seemed to just sit and stare into space. What was his job? I honestly don't know. 

I don't understand the shit-craze everybody has for Voodoo. Everyone makes it sound like it's super original and trendy, but in all truth the doughnuts are sub-par and pricey. Clerks are super rude, they only take cash, the lines are long...and just the simple fact that it's overrated. It is just like those cupcake places that have sprung up in every metropolitan area. It is cool for the moment, but eventually it will collapse when something else "cool" comes around.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Voodoo Doughnut was a long drive for me. I live in Washington. Personally, I thought  the donuts were not really worth it. The bacon maple donut is the only donut that i liked, because of the bacon. Only go if you are craving sugary sweet donuts and willing to stand in a two hour line.

text:
Made my way here the first day I was in Portland and there was a crazy , crazyyyy long line. No thank you! I did enough waiting for one day, so decided to stop in on my last day in portland. Stopped in around 9am on a Monday and I was a pretty happy girl - No lINE & even happier with my nom nom's in hand, lol! :) 

Picked out a few of the doughnuts :

Fried dough with banana chunks and cinnamon sugar covered in a glaze with chocolate frosting, peanut butter, peanuts and chocolate chips on top!
*Apple Fritter

My tummy was pretty satisfied with my 2favs-bacon maple and the Memphis mafia! 

The whole "Cash ONLY"  was such an inconvenience.  So make sure you bring cash!  There are 2ATMS right next to the place, but they are filthy! !! Really filthy , lol!

text:
I would recommend Voodoo to a first-timer, or somebody looking for a good experience, but not much for the doughnuts. I used to love Voodoo; of course, I've noticed a diminishment in quality and service the last couple years.

If you're looking for good doughnuts, I recommend Blue Star or Annie's. Blue Star is great for artisan, gourmet doughnuts whereas Annie's is inexpensive and very reliable.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Great donuts as always, BUT... I bought Rogue's 22 oz bottle of Maple Bacon Ale which a rep was selling at Voodoo Donut. It was $13 which is well above what anyone should ever pay for 22 ounces of beer but I took a chance - key word... "chance". I understand now why they weren't tasting the beer and force people to make a blind purchase - it was H-O-R-R-I-B-L-E. I brought it to a party with a bunch of friends - quite a few beer connoisseurs - none could finish the 2 oz sample I poured. I tried to give it chance - came back to it a couple of times - no luck. I feel robbed. At least I have a story to tell. Find a way to get a sample before you buy - if all else fails, call me - I have quite a bit left. Rogue - pretty bottle, but you can do MUCH better.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Today was my first time having a Voodoo Doughnut. I thought it wasn't going to be a big deal. I've eaten donuts before ;), but these are unparalleled. I had a cinnamon and sugar doughnut and a glazed. My husband really liked his maple bar, and my Grandma said her apple fritter was perfect. Yummy, yummy.

text: Oh Voodoo, you are sitting in the back counting your green going SUCKERS!! I am a Chicago donut connoisseur!  You are par with Dunkin, but you market and have made a niche for yourself. Brilliant!!! I laugh when i drive bye and see the hundreds of tourist waiting in line for your big pink box. Suckers!!!! Donut on!

text:
Definitely gimmicky but I think that's kind of the point. I brought a friend that was visiting from out of town. Being new here I had not been to Voodoo yet either. I wouldn't wait in line for it if I didn't have an out of towner with me with a time frame, especially with the camp out of people asking for change on the corner where the line wraps around the block. That's just annoying, especially when they're parked under the only spot that's covered when it's raining. I also got a $60 parking ticket for not backing my car in the spaces just out front. It was raining, and I was parked between two big SUV's (one parked front in and one backed in) in my little car so I couldn't see the two signs on the ends of this parking strip that said to back in. I'm hoping they will let me off if I take a picture into the courthouse that shows that I really couldn't see that sign. 

Despite all of that, it is a fun place if only because it's different. I like independent businesses that figure out how to do so well selling things as simple as donuts! The staff doesn't have time for you to be a slow wishy washy goober at the counter but they weren't ever rude. They weren't overly nice, but there's a lot of potential to be rude and the staff was generally pretty nice. After reading reviews, waiting at least 20 minutes in line, and just seeing the set up, I was happy to not have to face a tragically hip jerk at the counter. They were out of the first 4 donuts I wanted to try but egh... it's a doughnut! It's not like they don't have a variety AND they did tell me that more were coming up if I wanted to wait. 

There was a little poster with just a very few donuts with descriptions on it by the glass case. With how busy it gets I'm blown away that they don't have more of those up to help people decide while they wait in line!!! I have to believe it would make the line go so much faster! I'd probably give them that last star just for that since the line situation is ridiculous and there's a pretty simple solution that would at least make it better. OH, AND CASH ONLY!! I usually don't carry cash, but it would SUCK to wait in that line just to find out that you can't pay with your card!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: yuuummmm.. more later
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Ive lived in Portland 25 years and just had my first taste of voodoo in the past 6 months via an office gathering. Im not a doughnut fan but I dont hate them either. These are just doughnuts folks. A lot of them are even a little over the top which I hear is a selling point for a lot of people but there are tastier ways to elevate your A1C as far as Im concerned. If you love doughnuts go to pretty much any doughnut shop in town. If you love long lines, people rudely blocking your path in their selfie taking oblivion and despondent "over it" staff ordering your dozen for you because your just too slow. Go to voodoo.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Thanks goodness the lines are so long, or I would probable live on these donuts. Man they are so good!!!!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Having a pink box gets a girl a lot of attention!

As do Voodoo Doughnuts innuendos.  And they are very well marketed; the magic, IS indeed in the hole.

My top 3 favorites are: 
Maple Bacon Bar- those flavors go so perfectly together.
Gay Bar-  There are fruit loops on this donut. 
Grape Ape- lavender and grape!  Oh yes yes.  I love these flavors together too. 

The best thing about these donuts is the fact that they are always FRESH.  The dough practically melts in my mouth.  

Today it was raining and there was absolutely no line.  Usually I can see it from a mile away.  I call it the VDL: Visible Doughnut Line.   But today- none.  I had reached Mecca.  Through the wind and the rain.  Donning a broken umbrella.  And it was worth it, every step of he way. 

Best conversation from strangers: 
Homeless Man: "You have a pink box." Me: "I am well aware." Homeless man: "You have some sugar on your chin." Me: "I was unaware, but I think I'll just keep it there. Thanks, though." Homeless Man: "Have a great day."

Second best conversation- Lady on hotel elevator: "Oh my! Voodoo donuts! I hear all about those on the food network! Is it worth the walk? How far is it? How many donuts are in that box? Do you work for the airlines?" Me: "Yes, .7 miles according to my phone, 13, yes."

Needless to say, I love this place.  It sends me to Donut Nirvana.  

PS-  How do you spell doughnut/donut?
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Had to stop here during my first trip to Portland and I'm a fan. We wanted to try Blue Star first but they were sold out for the day, so we headed over to Voodoo. The line was pretty long but moved at a good pace. Good stuff, Voodoo is a win!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I stopped by here with my wife whenever we were in Portland.  It seems like everyone has heard of Voodoo doughnuts and wants to give them a try.  So it wasn't surprising that there was a huge line outside the shop whenever we go there.  Thankfully that long line doesn't take too long to get through.  Whenever you finally make it into the shop you are able to see a pretty nice space.  It was brightly colored with lots of photos on the wall and had a cool chandelier type light.  By the time we got up to the spot to order we had already made our selections long before.  So it was with great sadness that they told me that they were out of the lemon chiffon that I wanted.  As a quick backup selection I ended up ordering the maple bacon bar.  We then made it to the register and paid our cash (it's a cash only place) before heading outside to sit at one of their tables.  The doughnut portion of my bar ended up being fresh and really good while I also enjoyed the bacon.  What I didn't enjoy as much was the maple frosting which i found to be a bit too sweet for me.

The bottom line for me is that I would head back here again in the future.  Hopefully the next time they will have the lemon chiffon and I can leave a bit more impressed.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I visited this place twice in one day.  The first time I visited was around noon and there was a long line around the corner.  Not worth the wait as I wanted to explore more of Portland.  Came back again around 11pm, no line this time.  For two people we ended up getting the No Name, Old Dirty Bastard, a regular glazed doughnut, and the maple bacon bar (my favorite!!!).  Of course, we didn't eat it in one sitting though ;)
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: get the "dirty old bastard", you won't regret it!:) I tried the maple syrup bacon donut that Anthony Bourdain went crazy over, and I can't say i iked it. It was way too sweet. maybe if they made a "bacon and eggs" donut w/ a salty flair I'd like it! how bout that voodoo??
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
When Anthony Bourdain says you should try something, I'll go for it. 

Three words: Maple Bacon Doughnut. Yes, I said maple bacon. This sounds gross, but I've got to tell you that it was quite amazing.  The saltiness of the bacon brought out the sweetness of the maple. Yeah, Bourdain got this one right. 

Another thing he got right was the fact that these are highly addictive. I went back the next day for another. It was a staple of my diet the short time I was in Portland.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I did what most other people do when visting a new spot, see where Adam Richman has visited on his past shows (Man vs. Food, peoples). So after all the hype and hearsay, we decided to check this spot out. Love the fact that it is downtown and you get the listen to some whack ass kids trying to sing (yeah, they sucked), but standing in line and people watching was a blast. Some cute chicks, some weird ass cats, and tourists (like me) all waiting for the delicousness of the voodoo doughnuts. I am sold!!! They have some pretty crazy combos and I had to get the dozen cause where else would I get a crunch berry donut. a cocoa puffs donut? a bubble gum donut and the infamous voodoo dude donut! I am serious, this place is damn good and a donut is not a donut people!!! Check it out, cause it really is worth the wait. Peace
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
preface: i am not a doughnut connoisseur. I cannot remember the last time I had a doughnut.


we went here on a friend's suggestion. the selection is pretty creative. you will find a line out the door. the staff does their best to expedite orders.

the maple and bacon tasted better than it looked, the sweet and salty flavors complemented each other. the Tex-Ass was huge and I had to go for a cup of green afterward to wash down the sugar.
I wanted to ask for the "Cock - N - Balls" doughnut  but did not have enough room to fit down my throat. hehehe

overall, as a novelty experience, it was great.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
O. M. G. 

I went into this place with an already well-developed LOVE for doughnuts. When I heard there was a doughnut place that was on the food network and supposedly exceptional RIGHT UP THE ROAD from where I was, there was no stopping me. 

The doughnuts are Freakin delicious! Mmmmm. So bomb. 

They get an extra star for creativity, with doughnuts such as bubble gum, captain crunch, the Gay bar, and even Cock and Balls (although I more than likely would never order it) I thought it was funny.  We got a "Voo doo Dozen," which consists of the counter guy randomly picking different doughnuts for you.  With all the choices, that made life much easier, because I thought I'd never decide. :)

The actual inside wasn't much to speak of. It is a tiny little hole in the wall. They only accept cash, but have an ATM inside. Next time I go to Portland, I for sure will go back for more doughnuts!! I love it when a place lives up to it's reputation.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Meh doughnuts... a tourist trap.  Fun ideas though, wish they tasted better.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Note: If you are going here for vegan doughnuts on a weekend, don't bother. Head over to Sweet Pea Bakery. Support an all vegan bakery with better tasting doughnuts. 

Who do they think they are? The Doughnut Nazi's? Only reason we tried this the first time is because I wanted a vegan doughnut while we were visiting. My husband went to pick them up and when he came back he was a little annoyed. The guy behind the counter was super rude and the line was long. I was surprised that my doughnuts weren't that good and he said neither were his non vegan ones. 

We moved to the Portland area and went again recently after a day walking around town and eating Delicious Thai Cart Food (with awesome service). After waiting in a line for about 30 minutes we get up there and there is only one guy doing the cash register and getting the doughnuts. He's got an attitude like he wishes he wasn't there and he's doing us a favor. We order our doughnuts and I have to scrape the frosting off of mine because it is unbearably sweet. 

Then just today I went down there to get three dozen for my daughters bday tomorrow in class. Line was only about three people out the door. Once I got up to the front there I got a blank stare from a skinny chick that could double as a meth head ( I know I'm being mean). I told her I needed three dozen and I swear she rolled her eyes and sighed. I asked if she had a dozen chocolate glazed vegan doughnuts and she looks at me so perturbed and says "no". So I said, OK, how much you got. She actually starts getting them and then realizes that she does have them. Then I point to above them and say and ask for a dozen of the plain glazed. She snaps at me "are they vegan? If they are, you have to tell me or I'm gonna give you non vegan!" Again, maybe too much meth? It didn't get much better as I picked the remaining. She took my money when I was done and her "thanks" was very phony. I walked out of there and swore they would never get any of my money ever again. 

Now I can imagine if their doughnuts were the best around but they are not. My husband gets the non vegan ones and says Krispy Kreme is much better. The vegan ones aren't that great either. Especially the powder. Made me ill. And I just get the feeling that if they are going to treat me that bad when I'm ordering maybe the doughnuts aren't even vegan. Next time I need vegan doughnuts during the week I'm calling a vegan baker and seeing if they can make them for me. Otherwise, if I really want a doughnut I'll wait for Saturday and go to Sweet Pea.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I have to say I was so excited to be able to go here, after all it was one of the first things that came up when I googled Portland.  Apparently I should have took the time to read some reviews first.  After waiting in line for 25 minutes on a weekday afternoon to get a doughnut, the ordering process was bad, I had no idea what any of them actually were because of the crazy names so had to ask a ton of questions, when all was said and done I walked out with a dozen priced at $24.75 and was ready to experience pure bliss in a pastry, it only took me one bite to realize that the only reason they were popular was the crazy names and the voodoo doughnut.  I got the apple fritter and my mouth was so coated in grease I had to go get a drink to stop from feeling sick.  

In short Save your money and your time, because Krispy Kreme is WAY better.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Stale doughnuts and obnoxious employees. If you want to wait in line for forty five minutes to get doughnuts that have been sitting out all day, then stop by.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I love the interior of this place. With so many great doughnut places out there though, the line is always the biggest turnoff  to me. I do enjoy the Portland Creme, the voodoo, and the Elvis fritter thingy. It's always a treat when someone is visiting town. Don't forget cash!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I've seen / heard about VooDoo doughnuts literally everywhere - especially Instagram. So when I was visiting my grandma I knew I had to do this while I was in town visiting. The store is really cute and the doughnuts are the cutest thing I've ever seen, but they are SO SWEET AND RICH. If you're really into rich, doughy treats then you'll love this place. It was a little too sweet for me (which is nuts because I'm a huge sugar / sweets eater) but I couldn't even finish one doughnut. Not knowing how sweet they were, my mom and I bought a box of 24 to take back home to give to people and we ended up giving away all of them saving none for ourselves because they were just way too much for us. I think this place is mostly just for looks and to take pics of the doughnuts and if you're going, just buy one to eat there. Other than that, cute place & if you're in Portland, stop by to check out all the hype!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

much satisfied.

Crunch donut along with an RC Cola, which made for a unique mix. If you sit outside at one of the picnic tables, you'll be visited by pigeons begging for crumbs and homeless heroin addicts asking for a dollar or a beer. Keep Portland Weird!!!

text: Voodoo Doughnut is a Portland novelty, not a good doughnut bakery.  I would say go at lease once, just to say you have. Luckily we hit it at the right time and did not wait in line at all.  The doughnuts are very dry and not good at all.  My daughters thought they were literally the worst doughnuts they have ever had.  We will not go back.  If you're looking for a good doughnut, Voodoo is not the place, do not waste your time.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Oh, Voodoo. You broke my heart. How I wanted to like you.

We came here on a ridiculously steamy Friday night (88 degrees at 10:30 pm ... in Portland?) to pay tribute. We waded through what appears to be Portland's version of what every city has ... an obnoxious club district. It was very Portland-style, though, and I leave you to interpret that in your own way.

We got the Voodoo Dozen and brought the box back to our gracious hostess. We all agreed that the novelty far outstripped the flavor. These babies just ain't fresh. No amount of Butterfinger, bubble-gum flavor, or M & Ms can hide that. Not to mention the fact that I wanted to clock all the little club bitches teetering on their tiny heels. (Isn't this supposed to be the Northwest? Get out your Timberlands, ladies, even on a crazy-hot night like tonight! Represent, damn you!)

Two stars for sheer originality. I would still get married here. But I am already married. Signed, Crazy From the Heat.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Best doughnuts I have ever had in my life, bar none.  Must get the voodoo doll!!  What do they put in that chocolate?  YUM!  We also ordered the ODB and the maple with Bavarian cream.  Great choices all around.  Wish we had one in LA!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
This is its own, unique experience. 

We went to the location on 3rd as we heard it was more "authentic" and they were right.  

It's a little intimidating for a VooDoo virgin.  The space is small, the music is intense (Sid Vicious blaring in the background), and you have to know what you want. 

I opted for the Portland Cream and the Miami Vice Berry.  My boyfriend tried out The Loop and Neapolitan.  

The portland cream was amazing.  The Miami Vice Berry was a little too sweet for me.  The Loop, according to the boyfriend, was just a doughnut with fruit loops on it, and his Neapolitan was "bad ass". 

I would totally go back, there are so many great options to try.  Like they say... the magic is in the hole.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Just an average donut shop. Actually, I think they are overrated.

The last time I went there I ordered a raspberry filled donut and it was only full of air, unfortunately!

I prefer Krispy Kreme after 9 at night, when you can get a really good deal on a dozen.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
I always pick up doughnuts for everyone I visit during work trips and then I bring some home after for locals.  It is interesting to see all of the pink take out boxes in the airport.  They will allow you to take these through security, something most airports won't allow.  

I brought these back to a stone brewing event in San Jose and I easily could have taken $5 a pop but I kept them all for my crew!  I am not sellout.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Living in Seattle I've ventured off to Oregon about 6 times in the past 3 years.  Of those four times, a trip to VooDoo was never passed up.  

First hearing about it from Anothony Bourdain and his encounter with the "Maple Bacon Bar", I made that my doughnut of choice.  It was a little to sweet for my liking and I could have done without the bacon but I still enjoyed it.  The doughnut itself was soft and moist, not doughy.  My friend had the "No Name".  I loved it, it was like a different take on a s'more.

I have tried just about every doughnut on the menu and can narrow it down to a top three: The Memphis Mafia, Miami Vice and McMinnville Cream.

VooDoo wins for fun and comfort.

I am not a fan of the super sweet frosting and topping overload but it keeps me from overeating!  These doughnuts are soft, moist and made fresh.  A plus in my book! They also provide a vegan selection.

A must when traveling with young adults and the young at heart!

TIPS:
- Open 24 Hours
- Street Parking
- Cash Only (ATM inside)
- Long Lines
- Selection is limited in the evenings.
- Bring a Camera
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: It was my favorite coworkers/close friend's last day of work and I got up at the break of dawn for these tasty treats. SOOOO worth it. I picked up a box of their recommended dozen and NO ONE was disappointed. I was pleasantly surprised by a couple thrown in there that I never would've tried on my own. I shall be back ;)

text:
On a Sunday morning I step out of the hotel and into the freezing wind that's blowing all around the city. I just wanted two doughnuts and Voodoo doughnuts is 4 blocks away... this shouldn't take more than 15 minutes right?

Not quite. The only way the number 15 was accurate was that I had predicted the number of people lined up outside the store. It was freezing and I had forgot a jacket, but I waited. It took probably 20 minutes just to get inside and wait more. Once inside it was at least warm, I could hear the Velvet Underground (and the employee up front singing along... sadly his voice paled in comparison to Lou Reed) and smell the deep fryer. 

Finally got the doughnuts and left. They're real tasty, real gimmicky, and given the same situation, I'll probably go again. But couldn't they just go ahead and put a second person up front to grab people's doughnuts... on weekend mornings at least? I'll bet they could justify it by adding someone to sing Nico's part...
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Everytime I go they have fresh doughnuts, never are out of anything, always taste good, and i love that they have a secret bucket option! :)

text: There are varied types of Donuts that they serve.   Somehow I prefer a hot donut served at Krispy Kreme over Voodoo.  If I did not wait for 30minutes in line to have this, I wouldn't have been as disappointed.

text:
Came here with my family after checking out the Saturday market. 

The actual donuts are pretty but a bit dry. They are definitely creative and have a bunch of unique flavors. They are very sweet so couldn't take more than one bite if you want to try out a couple flavors. 

Overall it was worth the visit to see what the hype was about but not your traditional soft doughy donut.

text: This place is cool. Open 24 hours, crazy doughnuts, weddings, and Swahili lessons. 'nuff said.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I don't ever eat doughnuts. I rarely eat carbs, preferring to only drink them. Yet, after riding the drunken buzz of the Fanfarlo show, my friends and I headed to Voodoo for some sickeningly sweet goodness. You can smell Voodoo from blocks away, with it's aroma rising above all the urine and feces that surround this area.

I love all the vegan options that they have and the rotating wheel of candy coated, diabetes inducing concoctions. Through the recommendations of the guy behind the counter I got some ghost shaped doughnut with jelly filling. I know we also got an apple fritter that was the size of my head and some other chocolate doughnut. Oh my god, I only wish I had bought a chocolate milk to enhance all this tastiness.

Voodoo doughnut helped make my night pretty much perfect! I don't think I would make this place a staple of mine to go to in town, but I can see my drunk ass ended up here more than a few times in the next couple of months.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Good donuts made sweeter by iconic hype. A trend setter in the doughnut game. They brought the bacon maple bar to light. Slow clap... I'm not a jelly filled but the guava filled coconut flake topped was quite good. 
Pro tips: Cash only (There are ATMs near by in a pinch but they charge a maple bar and a doughnut hole in ATM fees. $4) 
Go on a weekday afternoon to avoid the Disney size lines. Around 3pm I was able to get right in. Plus they were still making fresh doughnuts.
Vegan Paradise, they make real donuts for vegans. Like real maple bars and specialty flavors. They don't play with those weak chalky imitations deprived vegans call donuts. 
Your children will be exposed to the world. This includes sexually suggestive shapes and dark magic themed foods. It is Portland but just a fair warning. 
Voodoo D. A vegan paradise. OG food gimmick creators. Enjoy the ride.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: We had to go here because it's one of those tourist things we were told everyone has to do. There was a line outside the bldg, and you could smell the donuts when you walked up. We went at about 5:30pm. Still busy. I don't think it's ever not busy. I had my heart set on a voodoo doll donut. They had run out but just finished baking more. They decorated one quick for me. I was happy! The donuts are good but I don't think they are worth the hype. I liked blue star better. But these folks had great customer service. They also have an ATM inside the store. They only take cash. Oh and there are a bunch of druggies and bums that hang out outside... that was gross.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I tried 4 different kinds over the course of a few days.
-the original portland cream
-the voodoo doll
-the arnold palmer
-the old dirty bastard

Love the choc, PB, and Oreo combo of the old dirty bastard but preferred the Portland Cream overall.  It was a good sized doughnut with a great texture to the filling.  DO NOT think this is anything like a Boston Cream, it has a totally different flavor to the filling.  Reminded me of white cake batter in the center.  

Cool little location with a few picnic tables outside. 

WARNING*******Cash ONLY but the do have an ATM right inside.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Love Voodoo Doughnut. The bacon maple bar is a little piece of heaven, I kid you not. I could eat piles of them, at one sitting.

If the lines weren't so long, I'd give it five stars, but some days the lines are so long I can't bring myself to wait in them, not even for bacon maple bars. I wish management would figure out a way to move those long lines along faster.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

Despite being out the door, the line moved relatively fast.

text:

I got the maple bacon doughnut with a little trepidation and boy was I thrilled. The perfect combo of salty and sweet, and the bacon was thick and crisp! 
I also got the cream filled- I think the Portland special or something. It also was great 
I'm not huge on doughnuts, but wow we're these impressive

text:
When I woke up in the morning my first regret was that I had a donut!

BUT it was soooo good!

My buddy ate TWO of them in one fell swoop so you know its good however the next day I felt like I still had sugar in my system. 

This is a once in a long long while treat.....
