name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
This was a recommended donut shop for me to try when I visited Portland. I was very excited to try it because of its unique designs and unique flavors. 

I went on a Saturday afternoon and there was not a long line. The service was great and I ordered 3 different donuts: Dirt, The Loop, and Mango Tango

Dirt: It was essentially a cookies and cream donut that had vanilla frosting and Oreo cookies on top. This donut was pretty good and what you would expect out of a donut of this sort. It was on the sweeter side tho.

The Loop: This donut had vanilla frosting topped with fruit loop cereal. This one was my favorite out of the three, however, the cereal tasted stale and not crunchy at all. Even then, I still enjoyed the taste.

Mango Tango: this donut was filled with mango jelly and topped with vanilla frosting. This donut was pretty decent but my least favorite out of the three. The jelly was thick and a little too much for my liking. Even then, the donut was decent.

The design and layout of the store was quite interesting as they are all in with their theme of voodoo. 

Overall, this place is worth trying once if there is not much of a line.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Talk about the voodoo that causes this place to be so hype. These poor souls have not been blessed by the other certain -colored celestial object- donut shop that is present in Portland. Sure, you get some fancy flavors here but for the price and wait time- take a pass!

That being said, I guess if you're in Portland for the first time, I'd give it a try. THEN go to Blue Star and see what a real quality donut is like. I'll give them perks for being open 24/7 though! Voodoo has a very fun and pink aesthetic that makes them so special. Are you really a tourist if you don't get a pink box to take a pic of? There's outdoor seating for you to set up the perfect scene right outside their shop.

Anyways about the donuts- what you actually came here for right? They are alright lol. I did enjoy the maple bacon and the Old Dirty Bastard (peanut butter and oreos), but was whatever about the hibiscus and Homer Simpson donut. Their glaze didn't give me this high quality feel for the high quality price I was supposedly paying for. I'm glad I only waited in line for like 15-20 minutes, and this was on a Monday afternoon. I can't even imagine how long a weekend line takes and I've seen it- poor people waiting in the sun. However once you're in there, it seemed to move pretty fast. They are efficient with taking orders and they have donuts on a rotating display so you can choose donuts based on how they look (which is really what you're here for).

But yah I won't be back here when I know there are better quality donuts elsewhere in Portland.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Yes, everything is that good.

From a San Franciscan - Voodoo is Bob's Donuts donut with Psycho Donuts toppings and flair.

Tip: in the time it takes to line up at Voodoo (proper) you could drive to Voodoo Doughnut Too, get your donuts, and come back. #justsaying
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I've read almost all these reviews and the lack of consensus about Voodoo is amazing.  It's a pretty polarizing place.  I agree with most critics who say the donut itself is rather ordinary.  You never get one hot (like Krispy Kreme when they come right off the conveyor) and the base unit can be greasy, as I experienced during my last visit to Portland.  I also concur that the people behind the counter leave much to be desired...rude, and downright obnoxious.  That said, when the base unit is combined with the other ingredients, some surprising stuff can happen.  I'm generally not a fan of donut creativity--but there were a couple donuts in their selection that were great flavor combinations.  Others were absurdly stupid combinations of anything they could find in a grocery store that will stick to a donut--just for the sake of having a donut that's "different" from other donuts.  I think the popularity of Voodoo--and their success is due more to the novelty of putting breakfast cereal on donuts than the quality of their baked goods.  That also being said, on a good day, many of their fritters and donuts are at least as good as the best donuts in the US.  On my last visit, I took the Texas-ASS donut challenge--attempted to eat their gigantic glazed donut (the equivalent of a dozen) in 90 seconds (I think).  Took me 120 seconds to complete (no prize) and it was actually a very good glazed donut, despite its novelty size.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
The World According to Noelle
Allergic Girl's Guide to Life

"Just say no to Voodoo Doughnuts." Noelle W.

On our long road trip Voodoo Doughnuts was definitely on our list of places to try. We parked around the corner which was a short 5 minute walk to the doughnut shop. Passing the dive bars and restaurants my senses were offended by the smoke from the local patrons.

We stood in a rather long line. Most of this line was comprised of locals and a few tourists. The people in front were definitely hippie like and had the worst body odor ever. I was not going to be deterred. I was on a mission. That mission- to get a dozen of these Voodoo Doughnuts. We finally were ready to order. I picked three Portland Creams, three cinnamon sugar, two Voodoo Dolls, two Bacon Maple Bars and two Neapolitan. The only doughnut that tasted decent was the Portland Creams- delicious chocolate frosting and amazing Bavarian Cream. I saw the customer service person take our doughnuts from the racks and they seemed fresh. The doughnuts were extremely dry almost to the point of stale. 

CONS
~The flies flying above in the foyer.
~The dirty and smelly foyer.
~The fact the customer service person told me while picking my doughnuts, "You don't have to order one dozen." Whereby I replied, "I want to order one dozen of your doughnuts."
~When I inquired about purchasing a t-shirt the disgruntled employee rolled their eyes, quickly walked away and quickly came back to say, "No we don't have any more."
~The dry and staleness of the doughnuts.
~Cash Only.

PROS
~If you've never been here and are lucky to read my review- save your money and taste buds, just skip it.

Noelle's Notes
There's got to be better doughnuts in Portland.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Voodoo Doughnuts are a little over hyped.  I imagine this place is more for the novelty and Instagram pictures than for the doughnuts themselves. The doughnuts were not fresh, and for having so many doughnut options ready to order I can't imagine how they could be. I tried a cake doughnut and a rised doughnut and both did not have the rich texture I would expect out of a fresh doughnut. The flavors were also sort of bland. The cake doughnut was dry. Do not go here if you want a real crafted good quality doughnut, go here if you want a novelty picture, then throw the doughnut away. 

On the bright side the line did move fast.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Voodoo is, I think, exactly as you would expect. It is quintessential Portland and I would never discourage a tourist from going there for the first time - but, I would suggest that once you've had voodoo, there is no reason to go back. 

First, the sheer popularity of it is enough to discourse me to Blue Star or Coco's or.. dare I say? The Fred Meyer bakery. It sits in the worst neighborhood, both for parking and heckling, and the line to get in zigzags between metal gates as if a Disneyland scale roller coaster awaits you at the end. Nope, alas, just mediocre donuts. 

They are fun shapes, unique flavors, etc. so they are perfect for getting a selfie with a novelty donut in a pink box so everyone knows you went to Portland and didn't explore anything cool. 

I am not unhappy with my overall experience, but unless it's 4am and I'm leaving Kit Kat, I do not see any reason to return.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
"The magic is in the hole" - it really is. If I could ever dream of a concoction of magic, creamy, addictive, sweet, savory, and orgasmic.. all in one hole.. it really is Voo Doo Doughnut. 

Really, the line to wait for Voo Doo Doughnut on a Saturday morning over Labor Day weekend was 75 minutes long. Seventy-Five-Fucking-Minutes of my time that was entirely all too worth every damn second. Yes, it was worth it. Would I wait in that line again, probably not. But visiting Portland, everyone has to try this place at least once. The magical question of the 75 minute wait was "do these doughnuts have drugs in them?" These people go crazy over a cracked out doughnut?

So no, there are no drugs in the doughnuts, but you really feel like it when you have a 5 minute long moment of euphoria and tingles all over your body after consuming a maple bacon bar or ODB (Old Dirty Bastard). 

-Cash only
-Vegan doughnuts available
-Stop by Stumptown Coffee on your way over for a beverage to hold you over
-Try the maple bacon bar no matter what.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Really creative flavors, very tasty doughnuts, and surprisingly affordable for their popularity. Lines are shorter in the afternoon, but pickup quite a bit after dark.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Amazing donuts!!!!! OMG! We came here a bit after our friend and she suggested that go to voodoo to check out one of Portland's pride jewels. Not kidding, it was foodgasm and I don't even like donuts. I never eat donuts. The thought of doughnut has never been appealing to me. This, my friends, was seriously mind blowing. 
The place is open 24/7, which is good if you want donuts after a night out partying, for breakfast or just for no reason at all because you are a free human and if you want donuts at ungodly hours you might as well get them!!! 
We ordered 3, and it was hard not to order more for 2 adults trying to not gain a million pounds while eating our way through Portland. The lady behind the counter was so kind and helpful (and she had a great style) helped us narrow down the sugar bombs that would become ours. We ordered 2 dough-y ones: a dirty old bastard with vanilla frosting, cookie crumbs and peanut butter drizzle and a dirt one, vegan I believe with vanilla frosting and crushed Oreos. We also ordered a cake one, much smaller and more reminiscent of your traditional donut, with crushed up butterfingers on top, our Voodoo representative's favorite! 
Have I said OMG yet?!! While all 3 of them were to die for, the big ones were our favorite. The texture of the dough was very light and fluffy, it reminded me of a delicate brioche bread. The toppings were decadent and outrageously amazing. It's the bomb. 
I have heard that there is a rivalry for the best donuts in town between Voodoo and the Blue Star, and Voodoo definitely takes the medal by miles! (We compared... haha). 
Go, go, go! Even if donuts aren't your thing, it's a fun food experience and it's totally worth it. TOTALLY.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
TL:DR - Long lines but wait is short. Voodoo mascot donut and mango donut are great. 

I recommend the mango donut because it's bursting with flavors inside. 

There's a line but the wait was short. There's four cashiers helping. When you're lining up outside, you can see what kind of donuts are on the window with names and photos. After you get inside you can see what the donuts look like. 

They have souvenirs like shirts, finals, and stickers you can purchase. We always got the voodoo mascot donut and tried a few others.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Dare I say it? Even within Portland, there are better doughnuts to be had... DDOH! NUTS!!!

I may be bringing down some bad juju on me for saying this, but Voodoo Doughnuts is an overhyped tourist trap. Yes, the donuts look creative and cute, but taste-wise, there is nothing special here that your local Southeast-Asian-owned doughnut shop most likely named Happy Donut cannot duplicate.

The original location is in what was the old Chinatown, steps from the waterfront and the Willamette River. After stopping by the Portland Saturday Market a block over, we noticed tourist after tourist carrying around those Pepto Bismol pink boxes. So, the wife and I finally caved and reluctantly decided to try Voodoo. 

Surprisingly, the line moves pretty quickly and the inside of the store is decorated with a ton of cool stuff. Also, the workers were really nice. Sadly, that is where the positive experiences ended. 

We got the Voodoo Doll, The Homer, and the Bacon Maple Bar. The Voodoo Doll is definitely Insta-worthy. However, the raspberry jelly was way too sweet and is probably what is going to kill you more than the pretzel stake. The Homer, named after Homer Simpson, is a doughnut with strawberry frosting and sprinkles that was alright. And, the Bacon Maple Bar was good, but it's something that I've had at other doughnut shops. 

After sharing three diabetes-inducing donuts, the wife and I immediately had to eat the yuzu ramen next door even though we weren't even hungry. You see, we needed to balance all that sugar with some soup. 

At the end of the day, Voodoo appears to be magical for some since they have expanded across America from Hollywood to Austin, Denver to Orlando. But for me, I prefer doughnuts that are not so sugary.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
I just don't understand the hype behind this place. The lines are usually long, the donuts are just too sugary sweet, and the dough itself... meh.

it's one of those places where it's a neat idea to have a "Dirty old bastard" but i won't go outta my way for one. There are better donuts places in Portland. (Pip's, Blue star, Byte Labs when it was around, etc)

If someone offered me a donut, I wouldnt turn it down but i just don't understand the hype, and I think most Locals would agree with me. It's just a tourist trap..
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Today was my first time coming to Voodoo Doughnuts with my partner and we loved it! we're visiting Portland from California and we made sure this was our first stop !
the service is nice & quick. we didn't know what to get so the cashier helped us a bit (: 
can't wait to come back soon !

text:
If your ever in downtown Portland, definitely try Voodoo Donuts. It's a great place to take pics and eat sugary treats. The decor inside the shop has a little shop of horrors/Graceland meets New Orleans Victorian macabre.
As for the donuts, they're pretty good. Creative and interesting concoctions of candy, cereal and other delectables drizzled on fried cake.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Voodoo Doughnut is a unique doughnut shop that reminds me of the wonderful spirit of Louisiana that I miss. I love going there for the cute doughnuts and the friendly atmosphere.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Very bad service; the staff are incredibly rude! The donuts are good but not THAT good. I think I'll just stick to the traditional mom and pop donut shops. Oh! And this place is not very clean!!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: We tried Voodoo Doughnuts based on word of mouth from friends.  We ordered the bacon maple bar, memphis mafia, and triple chocolate donuts.  OMG!  They were all amazingly delicious donuts! We couldn't resist trying these donuts as we visited Portland.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: This place has straight up the best donuts I've ever had. The dough is soft and fluffy and melts in your mouth and the variety and combinations of normal, slightly different and crazy flavored donuts you've never heard of before is seemingly endless. (plus the names are fun to order too!) My personal fave is the Old Dirty Bastard. The only problem I've ever had with this place is trying to decide what I want to get. Give this place a shot,  especially if you're a donut lover-you won't regret it!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: When people talk about Portland they talk about Voodoo Donuts... "you gotta go!"  Each time I walked by the location I saw a line of people that extended down the sidewalk and around the corner and down that sidewalk...  one day, finally, I walk by and there's no line!  Hallelujah!  I head in and order 6 donuts... as a test... to see if they really know how to make a donut I order a plain cake donut, a double chocolate donut, and 4 wild and crazy creations.  The plain cake donut sucked - it was unevenly cooked and the exterior was not at all crisp.  Ditto for the double chocolate donut.  Now... the wild and crazy creations - if it had cereal on it, it was stale.  Think about it.  You're putting cereal on unremarkable frosting... the frosting's moisture destroys the cereal.  The magic is in the hole?  I think not.  The magic is in the remarkable job they've done with advertising.  The magic is in how unrefined the American pallet has become.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
A Portland hot spot, this place is known for their voodoo doll and phalic looking donuts. There was a line out the door but the wait was pretty short. 

The interior is unique and they sell merchandise. The donuts aren't overly priced and it's a definite tourist spot.

I'm not the biggest fan of their donuts, as they are way too sweet but they are soft and very generous in filling. I got the basic voodoo doll donut which is a chocolate covered donut filled with raspberry jam. 

Overall / it was a great spot to hit up for it being my first time in Portland
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: A+ for creativity. Incredible selection. But the one I had didn't really seem fresh. Coming here once was probably enough!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Okay, this is a MUST see if in Portland, but you MUST get there early if you want one of their famous Bacon Maple Bars...plus you can get married right in their parking lot without worrying about what the guests are going to eat! This place is one of a kind and fun to go to on dates or with friends. The only negative is how packed it gets and runs out of the best stuff early on the weekends, so not great for those who like to sleep in.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Extremely sugary donuts and poor service. Check out another artisan donut shop in town if you want something good!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I was here when it was a one room shack. My friend did a one man musical show on top of the bathroom (makeshift stage on top of the bathroom back then). I like that this place has survived, not many businesses can. Their stuff is the best! I can't remember (it has been a long time since I have been there) what the one with purple powder (grape) topping was called but it was my favorite. I was there when there wasn't even a line to get stuff. Back when the Church of Elvis was still around. Back when Umbra-Penumbra was still around. And Ozone Records still was around and selling tape cassettes of local bands. And The Big Bang was selling used 18th century gothic dresses to the upstairs crowd at the city nightclub 13 nw 13th. It's hard now to go to the downtown location without a crowd. But there is a NE Portland address that is less busy: 1501 NE Davis St, Portland, OR 97232.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Yes, it's overhyped, and no, I don't think it's worth waiting in a line more than 30minutes, but it really is a Portland institution, and a box of Voodoo doughnuts is an obligatory accessory when in Portland for the first time.

Would I go back?  No, but I'm glad I went at least once.  

If you get there early and there is no line, definitely get the peanut butter donut or the caramel one.  There are so many choices it's a little mind-boggling, but everything about it is entertaining, unique, and special.  

Service is non-existent, and the person working the cashier seemed tired and uninterested, but the interior is cool and you gotta love that pink box!  A conversation starter among tourists too, with many people asking if we'd been to Voodoo Doughnuts yet.  Now I can say "yes, definitely!"
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I'm visiting Portland for a week. And every sense I seen Voodoo Doughnuts on Man vs Food, I've been dying to come here. AND I DID!!!!!!!! AND I'M IN LOVE. I highly recommend
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: So glad we waited! Love donuts and never been much of a fan of the crazy fad kind but really enjoyed the humorous selection. Tried the bavarian filled and it was so delicious. Even splurged on a sweatshirt too!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Have you ever ate a handful of wet sugar? If you haven't you'll soon be doing that here at Voodoo. 

"A must try in Portland" Who ever even came up with that? VD is definitely all hype and doesn't live up to it's name. We waited 50 minutes, 50 MINUTES for this nasty donut place because people said "a must try" and we fell for their voodoo...

So were expecting it to be at least decent because it can't surely be good if it's just spitting out thousands of donuts a day for the big crowd. We got 6 donuts: maple bacon, voodoo, portland creme, dick and balls, lemon filling one, and a glazed with raspberry filling. My god, these were all horrible! The only thing we found decent was the plain glazed with raspberry filling, because it wasn't drench in all nasty frosting! The dick and balls were a waste, nothing special, not even decorative. Literally just a molding of a dick and balls. The maple bacon was drenched in maple frosting that literally overwhelmed the bacon slice on there. The lemon filling donut was okay... nothing great. And the voodoo special one was just plain nasty. That was a handful of wet sugar. The portland creme donut was the grossest thing ever. The creme tasted like some other "creme" it had a nasty flavor to it. Also the guy gave us a small box for 6 big donuts and everything got a little of everything on it. Seriously dude? The donuts look like it was sitting for awhile...that probably explains why it was also dry inside. Eating the donuts between 3 people, we felt sick to our stomach. The sweetness was just too much. And me, I LOVE SUGAR but they just overdo it. 

I had MUCH better donuts in LA. Heck, I think Krispy Kreme makes better glazed ones! It's not soaking in frosting. It was so disgusting. We will never ever wait 50 minutes for a handful of wet sugar again. 

Somebody cursed us that day we thought of VD.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Some could say overrated but I enjoyed this place. I think it's part of the portland experience so I had to!! The voodoo donut was actually amazing.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I didn't reach a higher level of consciousness after eating these doughnuts like some other reviewers. But they were good. The biggest selling point is how cute and funny the doughnut decor is. Be prepared to wait in line for an hour or so. It's a big tourist trap.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
When we moved to Portland I was prepared to break my no-sugar diet to try some of the pdx staples.  Voodoo doughnuts was one of those places that we were eager to try based on the rave reviews we heard from friends and family.

First of all the queue was really long and hot (you have to wait in the huge line that wraps outside, and when it is 90 degrees with no shade, 20 minutes can seem like a long time.  When you finally reach the door, the people behind the counter are yelling at the people in line to leave enough room for the people who just purchased to get out (seems like poor planning on their part when there was plenty of room to wrap the line the other way and not have this door issue.)

Because the inside is so small, you have approximately 2 minutes to look over dozens of flavors and decide what you want before a horn goes off at the counter and you are expected to come with your order ready. (There is also no AC inside which is kind of disgusting when you realize all the doughnuts are sitting there in the heat all day)

In spite of all this, we were still eager to try it and ordered 4 different kinds.  All of the doughnuts were just short of "Blah" and not just in my opinion (I know I am a little skewed by admitting that I don't eat sugar) but also from my husband who eats enough on a consistent basis for both of us (plus a little extra for good measure.)

After all this, I would say skip this tourist trap and try some of the much better doughnut options in downtown Portland (Blue Star) or do what we did and have a mini doughnut tour and test them all out for yourself.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:

text: Cheap donuts, like $1.50 per. Went at around 10:00 am and there was not a long line. Many options of donuts, I picked Portland Cream which was cream filled chocolate glazed donut. I'd give it 9/10. Cool rotating donut platform inside where you wait in line allows you to see the donuts up close before you buy. text:
The thrill of it all was "Yea! I finally made it to Voodoo Doughnuts." Boy, was I disappointed! Did i mentioned that I waited in line, SUN beaming down my back, SWEAT  masking my face. Got a visual....
 I had the doughnut with Chcolate frosting,  Rice Kripsies and Peanut Butter, although the topping was good, the doughnut was stale. I really would have liked to bite down to some softness but instead I bit into the Sahara and  didn't have a drink to quinch my thirst. So I just ate the topping and tossed the rest.  VOODOO was a BOO HOO for me!

text: I thought this was going to be just another tourist trap, but the doughnuts here are actually pretty good! Apparently there's usually a long line, but I guess we got lucky because there were only two groups in front of us when we arrived. They had a nice variety of doughnuts to choose from, and each was a pretty good size. The two that I got to try were the Grape Ape and No Name doughnuts. The Grape Ape is a raised yeast doughnut with vanilla frosting, grape dust, and lavender sprinkles. This doughnut was super soft and airy! The No Name doughnut is also a raised yeast doughnut but with chocolate frosting, rice krispies, and peanut butter. It was rich and chocolately with just the right amount of peanut better. I'd go back to try some of their other doughnuts!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
The Maple Bacon donut cannot be beat. It is hands down the best donut I have ever eaten (loyal Krispy Kreme devotee). I cannot stand maple donuts, I particularly hate their sticky sweet flavor but Voodoo has made me a believer in their sinfully delicious, puffy, maple frosted donut in all its bacon-y glory. This is like the filet mignon of donuts, friends. It is more than a sugary treat, it's a meal. This sucker is huge, dense, moist and everything a donut was meant to be. All other donuts aspire to be this donut. 

This was out second trip to Voodoo in two days and we went for this puppy. Venturing to Portland for a short 2-day donut tour, we were going to hit 7 local donut shops and do a tasting adventure. Unfortunately, on Tuesdays and Wednesdays almost all of the shops were closed. Plans squashed, donut dreams dashed. But Voodoo pulled their weight and delivered some of the best donuts we have ever had. Be prepared to get messy. All filled donuts will ooze out in your hands. 

The location is fun and very Portland. This location was short several flavors compared to the Davis location which I will also review with 5  for excellent customer service, variety, and warm Portland welcome. Thanks Voodoo!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Fun vibes, nice flavors.  I like that area, too, close to the waterfront and Saturday Market
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: The most unique donut place I have ever been to. I guess when you are in Portland, voodoo donut is a must go to place. Each donut has its own taste and flavor. My favorite is the original voodoo donut. I mean who doesn't want to eat a mini donut shaped like a human. :) The outside may look dangerous but you will be okay. Go with a few friends. The bathroom is dirty at times but it's a city.

text:

Good to try just to see the hype but don't order too many and just skip it if the lines too long. 

Trust me you're not missing out.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
*******************KRISPY KREME IS BETTER***************

So, after a disastrous experience at Bunk Sandwiches (hated them!!) the hubby just had to have Voodoo Doughnuts because as with Bunk he had seen them featured on TV; so off we went. 

Not being used to the many one way streets we literally drove around in circles before turning down the correct street and luckily we found parking right in front of the shop. 

Once we arrive we were surprised to see a line wrapped around the building and though "these donuts must rock!"  We eagerly and happily awaited our turn to go inside. 

Once inside we expected the warm and pleasant smell of fried deliciousness but not so much.  I won't go into the decor because I'm sure by know everyone has seen plenty of pictures and know what to expect inside at least visually. 

We ordered the little voodoo guy, a maple bacon donut and coffee...and the verdict is....drumroll please:

Coffee:  Holy willykers batman! It seriously tasted like they used the year old sock of an unbathed transient (which there happens to be plenty in the area) to filter the coffee.  It was bitter, acidic and talk about after taste...just putrid! 

Donuts:  Save your pennies and go to your local Krispy Kreme or anywhere else.  My little voodoo guy had no taste as far as the dough went.  The frosting I just about went into diabetic shock it was like taking a shot of sugar dressed with powdered sugar topped with brown sugar with a sprinkle of splenda.   

I was really hoping to be WOWed, it didn't happen :(
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Satisfy your sweet tooth with this Portland go-to. The line wrapped around the building seems intimidating but with four cashiers inside it moves quickly. Staff was friendly and the donuts were so good. Be aware, super sweet!

name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Omg I can't rave enough about this place! The donuts were so unique and all the ones we got tasted amazing! The prices were all reasonable as well. The line was out the door but well worth the wait. Next time I go to Portland I'd def try more. A must try when visiting Portland!

text:
Let's be honest, if you are in Portland you are going to check this place out...buy a donut, take some photos, and cross it off your list.

There's nothing special about the donuts here....they have some crazy flavors but crazy doesn't mean good.... it usually just means different.

Like I said if you are visiting Portland you are going to check this place out...but i can't imagine ever wanting to go here if i was a local.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Visit VooDoo once for the novelty of it all but no need to return. I was tempted to book a visit with my dentist afterward, these donuts can seriously cause some cavities in one bite. I'm just thankful the line was not long when I went because I would have been sorely disappointed otherwise. I'm also thankful that my friend knows one of the girls that works there because we got a box of VooDoo dozen and a maple bar for FREE! That alone made it a 5 star experience BUT the donuts themselves did not. 

The maple bacon bar was delicious, I'm a fan! The rest of the donuts were waaaayyyy too sugary and rich. Yes they are unique but not necessarily good. I'd rather eat a bowl of cereal than eat any of their cereal coated donuts. If not eaten fresh they do not hold up well for the next day...or even a few hours later. 

Like I said, go once to say you've tried it but check out Blue Star donuts too...they've got some creative choices as well, and better tasting in my experience!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: The homer the homer the homer!!!! Ugh it's one of my favorite things in life and tastes like strawberry pocky! I have noticed that the freshness varies and isn't consistent but when it's good, it's so goo!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Great selection, weird location, interesting staff, but good donuts.  Better than Krispy or Dunkin anyday!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I've been to Voodo Doughnuts multiple times during daytime and nighttime and I would prefer to go during nighttime. At nighttime there is more parking that is available and also there isn't a huge line to get a doughnut. Although this place is a very touristy spot in my hometown I would say that it is overrated. Maybe I believe that because whenever I go it's nighttime and the toppings are always stale but I've had better donuts from even a grocery store. I will say that they do have a lot of unique donuts that you can't get anywhere else and that the price is very inexpensive but I don't think I would recommend this place to a tourist. I will say that the inside of the restaurant is decorated very uniquely and I've never seen a place decorated like that before though. Overall I wouldn't recommend this place.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Visited Portland and everyone recommended VooDoo Doughnuts, when I heard they had vegan options we had to go. I'm not a sugar person and usually don't even eat doughnuts (or sweets) but this was the exception. The doughnuts wear great and tasted amazing! Very sugary and worth it ;)
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
What a shame that I did not eat Voodoo when I was in Denver, but I got a chance to redeem myself in Portland for its glory. With such creativity and deliciousness, this donut joint is definitely worth it. We waited only 15 minutes before getting to order.

DONUTS: We ordered the random dozen and chose another dozen. We got to sample everything from the traditional voodoo to maple cream filled to mango to Oreo. For eight people, two dozen is a LOT, but who doesn't love creative and fun donuts? The donuts come in such fun shapes, colors, and designs that it mixes play with food. I loved it. The one caveat that dinged it one star is the warmth of the donut. I love a warm freshly fried donut, but I understand that to meet the demand, the donuts can't be super warm. It's a tough place to be in for Voodoo. 

OTHER: The inside is quite fun. The decor is bright and colorful, with revolving plates of donuts. The service is great too. 

Voodoo donuts and Portland go together. So come on by, eat a donut, and feel happy on your sugar high!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
If you are in Portland, you must make a stop at Voodoo Donut. It's a must-see! Even though you don't like donuts, just stop by to check out the place out. 

I came here for the first time last year and tried their famous maple bacon bar and cock-and-balls donut. The maple bacon bar is like eating pancakes with a side a bacon. It sounds weird, but it tastes good. The cock-and-balls is just two chocolate bars perpendicular to each other with vanilla pudding in the "balls". They make great party favors for bachelorette parties and those crazy nights with the girls only.

On my second visit, I got the maple bacon bar and got another specialty, the Tex-ass. A huge glazed donut that is about the size of a regular dinner plate. It probably would go straight to your ass if you eat the entire thing by yourself. Fortunately, my friends helped me eat it.

What I find hysterical is that they offer wedding packages for their two locations, but they offer more options at their Davis Street location than at this location. I didn't see where people can get married, but I assumed it was upstairs since I saw a roped off staircase. If you don't want to get married, they do offer a commitment ceremony for $25.

They are not the best donuts I ever had, but I really enjoyed the novelty of them. If you don't wait in the long line during the day, head back here again at night. Hardly anyone in line. I would say that this place is similar to Psycho Donuts in Campbell back home.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I had a maple bacon donut. It was ok, but seriously overpriced at over $3. Nobody in my group thought the flavor of the donuts was anything special and we all agreed they are overpriced. Sorry. Don't recommend.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Ok a solid 3.5. We came because we were visiting Portland and had to try Voodoo. I feel like Voodoo is such a landmark that even if you're one of those people that hates everything that's popular you have to try Voodoo just for the experience.

First of all, there's a line. I know some people are probably thinking, "oh my gosh, a line?" Yes, there's a line. You'll be fine. I promise. Second, they don't take card. "Oh my gosh I have to get cash?" Yes, you'll have to get cash. 

I ordered the standard maple bar. I know that sounds ridiculous to order a regular donut that I can get at any donut shop but I wanted to compare apples to apples. Anyone can be fooled by bells and whistles. I needed to get down to brass tax. The maple bar was good, but I've probably had better at little hole in the wall donut shops with the white greasy bags. My bf had the maple bacon bar and exclaimed it was the best donut he's ever had. It looked good but I didn't have any. I appreciated that there were whole bacon strips on top. None of that artificial flavoring business.

The service is ok but I don't think you go here for the amazing service. It's a doughnut shop. If it's your first time in Portland try Voodoo.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Portland tradition but NOT the best doughnut in town. So many other options in Portland. Locals do not visit Voodoo Doughnuts, only tourists. This is not where locals frequent.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Interesting donut designs that fit the Portland eccentric character. However, the flavor literally is indistinguishable from the fifty cents donuts you can pick up on the Safeway discount rack. 

I don't blame them though, quality donuts usually stand out when served freshly made and warm. The donuts here have been sitting for who knows how long.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Best doughnuts in town not a debate. Never fails me
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Portland's tasty, weird doughnut institution, internationally known. The perfect place to find regular doughnuts and those with exotic designs and flavors. Yes, they have a creamed filled penis doughnut.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
After hearing about this place for years, what a let down. Overhyped. There was no line when I went but I went at an odd hour. This place is all about the weird flavors, naughty shaped, and crazy add ons, not necessarily the fact the actual donuts are high quality fluffs of sweet heavenly dough. 

Portand has to die for bakeries with award winning chefs and bakers so not sure the hype surrounding this place. I am sure it is just a fun tourist trap kind of place that every city has. Decor is cool though! And I am guessing it is fun to come in and get a phallic shaped donut especially if you are drunk after-hours. ( Voodoo is open 24 hours) 

I chose two donuts on my visit. On the first one I could not taste the donut itself because there was too much stuff and extra flavorings on it. It was also kind of stale/ hard. This was the, "Dirty Bastard" flavored donut. The verdict was that it was good but it was like a 5 year old's birthday cake, just too much going on. Sometimes less is more, ya know? 

However, i also got a Guava Colada and that one was tasty and came with an umbrella. Haha!  I loved the coconut and the filling. ( who knew) However, yet again, the cake part was nothing special.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Fun and creative doughnuts but a little airy. I really enjoyed stopping here on my trip to Portland!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
The hype about the must see spots will always get any yelper to go see and experience themselves what it's all about.  The amount of attention the donut industry has received within the last few years is amazing.  It's so mainstream now as everyone's go to dessert or to fulfill our sweet tooth or cravings for sweets, it brought Chel here. 

On my northwest vacation earlier this year,  I knew I was going to drop by here no matter what.   It was definitely in my bookmark.  Located in downtown Portland, street parking wasn't too bad midweek right before lunch hour.  A short walk led us to a short line that took about 20 mins to get inside the building. 

So wow.  The first thing that I noticed was that Huge donut artifact on top of the ceiling.   Very eclectic decor indeed from one wall to another,  then you have the several glass cases, rotating ones too, with displays of their unique donut creations.

What to get? Hhmmm...this and that but the bacon maple bar was definitely first on my list.  The oblong shape maple donut with two strips of bacon on top can make anyone drool just by looking at it as it did Chel.  Although   I'm not too much of a donut fan, that balanced taste of salt and sweet just screams, "eat me, eat me Chel!" So she did gracefully only to wash it down with a cup of Stumptown coffee (ty Ninong Joseph A. for reminding me). But I wish it was warm, and the maple still slightly wet, and the bacon freshly made and more crispy so when you bite into it the entire bacon doesn't come off the donut.  That's just my idea of an awesome,  honest to goodness, BOMB azz bacon maple donut!

Soft.  Tasty.  Teaser.   Unique.  Sweet.  Yup.  Creativity at its best but nothing I would tell anyone that you HAVE to go and have a Voo Doo donut because they would be missing out on something incredible.  No.  It's a tourist spot for us yelpers to see for ourselves and be wowed but eh...   after this trip to Voo Doo,  I did find a spot that I can totally recommend to anyone to go to for some bomb azz maple bacon donuts!

Ty Portland for the VooDoo experience!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Very cute donuts! Really fun and super sweet! Some flavors were better than others. Donuts were huge.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: I have to say it is over rating. I don't see the donuts have any different than others. We came here out of curiosity as everyone said We have to pay tribute If we are around Portland area. It was not super busy may be because of Sunday? However we still had to wait for 20 mins before placing order. Unlike others who ordered boxes after boxes, we just got 2 regular donuts - Homer and Daisy. If the line is too long I would not recommend for the wait. It is not worthy.

text: Well if you're visiting Portland I guess you have to go to Voodoo, but I found it pretty gimmicky.  Donuts were good, but this is not much more than a tourist place.  Since it is near the Keep Portland Weird sign, I guess it's kind of an obligatory stop, but once was enough for me.
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text:
Yesterday, I visited Portland for the first time on business, and my only plans for my twelve-hour visit was to go to a meeting, have dinner with the client (at Clarklewis - rather delicious), get a few hours of sleep, and hopefully not miss my 7:50am flight.  However, over a round of drinks in the hotel bar before bedtime, my colleagues informed me that I had missed a critical item on my Portland to-do list: a visit to the famous Voodoo Doughnut shop.  Being from New Orleans, I obviously have an affinity for voodoo dolls, and I'm actually familiar with this doughnut shop, both from the Food Network and from some Google searches for voodoo doll-themed desserts.  I had completely forgotten, however, that it was located in Portland - and only three minutes or so from my hotel!  So, I stopped by the front desk before heading upstairs and changed my cab from 6:30am to 6:15am so I could pop by and grab a doughnut before my flight.

In the morning, the very nice cab driver agreed to make a pit-stop at Voodoo Doughnut.  I had looked at its menu the night before and decided what I wanted - however, when I learned that their "cream" filling is actually Bavarian creme and not the whipped, sugary "Kreme" one finds inside a Krispy Kreme doughnut, I changed my order a bit.  However, I still ended up with a whopping five doughnuts (this behavior will not bode well for me in a few years).  For $10.80 (cash only, but thankfully they have an ATM), I walked away with a lovely pink box full of the following doughnuts:

(1) Dubble Bubble - This was my "fun," "funky" purchase, but it ended up being my second favorite doughnut.  It's a soft, fluffy yeast doughnut topped with vanilla icing and bubble gum dust, making it a lovely pink shade.  The dust on top gives it a strange but only slight - and actually quite enjoyable - chewiness.  It even comes with a piece of bubble gum!  Very cute and very creative - and very tasty in that nice, old-fashioned bubble gum way (it does not have the artificial bubble gum taste of children's toothpaste).

(2) Old Dirty Bastard - This doughnut was extremely delicious, but very heavy.  It is another delightful yeast doughnut topped with chocolate icing, Oreo cookies, and peanut butter drizzle - and it's truly a dessert.  It should be banned before noon.  Except it's too good to pass up!

(3) Memphis Mafia - I've read rave reviews on this one, but I really disliked it.  The cake doughnut was too heavy and the glaze too saccharin to be combined with cinnamon sugar, chocolate sauce (not chocolate icing; it was much harder and had an odd flavor), chocolate chips, bananas, and peanut butter.  I only took two bites.

(4) Captain my Captain - I love Captain Crunch cereal, but having crunchy carbs on top of soft yeast doughnut carbs was a little much.  Too many carbs, too many different textures, and too much sweetness from the vanilla icing overpowering the salty-sweet flavor of the cereal.

(5) Voodoo Doll - Saving the best for last!  I love the concept, design, and flavors.  Their chocolate icing is great and less sweet than the vanilla.  However, I didn't get an authentic experience, as my doughnut somehow wound up with cream in the center instead of jelly.  Kind of a bummer, but I will say, the cream was far better than I could have hoped.

Overall, this was a great experience - high quality, fresh doughnuts with inventive toppings and amusing names, all at reasonable prices.  Definitely stop by if you're visiting Portland - it's open 24-hours!
categories: Local Flavor, Food, Donuts, Wedding Chapels, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
name: Voodoo Doughnut - Old Town

text: Great food at a great price.  I come whenever i'm in town.  My favourite is the fried chicken. I've had it with waffles for breakfast and with mashed potatoes for dinner.  We've tried some other menu items too, catfish, french toast, mac and cheese, etc but it's the chicken that stands out the most.  It's usually pretty busy so expect a line up and wait unless you go during odd days/times.

text:
Although I wasn't wearing pink sunglasses looking like Trevor Horn of Buggles I still felt comfortable here. 
In a sea of hipsters (more so the diners than the workers), I sat there enjoying some of the best grits in town (not soupy like the Tin Shed) and great gravy and biscuits. 
A long wait but worth it.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: What can I say about the Screen Door restaurant that hasn't already been said. I got very lucky, I had no waiting, got quick service, and was immediately seated, plus I had a wonderful lunch. My head was on a swivel the entire time inside the restaurant as I was noticing people taking a lot of pictures of their food and I heard a bunch of ooooooh's and aaaaawe's. So how was my lunch you ask?  OMG, the BEST chicken sandwich (especially the chicken) ever and my side of Gumbo was the best this side of New Orleans. Waiter chose my lunch items and he nailed it. Next time I'll try to the Pecan encrusted maple bacon and the Mac n' cheese. This place is everything it is billed up to be. So go, stand in line and enjoy.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: This place has a unique and interesting menu and the food is amazing. The atmosphere is casual and the staff is friendly. I got the shrimp and grits, which also came with a biscuit and two eggs. I was very pleased with the value and the quality of the food. What really sets this restaurant apart is the unique menu offering. I'll definitely return whenever I'm in town.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I've always wanted to try this place but what I hesitant about is the wait. So I went solo, bellied up and got in within 5 minutes. Their Oyster Po Boys were great!!! If you love oysters like I do, get it!!! Their pecan bacon is different but very tasty! It's very decadent so one was enough for me (I eat 3 pieces of regular bacon normally).
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Hearty meals that pack a flavorful punch. 

Screen Door's infamous waiting time is well worth it for those who like their breakfasts to be indulgant. Large portions, complimented by heavy sides such as their famous grits is only overshadowed by the wonderful array of unique tastes you'll sample at this complex brunchery. 

The picadillo scramble may just be the best scrambled eggs I've ever had. Flavoring the eggs with spicy meats and jalapeno leaves no need for extra seasonings while the cream sauce topping gave the dish a robust and full flavor. I also tried the open face cheese and mushroom frittata. The omelet used fresh ingredients that reminds me of a California breakfast. There was plenty of love with each bite. 

My one complaint is that Screen Door has a lack of coffee choices. The only option is regular pot coffee. 

With a variety filled menu of unique morning meals, Screen Door is sure to please on every visit.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Damned solid food. Really good fried chicken. Nice cornbread, good beans and rice.

I really need to go back and sample the menu more. Next time I'm in PDX I will absolutely be stopping by...
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: The service was amazing! Loved the outdoor patio w/ the heaters. Can't beat a place where your coffee cup is never empty!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I've been going to the Screen Door for a while now and you can't go wrong with anything on their menu. 

I had the soup of the day today which was the carrot velouté and it was simply orgasmic!!!!  Their beef brisket and catfish are my absolute favorite and the way they make their mashed potatoes with gravy, the potato salad, or the coleslaw is pure art. 
The fact that all the produce used is from local farms makes the food so much more enjoyable because you're eating natures finest. 
Long story short, the Screen Door is a monthly must for me to get my fix. 
Now go get yours!!!! ;)
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
If you're looking to get the most bang for your buck and/or just want to eat one meal for the day, Screen Door would be the place to go.  The wait was about an hour when we got there, but there is a coffee shop right next door where you can go and chill out while you wait.

Both my girlfriend and I got the chicken biscuit with gravy, which was both delicious and enormous.  The chicken and gravy both had some very nice heat that lingered and the biscuit was flaky and buttery.  I barely touched the fried potatoes that came with it and still just managed to finished the rest.

And for reference, while we didn't get the chicken and waffles, I saw more than one plate come out, which contained THREE friend chicken breast on a massive waffle.  I honestly don't know how someone would finish even half of that, but if I'm back in town someday I may just have to give it a go.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Went here last Sunday evening! The wait outside the door was definately worth it! Our waiter was super fun and inviting the food was so amazing that it brought me straight back to the south! Yum yum will definitely be coming back to this place!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
My friends and I were in Portland for a wedding. A couple friends recommended screen door and looking at the pictures...we had to go!

We arrived at the restaurant around 8:30 and was told that the wait was an hour. We got a couple drinks at the bar and hung out around the patio till my name got called. 

My friend and I ordered the screen door plate, where you choose 3 "sides" and make up your own dish. While our SO's got the fried chicken plate. For my plate, I chose the fried catfish, gumbo, and mac n cheese. 

The food did take awhile, it was around 10pm when we started eating. But, every bite was so freaking fantastic. I had about half my plate left over, and it was still awesome the next day (I ate it for breakfast...shhhh). I had a bite of the fried chicken as well, and they know how to do it. It was crispy yet juicy. 

It's very well priced considering how much you get. Service was nice and the ambiance was very cozy. I highly recommend giving this place a try if you haven't already. Just expect to wait a bit, but know it'll be worth your time.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
i do love this place.
the mac and cheese might be the best in pdx.
the hamburger and pulled pork sandwich are both yum.
the sweet potatoe fries are delicious.
and i know this sounds nuts cuz its a southern restaurant but i love the salads here.
we are frequent fliers here and have had consistently awesome service.
it's a great spot but the lines can be daunting.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Great amazing southern style cuisine. Huge portions- definitely can share meals. No need to order a full plate unless you are starving. Their fried green tomatoes with a spicy hollandaise sauce tossed with gulf shrimp in the summertime is to die for. Their cocktails are expensive and can be sucked down in 2 sips. maybe sneak in a flask of your own whiskey and just order lemonade. The waiters are kind of rude and too cool for school but its all good- its Portland. Just remember they don't take reservations and it is always packed so get there early when they open and enjoy.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: As legit as it comes. Got here 15 min early on Sunday PM and a line had already formed. Fried chicken was some of the best I've had. Sides were terrific. One of the best restaurants in Portland.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Ridiculously sensational brunch spot in Portland, and probably the best meal I had while visiting there recently.  Hadn't even heard of Screen Door until searching for a place for Sunday brunch and saw the huge number of reviews. When my girlfriend and I got there, the line was, um, substantial. Table for 2 = 90 minute wait.  Typically, I would probably start looking for backup plans, but I had a good feeling about this place.  We killed time down the block at Heart coffee roasters and came back after about 45 minutes, thinking that maybe they overestimated.  No such luck as we waited in the drizzly rain.  Thankfully through the natural course of attrition, our name was finally called and we got a seat at the counter.

First order of the day: Bloody Mary's, and these didn't disappoint...except that they weren't as spicy to our liking.  So added some of their house made hot sauce, and that helped considerably.  After studied perusal of the menu, and observing the plates leaving the kitchen, my GF determined the fried chicken and waffle was the obvious choice.  I opted for the shrimp with bacon and cheddar grits with over-medium eggs.  While waiting (not so patiently), the sheer number of chicken and waffle plates emerging from the kitchen was mind boggling.  Clearly this was the star of the show here.  And once our order arrived, it was easy to see why.  Perfectly fried chicken, juicy and flavorful, especially for all white meat.   The light and fluggy Belgain-style waffle was spiced with clove, nutmeg and all-spice and provided a nice counterpoint to the chicken.  Alternating between sweet maple syrup and the house hot sauce made for deliciousness, bite after bite.

My shrimp and grits dish was no slouch.  Creamy cheddar grits and perfect cooked shrimp with bacon is a classic combination, and one very well executed here.  The nicely cooked eggs lent a nice runny yolk which added to the richness of the grits.  Served with a great biscuit alongside, this was a deeply satisfying plate of food.

Thoroughly stuffed, we rolled out of the Screen Door immensely happy and looking forward to the next time we were in Portland for another visit.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I was about to write about how amazing their fried chicken was. How I never tried fried chicken that was so tender, juicy, and buttery as Screen Door's. And how their mashed potatoes melted in my mouth before they even reached my tongue. But I'm not going to write about their food. Why? Well, read the rest of 700 reviews.

So in order to pitch in this conversation, I'm going to write about something that might save you time when you go here.

I arrived here at 4:55 in order to save seats for my family (3 adults, 2 children, 2 infants). The guy told me it was going to be at least an hour wait. Ok. That's reasonable. I waited and waited. After an hour, the guy comes back and ensures me that I'll get seated within 20 to 30 minutes. Fine. I can wait. Around 6, four people came in and wrote their names on the list. Within 15 mins I was seated with my family; and at the same time the party of 4 was seated ALONG with another party of 5. 

SOOO.

Go here around 6:30ish and you can find seats quickly. FYI, I went here on a Saturday.

I'm giving them 4 stars not for the wait but for the service. The waitress (I think she was very stressed out or something) was very pushy and passive-aggressive. I guess that happens when you table has 4 kids but don't make it so obvious.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Had the mac n' cheese, fried catfish, creamy grits, mushroom hash, and a strawberry shortcake for dessert.  Was so good, definitely will order the mac n' cheese again, and will try the chicken next time...saw a lot of that going around to the tables nearby :-)
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
The brunch I had here was one of my favorites.  You know it's good when you see the line out the door - there was about a 20 minute wait to get a table.

Once we got inside, the wait was worth it.  The mimosa was generously poured, the fried chicken was AMAZING, and I built my own breakfast so along with that fried chicken I got scrambled eggs and biscuits with sausage gravy.

I don't live in Portland, but should I ever find myself there again, I would absolutely return!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Screen door was a must for my first trip to Portland. I went for brunch on a Sunday, arriving around 11am. The wait was well over an hour but the local shops helped kill the time. 

I ordered the chicken & waffles, which upon first sight are completely overwhelming. Stacked 3 high, each chicken breast is breaded in the MOST flavorful breading I've ever had. Atop a sweet potato waffle, the spices and flavors mix together for a heavenly experience in one's mouth. 

Service was great, the waitress was attentive and courteous. Screen Door is now a must visit each time I'm in town.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Okay first let me just say that wow, the fried chicken was amazing. The waffles were also very delicious. They're like crispy on the outside and soft and warm on the inside just like the chicken! If you love crispy carbs like I do, you're going tk enjoy the waffle.

Okay now on to logistics of service and wait time: Wait time is pretty extensive. I dropped off a friend to stay in line for us while I picked up the rest of the party who were wandering around (we are from California). She waited a total of about 45 minutes until our party was called but since we didn't make it there in time, they weren't able to seat us. Once we arrived, we were prioritized but it still took us about 15-20 min to be seated.

Ordering was quick; we all knew what we wanted! Chicken and waffles please!

WE SAT AT THE TABLE FOR NEARLY AN HOUR BEFORE THE FOOD CAME OUT HAHA. I know it was great but damn. Expect a SHIT ton of waiting.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Love the fast service.  But this is fat boy food. Forget your diet. .I read the reviews and got the highly rated chicken and waffles with praline bacon and eggs.  Plus orange juice was not freshly squeezed but still good.  

I enjoyed the brunch but felt heavy after. Understand that it is big portions. The one in Seattle is definitely better called waffles and chicken.

No wifi here so that blows. Sit outside. It's nice.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: This place was so good I almost cried. Hot link Po boy was amazing just a little spicy but I have a very low tolerance for spicy food so anyone els should be fine. The other plate was out of this world. Aliens must of cooked it
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
So this place has a ton of hype around it.
We passed by to see the line rounding the block and decided that our hunger wouldn't hold out any longer so passed.

But later in the day, we decided that we were within the time when they opened up for dinner. When we got there... which was about 30 mins from opening there was probably 5 people in line from the door. We decided we wanted some AC so we killed some time at a pet store down the street for literally 15 mins - and when we got back, the line was wrapped around the building with about 20 more people in line -_-

We weren't sure if we were going to get a table during the first round of people but we were SUPER lucky and nabbed one of the last tables. The host asked if we were okay with the table by the kitchen - just in case we didn't like it. We weren't picky and at this point were just happy to get a table so we happily went what we dubbed the "Chef's Table" - it was actually pretty cool. Not sure why people wouldn't want this table.

I wasn't too hungry so I decided to just stick with a Starter - Fried Okra which was buttermilk battered and deep fried okra wheels served with homemade remoulade. It looked yummy but I wasn't a fan.
It tasted really slimy. Almost like gross slimy. I don't know. For a lack of a better term it tasted like a loogie. LOL. I know, I know. WTH Camille?! I know. But that's what best describes it. Sorry!

The service was great! But the food was okay.
I'll see if I give them a try in the future but for now, I think I am good.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: The food here was delicious!  Me and my buddy decided to try the fried green tomatoes to start....and then moved in to chicken and waffles  WOW is how I would describe the flavors in my mouth.  If you love maple then you'll love the waffles. The chicken was so favorable, juicy,  and just plain delicious!  A definite must try when you stop by.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Best brunch ever. Had one of the daily specials - fennel and sausage scramble. It came with a huge side of very yummy, well roasted potatoes and toast. The food just compliments each other! I don't know how to describe the scramble besides calling it perfect! Speaking of perfect, we got the banana fosters french toast to share for dessert. WOW!!!!!!!! FIREWORKS IN MY MOUTH!!!!! It's like a good 6 pieces of french toast, so it's a big plate. I want to find a place like Screen Door back in LA.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Holy cow the food is fantastic! Try the hush puppies, cat fish, corn bread, mac n' cheese, greens. Try everything! I have found it best to go with several people, each order the screen door and share. 

The wait is long (cuz its so stinkin' great!) so get there early. 

Do not, however, stuff your face, drink a hurricane and then run a 5k an hour later. Doesn't go well.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Every time we go we are "wowed'. The chicken is a must. Didn't learn until our third or fourth trip there to GET DESSERT. All made in house and heavenly.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Some of the best southern food I've had! Their boneless fried chicken melts in your mouth! Mac and cheese is amazing! Get their early, everyone else likes it too! Worth the wait though!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I don't know what all the hype is about.
Little food and a very rushed atmosphere.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
What can I say about this place - it's got high reviews for a reason. Waited about an hour for Sunday brunch but was told by several locals it was worth the wait - it was! 

The fried chicken is probably some of the best I've ever had - peppery, crunchy & juicy. 

The biscuits and sausage gravy are killer & the praline bacon is a weirdly satisfying sweet treat.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
It lived up to the hype. Fabulous food, inexpensive, and fast service.
Fried oysters, hush puppies, beef brisket with thing onion rings and baked beans, fried chicken, gumbo.  Everthing that our table ordered was excellent.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Delicious breakfast, might have been because they where in a to go box, however my eggs were overdone so I couldn't give 5 stars. Sorry.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: If there is a draw back to this place it would be that it is always extremely busy. The food rocks. This is a place that we always take out of town guests to.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Best chicken and waffle in the PDX!! My husband I will definitely come back soon! It's our date spot
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: These people know what they are doing! Southern food at it's finest and the service is top notch!  The fried green tomatoes and fresh, crisp salad were excellent starters!  The fried chicken is a must MUST have!   The Mac N Cheese is truly southern and the veggies are so fresh!!! One of the best farm to table restaurants I we have visited.  Definitely a must if your visiting PDX.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
There is a reason this place is the best brunch place in Portland.

My friend and I got there at the worst possible time, 10 am on a Sunday morning. Perhaps fifteen people were in front of us in line, so we got coffee and prepared to stand outside in the rain for awhile. Lo, we were seated within 20 minutes. 

Service is fast and efficient without being untidy or unfriendly. Our cheerful waitress filled my water and coffee were filled whenever it went past the halfway point. The fried chicken was better than Pine State's, and when you order the chicken and waffles there's a HUGE pile of it, about ten inches tall! I stuffed my face and still had half a waffle and basically two chicken breasts to take home with me!

Screen Door doesn't need any more five star reviews, but it's such a relief to find a great brunch place that doesn't suffer from pretentiousness or trendiness. I will be back.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
We enjoyed this place so much yesterday that we came back again today for brunch. It was so delicious that we went against our own rule of trying out as many new places as possible during our short 4 days in Portland. The wait was a bit longer this time - even at 9:30am on a Friday morning, there was a line out the door and a 30 minute wait. It is worth it though! 

This time, we shared the following:
Praline bacon waffle ($9.50): this was as delicious as it was the first time. The waffle is light and fluffy, and is covered in ample whipped cream and maple syrup. The chopped pralines added a delicious crunch and sweetness, and the thick-cut slice of bacon covered in chopped pralines and caramelized in brown sugar was pure crunchy, salty, umami perfection. The best waffle I have had in my life!
Bananas foster French toast ($8.25): this was delicious as well, although not as much of a standout as the bacon praline waffle. There were two large thick-cut brioche slices that had been soaked in vanilla custard and grilled to golden brown perfection. They were accompanied by ample whipped cream (my favorite!) and rum-flamed bananas and topped with cinnamon and powdered sugar and maple syrup. It was a delicious, although a touch on the sweet side.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Died and went to heaven- hands down best breakfast my husband and I ever had. Small wait but friendly staff and great atmosphere. We had the shrimp n grits, chicken and waffles and a side of the praline bacon. Every part of our meal was so delicious and my husband has now requested this be his "last meal" We are not locals but I will tell you anytime we come back to Portland this is where we will eat.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
