text: Comfort food at its best--quality ingredients, creative takes on Southern classics. To be honest, this kind of place is pretty common in the South or Midwest; however, it deserves some kudos for being in Portland, where people don't always understand the history of chicken and waffles. Good stuff.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Soooo good. The wait was so long, but we found this awesome little geek shop across the street that was a pleasant use of our time. We had brunch and it was literally the best breakfasty (I think I made that word up) type food we have ever had. I got the Croque Madam and it was recommended by the waiter. Glad I took his advice. The service was great too.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I now understand why people wait in line for HOURS for this place. We went for brunch and waited an hour. Totally worth it. I had the bananas foster French toast which was amazing. I got to taste the fried chicken and waffles, grits, and huevos rancheros. The latter was my favorite and likely will be my choice next time I come. 

For dinner we arrived 40 minutes before opening and waited in line. Same kind of wait but felt quicker. I got the shrimp and grits but had the pleasure of trying the catfish, Mac and cheese, greens, friend chicken and brisket. Again the latter was my favorite.   Hands down everything was amazing. We did hush puppies, pork belly and chicken strips for appetizers and so we were extremely full and had plenty of leftovers for after the bar later.

My only gripe: the cornbread is very bland and without the honey butter quite plain. I think a little honey in the batter would do wonders. :)

I'm exited to go back and try more of the menu. There were far more items I wanted than I could really order.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Consistently amazing food. There is a special way food tastes and makes you feel when it is made with care and love! 

The service is always present but not overbearing. 

I've been enjoying Screen Door for dinner (have not tried brunch yet) for years and I highly recommend the fried chicken (as everyone does). Soooo good! Also, the macaroni is phenomenal! And you cannot go wrong with their mashed potatoes. 

I really appreciate the seasonal menu as well, whenever fingerling anything is on it, I get it. I've never been disappointed with the food or service here. The wait has always been well worth it!! :)
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: My boss ate here for brunch with her family when they came to town to watch Hamilton.  She raved so much about it that I felt the need to try them out.  My husband and I were on our anniversary trip and we decided to try their dinner.  I ordered the fried chicken with collard greens.  The chicken was okay...maybe they shouldn't put the pieces on top of the mashed potatoes because by the time I got to the chicken, it was soggy. The collard greens were too salty.  We ordered Fried Oysters as an appetizer...if I was reviewing just for the appetizer then that would be a 4 star by itself.  Maybe we should've eaten brunch instead.  Service was mediocre.  This would've been a 2 star but the 3rd star is for the amazing fried oysters appetizer.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: We went to try real Creole food and because the ratings were so high. We had a variety of things to sample the options. The only thing I'd recommend is the Mac and cheese. Everything else was over-breaded and too salty. Plus it was crazy loud and soo busy. Are people going just cause they think it's cool to be seen here? I think it's cooler to get fresh wholesome food and more authentically creole.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I have been here three times and I love it!  Food quality is good, taste is good, service was good, coffee is good.  Unfortunately, wait can not be so good!  Tip: go earlier than they open on weekends to get in line.  I am gluten free and can still find options.  I love the cheesy grits and ham with poached eggs-only on the weekend.  A must go if you are in Portland!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
OK, so it's Portland version of Southern Food, so what? It still comes down to very very good food. We left here hurting because we ate so much, but it was all so good to pass up.

We were lucky to get here at 5:10pm and got a good spot in line. Able to sit down right away when the place open at 5:30. We knew what we wanted got our order in and enjoyed our meal. But the key is to get here early.

I had the Fried Chicken, moist and very tasty. The wife got the pork shoulder and my daughter got the grits and shrimp. One side of mac and cheese and we ate it all.

Just well made food and staff is very good. This is the second time we have been here and will come again, next time we are in town.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Amazing food! Cool little spot to get breakfast! Our wait was only about 15 mins for two (even though we heard it's usually a lot longer). 

We sat in the outside patio and our waitress was really nice and informative. We had the praline bacon starter, and my life was changed forever. The best tasting strips of bacon and other goodness I've ever had. The rest of their food was also great tasting, but I must admit the bacon took home the gold.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Portland=brunch galore. So why screen door? Honestly I'm not quite sure. The wait was 1.5 hr for a table for 2, during which I was able to walk across the burnside bridge and back. Time well spent, if you ask me. We were seated a few minutes after getting back from the stroll, and ordered the chicken and waffle right when we got seated. Service was decent, space was cramped, no one rushed us, and the line outside STAYED long ( for those who think there's a "better" time to come). 

Food/drink:
-3pc chicken and waffle: I enjoyed this, especially because the chicken was boneless! I thought I'd have to start picking at the meat but nope, it's all meat. The waffle was interesting and tasted like carrot cake. Personally I would've liked it to be crispier. 
-hushpuppies: meh. I don't understand them. They were dry, not flavorful, just filled my tummy with something as I waited for the chicken and waffle.
-bloody Mary: yummy! Stronger than most I've had. The bourbon ( I believe) was pretty noticeable, quite a nice eye opener. Plus I love the pickled okra and olive.

Overall it was an enjoyable meal. I'd come back for the chicken and waffle + Bloody Mary only
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: First stop on a 30 hour whirlwind jaunt around Portland. Cozied up at the bar and ordered the famous chicken and waffles and a side of sausage gravy. The only downside to solo travel is no one to share more food with! Everything was great- flavorful and fresh. Personally I thought the breading on the chicken was a bit thick but the seasonings and juicy chicken were spot on. Would love to try more if I ever return!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Me and my husband came here while on vacation to Portland because of all the great reviews. It was definitely packed and we went on a Thursday afternoon so I can only imagine what the line is like on the weekends. The food was good. I had the banana finch toast with the one biscuit with gravy and my husband had the chicken and waffles. All the food was amazing and the OJ tasted so fresh. I would recommend this place. The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is because there was a long wait after we ordered our food and our waiter seemed a little disconnected.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Wowwo wowwo y'all!!!  During our trip to Portland, we didn't get a chance to cruise the town and hit up the popular places, mainly due to the fact that we spent most of our time at the outlets.  Sue me!

The one restaurant that I NEEDED to visit was Screen Door (if it wasn't unclassy to curse, I would say, "That's right m*tha f*%ka!!!" But I'm classy.)  We went for brunch, the server said that it was the busiest time ever, and waited for 1.5 hours.  Well worth the wait...dog!

For reals! It was so good!! The hubs ordered biscuits as an appy, which were so buttery and served with honeyed butter.  I think it might have been a not so great idea seeing as the main dealy (cue the monstrous plate of fried chicken and waffles) was so filling!!

Three large pieces of fried chicken (hand battered as ordered, btw!!) and a very huge sweet potato waffle! Needless to say, I couldn't finish!  Kept the leftovers for the car ride home...but didn't end up eating it until the next day...I WAS STILL FULL BY THE TIME WE GOT HOME! 8pm!!

MUST EAT HERE!.... AGAIN!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: The fried chicken & waffle!!! So delicious. They give you three crispy, big chicken chunks on top of a fluffy, cinnamon-y waffle, what's not to like! The chicken was perfectly seasoned and tasted great with the waffle + maple syrup. Also tried the chicken gravy biscuit sandwich. Also great! A bit too heavy but my friends loved it. Like the other reviews say, get the bacon praline. It comes with three pieces. Unlike most other restaurants that serve hard, crunchy bacon, this place serves warm, soft, perfectly sweet, melt in yo mouth bacon. Yum! The only downside is the wait which seems to be a consistent thing with every popular restaurant in Portland.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
5 stars and I mean it!   My vegetarian cousin declared this as one of the best veggie meals she's ever eaten, and I tend to agree.  

We waited ~45 mins for our table, but were able to take a quick walk around the surrounding neighborhood, so it wasn't bad.  The host was extremely friendly, which was an oddity compared to some of the restaurants we went to in Portland.

I was there with four other girls, and most of us decided to get the Screen Door Plate - a choice of 3 sides or half orders of the local veggie specials, plus cornbread.  I had:

- Slow Cooked Flageolet Beans
- Black Mission Fig & Ebony Heart Pluot Salad
- Roasted Beet Salad

These were all very tasty, if you couldn't tell by just their titles!  Be warned though - the portions are huge.  Another girl in the party had shrimp and grits and loved it too.  We were all so full that we couldn't fit in dessert, but it looked amazing too.

All in all - great southern cuisine, lots of local flavor and good veggie options.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: 40 min. Is well worth the wait! Very yummy drinks and food.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I've only eaten here a couple of times, but both times, it was excellent. Friendly staff, good service, and out-of-this-world food!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Great food! Lots of wonderful made on site goodies! Try the Pralines Bacon! Try the Biscuits n Gravy, you won't be disappointed, but only one biscuit, unless you want leftovers. They have a full bar and have coffee always available!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
The Screen Door was recommended to us during our one night stay in Portland.  They warned of the wait, but it was only about 30 minutes and TOTALLY worth it!  It was also super reasonably priced for all we got.

The food here is crazy good.  I have only had fried chicken about a dozen times in my life and not only was this the best, it was some of the best food I've tasted period.  The catfish was also incredible - not fishy at all, and the breading was perfect.  The red beans and rice was delicious, as were the hush puppies to start.  And the berry shortcake for dessert, oh my!  We had enough food for dinner twice.  My only complaint is that I like my jambalaya much spicier.

Our waiter was attentive and helpful, and the water and lemonade flowed appropriately.  It was extremely busy and a little loud, but we felt cozy and not too cramped in our little space.  We will definitely be going back!  Call in ahead and order take out if you don't want to wait for a space in the restaurant.  It seemed like a popular option for the local folk.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: As my gf pointed out in her review nearly two years ago, the food and drinks are terrific, and the service is excellent. But I would be remiss in not pointing out that there is frequently a VERY long wait, and that the interior is quite loud and crowded. I would love to return, but am on the fence until I can find a way to shorten the wait.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
There is always a wait.  However, they have coffee for you while waiting in line to make it almost painless.   

There is a reason for the lines:
Food is just so good.  Probably one of the best Southern style food joints in Portland.  As everyone else has commented, the fried chicken is delish as well as the praline bacon.   Their egg dishes are so rich as lush.  I haven't had a bad thing in all the times I've been here.

If you are looking for quiet or intimate, this may not be your cup o'tea.  It gets quite loud and feels a bit cramped, but it goes with the vibe.  Get there early if you don't like waiting or crowds.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Been here multiple times mainly for brunch.  Definitely a brunch standby for me since the roomie likes the praline bacon waffle.  I always steal a bite since it's sooo good but I really wish the bacon was IN the waffle instead of just on top.  Chicken and waffle is definitely good although I really like my fried chicken dark and on the bone.  
I've had the oyster benny It tasted like it should but one of my eggs was a wee bit over poached nothing that would ruin it though.

Had the brisket hash special and I LOVED the flavor only thing I didn't like though was that the brisket was cut in a way that left chunks of fat mixed in with the meat and potatoes.  The fat chunks also resembled potatoes so I would occasionally get a bit of just beef fat.

breakfast corndog is awesome definitely something i loved. 

Overall definitely recommend this place, long wait though so be prepared to stand outside for a while.  Also service is good, but nothing spectacular,
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: When in Rome, do as the Romans, right?  That's what I like to do so with over 4000 reviews we thought we'd try Screen Door.  The wait to get in was about an hour. I don't usually like to wait that long for anywhere but this place had glowing reviews. We got seated, ordered, and then waited another 45 min for our food. Not impressedWe all ordered the screen door plate which was any three sides and cornbread.  Cornbread was dry and not very tasty.  Mac and cheese on the other hand was creamy, cheesy with a crisp top and super delish!  The gumbo was tasty with a touch of spice. The boysenberry and beet salads were good and the chicken strips had a light batter seasoned just right.  The server was decent but seemed like he didn't want to reccimend anything for fear we'd blame him if we didnt like it.  Wanted to try dessert but we were full as portions are very large and can be easily shared. If the wait was only 10 or 15 min I'd come back but I wouldn't wait an hour again.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I knew my fellow Yelpers wouldn't fail me when they say that Screen Door has the best brunch food in Portland.. this place definitely lives up to its hype! They open for brunch on Saturday and Sundays from 9am-2:30pm. My best friend and I got there around 9:30am, and our wait was around half an hour. By 10am, they were telling all the groups (no matter the size) that the wait was a little more than an hour. 

I usually don't have a problem with picking what I want to eat for brunch, but looking over their menu, I wanted to try everything! Everyone on Yelp recommended the chicken and waffles, but since the portions were so huge and we wanted to try more items, we opted out this time. (Actually, all of their items have huge portions. But the chicken and waffles dish is bigger than my head!)

Sitting at the bar, we witnessed the bartender making Bloody Marys after Bloody Marys. They looked delicious! 

- Farm Grits: cheddar grits with ham, poached eggs, and provolone. This dish is super cheesey! 
- Biscuits and Gravy: warm and flavorful.. perfect comfort food.
- Chicken Strips: so juicy! If the chicken used for the chicken and waffles is as good as the strips, it's no wonder the chicken and waffles dish is so famous. 
- Candied Bacon: I'm not a big fan of sweet-savory infused food, but this was pretty good. My best friend LOVED it!

Southern Brunch food is the best kind of food, and Screen Door definitely proves it!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I've been going to Screen Door for years. I've gotten to know the owners and a good number of staff. This is how you do southern comfort food. Everyone else needs to take notes. Fried Chicken. Sweet Tea. Mashed Potatoes. Mac and Cheese. You can't get a bad meal here. Any time I've had a less than excellent experience the staff makes it right. Great food and great service.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: LONG LINE, but it went quite fast.  I got in for the second seating.  Food was great.  Definately not low fat, but worth a splurge.  YUM.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Cute spot but extremely busy, at least for Sunday brunch. Fortunately I was solo for this visit so I was able to get a spot at the bar in about 20 min after arriving around 1130am. The bartender was nice and really quick in taking orders and making drinks. I heard a lot about the chicken and waffles so I decided to try it but I must have missed where they said it feeds a party of at least 2-3 people. It's a normal size large waffle but 3 large chicken breast on top. It's ridiculously big so either share or plan on taking the rest home. Waffle is delicious, chicken is tender and has a small kick which I liked. I also had to try the Burnside Brandy Milk Punch since I do love Brandy Milk Tea, and it was very good. Definitely more Brandy than the milk tea version. Lastly the orange juice is good, fresh squeezed off site, not there, but still fresh squeezed. A small is enough to complete my meal because a large is a pint sized glass, which everywhere else is unheard of! I would have gotten the large is I was already so full. 
If you are in Portland, it is worth to try the spot out. I wish I could taste more of the menu but I'm incredibly full from just half my plate.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I'm sure all the reviews and photos do this place justice. Though a little hyped, this is by far the best fried chicken I've ever had, and the brisket hash marries flavors that are just unreal. The sweet potato waffle? Meh. The blood orange mimosa was light and refreshing and delicious. I'd definitely go back, but I'd go during the week when it's a little more quiet. Wanted to try their collards that are only served during dinner, and though they had gumbo listed on the lunch menu they didn't have any to serve. All in all a good experience, decent service, exceptional chicken! Get the chicken!!!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Screen Door was the brunch destination this weekend with some out of town friends who had been wanting to try it. I had been once before, but didn't remember the service being so stellar! 

The situation:
*I arrived after other guests were seated and without hesitation, a chair, menu, silverware and water were brought for me so I could immediately enjoy my party.
*Our food took a little while and our waiter brought us fruit to nibble on with apologies.
*The response to condiment needs were handled in a fast, friendly way.
*Our food was great, coffee always topped off, drinks came fast and our bill wasn't rushed.
Service A+++++++++++++++++ some of the best I've experienced in the 7 years I've lived in Portland. Truly miraculous. Especially on a beautiful Sunday morning and you know the house was packed.
Atmosphere A+++ (but not as many). It was cute, clean, but mostly just full of tables that has something of a cafeteria feel that I don't love. Their pickled fruits and vegetables on display were a really nice touch, but the interior design isn't...quite as good as the service, let's say.
Food A+++ (same rating as atmosphere). The portions are unappetizing. Grown men cannot finish their food. There's a lot of waste, take home containers, etc., which from a food industry standpoint, I do not like. I judiciously ordered 1 biscuit and sausage gravy and thought there could have been more sausage, but the flavor and texture of both the gravy and the biscuit were very good and made a good match, but wasn't the most flavorful of all time. I was stuffed after half a biscuit. Seriously. The 1 biscuit/gravy, a cup of coffee and a small mimosa with tip was $20, which I thought was reasonable. The chicken and waffles, while good, could be half the size and no one is going to leave hungry. it would still be impressive. It's just.too.much.food. I think the bananas foster french toast was good, but way too sweet. As in, it could put someone into a diabetic coma. The omelettes were very pretty and looked good.

All in all, I don't really think my experience justifies the insane wait, when there are perfectly great brunch options in the immediate vicinity (notably, East Burn) but I was grateful for the impeccable service and the food was served hot. No complaints, no one sent food back. I just hate seeing the waste.

I'll be back, but not soon.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
We FINALLY went to dinner here; we've been regulars for weekend brunch for some time. (Thanks, Cam, for the inspiration.)

Ah. Sweet satisfaction. The trick to getting seated immediately appears to be to show up in the last 30 minutes of a Sunday night -- thanks, folks, for feeding us!

Fiending for their juicy, crisp, spicy, savory fried chicken, but didn't want to leave feeling like a beached marine mammal -- the perfect solution, of course, was to split one fried chicken plate and one Screen Door plate: three local/organic dishes plus cornbread. I chose the celery root and parsnip gratin with andouille bread crumbs, the roasted beet salad (with arugula, avocado, pistachios, grapefruit, and citrus vinaigrette), and the concord pear salad (with black mission figs plumped in balsamic vinegar and honey, frisee, endive, watercress, toasted almonds & manchego cheese in a cider vinaigrette). Delicious! And aren't you proud of me for choosing such healthy options? The chicken, of course, was perfect. Mashed potatoes, savory porky collard greens, crumbly moist sweet corn bread -- perfect. The hubby almost didn't share -- I distinctly heard a growl from his side of the table when I reached for my half. The hubby even went for the peanut butter pie (after making lame reference to current Salmonella peanut butter epidemic), which was a tad rich for me, but very very tasty.

The cocktails were lovely. I had the Rhett Butler, which had perfect Southern Gentleman manners (with a hint of roguish bourbon charm). The hubby didn't share his.

Service: impeccable, as always. Friendly and personable, but not cloying; fast and efficient, with great suggestions at the right moments. Some of the least stress-prone servers in Portland.

I'm still glowing with satisfaction.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I went here for dinner with my parents. The food was pretty OK I think, but it was so loud that the noise is all I can remember. Not sure if it was just a fluke or if I was extra sensitive because it was, y'know, my parents,  but with the combination of the open dining area/kitchen/bar and the noise-bouncy concrete floors, in my experience, it was not a great place for conversation. I'm willing to be convinced otherwise, but currently have little interest in returning.

text: Best fried chicken that I've ever had in my life. We were lucky to have gotten a seat for two right away despite there being a significant lineup comprised mainly of larger groups.

text:
My friend and I waited over an hour for our name to be called and another half-hour to actually get our food, but goddamn it was worth it.  Every bite was an explosion of awesome on my tongue.  The cheese grits were so amazing I wanted to kiss them.  Kiss those grits, dammit.

The best strategy, I think, is to put your name down, grab a book, walk down to Heart for a cup of coffee, read for an hour, and come back to the biggest treat you can give your mouth besides French kissing God herself.

Next time I'm in Portland, I'm having the cab drop me off here first before I even check in to my hotel.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food

text: The food here was AMAZING!!!.. I had a bite of everyones plate :). Quite Busy- but definitely has a warm cozy feel. I liked the living room effect. The fried chicken is boneless and PLENTY  with the perfect amount of crunch and moist meatiness. The mac n cheese is made homestyle with melted chesse. I am not a huge fan of cat fish and it just seriously melts in your mouth. The brisket literally fell apart with some yummy BBQ sauce- and the griddle cakes are OH SO GOOD! Def recommend, but expect a wait..and make sure you have time to dine!

text: Unbelievable! I'm from North Carolina and gave up hope that there was true southern food in the Pacific Northwest... UNTIL... The screen door experience. You have to try the fried catfish... Mind blowing!

text: On the last day of a recent trip to Oregon Looks like I saved the best for last, found this eclectic neighborhood in Portland with the best food I've had this whole trip hands-down.. If you're in the Portland area you must stop at Screendoor Restaurant. First off it was the day after Gene Wilder WILLIE WONKA passed and their specials for the day were dedicated to him with images & a snapchat filter!! The menu had us indecisive as everything sounded great! It was a Tuesday 10:45am and the place was packed. We ended up ordering the Shrimp & Grits and OMG! It was delicious the cheese grits were creamy & the shrimp w/ lardon was amazing the sauce complimented it and brought it all together!!! Also the Chicken & sweet potato waffle i was pleasantly surprised at the moisture & taste of the boneless fried chicken. And the waffle! Wow you definitely have to request the La. Cane syrup to get the real southern taste that was meant to be.. And of course we could not pass up the Screendoor praline bacon, this my friends is the TRUTH! its rare we find southern comfort food were EVERYTHING is so right, being a southern girl (Ga) my friend normally leaves missing home for lack of authenticity, however this trip she left missing home because the food touched her tastebuds in all the places her momma used to with her home cooking. SCREENDOOR restaurant is a must, we will be back!!!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I was astounded to find a place up here that had fried chicken and waffles.  Having spent four years in LA, I immediately recalled memories of the original thing from Roscoe's Chick'n n Waffles...sounds strange, but amazingly yummy.

This place isn't Roscoe's, but it is darn good.  They give you three HUGE pieces of fried white meat chicken strips on an enormous sweet potato belgian waffle.  The whole thing is dusted with powdered sugar and held together by a knife plunged through those honking huge pieces of chicken on top of the waffle.  

It takes some maneuvering to assemble the dish properly  As my sister and I have discovered through many trips to Roscoe's, you have to pour the syrup onto the waffle, then lay the chicken on top of the waffle, then pour gravy (which you have to order on the side) over the chicken.  Then dig in!  (oh, very importantly, chicken and waffle go in your mouth at the same time)

Their chicken here is great...they might be lacking the juicy dark meat chicken that you can order at Roscoe's, but it is fried perfectly, not at all greasy, plus they make their batter a little spicy so it's got this incredible kick to it.  I was only able to finish a piece and a half of it before my stomach protested.

They had a special of ham and asiago biscuits that morning (deee-lish!!) which were absolute perfection, not too greasy, but flaky and flavorful.  They didn't require any butter or anything else.

Their coffee is bottomless.  Their eggs fluffy.  Their potatoes are big and chunky slices but roasted and crispy on the outside.  How can this not be the perfect brunch place?  Be prepared for a wait however since it seems that others have also realized this fact as well!!

Overall, this place gets a solid four and a half stars.  The only reason I took anything off is because my heart will always beat for the original Roscoe's.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: This is the place to go for some good southern comfort food. However, be prepared to wait for a table. My hubby and I arrived here at 6PM on Saturday (the place opens at 5:30) and the restaurant was already jam packed and there was a crowd of people waiting outside. We were seated after waiting for 40 minutes and let me tell you if was completely worth it. We tried a number of items from the menu but the one dish that stood out was the lowcountry shrimp and grits. The mac and cheese was tasty as well. Not only was our food extremely good, but waiter was superb (I wish I could remember his name). This place was loud and bustling (in a good way) and we couldn't have asked for a better dining experience.

text:
Who doesn't love comfort food, right? After a long, tiring drive down from Seattle, our first stop was at the Screen Door for dinner. A bit of a wait at 6pm - about 40 minutes or so, but to be expected for such a popular place.

We started out with the hush puppies and fried green tomatoes. The hush puppies were light and flavorful, and the tomatoes were very good and something we had always wanted to try.

For our mains, my husband ordered the beef brisket with 2 vegetable sides. He enjoyed the brisket, but didn't find it to be specatular and noted that the veggies were just "ok." I had the Screen Door Plate with a thin, crispy pork chop, grits, mac & cheese and cornbread. Cholestrol city! The pork chop was perfectly cooked although underseasoned. Loved the mac & cheese and grits. Just what I would expect - yum!

I really debated between 3-4 stars but after much discussion and thought, had to go with three stars for the following "misses." The heavily touted cornbread was dry. Really, really dry. Same for the humongous slice of red velvet cake. Sahara desert dry, and unfortunately, quite tasteless to boot! We managed a few bites with lots of vanilla ice cream but then just gave up.

I'd like to give the brunch a whiril next time we're in town, but not sure that I'd make an effort to stop for dinner. Not bad.. some items quite good, but too many other places to choose from.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Chicken and waffles were amazing!  The waffles were sweet potato waffles and the chicken went so well with it!  Definitly a must go if you are in Portland!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: This place seriously smokes surrounding restaurants!!!! Some people might be put off by the line that hangs out the door; but don't let it deter you!!!  The Banana Foster French toast is heavenly, fluffy and so worth the wait!  Oh and let's not forget to mention their Huevos Rancheros, flavor, flavor, flavor and more flavor!  Oooh wait, there's more, the Cheese Grits equivalent to a cozy warm blanket on a cold day GOOD!! So Good!! Cheese'd up just right!  I'm not a drinker however the drinks that these bartenders where busting out looked delicious.  In addition, EXCELLENT service!!!  Without a doubt this is my go to spot for breakfast, I'll make the drive and bear the wait.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Recently brunched here a trip through Portland and loved it. 

The place is pretty big and busy so there is a wait, but things do keep moving. I had a good view of the kitchen from my seat and everything looked so amazing, fresh, and quality coming out of the kitchen.

The most amazing thing anyone at our table got was the fried chicken and waffle. 

The fried chicken alone is awesome. They do something great to the batter and it's a little spicy and the chicken is perfectly cooked. 

They present it with three pieces piled on a sweet potato waffle with a knife stuck through the top, through all the pieces, and into the waffle. It's served with maple syrup and is a big portion.

Fucking yum.

One thing I'm deducting a star for is the biscuits. I am a biscuit kind of girl and was really disappointed. I like a biscuit that melts in your mouth and is crispy/flakey on the outside moist on the inside and ready to melt butter. The biscuits at Screen Door are kind of dry and flavorless, square cut out from a pan, and not butter melting temperature. It was like a lukewarm buttermilk bread.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: The chicken, mac n cheese, and mashed potatoes are excellent. Best meal I've had in a long time!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: When locals and travelers alike are waiting outside in the rain for over an hour to eat somewhere, you know it's good. My husband and I waited for about an hour and a half and were not disappointed! The fried oyster poboy was to die for and the brisket hash was melt in your mouth. You also get a lot of food for your money, so why not wait?! To top it all off, the staff was super nice and helpful despite it being a busy Saturday morning.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Ah, nothing says the weekend like hanging out on a random sidewalk on E. Burnside for an hour with a hot cup o' Stumptown in my hand. This may sound awful, but in fact I quite enjoy it, because I know that this food is worth the wait. If we have folks from out of town, or are just in the mood for some deliciousness, we come to Screen Door.

The mimosas are good, the Bloody Mary is better. I can't stop ordering the cajun scramble: the veggies, the andouille sausage, the amazing potatoes on the side... Ahh. Ask for a biscuit instead of toast, there's an upcharge but (again) it's worth it. If you're in the mood for trying their chicken and waffles you will be so so happy. I'm not a big fan of either generally but, Oh Baby is that batter crispy and is that chicken beautifully moist. It's also boneless which is a huge plus. The benedict is always a winner with my husband, and my friend who ordered the bacon praline waffle almost lost a finger once I caught sight of that beauty. The service is always a team effort, and it's the same hard working group every time I'm there. They are a well-oiled machine and it's no surprise considering the demand. The prices are also incredibly reasonable, they could easily charge double and be just as busy.

Take a few friends, write your name on the list, and settle down for a long winter's nap on the sidewalk until that glorious moment when it's your name that's being called. At least there's the hot coffee and good company while you wait.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: We got lucky and didn't have to wait we sat at the bar. We had the fried oysters appetizer best we've ever had! We had the screen door plate this allows you to choose three items the catfish is amazing we will definitely be back! And you won't be disappointed with the cornbread
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
It was silly of me to go to Screen Door on Father's Day, but I really wanted some fried chicken and have only heard good things about their brunch. I ended up waiting for about an hour for a table but it worth the wait. I went traditional brunch style and had their Bloody Mary which came with an olive and pickled okra. It had nice flavor and rimmed with cayenne salt which gave it a nice kick. 

We started off with their strawberry blitz that was filled with ricotta and mascarpone cheese. It was tasty and a lot of the sweetness came from the strawberries. I should also mention that their whipped cream is always perfectly whipped. I ended up ordering one of their specials called Fried Chicken Cathead Biscuit Sandwich-fried chicken, sausage gravy, a biscuit and your choice of potatoes or grits of which I picked the grits. It was definitely a sandwich I had to eat with a knife and fork but oh so tasty. The chicken was crunchy and the meat was still moist, the biscuit was of a cakey sort and the gravy was rich and full of chunks of sausage! The grits were also good, nice and creamy and full of flavor.

We also ordered their Screen Door Praline Bacon, OMG. If you love bacon you have to try this which I believe they only serve at brunch. You get three strips of bacon and they are packed with pecans. They salty and sweet and not really on the crunchy side but that's because there's so much happy goodness going on on that piece of bacon. It just begs for an accompaniment of a good waffle. I can't wait to go to brunch there again and maybe that time I'll order the fried chicken and waffles...with a side of praline bacon.

For those of you that like watching the bustle of the kitchen, they have an open kitchen. It's one of my favorite places to watch, seeing the fantastic dishes come by begging to eaten and the quiet dynamic of the cooks while enjoying your own fantastic meal.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
A must. Worth the wait.

The two of us had our bags with us and the wonderful staff placed it in the office to help with the tight space between table. I thought it was thoughtful.

We visited during lunch time. The BLT was yummy and my son ordered the fried chicken and waffles.

text:
Better than food is suppose to taste

I recommend the screen door plate to try several things. Well worth the price of admission.

text:
We arrived at Screen Door after seeing all the great reviews. There was an about hour wait for a table, but since we were on vacation and weren't rushed, we decided what the heck. Waited an hour (in the rain) when we were finally sat. Great place, packed with people both at the bar and tables. The kitchen is exposed, which is pretty neat. The restaurant have jars all over with preserved veggies. The coffee was amazing (they serve unlimited Stumptown!) and we also ordered the Bloody Mary which was top notch and spicy. The service was a little slow, but I imagine it was because they are just so darn busy. It took maybe 35-40mins for our food to arrive after ordering.

For our entrees, we ordered the fried chicken and waffles and the Catshead biscuit sandwich. Chicken and waffles were delicious (and quite a lot to eat) 3 large chicken pieces piled high. I added the house hot sauce to give them an extra kick. The Catshead was even more delicious! The biscuits was fluffy, served with a piece of fried chicken and topped with creamy-good gravy. I would absolutely recommend both dishes and this restaurant. It was well worth the wait, but we weren't on a schedule or anything.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: OMG...this place was amazing and well worth the LONG wait.  The biscuits and veggie gravy were the best I've EVER had!  I love biscuits and gravy and since choosing to not eat land animals I have not found very good gravy.  They make a delish mushroom gravy that is a must-try for anyone who enjoys mushrooms.  The side of potatoes was also some of the best I've had.  We had the banana french toast - I'm not usually a fan of french toast, but it was delightful.  The oyster boy boy was not my favorite, but only because it was not to die for and I'm sure there are other things on the menu that are.  YUM!  I never wait over 20 minutes, but will continue to make an exception for this place.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

name: Screen Door

text:
I'm sad to say that I did not love the food here. I have learned after trying it a few times that I am just not a southern food kinda gal. Who knows? Maybe one day I'll come around...

So, I can see the appeal in Screen Door. It was my first visit, and everything on the menu sounded amazing. I have been eyeing this place for some time and finally made it for lunch. I read some reviews and decided to get the chicken and waffles and the cat fish po boy. For appetizer, the praline bacon.

The bacon was delicious, I have to say. I've tried a similar style of bacon at a nearby joint, but I found the other version too nutty and overly sweet. Screen Door has perfected this balance. As far as the entrees, the chicken was certainly flavorful and juicy, but my fiance found himself craving some dark meat on the bone probably should've gotten the drumsticks instead); and in ordering the po boy, I have realized that I do not like catfish. It was my first time, and I just don't prefer the flavor. I ended up removing the catfish and replaced it with a piece of fried chicken that came with the waffle. In the end, we left feeling heavy and unsatisfied.

I really think it must be personal preference though because of all the stellar reviews on here. At least, that is what I'm going to chalk it up to this time. I will probably try again someday and see if I can change my review. (The biscuits and gravy looked amazing.) In the meantime, if you are thinking about trying some it and enjoy southern comfort food, I'd say try Screen Door. If anything, they definitely give you the bang for your buck.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
A friend who used to live in Portland recommended this place for me to go while I was here on vacation and she called it the best restaurant in Portland. This was obviously a huge statement so I had to go.

Got there about 20 minutes before it opened and was seated about 10 minutes after they opened the doors. The atmosphere is warm and homey, and our server was very nice and helpful. He was attentive all night and service was good considering how busy they became so fast.

I have to admit, it was worth standing in line in the cold rain.

We got the fried oysters, which were incredible. The batter was perfect and a great teaser to get us excited for the fried chicken. 

I got the Screen Door option, which was 3 sides plus cornbread. I chose the 4 piece fried chicken wings (which were way bigger than I was expecting and deep fried into perfection), mac n cheese (so rich, I'm lactose intolerant and frankly this was worth it), and gumbo (I'm no expert on gumbo but this was amazing and the small bowl was filling). The cornbread was dense and not sweet, so I was a little disappointed at first but then I ate it with the honey butter and I couldn't get enough. I only wish they gave more of it. 

I have nothing more to say except go. Just go. Go early if you can, but it's worth the line. Trust me.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:

text:
Holy deliciousness, Batman! This was by far our favorite breakfast spot on our week-long road trip from Portland to SF. We came on a Monday morning when they opened to avoid a wait, which was a good idea (we walked by around 9am on Sunday and there was a line around the block)! We started with the praline bacon, which let's be real, was one of the best things I've ever eaten in MY LIFE. Lucious praline and thickly cut, and not overwhelmingly sweet. My husband had the Chicken and Waffles, which was perfectly breaded and had an excellent flavor. I enjoyed the Blueberry Lemon Curd Buttermilk Pancakes, which had a nice sharp flavor contrasted by the sweetness of the berries, but probably my least favorite out of the three. 

There is a reason this place has a reputation and long wait times on the weekends - it's freaking delicious! Only wish we had more time to stay here and check out the rest of the menu.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food

text: This is one of those places that, even after traveling all over the world, still stands out as one of the most downright satisfying spots on the west coast in my opinion; you might wait a while but I assure you, it is most definitely worth it.  Now might be like "But who is this unknown perhaps godless heathen of a man to just assure people left and right?!" ...consider me a guinea pig that dropped $80 at screen door and would happily do it again.  I went in with my fiancee and we shared the brisket and fried chicken; 9/10 would come back just for those two items.  Tender is an understatement when it comes to their brisket, the fork might as well have been a light saber, ze chicken? basically everything you've always wanted fried chicken to be...I could write a page on their banana caramel pie alone but I'll spare you. Now go fork yourself. :)

text:
My wife and I rarely get the chance to spend any time or money on ourselves -- we have 3 kids. On the occasion of our tenth wedding anniversary, I thought it important to make an investment in ourselves.

From the moment we walked into Screen Door, I knew we had made the right investment. The decoration, the staff, even the smell of the joint was amazing. 

Walking in, we were greeted by a bespectacled man who introduced himself as "Salty." Salty made us feel like we were the only people in there, even though there was a twenty minute wait for a table. He made suggestions, was appropriately congratulatory about our anniversary, he even found us a booth in a packed restaurant.

Once we sat down, the service was incredibly fast, even in spite of the place being absolutely packed. My wife had seen a side dish that was part of one of the specials-- an incredible succotash-- and Erika, our server, took the time to suggest an appropriate way to group the Screen Door Plate so that she could have that as one of the three sides that would comprise her entree. She also had Em's salad, now one of four choices, come out first because "it's a lot more generous when it comes separately."

Then came the food.

The food here is amazing -- homey and filling while not overwhelming. The portions are generous and the flavors are on point. This is a place you go when you want to cast aside your gastric limits and simply devour everything on your plate. Plan on taking food home if you have any self-control.

Since our anniversary we have returned multiple times and we're always impressed with the fare. We will definitely be going again, hopefully sometime for brunch.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: FAntastic fried chicken (maybe the best in Portland) The birthday waffle tower with praline bacon and creme fraiche is off the hook! Great cocktails as well. text: It's loud. It's a long wait. It's ahhhmaazin! Best food in all of Portland and it never disappoints. If you're lucky you may even see some of Portland's most famous eating here, as we have. My favorites are the fried chicken and mac and cheese, but everything I've ordered has been stupendous.

text:
I have been wanting to go to Screen Door for years and finally got my wish for a birthday dinner.  We went on a Sunday evening, showing up 20 minutes before they opened.  There were already 10-12 people in line when we showed up, and by the time they opened the door, there was easily 40 people total in line.

We ordered the pork belly appetizer, which was good.  I also ordered the Scarlet O'Hara cocktail, which was dangerously delicious.  For entrees, I ordered the pulled pork sandwich, which I just thought was okay.  My husband ordered the brisket which he felt was also sub-par.  We had a side of macaroni and cheese which is by the far the best I have ever had in a restaurant, and I am kind of obsessed with mac and cheese.  Our desserts were also ridiculously amazing.  We got the banana cream pie and the pecan pie.  Again these were the best I had ever had.

I would definitely go back, especially since neither one of us order the fried chicken which is rumored to be some of the best in the city.  We are not to sure about their barbecue options, but their other southern comfort dishes are the best I've ever had.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food

Jakes in Mcminnville

text:
My boyfriend and I visited Portland and this was one of the brunch places I was most excited for. We came by around 12:30 PM and there was a huge line and an estimated hour wait for us. Obviously since I've come so far, I didn't feel like being a quitter. We walked around the neighborhood and eventually ended up getting a snack from the Cheese & Crack Snack Shop (no regret). 

After an hour we finally got seated in their dining area outside. It was a cold and chilly day in December but they had outdoor heating coming from the ceiling lamps so that was pretty considerate! We came into the restaurant with our carry-on luggage since we were going to catch a flight after brunch and the staff was very considerate, they kept our luggage in their office so it wouldn't get in our or anyone else's way (thanks!). 

It was already 1:30 PM when we sat down (they close weekend brunch at 2:30 PM) but the restaurant itself was still packed from wall to wall. Clearly, this place is poppin'. After seeing stacks of chicken and waffles served to tables all around us, we ordered their two most popular dishes.

* Praline Bacon *
This is dangerous. Slightly sweet, slightly salty, slightly savory, plenty fatty. I was expecting the bacon to be more crispy but this bacon is served quite soft. It was delicious but anymore than a couple bites felt too heavy, on my body and my soul. Perfect to share!

* Fried Chicken & Waffles *
Pancake stacks are so yesterday; it's all about a stack of fried chicken atop a thick and fluffy waffle now. The batter is very flavorful, with flakes of black peppercorn all over it. The chicken is moist on the inside and crispy on the outside. The sweet potato waffle was soft and airy, almost like a sponge (delicious). You can actually taste the sweet potato flavor! We got one order of this to share and it was more than enough food. The proportions here are ginormous and definitely meant to be shared or turned into multiple meals.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: One of my favorite restaurants of all time.  I get sick because the fried chicken is too good to stop eating.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I love restaurants that give you the option to order lots of a la carte options.  I did the make your own breakfast and ordered a biscuit, veggie sausage, veggie gravy, grits, and fruit salad.  I will detail the magic that was my breakfast:
    * biscuit: perfectly flaky, buttery, but not greasy - must order
    * veggie sausage: above average - not a must order
    * veggie gravy: BEST I've ever had, it was mushroom, which most veggie gravy is and had just the right amount of pepper.  It came in a gigantic tub, which I thought was excessive, but what do you know, I finished it all and wanted more! - must order
    * grits: pretty good, creamy, but still light and flavorful - not a must order
    * fruit salad: very good, grapes, pears, grapefruit, and pomegranate, not a must order, but definitely a good addition to what was otherwise a pretty heavy meal

One of my friends ordered a pimento cheese and bacon sandwich and he loved it.  The other made his own breakfast too and also was very pleased.  We also shared winter squash and ricotta beignets tossed in cinnamon sugar with powdered sugar, which was a special and were very good, not too sweet or greasy, reminiscent of hush puppies - almost a must order, but not quite.  

I would love to make it back to Screen Door for dinner some time.  This is a must visit place in Portland.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Delicious!  Loved everything!  We tried the back door lemonades, fried okra, fried chicken, mashed potatoes & gravy, collard greens, Macaroni and Cheese, Pear Salad, & Pumpkin Chocolate Layer Cake with Pumpkin Ice Cream. Great Service, too! Definitely recommend!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
This restaurant makes me sad that I've given out five-stars to others. It is deservedly the BEST dining experience, even with the wait, I've ever had. For starters, you can PARK! There is ample parking on the streets surrounding this little gem. There was garden porch seating when we were there (it's May 2nd) as well as bar and booth and table indoors. You can grab a cup of joe while you wait, just walk up and get one, or order your poison from the bartender. Lots of bloody mary's were tearing out of there, and few screwdrivers as well.

After a mere 50 minute wait, and it was SO WORTH IT, we were seated at a table inside, and I was luckily facing the kitchen. It's a large, beautiful open kitchen. You can see the guys and gals doing their thang back there, and it's ALL GOOD. We had to order the chicken and waffle, having heard from far and wide how extraordinarily good it is. IT WAS. BY FAR. THE BEST. FRIED CHICKEN. AND WAFFLE. I'VE EVER HAD.

I'm not kidding. This is a fattsy talking, with lots of poundage of fried goodness from up and down the West Coast. I've got POUNDS of experience, and this is IT. By God, you can't get any fresher, any crisper, any juicier, chicken. You can't get a fluffier but dense, light but heavy, crispy but creamy waffle, done to PERFECTION, anywhere on the left coast. And if you can - PLEASE TELL ME, I'll go there. But seriously, you have to try this place. I mean, how much worse can the wait get? No one is sad, no one is antsy, everyone in line is happy just to be alive and getting ready to eat at this place.

There's also a line-up of three benedicts with REAL hollandaise sauce, yes real. There are a bevy of skillets that we saw come out and they looked SO fresh and vibrant and clean, and they have an appetizer of a breakfast corn dog, hand dipped sausage, that the neighboring table said was the BEST CORN DOG SHE HAD EVER EATEN.

Go here. I hope you too get Eric, our excellent server! Give him a hug for his recent rough patch.  He filled our coffees up PRONTO and I mean fast. I had at LEAST 4 refills - and he's good with the advice too. He steered us to gravy on the side, and honest to pete - this is better than my OWN gravy, which should be in a museum of the best gravy ever made by a human being. So i abdicate the throne and hand my title to the chef(s) at the SCREEN DOOR. I bow to you in the chicken, waffle and gravy departments. HONESTLY, YOU GUYS ARE WICKED-GOOD. I WILL BE BACK!!!

Nomination: Best Breakfast ON THE PLANET
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
A couple of minor negatives first: the service can be hit-or-miss, which is much more due to the popularity of the place than any failings on the part of the wait staff.  And they run out of stuff.  Also, I find the cheese grits to be strangely acidic in taste.

Now that that is out of the way, there are a lot of positives.  The fried chicken is among the best I have tasted.  They have a lot of wholesome organic-y sides, and the portions are massive.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Best fried chicken known to man. So yummy. The Screen Door Chicken is great for dinner, the Cat Head Biscuit is great for brunch and the Chicken and Waffles are great for brunch/lunch! Love love love this place! Favorite for sure
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I just don't get it Portland... this place, like so many, is completely overrated.  The food is NOTHING special and NOT worth the wait.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Just loved everything about this place. Cute little spot with great food and excellent service.  The Chicken and waffles is their most famous dish, and it comes with three big chicken breasts on top of a waffle.  It is a must try! Their portions are huge so I recommend sharing your entrees and trying out more dishes.  

Some of my other favorites were their Bloody Marys, Fried Oyster Benedict, Praline Bacon, Banana Fosters French Toast, The Breakfast Po Boy, and The Croque Madam.  All were so good.  

Next time I come back I'd want to come back for dinner and try their Mac and Cheese!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Finally found some good food in pdx and by far the best. So far I have tried the dinner beef brisket, shephards pie, and shrimp with grits. Being a huge food snob and critic, I have nothing bad to say.  Food was amazing and unexpectedly good since many restaurants failed me in pdx. Another side note, I had a lot of coworkers (about 20) from the south who agreed this was one of the best southern food they had. Kudos to Screen door!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Screen Door is crack and I am an addict!  There are too many amazing places in this city to wait for brunch like this town waits for brunch, so I just don't do it.  Dinner time here is my jam, the wait is generally brief, never been over 10 minutes, and often as easy as sidling straight up to the bar.  Speaking of the bar, my friend with the bitchin' mustache.  Yeah, he makes the best Spanish Coffee in town.  Now I know what your brain is thinking, "But, have you been to Huber's?"  All pomp and circumstance aside the Screen Door has a gem in their cocktail professionals.  There is showmanship with the mixology but the cold hard facts are the drinks are wonderful.  Oh yeah, the fried chicken blows the doors off of any place that I have ever tried the fried goodness...and I used to be a long-haul truck driver so I know my way around a piece of fried chicken or two!  See you soon friend.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I finally tasted the glory of Screen Door. I've been hearing nothing but good things for months about this restaurant and I can tell you it lives up to the hype. If you don't mind a long wait you will be treated to some of the best southern food west of the Mississippi. The staff is very attentive and knowledgeable and the beer on tap complements the cuisine.

I was overwhelmed by the menu options so I went with the classic fried chicken with collard greens and a cold oatmeal ale. This was by far the best fried chicken that I have ever had and I can't stop thinking about it. The seasoning was spicy and appropriately salty. The collard greens were perfectly cooked and as far as I know, done well.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Best fried chicken we've found in Portland. Always great food and helpful friendly service. The Rhett Butler is a FANTASTIC cocktail
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Definitely a fun and hip restaurant! 

**Make a reservation, even if you're only giving them an hour notice, somehow our group of 7 ended up walking in and were seated within 10 minutes! Total score. Everyone else waiting just looked at us like "who da heck are you."

I shared the CRISPY FRIED BUTTERMILK-BATTERED CHICKEN with my friend. It was plenty of food for two! Nice, crispy, and tender chicken breast. Just how it should be. Though I would say that the batter was a bit tooo peppery, I ended up eating the chicken with ketchup. In addition, we ordered a side of CORNBREAD - I was super underwhelemed by the cornbread, it was dry with little flavor. Definitely dissapointed.

For dessert, our group shared the CHOCOLATE GANACHE CAKE WITH RASPBERRY ICE CREAM - really yummy raspberry ice cream but just like the cornbread, the chocolate cake was underwhelming and dry, I felt like I could've bought the cake at a grocery store. Also ordered were two other desserts, I'm blanking on the names right now but one was some sort of blackberry crumble & the other was a lemon bluberry layer cake. Both were not the best desserts I've ever had. Next time, I would pass on the sweet stuff.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
It's all true. I won't repeat the other reviews. Or be redundant.

It would have been nice if they'd prepared me for the size of the portions though. It made my heart scary! Like the chicken and waffles, it was a goddamn tower of chicken. Tender, moist, boneless, engorged breasts heaving out of heavenly crispness. 

We got there at 9:30 am on a Saturday and only waited 1/2 hour...and they do set you up with coffee for the wait. Nice! 

I especially appreciated that, though it could feel like a flurried madhouse of brunch craziness, the servers were all on their A-game, calm and did everything one could ask.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
I don't even know how to write this review because this is on my top 5 best restaurants in PDX. The brunch is unreal, every time. From the chicken and waffles, to the pecan bacon, to all of the specials they have every weekend, to the bloodys. i cannot get enough of this place. It is worth the wait or getting up at the crack butt of dawn to wait in line. Bring a book your coffee and just wait, you wont be mad that you did.

Dinner is pretty darn amazing too and doesn't have the awful wait most nights. I cannot stay away from screen door!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Everything we ordered here was delicious. Portions, prices, and service were excellent. I don't think we'd eat here regularly, but when we want a special treat for breakfast, Screen Door is one of our first choices.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Been here two times now. I try to go during the week so as to avoid a long wait. Cool place to eat breakfast. The only gripe I have is that you have to order a full order of the pecan bacon, which is outstanding, however I do not desire that many pieces. The only only item on the menu that includes a piece of the pecan bacon is the waffle, so look for that if you don't want a full order. Possible 5 stars if patrons can order 1 or 2 pieces a la carte.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: New to Portland, and this was a breakfast stop when we were still in the house hunting stage. If they were around my (new) corner, I'd be there 3 times a week! Just delicious, friendly, comfy and even the coffee was great. Made me love my new city even more.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Ate here with family after seeing a Broadway show. Heard good things and thought we'd try it. The food is awesome and I won't get into that. My review is solely about their reservation system: they'll let you reserve a table as long as you have 6 or more in your party.  For dinner service, the only time they'll take a reservation for is 5:00 - the time they open. They're very clear at the time you make the reservation that you must be there, with all six people, within 15 minutes or they will give your table away. The problem is, you still have to wait in line to tell them you have a reservation. If that takes longer than 15 minutes, you're out of luck. Try to cut in line and tell the hostess you have reservations could result in an ugly confrontation with others.  When we got to the front of the line and I told the hostess we had reservations she made a big deal about asking if all 6 of us were there. I thought about telling her 'what the hell does it matter when we had to wait in line like everyone else?'  Figured that conversation was above her pay grade and pointless so, let it go. They really need to start their seating process by calling out the names of those with reservations when they open and then 15 minutes later to be fair.  Someone to organize the waiting line (at least some exterior markings, ropes, etc) to indicate the structure of the waiting line would help. There were a few scumbags who felt they were better than everyone else and blatantly just came in the opposite direction of the formed line and forced their way in.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I don't get the hype. Why is this place so popular. The food was horrible. Everything had way too much salt and pepper. On top of that, everything had the exact same overly smoked flavor to it. My wife had a side of corn and cheese and roasted peppers that tasted just like bandaids smell. I kid you not. The mashed potatoes were worse than idaho flakes mixed with watet. On top of that, I think I'm slightly deaf now from the level of noise in the place.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: The chicken and waffles are among the best I've had and the service was fabulous. Get there before 10 if you want a seat quickly.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Oh my god. Their chicken and waffles are perfection. I came here with my sister and we had to wait about an hour to be seated. We already knew we wanted to share the chicken and waffles, so as soon as we were seated, we ordered right away. Our food came out within 10-15 min. Oh my, when I took my first bite of chicken with Tabasco sauce, it was SO DAMN GOOD. By far one of the best chicken and waffles I've ever had. I wanted to knock off half a star because one of the waitresses couldn't even give us some ice when we asked. She said "I'll let your waiter know." Girl, even if you're not our waitress, it's not that hard to get us a cup of freakin ice. Overall, the wait for this place is worth it. And if you don't know what to order, just get their chicken and waffles. You won't regret it!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Went here on a Friday night at 9:30. There was a short 5 minute wait. We got seated at the outdoor patio. The menu is simple. Enough option but not too many. I got a screen door plate. $14.5. It was alright. I got chicken drumsticks, wings and Mac n cheese. The drumsticks were great. The Mac n cheese and the wings were alright. Service was fast and the ambience was elegant. The food could I have been better. Portions are filling. There is some street parking around but it can be tough sometimes.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Happy with the beer and food this evening at the outside bar, but the happy hour service was sub-par. Long time to have a good order take ,longer time to have them run my card.  Sure, I'll be back. But spotty service this trip.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: This place was definitely overhyped and underwhelming. My bf and I previously came on a late Sunday morning and line was crazy with a bunch of people waiting both indoors and outdoors. After finding out that we would have to wait 1.5 hours to be seated, we left and decided to come back the next morning. We got up extra bright and early and arrived by 9 AM. No line at all and no wait to be seated, but it was most likely because it was a Monday morning when everyone is at work. Fast forward to ordering, I decided to go with the Texas Veggie Migas and my bf got the fried chicken biscuit sandwich. We waited awhile for our food to come out, which kind of sucked. The scrambled eggs in my dish were plenty flavorful with the pepperjack cheese, chiles, salsa, and onion with a side of crunch factor from the tortilla chips. Eating it with the tortilla made it taste like a well put together breakfast burrito. I don't think my dish was all that special though. If I had the right ingredients, I could have easily made it at home. My dish also came with a side of cheesy grits, which I barely touched and didn't bother to finish since I'm not a huge fan of grits anyway. I ended up not finishing my meal because it was way too much and I left feeling overly stuffed. My bf on the other hand enjoyed his fried chicken biscuit sandwich. I would say that it is hard to go wrong with that type of food because how hard can it be to make?? He didn't finish his grits either and agreed that they weren't really that good. Our waitress was pretty attentive with refilling our water and asking us how our food was, which we appreciated. There was also another waitress walking around asking people if they wanted coffee, so my bf said yes, but didn't realize until we got the bill that we were charged for it. So here is a fair warning! The coffee isn't free and they won't let you know. It didn't taste that great either, just plain coffee with the option of milk/creamer. However, I do think it's safe to assume that all breakfast places like this one do the same, so beware!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Waited almost an hour but was definitely worth it! Service was super friendly despite the crazy amount of people. We shared the chicken and waffles and winter vegetable hash. One word, amazing. Coming from New York I was skeptical that this brunch could live up to the hype, but this was probably the best brunch I have ever had. Chicken had the perfect amount of crunch, was seasoned to perfection and most of all was so so so moist. The waffle was the perfect amount of sweet and was light and airy. Vegetable hash was the perfect accompaniment to the chicken and made us feel less guilty because after all we included vegetables on our meal! Love love love this spot!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Definitely our favorite restaurant in Portland. There's not much to say that hasn't been said already, but order the steak whenever it's on the menu ($22.95, only on the weekends) and fried chicken or the shrimp and grits when it's not (or even when it is).
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: I have been going to Screen Door since they opened. Their food and service has remained consistent as well as their prices. This is always my go to place for Brunch! If you swing by for dinner their mac and cheese is awesome!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Good, southern-style cooking in a place you wouldn't expect it. Worth the wait though? I'm inclined to say "no."
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Breakfast was a precious gem of an experience recently!

Arrived at 8:20, translating into no wait---- ran into an old Emanuel friend I haven't seen since 2006! I plopped down at a table right next to her--- so so awesome.

Couldn't decide at all save to know I wanted some bottomless Stumptown, so ordered two dishes .

Could have been dessert or bread pudding, that French toast richness. And my sausage gravy--- top 2 gravies I have ever had in my life. The biscuit, however, has been bested by plenty of others, sadly.

The environment is casual all the way, and folk here are genuinely friendly, "small town", devoid of much pretense that one oft and unwittingly encounters here in the Bay.

Memorable ... Easily reached from Society Hotel too! Bonus
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text:
Went here specifically for the chicken and waffles and they did NOT disappoint! Parking took a couple of tries since most of the available spots were for 15 minutes--which does not exist where I'm from. Also, have you tried getting foodie food in Portland in 15 minutes? It's impossible! The wait in line alone eats all that up. 

Anyways, we got lucky and were immediately seated at the bar. They serve unlimited refills on their Stumptown coffee--awesome! We each went with two pieces of chicken...one piece would've been enough! They're filling! No complaints though, ate the leftovers as our snack after a hike up to Multnomah Falls Overlook.
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: You see that long line of people ahead of you to get into this place? Well, darlin' let me tell ya, there is a reason for that! Go. Just go! So delicious. I wanted to just live near this place- I'd go everyday!
categories: Caterers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Southern, Event Planning & Services, Bakeries, Cajun/Creole, Food
name: Screen Door

text: Delicious and over the top flavor (and of course calories, yummy yummy calories) in all of their dishes. The service was very good considering how busy they were (and always are). However, about that wait....it is just silly and the host/hostess never seems to be at the front ever. The last time I waited about 15 minutes to put in our groups name and no one even came close to helping me so we left.
