text:
If you're in the North End Neighborhood, chances are, you'll see plenty of people walking around, with a Mikes Pastry box. I do have to say...the hype is definitely real for this place. The line does get long, but it does move fast. As soon as you walk in, you can all their offerings on the wall. Although they had so many choices, I ordered their original plain Ricotta Cannoli as well as my wife. My son ordered their Oreo cannoli. We also ordered a slice of their Boston Cream Pie. They put all your goodies in a box and then tie it up with string that's hanging from the top. 

These cannolis are no joke, the best cannolis I've ever had. They were huge and had plenty of ricotta filling with a fresh crispy shell. I will admit I've never been a fan of Boston Cream Donuts, but a Boston Cream Pie is sure something else. It was very soft, but dense and sweet. Definitely very flavorful. I wouldn't hesitate ordering again, but next time I come, I'll be ordering other flavors.
categories: Candy Stores, Gelato, Food, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Specialty Food, Bakeries, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

name: Mike's Pastry

text:
Mike's Pastry was not on my radar until we saw 10,000 branded Mike's Pastry boxes being carried around the greater Boston area. These folks have got their marketing down to a T.

You'll know you're at the right place when you spot a zoo. Arriving at Mike's Pastry you'll see about a million people haphazardly lined up under harsh fluorescent lights all vying for a chance to order like it's The Hunger Games. Upon making eye contact with a worker at the front you'd best order quickly and swiftly before a hungry savage behind you pushes their way forward and you lose your turn. Apparently it's all part of the Mike's Pastry experience.

I have never seen so many cannoli flavors in my life. I have never seen cannoli so giant in my life. I have never seen human arms turbo wrap a string around a box like they do here in my life. 

The menu is vast if not overwhelming and yet it's hard to come away impressed by anything. The pistachio cannolo I had was mediocre at best, reliant on overly sweet filling for most of its flavor. There was something weirdly whipped about the cream which, aside from the saccharine taste, was sitting in a dense exterior that had already moistened and lost its flake. 

Lest anyone forget the primary flavor in this classic dessert should be CHEESE. Cannoli are supposed to have a rich yet refined taste and should not be sweet enough to send you into hyperglycemic shock. Bakeries in the USA use cow's milk ricotta and overdo the powdered sugar to thicken it up, leaving little of the ricotta flavor in the process. This creates something that's cloyingly sweet, compared to cannoli filling in Italy where the sheep's milk ricotta is denser and has a bit of tang, allowing it to balance well with any added sugar. Sometimes chocolate morsels are mixed in or there's a candied fruit applied to the outer ends for added flavor and texture. The shell should be thin, light, and flaky, just formidable enough to hold the silky filling within. Shells and filling should be kept separate until an order is placed, ensuring a crunchy outside and a cold smooth inside in every bite. Doesn't that sound great? You won't find any of that here.

All the people raving about how these are the bestest cannoli in the universe have yet to experience the delight and taste of real Italian cannoli. These are sugar, pure and simple, and far from the best dessert you'll find. In Boston alone Maria's Pastry and Modern Pastry serve a better product without the feeding frenzy atmosphere.
categories: Candy Stores, Gelato, Food, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Specialty Food, Bakeries, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
name: Mike's Pastry

text: Ricotta cannoli is so good. It's nice not to get the cannolis covered with powdered sugar because it makes a huge mess. Know what you want before you order, it's hard to see the display case because it's blocked by other customers. Cash only. Be focused, get in and get out with the goods.

name: Mike's Pastry

text: I can only speak for the gluten free pastries, as my family has allergies, but we were so excited to try since we were in Boston for a couple of days and this place had a line out the door.  We tried the chocolate cupcake, the vanilla cupcake, both with vanilla icing, and the black and white cookie since its been a favorite of mine since I was a kid.  The B&W cookie was by far the best, but doesn't come close to comparing to its glutenous counterpart.  It may be that I am use to the NY style version of this cookie, but it was just okay.  The cupcake was a tad dry and had an excessive amount of too sweet icing.  The other glutenous options looked good, but as I said before I cannot speak for any of them since we only tried the gluten free stuff.
categories: Candy Stores, Gelato, Food, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Specialty Food, Bakeries, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
name: Mike's Pastry

text:
Definately like cartoon food. I ordered the sausage and it was good but it was plated with five baby greenbeans tied like a pretzel and a one inch wedge of COLD steamed cabbage that had the core still attached. I had to ask for a knife and had to ask how this dish was to be eaten. I couldnt separate the leaves on the cabbage and had to ask for a knife.
To garnish the dish was three teensy fried pork rinds out of a conveinience store bag and a hack off branch of thai basil. I also had to ask what it was and what do I do with it. They charge for sticky rice that would serve well for a mason brick layer. We only ordered and ate it because we were so hungry after eating the $13 ridiculously spare plates.
I've travelled all over the world and consider myself a very good understanding of foods and this place only made me believe the owners of this place a laughing all the way to the bank!!
If you want an actual meal...Don't wast your hard earned money! 
Go somewhere that actually has walls and heat!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The first time I ate at Pok Pok was close to 10 years ago. I thought it was good, nothing to write home about. It was just becoming a fairly popular restaurant. The next time I ate here was a few months ago. I think maybe the place has succombed to the "Food Network Syndrome" where they could give two flying cats you are eating in their establishment cause they are "famous".  Customer service and food quality have dropped off the map. Waiting for a table is ridiculously long. There are far better places in the Portland area to eat then to waste time at this joint.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Tried the papaya salad (really spicy, don't recommend getting if you have a low spice tolerance like I do), Ike's Vietnamese fish sauce wings (amazing flavors), pet pha lo (Thai style stewed duck in five spice soy broth, quite salty in my opinion), khao soi neua (beef curry noodle soup). Portions are fairly small, but everything is meant to be shared family style. 

Pok Pok is on the pricier end of Portland restaurants, but still worthwhile to try for lunch when there's not much of a wait so highly recommend going during non-peak hours. 

Make sure to ask for the allergy-specific menu if you have any dietary restrictions -- it points out anything that you might be allergic to, i.e. shellfish and peanuts
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: It was good, tho a little on the expensive side considering the size of the portion and that there are a million Thai restaurants in Portland.   Service was very prompt.  I would go again, though i would try something more exotic.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Came here at an odd hour - little past the normal lunch hours and there was barely a wait! The space was nicely decorated with hanging bulbs and there was a good amount of seating indoors and outdoors. 

Since a few hours from dinner, we decided to only order the Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings & Kung Op Won Sen. The wings were superb! We got them a bit less spicy - next time will just order as is -  a bit strong with the fish sauce (kicks you in the face after taking a bite!), but they were perfectly flavored. The wings plus the entree was a good combo. The entree came with a side sauce for the prawns and that was tasty as well!

Would definitely come back for the wings, to try the other entrees and the drinks as well!! The drinks looked amazing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I lived in Cambodia for two years and this place has some AUTHENTIC cuisine. The line to get in was a little longer but that is expected when you prepare food as good as they do here.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: There is always something unusual and wonderfully scrumptious on the menu. Outdoor or indoor seating is a nice choice on a rare sunny day in P-town
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Exclusively for the ozone-dusted noses of New York elites, LA/SF transplants and white Portlander's looking for a white, safe and privilege-friendly place to shoot each other Caucasian death glances while contemplating which of their poor PDX native tenants to evict next.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is the best. Absolutely delicious. The Laap Khwai Meuang is wonderfully spicy and interesting. Get the drinking vinegar if you can, it's a killer experience.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Lately Pok Pok has been all over the news, NYTimes, WWeek, Portland Monthly etc. Wow, I don't know what all the hype is about. The wait was well over an hour, however they ring the bar across the street to get you, which is cool. Our food came before I even could have a few sips of my beer, it was too fast. I don't know if it were the dishes we ordered (game hen and duck livers) but there weren't any vegetables in the meal. And when we asked to see the menu again for a side of veggies or something there wasn't even a salad available. I left with a very heavy stomach, and wondering why everyone raves about this place.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: While the taste of the food was good.  I was disappointed with the size of the portions as compared to the price of the food.  There are much better values to be had in the Portland area.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I've been wanting to come here since we moved to Portland.  The first time we tried, we were thwarted by the usual ridiculous wait for a table.  That turned my wife off to the place so much that it took a long time to convince her to try again.  My sister and brother-in-law's visit was the proverbial straw that broke the camels back.  I wanted them to experience an authentic "Portland Dining Event" and this certainly fits the bill.  We were going to go on a Friday night (foolishly).  It was going to be 6 people in our party, so we qualified for making a reservation, which we tried to do that morning and basically got laughed at.  So, we re-scheduled for Sunday.  Got there around 5.45.  The wait for a table for four on the patio was 30-40 minutes.  We opted for the drinks-at-Whiskey-Soda-Lounge option while waiting (I have to say that's pretty convenient!).  When we were called up, we crossed the street just as another group was heading for the hostess hut.  One of the girls in the group broke off and ran past us, thinking she would get on the list ahead of us.  It felt good to just walk right past her, hand the reservation stub to the hostess, and be seated as that group was told they would probably have to wait an hour.  "Smells like victory."  

I tell this story in an effort to illustrate what I mean by "Portland Dining Event".  Now, on to the food.  I'm not going to spend much time on this because it is thoroughly covered in other reviews.  Instead, just a few bullet-point-style observations.

-Ike's Fish Sauce Wings are a must.  Get them "spicy" (unless you're a total weenie) because they taste better that way and aren't actually that spicy, anyway.  These are so fracking good that you are tempted to eat your fingers when you are done due to the sauce sticking to them.  PRO TIP: Order at least 2 portions of sticky rice per order of wings, then pinch off wads of rice to wipe your fingers on and then eat that.  That sauce tastes so damn good, it's a shame to wipe it on a napkin (which doesn't work anyway due to the stickiness).

-The green papaya salad is definitely spicy, but very flavorful.

-The Tamarind Whiskey Sour and the Tamarind Som are perfect for washing down this lovely food.

-Andy Ricker deserves all the praise because this food is phenomenal.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I have been here twice while visiting from Seattle. This place can be very packed on a weekend night. The most recent time I visited was a weekday afternoon and it was still pretty busy. Their spicy fish sauce wings are amazing! I basically came here the second time just for that. They are spicy, flavorful, and have a nice crunch. Also the boar dish is a very flavorful dish with lots of spices, they give chilled mustard greens on the side to clear your palate from all the flavor it contains, and it really works! Great service and awesome food, will probably drive down just to eat here again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Every once in a while, I completely disagree with yelp users.  This is an example of a restaurant that I believe is all hype.  The fish sauce wings are very good, but the rest of the plates are overpriced and not worth the money.  Small portions, pretentious service.  I walked out very disappointed
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Can't go wrong with the chicken wings. But this is not your typical american Thai food restaurant so don't expect to see pad Thai on the menu. Also, their cocktails are all tasty. Our reservation was pushed 15 minutes and so they gave our party of 6 complementary drinks!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Yes there's a wait.  But waiting's underrated... 
I've noticed that lots of people are enamored with the gooey-sweet brand of cuisine found in most Thai places. I'm not. As a result,  I take Thai food recommendations with a grain of salt (or a drop of  corn syrup-based peanut sauce, more like). Pok Pok was a surprise. Subtle flavors and unexpected ingredients like duck liver and stewed brisket showed up with more familiar flavors of lemon grass, basil, chiles and comforting sticky rice. Suddenly, I had a new appreciation for Thai food! The cocktails ( I had one with plum wine) were delicious and, by then, welcome. And the service? Spot on. 
Let's face it, when you are served bad food by a surly waiter, you'll never get that time back. So I urge you: exercise your patience in the Pok Pok line. It's worth it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
FISH SAUCE WINGS are a must have. While you will get messy eating them, they are well worth it. 

Loved the kao soi, the flavor of the broth was so good and complemented the noodles so well. I could have eaten 3 bowls of that. The half chicken was also super good! 

My only con is that we had said we hadn't been here before and the waitress just told us to read the menu and all the ingredients for each dish were on there - when really I was hoping for some recommendations. This is the reason for the 4-star instead of 5-star review.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I am from Thailand. It's been difficult for me to find the authentic Thai restaurant in Maryland. Only authentic Thai food I could find was my own cooking. I have heard a lot of good things about Pok Pok. Finally, I had a chance to come visit Portland and Pok Pok was one of my destination. Here I come! I can say they make the authentic Thai food here. Grilled chicken, Khao Soy, Yum eggplant and Stir-fried Brussels sprouts tasted exactly like what I had for 26 years in Thailand. I felt like I was home again. Just imagine yourself sitting on a street walk in Bangkok and enjoying Thai street food. Oh my goodness this place is AMAZING!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Amazing and authentic. The crowded labyrinth that led to our seats felt like the real thing. Since it was our first time, we went with the servers suggestion, coconut curry special and an oatmeal stout. The best of both worlds.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I read about the fish sauce wings in Portland Monthly and had to try it.  Well I don't care for chicken, but I was in Portland on a foodie trip so I needed to see what all the excitement was about.  I thought it would be sweet since most American Thai restaurants tend to layer on the palm sugar, but I was pleasantly surprised. There a nice balance between the light sticky glaze and the saltiness of the fish sauce. It's not spicy at all, but it's quite satisfying. Besides, I had the papaya salad and it was perfectly seasoned with peppers. Just enough for the that spicy bite, but not overdone to where your lips start burning. They add small dried shrimp to the mix giving the fish sauce somewhat more depth. A bite out of the chicken wing and a bit of jasmine rice then a little pick at the papaya salad --- the contrasting flavors were intense.  

I also had the hang leh which was a braised pork shoulder. It just melted. Each scoop of the nicely thickened broth contained cloves of garlic that seemed to have been roasted then pickled.  Each lite crunch into a clove gave a subtle freshness to the rich pork sauce that I ladled over my rice. Yum. 

I ordered the khao soi chicken for my dinner guest as she didn't care for spicy. It wasn't bad, but it was a bit on the sweet side for me. It does come with lime and hot peppers to adjust the taste to your liking, but I already had enough contrasting flavors going in with the rest of the meal. 

I will return again as the menus has something for all tastes. Sweet, spicy, salty, rich, creamy, crunchy and zesty.  Plus I found some of the food names too suspicious --- for example the nights special was: "thwat phat fuk tong" sp. or  menu item "hoi thwat"
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: It was kind of a long wait for a week night, but it was okay because they told us to go over to the Whiskey Soda Lounge and they would call us. The table we got was upstairs and pretty cramped but the food was super spicy, super fresh and super tasty!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I was the most excited about this restaurant and also the most disappointed. We ordered just the fried chicken and it was so salty. The spice was nice as it removed some of the fish sauce smell but I still couldn't really eat most of it.

I liked the vinegar vegetable on the side.

Not sure why people raved about it so much! I'd like to try the chicken curry-like dish next time if I'm ever back. Not worth the drive!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Not only did this place have the best atmosphere but the food was amazing. I lived in Thailand for two years and I must say the food brought back memories immediately. The only major difference between Pok Pok and when I lived in Thailand was that the food in Thailand was spicier but nevertheless this is a must for Thai food lovers. I could literally eat here everyday of the week if I lived in Portland.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Please, please, PLEASE open a location in San Francisco!!  I'm still dreaming about the fish sauce wings... so crunchy, so tangy, so delicious.  It makes me want to cry a little bit.  I've never had more unique and more tasty Thai food before. Every dish had a little surprise in it.  Heck, even the water tasted different! They put this herb in it that tasted like cashews to me.

I can't wait to go back to Portland and back to Pok Pok. Soooo worth the long wait.  And if the owners of Pok Pok read this, seriously, you should come to San Francisco. We would go crazy for you down here.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: All I can say is this place is a MUST GO! We ordered a bunch of appetizers and all were fantastic!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
4:30. We got there at 4:30. 

"Right now we're looking at a 60-90 minute wait."

"I'm sorry. What?"

Gave them the cell phone number. Headed down the street to Imperial Taproom for some beers. And guess what, about 90 minutes later, we got the text. Your table is ready. We sat downstairs. There is also an upstairs, a left patio, and a right patio. Oh, and a center patio. Quirky but fun.

Wings are a must. They have been on tv shows and they're spicy and unlike any wing you've had. Just get them. Brussels and pork belly was delicious. Sprouts were perfect, firm consistency. Cha ca catfish was heavenly. Bed of noodles soaked up the sauce nicely. The Neua Naam Tok was amazing. Steak salad. Salad is a loose term and means anything mixed in Thai cooking. No lettuce here. Spicy is misleading. It's hot, but it's so flavorful. Sweat glands, engaged. The complimentary sticky rice comes in handy with this dish. A must.

Here's where I get confused. We sat, ordered, beered up, ate, and paid in probably 40 minutes. Pretty quick turnover. For us to wait as long as we did, that means an army came through while we had beers down the street.

Be advised, long wait, unique experience, great food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: All of our dishes were excellent - they are definitely not your typical Thai restaurant  fare so that could be off-putting to some people.  Would go back to try totally different dishes.  Can get really busy during certain times so be ready for a wait or go during the week day.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I've been here two times - the first time, I was a bit disappointed but I thought it might have been the consequence of too-high expectations. I went to Pok Pok a second time last weekend. It was the end of Snowpocalypse 2016 and it was about 30 degrees outside and they sat us outside. There was a heater above our table, but we still had to wear our down jackets and everyone had very cold legs. 

We got papaya salad, boar collar, chicken wings, catfish, curry noodles, sticky rice and steamed rice. The papaya salad was good. The boar was disappointingly small for $15.50 and it was covered in cilantro - which was too bad because the people who wanted to eat it both dislike cilantro and the menu didn't mention it had cilantro.

The wings seem to be popular with people who like salty foods, but if you're sensitive to salt they may not be for you. I liked the vegetarian curry noodles, but, I wouldn't say they were anything to write home about. 

The thing I liked most about pok pok was the level of spice. I like very spicy food and Pok Pok doesn't disappoint. If I could purchase their dried peppers alone, I would.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Total ripoff! Every "entree" is $15 or more and each entree is about maybe the size of a typical appetizer at most restaurants. This place has to be thriving/surviving on hype alone. They are known for their amazing wings which cost $16 for six wings. This in itself is a total pricing "eff you" to any customer that dines with Pok Pok. Just let that sink in a little bit... $16 FOR SIX WINGS! absolute joke. My group and I were starving after our meal. All the portions were tiny and over priced. It's also an extra $4 if you want rice with your entree. $4 FOR A SIDE OF RICE!!! Also... the taste of the food was average at best. Honestly nothing special. The greed of the owners of this restaurant will eventually come back to haunt them. Good Thai food is not hard to find so please save your money and go ANYWHERE else. You can thank me later.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Yup, you're friends are right.  You should go here.  They are also right about the wings.  Amazing!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Authentic and delicious. Period. Thai food with a twist (real and homemade, not typical take out Thai). Definitely order the wings and load up on spicy sauces, which are super flavorful. And expect a long line for sit down (or you can order take out). We thought you ordered at the counter and sit wherever, but there was actually a 90 minute wait. The only cons included a somewhat unhelpful staff and expensive menu for small portions - but overall great!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: 3.5 rounded down by a 90 minute wait. My family and I came here for dinner. Perusing a menu full of dishes I had never seen before got me excited. The glass noodles that I ordered were big-time spicy, with sausage and a sour sauce. I really really didn't like the dried shrimp littered through my food; they were tough to chew, ruining the texture of the dish, and their flavor was too strong. My brother had the fish sauce wings, which were big, meaty, spicy, and sweet. Pretty similar to normal chicken wings but with some added depth of flavor from the fish sauce. My mom's curry noodles tasted like a weird dessert, too sweet and full of pieces of pineapple. My favorite dish was definitely my dad's noodles in a clay pot with shrimp and pork belly, but I only got a little taste. Portions weren't exactly small, but we weren't stuffed and there weren't any leftovers. Prices ran at about $15 per entree. I would go again if it weren't for the long wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We ordered a bunch of items even though there were only two of us. Everything was soooooooooo good. My family is from SE Asia, and the dishes here are so flavorful. The wings are delicious! I love the sticky rice - it's the way my mom makes it. I am going back the next time I go to Portland. The only thing I'd complain about is the long wait...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: way overrated, in my experience. It is  a hip place to go,  and if you like spicy you ll love it, but does not accommodate  anything else, long lines,  super noisy and  tight spaces.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: They have a lot of interesting dishes that I think it's worth to try. I like their roasted duck, wings, Kai yaang, and some other dishes that I can't remember the name. I would definitely go to this restaurant again and try the rest of the dishes.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: If I had to eat one thing before I died running across the street with out looking, I'd take the fish sauce wings with me. It'd be one of the last tastes my body would agree with before I see more of them in my next life.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Ordered chicken wings and "khao soi" (curry noodle with chicken, beef, or veggie).  Sour, crispy, sweet, spicy.  Chicken wings come in spicy or nonspicy, but we ordered nonspicy.  I'm tempted to order spicy to-go.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Finally, we made it to Pok Pok. After seeing it on DDD, I couldn't wait to try the Vietnamese fish sauce wings. They definitely live up to the hype - very flavorful and juicy wings with hints of sweet & savory - although not my favorite chicken wings (Sab-ee-lee, San Diego, CA).  We also tried the special of the day - whole tilapia which had a very tangy and delicious sauce over it - cooked to perfection.  We also had the pork belly and papaya salad - nothing special.  The prices were a little bit more than I would expect for a Thai restaurant but we like it enough to come back for more.  

Although if I ever have a craving for their chicken wings and Pok Pok is packed, I may try them at their sister restaurant across the street at "Whiskey Soda Lounge".  That is the only dish that they have in common between the two restaurants.  

Make reservations. This restaurant is always packed and only takes reservations for parties of 5 or more.

Good job, Guy! Another great find!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We had dinner there this evening while in town for a conference. My colleague's son recommended it. We had Thai food the evening before at a local spot near our hotel, but are always up for good Thai, so thought we'd have another go. Pok Pok was very different than more traditional Thai restaurants. We ordered a number of different dishes (including the sticky wings) and none of them disappointed. The flavors were unique and the sticky rice rounded out the portions nicely. We ended the meal with the coconut ice cream sandwich and the whisky ice cream soda which were both unique.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Go for the Fish Sauce wings... stay for the smells and noises that come from the kitchen.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
There is not too much left to be said food wise- it was all very good. We actually had a friend working here so we let her order for our table of 6 and I'm glad we did because honestly the menu was too overwhelming to keep things straight- I'm too much of a Thai novice (I love it all, but I'll never remember what it was called).

So for me, minus 1 star for the menu and insane wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Four of us went on a Sunday late afternoon. The place was pretty full,so we had to wait for around 15 minutes; and it was worth the wait
We liked the Khao Man Som Tam best; Fish Sauce Wings and Kung Op Wun Sen (especially the Prawns dipped in the sauce they gave) tied second; the Pork Ribs was just about OK.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok is the reason I moved to Portland from San Diego.  The Whiskey Soda is also very good, fun atmosphere and the food is just the same as Pok Pok across the street, amazing.  Just be prepared for spicy food when ordering the appetizers, I love the heat, but my Mom and Aunt had a hard time with it.  The portion sizes are perfect for sharing if you order a couple for the middle of the table, or for just one person.  The drink selection is totally awesome, a lot of fun to try new things.  My fave is the Salty Plum Collins.  The servers are great and knowledgeable, and always eager to explain some of the ingredients.  I almost lost my mind when they opened Pok Pok Noi in my hood, now I only have to drive 2 miles to enjoy those wings!!!!

Update:  I just got home from spending a whole month in Thailand and this food is exactly what you get at the street consessions.  They nailed it!  So good!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I heart Pok Pok's chicken wings.  They have that perfect balance of spicy, salty, and sweet.  They are the reason I gave the 5-star rating.

Actually, I have thoroughly enjoyed everything I have ordered the two times I have been.  Some things are better than others, specifically the spicy beef salad, mango salad, coconut curry soup. But, all-in-all I really like this place.  I think the price matches the quality of food, the servers are helpful and quick, and the drinks are delish.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Being asian I didn't really find the food that special. It's a nice change from the "fancy" city Thai food and the dishes are more like country/common house hold dishes. It was made well but I guess I just wasn't impress because my Mom could have made this. And I found the house special wings a bit overdone. My brother makes it better.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Meh. I prefer Luc Lac by a wide mile. I enjoyed their wings (very salty, but still good), but the other dishes we got (an eggplant salad and the "flagship" dish) were so boring I was glad we had eaten Salt & Straw while we waited for our table. The chicken was dry, basically unseasoned. We got half a bird and at first I'd said we may need more, but we ultimately left about half of that half uneaten. The eggplant salad was cooked in the worst possible way: slimy and soggy eggplant with no integrity when you speared it on your fork. I put mine back on the serving dish.

All in all, I probably won't go back. This was definitely not worth the hour wait and $60 tab.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Started off with Ike's Vietnamese fish sauce wings with the red pepper flakes on the side to share with those who like mild/spicy. The glazed sauce itself is not spicy. Wings were very flavorful and infused nicely with the fish sauce but didn't have that "stinky nuoc mam" smell. The beef salad paired well with a side of rice (I would recommend 1 side of rice -coconut jasmine rice was our personal favorite - for two people instead of 2 because there was a lot of food). The Khai Soi Kai-curry noodles tasted like a combo of the Vietnamese dish Mi Quang and thai yellow curry. Good fusion take of Viet and Thai!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: First time in Portland and a friend suggested it to me. Sat at the bar and snacked on some spicy peanuts. The bartender presented me my drink which was the Tumeric whiskey sour and from the first sip I knew my experience was to be epic. I ordered the spicy catfish and it's impossible to rate food that good the sweet mixed with spicy, mixed with the marriage of catfish and....you can't rate food that good and for good reasons because you have to just eat there to appreciate and take it all in.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Chicken wings were great, but $15 for 6 wings is on the pricey end for this type of venue (dingey, semi-outside, dubious if it would pass inspection). I'd actually rather get them to go. 

Curry was alright. Standard thin thai style curry with some fried dough topping to try and spruce it up. Not worth a second shot. Originally ordered their special catfish dish, but they sold out :(

Service was fast, friendly and knowledgable on the dishes.

Come here to order their top dishes. Skip the rest since the price premium spans the entire menu.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Spicy wings, Bore Collar, sticky rice, DONE!   Very good.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm so torn on writing this review. Pok Pok comes highly recommended from not only Yelp, but Trip Adviser, and even a few close friends......but I don't understand why?!

Pros - 
Waiters were very friendly and helpful with the menu
We were able to make reservations and got seats right away 
Thai Wings are awesome 

Cons - 
The place smells like mold 
If you make reservations you get stuck upstairs and miss the ambiance of the place 
Other than the wings the food and drinks were just okay at most....
EXPENSIVE!! For 6 people, each getting 1 drink and 1 dish (we all shared) was around $410 

I'm all for trying new places and giving credit where credit is due, but this place just didn't hit the mark for me.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Whaaaaaaaat?! The good reviews of this place misled me. Very expensive mistake on my part. To be fair, I did order many different items on the menu. I am pretty indecisive, and like to try a little bit of everything. But even had I not ordered so much, the bill would have been too pricy. The food was bland. The service was good. The water tasted off. The wings don't even come close to touching some of the wings I've had at other Asian restaurants in town. Sad to say this is a no-go. I wanted so badly to like it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place was pretty unique among the Thai restaurants I have eaten at. From what I could tell from the menu and what I ordered the place stays far from your Americanized Asian food which many Thai restaurants tend to veer towards.

We sat out on a tented, heated patio that was fairly comfortable. The place was busy so we were happy to get what we could.

We got a few things among which most notably was Ike's Wings, I mean with the name similarity how could I not? Plus it was highly recommended by the server for good reason. The wings were big (think two to three American wings to one Ike's wing). The spices and flavoring were delicious and not spicy which was much appreciated by some of the milder palettes of our group. People as far south as Corvallis (an hour away) asked our group if we ate the wings at Pok Pok so they make an impression.

There seemed to be quite a few vegetarian options on the menu. The menu is pretty extensive so it seems that a diverse group should be able to find something to satisfy most (but not a hamburger so don't expect to order from a kids menu for more domestic tastes).
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I don't care how many people say this place is good. I will never, ever try to eat at  this joint shack calling its self a restaurant.   The attitude hereby the host is up the kazoo. The young woman host treats you like she is doing you a favor when you sign in and in front of costumers she talks to the rest of the staff around her about how there is no need to rush seating customer waiting that they will wait the 1 1/2 hour quoted when you sign in. Because if you happen to be a party of less than 6  you can't make a reservation . After waiting 1 1/2 hours we left to the Fantastic Indian restaurant down the street. 
I was so mad I threw and hour and a half waiting thinking I had already spent time waiting so maybe I would be next when there were so many empty seats available for two.  POK POK =SUCK SUCK!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Of course, we had to make a stop at Pok Pok after seeing all these posts about it and whatnot. We walked over here one morning for brunch, and luckily, we were seated right away. After consulting some of my friend's yelps, we decided to go with the boar collar, the curry noodles, and the cha yen. 

The boar collar was SUPER flavorful and VERY spicy (I believe it's a garlic, pepper, lime juice concoction on top). As soon as you bite into it, a rush of flavor smashes into your mouth (first the lime, then the spiciness and other flavors). I knew that my boyfriend would LOVE this dish (because it's spicy), and needless to say, he did! Very small portions though, so beware.

Boy oh boy am I glad we paired it with the curry noodles. It was light, full of coconut milk (as the base probably), and it definitely took the heat off of the boar collar. There was a good amount of chicken, but a small amount of the thick, flat egg noodles. Overall, it was good, but for some reason, I kept on having a bitter aftertaste. This was served with a plate of chili, pickled vegetables, etc. 

The Thai tea with evaporated milk (cha yen) came in a bottle, which was interesting to me. It tasted decent, but it was almost $5, so I am not sure if it was worth it.

All in all, this place is good to try, but keep in mind that it is very pricey for what you end up getting. The waitress recommended at least 3 plates to share between two people, but we wanted to save room for other stuff around the city too. We ended up leaving pretty hungry even after forking over $40 for a meal. :(
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I'm usually a little leary of the places Guy F features on his show but this place was great. We had to wait for about an hour even at 9 pm on a Thursday. You can go across to the bar next door and wait for their text. Really flavorful dishes. Don't miss it. Staff is really knowledgeable of the many dishes they offer. Would absolutely go back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
It's great food, and I'd return, but it's not perfect.

First, it's so dang popular so you are going to work to get a seat. James Beard awards and countless write-ups will do that to a place.

Second, it ain't cheap. 

While many of the dishes are considered "street food", or inspired by street food, the prices aren't street.

Those famous fish sauce wings?  $15.50 for 6 of them.

Green papaya salad? $10.

Lastly, and this goes with the first critique, it's crowded and tight. Not alot of elbow room if you were planning on peeling those shrimp or two-handing those chicken wings. It can be pretty cramped.

Final note - it's good food, very flavorful and tastes authentic Thai. (Yes, I visited many years ago).

But I'm glad I finally tried it.

4 stars and yes, I would return. I just would aim for a quiet, less busy night... if it exists.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Amazing food.  Great service.  Creative drinks.  I love this place!  Go - you won't regret it...as long as you don't mind waiting in long lines at the door to get in :)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The food and experience was different. I learned about Thai food. The food was pretty interesting and tasty but I don't understand what the big commotion about the wings. The wings were a bit to salty in my point of view. The reason I gave it four stars is because this place has the structure of a house which is an inconvenience because of how long people have to wait to be seated. I waited about 2 hours. They need to make the structure larger and add more tables.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Worth a visit for sure, a must go for natives and tourists alike!! The wings are world famous so you have to try them. 

Pro Tip: Natives, after you've tried the original, start visiting the other locations. Less wait, same foods! Wiskey Soda is a great place to start, they Wings are front and center on the menu!! Try the South Side, you'll want two!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This rating is based on take out a few nights ago. Got wings, ribs and papaya salad. Can't believe all the hype. Wings were so so -- I have made better at home. Ribs were laughably tiny and the salad was barely palatable. Small portions for the price. Even the rice was gummy. Sorry to have to be so negative, but it is hard to believe this place is so popular based on our limited experience.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: It was a bit of a wait but worth it. Understandable for a Friday night. We waited about 1 hr but there is a nice beer spot down the street that we grabbed drinks from. We ordered the chicken wings as they are known for them. It wasn't the best wings I've ever had but they are awesome.  The pork belly however was amazing. I would come back again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is packed and rightfully so! The food is out of this world. Wonderful flavors. If your looking for a place to get a unique flavors and have creative dishes look no further.  If you live in Oregon this place is a must try!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I came here while on a road trip with my boyfriend and was recommended this place to try their famous wings. I waited an hour in the rain to try literally the saltiest wings I've ever had. The flavor would have been good if it hadn't been masked by all the salt. It was so salty that my tongue was in pain. It was so salty that it made the ocean jealous. It was saltier than my tears of disappointment that rolled down my fat rosy cheeks. In all seriousness, I had to wipe the wings with my napkin in order to make it tolerable. I don't regret trying them, but wouldn't recommend them to anyone else.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We really love the spicy wings! Pairs well with the whiskey sour. Then finish your hunger off with the crab. The Pomegranate Caiparina was also a table favorite
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Dang it!  I was hoping that this place wasn't worth the wait.

But it was. 

I felt like I was transported to Asia, instead of feeling like I was going to an American-styled Asian restaurant.  Wish they were located downtown, but loved every second.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Amazing food! I had the chicken wings and they were fantastic! Recommended at anyone in the Portland area. Also was told the wait would be 2 hours and it was only about an hour and 15. Also way worth any wait time!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: There wings are good, the service Sucks!!! First I ordered the ribs that was acchually a shitty soup. Then they give us a container that's lid didn't fit and had us put the soup in the container the soup was to hot the container caved in next thing I know this shitty soup is all over my pants. Bullshit!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Do it. 

Come early. Get the wings. Drink the lemonade. Repeat. 

We came early on Sunday night for dinner, and were seated right away. 

I stupidly ordered the papaya salad as spicy... and through snot and tears still tried to eat as much as I could. It was so delicious. 

The brussels sprouts were surprisingly good as well, so if you are in a vegetable tasting mood, definitely get that to accompany your meal. 

A few of us also sampled the drinking vinegars which were weird but oddly good. I recommend the Lychee and the cocktail (I forget the name) made with the Clementine Drinking Vinegar. This was like a glorified mimosa with a KICK.. pretty good. 

I love the vibe... I am all about the atmosphere most places, and this one knocked it out of the park. We sat outside, and I felt like I could be anywhere but Portland... well.. ok mostly in Thailand somewhere... so well done. 

Come early, come hungry, order the wings and other side dishes, leave happy! (If you're not happy after this meal I don't know how to help you).
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The best table order perfected by dozens of visits: Fish sauce wings, spicy boar collar (don't be a wuss. Eat it with your fingers with rice as your spoon. You'll be obsessed, don't worry), som tam (papaya salad), any whole roasted/fried fish on the menu  that day (you seriously will love it. Don't be a wuss), sticky rice, Chang beer.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Fish sauce wings were yummy and I had the sai ua for my entree. While they were both good and were fantastic with my sticky rice (definitely was not enough rice), it left me feeling hungry for my mom's cooking. It could possibly be just the difference of my mom being from northern Laos as this is a northern Thailand restaurant. Give it a go!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great food and awesome service! The wait took a good 90 minutes, but it's easy to see why people go nuts for this place. The wings are amazing - probably my favorite dish.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We had the wings everyone raves about.  The server asked if we wanted them mild or spicy, we chose mild, but got zero spice and they were cold.  Are they supposed to be cold?  We were disappointed.  Also got the curried chicken soup, it too was cold and a little too sweet for my taste with lots of luke warm noodles floating around in it topped with stale crunchy noodles - it wasn't a good choice.  The claypot prawns with glass noodles was ok, I hated peeling the shrimp, it wasn't easy to get off either, just peel it will ya?  The noodles were really salty.  We usually enjoy the bloody mary's but they were watery and blah.  Our guests and I didn't enjoy anything that evening, it must have been an off afternoon, ate around 4pm (no wait) - between shifts?  What made it worse was that we had raved about the place to the two guests we took there - they were baffled over the fuss made about Pok Pok.  For the price, you would expect much more in the way of quality, service and attention to detail.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok Review Monday June 26th 2012

All I can say is that is that we've been wanting to try this restaurant for a long time! My wife had heard that the fish sauce chicken wings were the best in town! I must confess that I was a bit reluctant as I was craving italian and feared the options may be limited as I am of the veggie persuasion and i love options!
Suffice to say, we were very pleased with our meal!!!
I ordered the whiskey flights with the sodas, and boy was I surprised to see how strong they were! They were all local whiskeys and they EVEN had a clear one that tasted like tequila!!1
My wife wasn't drinking so I more than made up for the two of us!
The fresh papaya salad was scrumptious, and the forested mushrooms delectable!
My wife order the steak salad and boy was it spicy! but she absolutely loved it.
she had been craving red meat and it really hit the spot. tender, moist and cooked to perfection.
we split a vegetarian Cow Soi which is a thai noodle soup which was recommended to us by an avid traveler of the Orient who definitely knows what she is talking about.

As for the service our waitress was very knowledgeable and friendly a true professional. Even the bussers were courteous and attentive complimenting me on my choice of Thai affigado. I especially liked the remarks as it was a tough decision between that and the thai ice cream sandwich. Our waitress  described the ice cream sandwich as authentic street food AND adventurous which alarmed us. I am so glad that we went with the affigado it was the perfect end to a ABSOLUTELY perfect meal. the sweetened condensed ice cream was luxurious.

I would also like to add that there was only a five minute wait to be seated as I have heard horror stories about long waits to and my husband is very impatient!

I highly recommend this restaurant if you are looking for a Thai meal.
I myself will be returning to try the famous chicken wings and am so pleased my veggie husband will be returning with me as he was thrilled with the veggie options!!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Man if Pok Pok can hold a 4 star rating for Thai food, Portlanders would give ALL the San Diego Thai places at least 10 stars, guaranteed. 

We were so incredibly excited to try this place but, honestly couldn't be more let down. I mean, 1000+ ratings? 4 stars? It had to be awesome right? Nope. Not awesome. Not terrible, either. But, certainly not memorable.

We had the Papaya Salad which, was so so bland..in fact, all their dishes (aside from the Fish Sauce Wings) were desperately lacking salt which, is rare for me to say because my palate often times favor the less salty. It was fresh and a nice balance after half those wings but, mediocre despite the fact that it is apparently one of their best dishes.

Next up, Khao Soi with Chicken. I liked this dish. It was interesting with ample amounts of chicken (dark meat) and the noodles tasted home-made, it was thin and delicate and the crispy noodles on top added a nice crunch. The curry could have used some work though. It had good flavor but, just like the Papaya Salad, it was bland.

I would say, the one dish worth getting is the Fish Sauce Wings though. We had an order of it while waiting for our table at the Whiskey Bar (Also, run my Pok Pok so, they had some of their dishes AND your server at Whiskey Bar will also let you know when your table is ready at Pok Pok since they are partner restaurants which, is pretty smart). For about $12, we got a hefty portion of wings that were delicious! Great dish to start with.

Overall, Pok Pok wasn't awful..but, it wasn't great either. Unfortunately, it did not satisfy my Thai craving but, being as it may be one of the few Thai places in Portland, I guess it'll do. Nice service and cool interior though.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Let me save you the suspense and just say that the hype surrounding the fish sauce wings is justified! I knew I had to try Pok Pok after my aunt said it was worth waiting an hour for. Let me give you some background, my aunt doesn't wait for anything! Her favorite restaurant could have a 10 minute wait and she would go elsewhere. She always says, "I don't live in communist Russia, I shouldn't have to wait for my food". So when she said that Pok Pok was worth the wait, I planned my trip across Portland immediately. My dad and I came on a Wednesday afternoon. I figured there wouldn't be a wait considering what a strange time it was, but I guess no wait at Pok Pok is unheard of! After about 20 minutes of waiting in the rain we were seated inside. (I'm not exactly sure how the seating works. We sat indoors at a table by the bar but there appeared to be outdoor tents that people were sitting in as well?) I ordered the Vietnamese fish sauce wings as promised and a side of sticky rice. My dad ordered the Kai Yaang which was half of a game hen stuffed with various Thai ingredients. To my surprise, our food came very quickly! But to my dismay, the $3 side of sticky rice was smaller than my palm... I couldn't believe how much they charge for 3 measly bites of rice! But once I bit into the first wing, none of that mattered.. I was in love! The balance of sweet and spicy, the crunchy skin -- they were perfect! I ate every last bite and didn't even mind that my hair and face were completely covered in sauce. My dad agreed that the wings were a true gem. He was less impressed with his dish however. He said it was pretty boring and under seasoned so I recommend to stick with the wings! I would come back often if I didn't have to pay an arm and a leg for some wings and a side of sticky rice!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok is probably the most famous place when you talk about food in Portland and we were eager to sample the Thai inspired cuisine that has so many positive reviews.  What we weren't looking forward to was the waiting times (up to an hour at dinner) and the drive to an area that was nowhere nearby where we were staying.  Although they have two Pok Pok locations, neither is conveniently located near downtown, and their airport location appears to have been short lived.

Enter Amazon Prime.  I'm an avid Amazon Prime user and their Prime Now service had launched and was promoting fresh produce and groceries but also restaurants in certain areas.  Nowhere really interested me in the Bay Area but I noticed Amazon Prime Now delivered from Pok Pok (as well as DoorDash and Caviar).  They were even offering a $10 promotion as I was new to their service.

I chose a busy weekday night (Friday) so I wouldn't have to miss the Warriors NBA Finals game.  Sure enough, I entered my order and within about 45 minutes (the drive alone is 15 minutes), my order was at my doorstep as the game started.  Score!  Our order:

Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings - a hearty portion of very large chicken wings arrived still hot and tasty.  The fish sauce is mild flavored and the sauce is sticky, but delicious.  I liked that the wings were meaty and had plenty of tender and well flavored dark meat.  It was served with a side of pickled vegetables and lettuce leaves.  Very good, though I'd give the nod to San Tung chicken wings in SF being more addicting.

Kai Yang - the rotisserie chicken was a whole chicken/hen order nicely separated and cut out.  It was moist, warm, and juicy, especially the dark meat.  Skin was flavorful and delicious.  Some pieces of the white meat were a bit dry, but helped tremendously by the two sauce containers included, one a spicy sweet and sour and the other a green tamarind sauce.

Overall, we couldn't have been more thrilled to try Pok Pok.  Both dishes were filling and hearty and as good as I would have expected.  The drinking vinegars were more novel than anything.  I suspect the food would have been even better at the restaurant and with even more dishes, but this was a great taste of Pok Pok and it couldn't have paired better with a Warriors Game 4 win.  

Pok Pok accepts credit cards, including Amex.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Because of all the great reviews and tye no wait in the Sunday afternoon, we decided to give this place a try.  It's good! No strong flavor with fresh ingredients--really reminded me of the authentic food I had during my Southeast Asia trip. The food at Pok Pok is kind of blend--it's really more Vietnam-Cambodian. Perhaps It's more Northern Thailand?

So why 3 stars? Well, the portion of the dishes are small. It's good to be small as the standard American-size dish probably contributed to the obesity epidemic. However, small portion should come with much cheaper price. We ordered chicken wings with fish sauce, coconut chicken noodle and coconut ice cream sandwich. It came out to be $36.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is super good!!!! When I have visitors from out of town, I always take them here.The Vietnamese chicken wings are my favorite. The dishes are good portions for family style. The wait is really long on weekends. Long as in 2 plus hours. Maybe try going earlier,the wait isn't as long.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: What's the big deal about this place? They have some decent wings and an interesting drink menu, but the price tag is ridiculous, and the atmosphere just isn't that good. Not worth the usual wait one must go through. So they're popular & they're in New York City now... So what.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Nothing could prevent me from enjoying some of the finest Thai cuisine, not even the cold glare from my boyfriend sitting across from me. As I slurped on my vermicelli noodles I pondered, why settle for mediocrity?

Don't. Come to Pok Pok, ditch the deadweight.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I enjoyed Pok Pok.  This iconic restaurant is rightfully known for serving up authentic Thai and SE Asian food.  You won't find any Pad Thai or chicken satay here.  In fact, unless you are Thai, you probably won't find anything here that you've had before.  The menu is long - however, the number of items is actually not that long, but the descriptions are very long.  How to make roast chicken sound sexy and justify a $14 price for a half-bird? - call it Kai Yaang and list all the things that go into the Pok Pok (a Thai mortar and pestle) in 37 words.  Yikes!  That being said, the roast chicken was tasty.

Kaeng Hang Leg, pork belly and shoulder in curry sauce was tasty but the portion was super small.  Muu Papa Kham Waan, or grilled boar collar wrapped in mustard green, was also a tiny portion, and overly salted.  Cha ca "La Vong," by the way, not a MMA fighter's name, is marinated catfish fried in tumeric oil.  Tasty but truly a flyweight portion size.

The Papaya Pok Pok, a spicy green papaya salad, is very spicy and also quite tasty in a masochistic sort of way.  Northern Thai curry noodles, Khao Soi, is pretty good too, and appreciably mild.  The chicken wings, a specialty of the house, called Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings, are fried and coated with caramelized fish sauce; they're sticky and funky, a little spicy, but were a bit dry and could have been meatier.

The beverage program is distinctive.  They are known for having great beverages, alcoholic and non-alcoholic, including drinking vinegars and locally brewed Thai ice teas.

To sum up, tasty authentic SE Asian food, at premium, non-SE Asian prices.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Saw this restaurant profiled on national food program.  Happened to be near this location and made special trip to stop.  OMG!  Glad I did.  The chicken wings were Delicious!  Like none I've ever had.  I am a hard person to please so giving praise, is well earned.  Went on a fall mid day Tuesday and was no waiting.  Been ages since I've licked my fingers during and after a meal.  Yum Yum to Pok Pok.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: long wait 1-2 hours on prime time, OK food
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Hate being so trite - but the wings...wow, must be top 5 things i've ever put in my mouth.  And I eat a lot :P  

The duck salad was ridiculously spicy, but delicious.  Less salad, more shredded duck.

Boar collar was good, definitely...but not mind blowing.  A little dry, actually.  

We had a fancy vegetable ... a fern something or another.  Delicious.  

You can order most food across the street at the whiskey bar so that could cut down on the wait time.  Also, their salted plum vodka collins was delicious...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
ok, this place was supremely hyped up from friends, and i feel like i was expecting the world when dining here, this place did not live up to its hype.  honestly, this place is 3 stars at best.

we were able to reserve a bench at the top of pok pok for 20 bucks a person pre deposit.  
almost everything here is family style, i went with 10ish people and got 8 dishes to share around.  the best items were the Khao Soi and the coconut rice.  the khao soi is a a coconut curry noodle dish with chicken, and the coconut rice had hints of coconut flavors in it.  
if you mix the two, its an even better combo.

but yeah, saying the best items at this place is coconut rice tells you a lot.

i was excited to come here, because i assumed they would have pad thai (and i judge a thai place by its pad thai), but this place is more northern thailand, so they serve items that you would normally find on the streets of thailand.  very authentic, but not very good.  not to mention, the price you pay for the dishes are not worth your money. 

i mean, it was cool i got to try this place, but i will not return!
i'm glad we were able to make reservations, if we had to wait for our foods, i'd rate it 2 stars.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I had high expectations for this place because I heard locals and visitors rave about Pok Pok. I ordered their fish sauce chili wings for which they are known for and got myself a mango cocktail. I'm extra judgey on their wings because I myself am Vietnamese American and I've tasted a fair amount of fish sauce wings.

My first impression of the wings was that it was not too spicy which was fine with me, the server said it would be less than Siracha level spicy. The wings weren't as crispy as I would have liked, more on the soft side which is ok too, some people like that. However the deal breaker for me was the taste of the wings - it was too salty. Fish sauce is hard to cook with and if not balanced correctly, it can overwhelming be incredibly salty which it was. What's also weird would I get some chili bites in between so the sauce didn't seem evenly distributed. I finished the water pitcher they gave me by myself and downed my alcohol drinks. The only reason why this review gets an extra star is that the bartender who helped me was very attentive, making sure I had a pleasant dining experience, and made sure I enjoyed the drinks he made. Despite quality service, I was so disappointed in the wings and am shocked it is their best and most popular item on the menu. I'm not sure if what I received was a fluke or it's how the wings usually taste
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I could sit here and write me 3 pages about this place. but its not necessary.
the food and service speak for itself.
this needs to be on your must do list when you come to Portland Oregon.
nothing else will speak better than I have to eat here and say omg.
this food is prepared with an entity, that we should be prepared and that is great.
there's no confluence here.
this food has not been stylized around to an American taste. this should be for all ethnic restaurants.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese

text: way way way overhyped. Good Thai food, but definitely wasn't worth a long wait and squeezing it into a really tight weekend trip to Portland. I liked the glass noodles and the pork belly stew the best. Everything else we got (chicken wings, bbq chicken, steak salad, papaya salad) was pretty good but not outrageous. If you're visiting from socal save some time and just go to the LA location.

text: INSANELY DELICIOUS. Though, when they first opened, I would have given it a 5 star rating. They have lost a teeeeeny bit of deliciousness and service, but try their vinegar drinks! YUMMY!!! Also, expect a huge ass line all. the. time.

text: My wife and I decided to try Pok Pok after all the hype from Diners Drive Inns and Dives, and all the positive Yelp reviews.  We attempted to eat lunch on  a Friday afternoon, which wasn't busy at all, and were seated immediately.  There was water on the table already in a pitcher.  The water tasted nutty, like there had been some sort of coconut drink in the pitcher prior to the water and it wasn't washed thoroughly.  After sitting there for 10 minutes with no one saying a word to us, we got up and left.  All this hype and they can't even handle a non busy Friday lunch.  Lame.  Let all the drones of PDX deal with shitty service, I will not.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Arrived around peak dinner time on a Sunday, there was a wait time of 30-45 minutes, so while waiting we walked across the street for some Salt & Straw ice cream. 

We were skeptical on coming here in the first place, giving that we're from LA and SD, cities with endless options of authentic Vietnamese and Thai food, but with its stellar reviews on Yelp and the recommendation of a local friend, we were excited to give it a try. 

However, it's a huge let down. 

Fish sauce wings - The wings are big and crispy. The first few bite was good, but then it became way too salty. Probably goes well with rice and beer.

Khao soi kai - chicken curry noodle soup. Bland. 

Boar collar - this dish is actually pretty good but nothing over the top and very small portion. The waiter brought us a plate of raw greens covered with ice to go with this dish, just in case the meat is too spicy. We think it was mild at most medium spicy. 

Sticky rice - good, chewy like how sticky rice should be. CAUTION HOT!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The eating area is cute, they have dining outside n inside. They have a to-go window too. The food was a little pricey for the small portions that you get. The flavors weren't that great, have had Thai food all over California and there is really nothing too special about this place. We came here from Cali because of all the hype it had but I wished it was better in flavor or something special about it. People that worked there were really nice. We had to try it out because it was on triple D!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Omg I loved the food. Portions are a bit small but it was still good. Their famous chicken wing dish was a little to salty but it was still good. I had the thai papaya salad and I liked it beacuse it wasn't overwhelming with that dark brown seasoning so it was nice to eat it this way. Their beef salad was probably my favorite thing there.. I wanna go back
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm not from Portland and actually live in a place where Asian food is more common than anything else... so I can't say that this is the best Thai food ever, but it is pretty damn good. Stopped by here on a road trip from Seattle to LA, and I'd say it was a pretty good decision.

Had the fish sauce chicken wings, and I ordered them spicy but of course it was nowhere near the level of spicy I expected. But it was delicious! The texture of the chicken wings was probably the best part. It was crunchy, juicy, and tender. The sticky sauce caramelized the wings and flavored them nicely. I also ordered the curry noodle soup, which was also amazing. I don't think I've ever had this in any Thai restaurant, so it was a new experience. The noodles were soft and had the perfect texture, swimming in a pool of tasty curry soup. YUM.

Also ordered something else here, but wasn't memorable. Overall... delicious.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I lived in Thailand for 10 years - from 1989 to 1999. My wife is from Northern Thailand, and I've probably eaten at every little restaurant in the city of Chiangmai as well as a ton of great restaurants in Bangkok. I speak both Northern and Central Thai. I guess what I am trying to say is I know what Thai and especially Northern Thai food should taste like. 

I have eaten in Thai restaurants all across America - from New York, to Atlanta to LA - and am always disappointed, that is until I ate at Pok Pok. It was without doubt the best Thai food I've ever eaten in the States and as good as any in Thailand.  When I tasted each dish - I had everything on the menu over 2 days - I was transported back to Chiangmai. For those of you posting here that the food is too hot or salty or not authentic, you have absolutely no idea what you're talking about. Without doubt Pok Pok is the best Thai restaurant in the country and I only wish Andy Ricker would open up one on the east coast.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Wow, OMG, flavors explode in my mouth! Yum! I am originally from South East Asia, and I know my food. Atmosphere is good, waiter is very knowledgable. At first when you walk in there, it!'s small and cozy, play traditional thai music, but everyone there is non-Asian. The menu is something you can't find in the regular Thai restaurant. So I gave it a big plus. Food is not too spicy, but they do give you a side of your own chili to add if you need more spice. Flavor is fantastic!!! Love it, will always come here whenever I come back to Portland.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Couldn't tell you if this place was delicious or not, because the wait for two people, even at 8:30pm on a Sunday night, was 90-120 minute wait. Even the hostess who took my name/phone number down and gave me my estimated wait time looked put off and inattentive.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This is one of our top three restaurants in Portland. The wings are the best we have ever had, ever. The boar collar and khao soi are beyond delicious. The huge drawback here is the wait. We just order to pick up to avoid the line and enjoy this deliciousness in the comfort of our home.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
first time visitng Portland, Oregon. me and my group headed to Pok Pok cause my sis came here last year and she said it was really really good even they weren't thai cooking for you. also the ambiance were really nice like going back to Thailand.

when i first saw Pok Pok, i really loved the ambiance. yes, it's like my sis said. every parts of this place really reminded me of eating in an old style rest. in Thailand(but much much cleaner) with Thai and Laos old styles music.  

and what about the food? well, they all were just o.k. to me. 
start with.....

Kai Yaang (Thai style grilled chicken) - chicken was tender but was so so. you should eat this with spicy sauce or sweet sauce.

Muu(Pork) Satay - i'm glad that they had Muu Satay like in Thailand. wonder why they have chicken satay instead of pork in most of Thai rest here in US. one word, too much coconut milk.

Som Tum(Papaya salad) - i don't like it. only sour. no sweet, no salty, no spicy. and Khao Man(Coconut rice) - so so.

Khao Soi Chicken(Northern style egg noodle with curry soup) - chicken was tender and curry was good. well seasoning.

Shrimp chips - this is what i liked the most fr. Pok Pok. really can't stop eating this. crunchy and tasty.

Sadly that we couldn't wait til 5 for dinner so they had just to go order that had not too many dishes too try.

ohh... also overpriced and undersized... 

service, there's a street fair that saturday so they only had to go order before 5. however, they let everyone eat at the outside which was nice and were helpful.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Usually don't leave reviews for over-reviewed joints, but finally authentic Thai taste!  Ridiculously expensive basically for fast food.  But best meal I had had in a long time, even eating out daily.  Insanely good food but WARNING--don't eat here if you can't hack authentic level of red chilis.

Having stayed in Chiang Mai for six months during college and having had perhaps 100 bad (sweet, peanut, wrong ingreds, wrong soups, shwag noodles) Thai meals here over the past 20 years, I'd given up on authentic taste.  I test Thai restaurants by ordering their beef salad and somtom, also appreciate sticky rice if avail.

Way too trendy and hipster and urban pirate and foofey foofey gourmet bs, but the taste is simply there.  Either food is good or it's not and my dinner here was great.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We loved the food and service was good here! We avoided the long wait by sitting at the bar but worth the wait. We will be back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Wait staff is great and drinks were good.  Not sure if it was just the C team cooking for lunch but the boar collar and tenderloin skewers were dry.  Very disappointing given all the hype.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The atmosphere is fun - colorful lights lining the tin roof dining area. The food was a bit more authentic than we were expecting (which is great for most people, but I'm more of a noodles-and-easily-pronounced-dishes-only Thai 'connoisseur'). A coworker and I ordered the ever popular bbq ribs and a chicken dish with sides of sticky rice. Both entrees had wonderful flavor and the dipping sauces were great. The sticky rice was a bit too sticky, but complemented our choices well. Good experience overall.
