categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great ambiance, friendly staff, nice mixed drinks.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm stuck on the rating I should give Pok Pok because of some awkwardness. We came here to try their famous chicken wings like everyone else. 

The restaurant is in a residential neighborhood, but there are a bunch of small restaurants and bars along the way. We got there early enough for lunch so it wasn't crazy busy and it was easy to find street parking. 

The hostess was great at welcoming us and asked if we wanted a table outside with heaters or inside the dining room. We told her we will take whatever is available so we sat inside right next to the bar. 

We weren't asked what we wanted to drink right away. Our waiter first came by after about 5 minutes so by that time we we already knew what we wanted order. 

There was just something strange about our waiter. After we ordered, he would just pause and then start talking. He did this the whole time which made it very awkward. Just very strange behavior from him. 

Anyway, we ordered the fish sauce chicken wings and Pok Pok special which included half of a game hen, papaya salad and sticky rice. The chicken wings are on the saltier side so definitely eat this with rice. The game hen was perfectly cooked. So tender and juicy and the plum sauce that came with it was delicious. The papaya salad wasn't all that great, though. It was on the plain side and not spicy enough even though we asked for it to be spicy. 

I wouldn't mind trying this place out again so that I can try the other items as well.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Omg this place is amazing. The setting is super intimate and authentic and the food is INSANE. We ordered the pork belly curry, the chicken wings, and the papaya salad. All were amazing! Order the chicken wings, you will not regret it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Why wait in line when you can get take out and eat on the street corner... same thing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
In 2005, the NFL implemented a rule to outlaw the "horse collar tackle." This particularly dangerous technique, made famous by then-Cowboy safety Roy Williams, involves grabbing an opposing ball carrier by the inside of their shoulder pads and dragging him to the ground from behind. The tackle puts the ball carrier in an awkward position that is likely to cause knee or ankle injuries.

I am currently developing a technique called the "boar collar tackle" that is similarly violent and dangerous. It will be used as a deterrent to anyone who touches or longingly glances at my Muu Paa Kham Waan plate. The staff at Pok Pok will tell you that their dishes are meant to be shared, but I have trouble believing it on this one.


I had been wanting to check out this lauded establishment for quite some time, but my wife is rarely in the mood for Thai food (a tragedy) and the lines at Pok Pok always seem to be a deterrent. I lucked out this past Friday night when the wife brought Pok Pok up by name and the wait was less than 10 minutes for dinner.

We had agreed to sit anywhere they could put us, but we got a great seat on the porch of the house with a nice view of the street below. Our table had a bottle of rice water (that's right, rice... not ice) which was actually a nice compliment to the meal. After quite a bit of deliberation, she went with the baked prawns with pork belly, I had the boar collar with a side of rice, and we decided to share the famous fish sauce wings.

There was nothing subpar on the table... not even close. The flavors are all so unique, but it was really the boar collar that jumped out and stole the show. The wings were nice, a little sweet, but not the earth-shattering experience that has been described. I wish I had seen Don B.'s advice to have them spiced up a little. I didn't taste the prawns, but had some pork belly with noodles. This was also tasty, but not something that you slowly savored every bite like the boar collar. It comes medium spicy, by my calibrated pallet, with a side of greens to cleanse said pallet.

The service was friendly and very attentive once we had ordered. The variety on the menu definitely leaves room for another visit, but the prices are a little steep compared to other Thai offerings ($2 for a couple ounces of rice to go with my $12 entree). We'll probably be back for a special occasion or with visitors, but the prices might keep Pok Pok out of our regular rotation.


Full disclosure:  I shared several bites of my boar collar with the wife (who agreed that it was easily the best dish on the table) and did not tackle her. :)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: the menu is similar or slightly changed up. you can order the same thing and the consistency is not. it can be spicy or lack flavor. the ingredients are lacking. the only thing that is still the same every time is the fish sauce wings... which i get every time.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Crowded,overrated, and overpriced, it saddens me to see food restaurants maximizing profits just because they can. There are a ton of authentic Thai food places out there that have way better prices. I'll leave this place to the yuppies and go elsewhere.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We saw this on some travel show on tv and decided right away that we had to try it. I had read about 90 min wait times, so we tried to get there early.

They have a pretty legit bar and interesting drinks with lots of drinking vinegars. None of them were too sweet or tiki-ish.
- Tamarind whisky sour: interesting with the tamarind
- Hunny: well balanced, lots of citrus juice, not too sweet 
- Heat Ray: a bit spicy, with celery drinking vinegar which was really interesting and good
- Lord Bergamot: one of the best tea based cocktails I've had, and it had a honey drinking vinegar 

Food: I wish we had more people so that we could order more to share.
- Phak kuut Ko: fiddlehead fern salad with naam phrik. The salad was warm with tons of flavors and textures, and the fiddle heads were cooked perfectly  
- Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings: their most popular dish. The wings were pretty good and had a good amount of meat, and the flavor was so rich and good (sweet and savory, not too fishy). It's probably the best marinade I've had on any wings 
- Yam Wun Sen Chao Wang: glass noodle salad served warm, with lots of different proteins in it (mussels, ground pork, Chinese sausage). This was good, but then when I saw the table next to us with a clay pot with noodles, I wished I had gotten that (it looked so good)
 
I feel like any Thai place without pad Thai on the menu is legit. Their stuff has lots of complex flavors and is a lot more interesting than the standard Thai menu. It's definitely worth venturing out to the SE side to try Pok Pok. 

Get there early to avoid a long wait.  We got here a little after 11:30 on a Sunday, and it was already busy, but luckily we didn't have to wait.  There was definitely a huge crowd outside when we left.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
When in Portland, this place is a must, especially if you like Thai food! The Fish Sauce chicken wings are incredible (most popular menu item) & so is their papaya salad! You have to eat those with rice! Their bottled Thai iced tea was also good. 
The only downside to this restaurant is that it's so popular, the wait time is forever long (1 hr+ on a weekend) since they don't have very many seating. We had to take our food to go. If you have the time, it's definitely be worth the wait!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Chicken wings were very delicious. My boyfriend and I ordered cocktails which were made to perfection. I ordered a curry which left me a bit disappointed because if felt more like the consistency of a pasta then a curry. Too many things going on in the plate which overpowered the curry itself. Fair price.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Mediocre hipster-thai fusion.  You can get better Thai food close by, and not pay as much or stand in as long of a line for it.  The wings are OK, but nothing special, I really don't understand all the hype over them.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Wings are awesome and in my 3 trips since discovering this place I haven't had a meal I didn't think.  Not the typically Thai food found in the US that relies on pad thai as the base.  Sauces are light, favors are unique and the spice they serve on the side is fantastic.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Damn amazing Thai food.  Vietnamese spicy wings and beef belly curry were insane.  Could of eaten until I exploded!  Do come here, no way you will be disappointed.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Honestly, I wasn't impressed. We ordered the special, which was papaya salad with the hen and their famous fish sauce chicken wings. I'll give them the chicken wings, it is great but my sis can make them even better and for far less! 

The papaya salad was gross, I guess being spoiled from good eats in LA, I wasn't too pleased with limp, salty, no flavor papaya salad. The hen was flavorless and dry.

Service was ok.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Incredibly delicious and unique food! We came in Tuesday afternoon without reservation and were seated immediately. We got the pork belly dish, the pok pok papaya, chicken papaya, the spicy boar collar dish, and the beef coconut curry for the 5 of us (one plate per person) and it was all delicious and sufficiently filling, and also all pretty spicy!

The favorite was the pork belly dish and the curry; but everything was incredibly tasty! Also, we got the Vietnamese coffee with brandy, which came in a drip container (you would watch the coffee drip to completion and then mix it with the condensed milk and brandy) which tasted amazing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Do not understand the hype at all! Have heard nothing but raving reviews about their food especially their chicken wings! Went in with high expectations and hoping to leave full and satisfied! However the wings were far too "fishy" - I'm talking smothered in fish sauce which leaves little room for any other taste. The flank steak we ordered was dry, season less and tasted of a beef jerky like consistency. I will not go again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We had one night in Portland to go out to eat, and this place had all the buzz, so we decided to check it out. It's almost impossible for a place to live up to such high expectations, but they did a pretty good job. Overall, the food was inventive and tasty, the service was great and the experience was worth coming back for.

There was a wait when we got there, and we were told we could wait across the street at Whiskey Soda Lounge and they would tell us when our table was ready. Can't beat that. Had a horrible experience at the Lounge, but that's for another review. After about 45 minutes we came back and were seated promptly in an outdoor section that had heat lamps but was still a little chilly in late December.

Our server was warm, laid back, knowledgeable and not at all pretentious. There were so many things on the menu it was hard to decide -- and this is not your traditional pad thai joint. I settled on a Chinese sausage and my wife got a carrot salad. Both were packed with flavor. Coconut rice was outstanding. Portions were a little on the small side, so when we go back we will probably get at least 3 entrees and share them.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Excellent food when you can get in...but the wait is ridiculous. I live right around the corner and can't really go there anymore because of the touristmania. I agree with the other folks who mentioned the attitude. I guess that's what happens when they don't really need you because a huge line of people is waiting right behind if you aren't happy. The best approach is take-out.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: But if a wait to be seated because the place is popular. Service was friendly and attentive but the fish sauce wings were the reason I came. I was a little hesitant because they are 'fish sauce wings' but I heard they were amazing and I had to give them a shot. Needless to say, I wasn't impressed... I'm sure there are other things on the menu that I'd enjoy but their claim to fame turned me off.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This may seem immaterial, but I could almost crawl here from my house. But this is why I discovered it one cold, blistery day. It was just the Shack then, and it had been open for about a minute the first time I feasted on khao man sum tam (bbq-like pork over coconut rice) shivering at one of the tables not yet accompanied by heat lamps. 

It was incredible and unique and even though I am a pansy when it comes to tolerating spicy stuff, I couldn't keep away from the then-punishing papaya salad. (It has since mostly slipped into a friendlier, compromised version of its former self, possibly because other pansies are whinier than me.)

Anyway, I also have bragging rights to having dined inside the night it opened, before people wearing golf shirts from Lake Oswego started showing up. It is truly depressing to be deprived of the full menu there - the take-out window (with its painfully small selection) is a 2-3x/mo gig for us because we have a toddler - where the decor is oddly cool and the steak salad sings with delicious pungent spices and the wings are so addictive that one could almost cry for them. 

Over time, I have seen the backlash to the country-club-looking set's arrival, which has been an increasingly condescending wait staff, replete with tats, beads 'n scruff, talking to customers with their eyes closed. For some reason, I find this more amusing than anything else, but definitely can see the attitude sometimes intruding unfairly into someone's dining experience. I nevertheless urge everyone to take a deep breath and venture into the unfamiliar, because it is all good, and the game hen alone makes it worth the trip. But leave your golf shirt at home.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So I found Pok Pok while searching for places to eat that were featured on Food Network's Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives. I was searching for it on the plane and mentioned this place to my buddy. Just as I mentioned Pok Pok, the random stranger (Drew, who lives in Portland) sitting next to me said this is a place I gotta try. It's very well known / renowned in Portland. 

We came here on a Thursday afternoon for lunch, so we didn't see any of the log lines or crowds mentioned in other reviews. We sat inside which was a very good decision...since it must have been 90 outside. 

I can't speak for the authenticity of the food. Seems more like a Asian fusion that works very well. 

For starters we ordered the Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce wings. Everybody seems to be raving about these...with good reason! Delicious! Tons of flavor, just the right mix of sweet, spicy & tangy. I'm a big fan...it would take a long while to get sick of these.

I got the Muu Paa Kham Waan (Boar collar). SPICY! Tender meat with tons of flavor and spices. I'm sure it's probably not spicy enough for true spicy lovers, but it definitely gave me the spice sweats. The dish came with a side of mustard greens on ice to cool you down. BRILLIANT! Lets just say I used all the greens...

My buddy got Pok Pok special. Good healthy size dish. The game hen was delicious...just done perfectly! The dipping sauces had good flavor, not overpowering at all. The salad was nothing special, but definitely edible. 

The biggest disappointment here was the sticky rice. Its hard and dry, like it was made in big batches and was sitting around for a while. I usually love sticky rice, one of my favorite things to eat while in Thailand. I would definitely pass on this one...

For dessert we ordered a Coconut Ice Cream Sandwich. Its pretty big, so we decided to split it. It was interesting / different...like a fusion of east & west. It actually came in a piece of white sandwich bread!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: If you watch the Anthony Bourdain episode with Andy Ricker, you start to realize what it takes to create this wonderful menu and how much effort goes into making each of these dishes. I even travelled to Chiang Mai and fortunately stayed 3 blocks from SP chicken (Pok Pok's inspiration came from here) and at some levels, Pok Pok does an even better job that SP chicken with their food. While the wings are definitely their top favorite, one must definitely try their Laab and other dishes. And yes, you need to have some tolerance to spicy food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Amazing the Sunny wut yen sun plate was delicious the rice was delicious great service and the wings were the greatest especially the spicy ones if you want good Thai food pok pok is the place to be!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Arrived to an hour and half wait on a Thursday night, not unexpected.  Got right in a Whiskey Soda Lounge for 3 apps including the famous wings.  30 minutes in, we got an hourly early surprise. Not a fan of waiting, but I wouldn't have ordered 3 apps if I knew it would only be 30 minutes. Dinner was excellent, make sure you get the catfish salad.  Pork sateh is a skip you can get anywhere, I was hoping something different here. Service was so so. Slow, unattentive, not super helpful. I went before so kind of knew my way around, without that I think I would have floundered.  Bad acoustics. Come here with a group of 6 and order the whole menu and have some of the best food you can find.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Interesting food. Not many options for vegetarians. Tried the papaya salad. Place has really long lines. I may not go here only because of the limited vegetarian options.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
My cousins and I went wild in trying as many menu items we could stomach and my highlights would be the following:

1. Khanom Jiin Sao Naam (Coconut Ginger Pineapple Vermicelli): My favorite of our lunch due to the nice sweet to savory balance of the flavors. Make sure you're open to all the ingredients before trying, as that should be a prerequisite for enjoyment.

2. Khao Soi Chicken (Curry Noodle Soup): Very simple, but tastes homey and very in tune with a comfort soup dish vibe.

3. Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings: A bit overrated, but you should try it anyways, at least once. I suggest sharing, as it could get a bit heavy after a couple wings.

The wait could be a bit much, so plan ahead and try to make a reservation if possible. If all fails, feel free to take a mini excursion to Blue Star Donuts or Salt and Straw which is within a 15 min. walk radius.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This is it. Ground zero for the Portland restaurant movement. If Thai Orchid or Thai Elephant or whatever serves the "top 40" boy band version of Thai food, Pok Pok serves the deep tracks of legendary classic rock. 

When you say to someone "we're going for Thai food," they're probably imagining the ubiquitous pad thai. The green and red curries dotting the menu like Christmas decorations. All dialed into that American palette with a sickly sweetness.

Not at Pok Pok. Unless you've been eating food from street vendors in Northern Thailand, most of this menu is probably little more than an incomprehensible list of Romanized Thai words with weird descriptions of "pork belly" and "duck leg" and... and... and... 

So, what I'm saying is this: set your expectations aside for an evening and step up to some flavor, for once.

True, Pok Pok empresario Andy Ricker is building a nationwide empire on his chicken wings. And you should order the chicken wings. They are sublime. Though if all you want are the wings, you can get them at the Whiskey Soda Lounge across the street and not have to wait 90 minutes for the privilege, or next time you're at PDX, grab them from the food cart before security.

So, maybe when you put your name in here for a table and they tell you it's going to be an hour and a half, you head to Whiskey Soda and order the wings for a preview of what's to come. That's a good strategy. 

But then, when you finally get your table, look at the menu and pick some things that sound unusual. Even scary (there's nothing all that scary on this menu, but to the uninitiated it can be a bit intimidating). The Neua Nom Tok (spicy flank steak) is crazy delicious. The Khao Soi (curry noodle soup) is completely out of control. The Kaeng Hang Leh (sweet pork belly) will, in all likelihood, blow your mind. And that's just scratching the surface.

The surprising and delightful flavors just keep coming. And, yes, it's a long wait. And yes, it's got all of the hype that Portland has to give. But sometimes, every once in a while, the hive mind gets it right. Plus, it's a lot easier than a trip to Thailand.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I came here prepared to dismiss it as over-hyped. I left admitting that the fish sauce wings are worth the price and the wait. I mean, I'm not trying to come here on a weekend, but I can't wait to try them again. I'd say it's like Salt & Straw, if you happen to walk by and for some reason the wait isn't too bad, then stop in and get some wings even if you're not that hungry.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This is one of the few places that's worth the hype. The wait can be abysmal so you have to be smart about when you go. It literally has the same wait at its NYC location. The wings are crazy delicious but they are incredibly salty from the fish sauce so be prepared. My favorite dish is the boar collar with the chilled greens. My one complaint is that it's supposed to be super spicy and it doesn't always come out that way.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok pok is one of those few places that I can categorize as a truly memorable meal. The flavors weren't the typical southeastern asian affair, and even though I'm not too experienced with food of that reason, there was definitely an inimitable authenticity to the food served here. 

The chicken wings, the signature favorite of Pok Pok, lived up to its name, contrasting the juicy, tender chicken with a crispy outer coat, with a sprinkling of chopped peanuts over the crispy intensely colored skin. The flavor bombs were dynamic, with a punch of sourness, then a kick of spice, and bringing it together was an overwhelmingly good savory flavor. 

Be warned despite the spiciness of the chicken wings, it was probably the least spicy part of the menu we ordered from. Pok Pok doesn't back down, it continues to throw its punches at you with a diverse array of flavors, with one similarity, a spiciness that only the brave can handle. (note to all* order the Thai iced tea to help balance out the flavors). I don't want to get too into the specifics, because you should just go to Pok Pok and experience it for yourself, but its one of those places you can't find anywhere else, and thats what makes it a gem in Portland.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I had a late lunch at Pok Pok yesterday. It was my first time dining here. A friend who eats here often recommended I have the Pok Pok Special, which is half a roasted game hen with a small papaya salad (papaya pok pok), sticky rice and dipping sauces. It was all very good. The hen was moist and had a good crisp skin on it. There is enough leftover for a big meal tomorrow. One of the two dipping sauces was pretty spicy so test the sauce before dipping. For 2:00PM it was pretty busy but the service was very good. I will eat here again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Went there today at 5:30pm, received a a slip of paper, left my cell number  & told 1 1/2 hrs to 2. We were never called. Thx for nothing. :(
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I really enjoyed my dining experience here even though there was mixed reviews amongst our table of 9.

Favorites of the night:
Chicken Wings - clearly. There are fifteen bajillion pictures of these on Yelp..check it out and OF COURSE you will order them. Crispy skin and super saucy!

Papaya Salad - they said it was spicy but i didn't think it was unmanageable, just a tiny kick. Really yummy, but i generally like papaya salad anyway

Pok pok special - my favorite item for the night. Super tender and wonderfully spiced skin. 

Hui thawt - the crepe!!!! Omgomg..a lot friends said this was their fave,  but i thought my piece was a little bit salty. Its super crispy and fluffy

Other notable items:
Boar collar  - this was a spicy dish, but really flavorful and its great with sticky rice!

Coconut Rice - hahah i know this is a side. But dooood. So good!

Also a huge shoutout to Michael, our server..he was AMAZING!! he's clearly passionate about the food and gave us some great suggestions for our table! :)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: One star down because its such a racket - the wait (which inevitably sends you running to whiskey soda lounge across the street). But the food is SO DELICIOUS. And this is why I keep coming back. Pro-tip -- if you only want wings, WSL also has them, but everything else at Pok Pok is just so good and so hard to describe. It is something you simply have to experience for yourself!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Waited an hour and a half for a Saturday night table and still have raving reviews! Excellent flavorful unique and authentic Thai food. Fun atmosphere and eclectic options while staying true to Thai flavors. Amazing!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: OMG! The BEST wings I've ever had in my life!!! EVER. The Fish Sauce wings are hands down to die for. They are quite spicy, so if you're not into spicy foods, you're probably going to want to order them non spicy. But trust, it just isn't the same without those chili peppers! Cute little venue hidden in the neighborhood with indoor and small outdoor seating area. Great ambiance and awesome service.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Just wasn't my cup of tea. The wings were super salty, and everything was very pungent. The pork loin skewers were good tho. The service was ok as well. Come early, because we came 10 minutes before it opened there was a line.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok is great! Def have to be in the mood for it but the flavors are amazing. Great date night.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Highly overrated.  Slow service.  Average experience, and not worth the hype or wait.  

Waited 20 minutes to have drink order taken.  Showed up at 4 and had to wait until 5 to order the boar.  Boar came out of kitchen and was cold - room temperature.  When we told the server, he informed us that it is supposed to be hot but sometimes it is cold.  What???

Two entrees and two beers was a two hour experience and $40.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I have never had any thing like the food and drink at Pok Pok. I had the Kai Yaang and Hunni; over the top. The man sitting next to me had the wings and was making noises as he ate them. He raised his head with sauce covering his face and said that the wings were awesome, I believed him.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Great food! We ordered an appetizer that was not available also they need to work on a better queue or order management, just because people were lining up, just to find out the wait time and then leave. We went at 9:30 ish too, and were going to have dinner elsewhere when we decided to return and just see if we got lucky with a table (the queue died) and yes! indeed they managed to place. We were also the last party to leave. 

But food was delicious. The wings were awesome. The papaya salad left my tongue paralyzed a pepper strike, but it was delicious. Would love to revisit to try the rest of the menu.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Sigh, I hate to give you 2 stars, but Pok Pok, you really let me down. We waited about 20-30 minutes to be seated, not too bad considering it was a Friday night, I didn't mind the wait. But when we got seater, no waiter greeted us until 10 minutes later. I kept trying to make eye contact to have them come take our order, but I was unimpressed by their lack of customer service! I should be greeted right away by someone, not wait forever and tell them we are ready to order. 

Now, I was quite excited about this menu, the descriptions on the menu made everything sound oh so delicious, but unfortunately we were let down major. The fish sauce wings everyone raves about, was not as good as I thought it would be. Super salty and overrated. We also had the ribs, every piece we had so much fat on it. You could tell the meat was quite cheap. And our last dish was the seafood glass noodles, it just didn't taste good, plain and simple. 

Lastly their dishes are way overpriced for the amount they give, and the quality of the ingredients as well. All in all, poor service, overpriced, and overrated. On a positive note, I would say their drinks are great, the Vietnamese coffee and Thai iced tea were tasty.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great food, busy for a reason...but the wait staff always seem mad that customers have shown up. I get my wings to go.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Good service! Love the atmosphere in the restaurant! But their most famous dish: the wings was a little too strong and salty for me. Except that, everything was perfect! Will definitely visit again!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The food is very tasty and beautifully seasoned but there are several other places I would choose before waiting in line for a hyped restaurant such as this. 
I think the alcoholic drinks are ridiculously overpriced although tasty. 
Thankfully you can get some of their signature dishes at their other restaurants without the wait!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: For as popular as this place is, I am surprised I've never had to wait more than half an hour for a table. The boar collar is outstanding. Probably my favorite dish in Portland. It's unfortunate they've raised their prices in the past few years.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great lunch & 1st sipping vinegar cocktail 5 years ago!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok is delicious. We came here with a large group for a birthday party and they were able to accomodate us in a room upstairs. The drinking vinegars were delicious and the food was amazing-- I've never been to Thailand, so I can't vouch for the authenticity of the dishes, but I can tell you they are tasty! With a very different menu than you typically see at Thai restaurants in the Portland area, a trip to Pok Pok will take you out of your comfort zone in a wonderful way. I can't say enough about how delicious this place is! No wonder there is always a line to get in!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The meal and the drink I ordered here were both delicious, however, I became ill about two hours later (&this is coming from a person who has a very strong stomach).  Feeling a bit weary about giving it a second shot.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place is definitely worth visiting. The food is spot on. The wings were awesome as well as the curry.  

The only thing prevented me from giving this place a 5 star is because the sticky rice we ordered was a bit on not so sticky rice. Felt like it was cooked a while ago and dried up a bit which made it hard.

This place can be on a pricey side too for the amount of food served, but this is a must eat while in Portland
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
My oh my!
This place rocked my world once my roommate felt like ordering just before it closed, It was just before February I recall, and I noticed she had it on speed dial. I wondered why and found out it was due to the extremely long line made of cloned humans with Dark rimmed glasses, both sexes, dressed mostly in black, and approximate weight of 115 lbs each. The spice level and flavor on the wings were dream like, the portions were scientifically exactly calculated. We picked up our meals and paid as we smiled at the frustrated  faces in line awaiting for a table. We gladly went home to watch an episode of the Walking Dead with with a satisfying meal.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
As tourists in Portland, we had to come here. We waited 1 hour for this place at 1:30pm on a Saturday, but spent that hour eating and drinking at a nearby food truck pod. This is why we only shared 3 things between 4 people. We ordered the fried wings, glass noodle with shrimp and pork belly, and papaya salad. At first I thought this was a Thai restaurant, but there are a lot of Vietnamese influences. The flavors are bold. 

The wings were good, but could have used more salt. It reminded me of Korean fried chicken - deep fried wings covered in sauce. The papaya salad had a pleasant spicy kick. It was a good contrast to the cabbage wedge that it laid on. I wish the quantity was a little bigger. The glass noodles were a disappointment. There was one piece of pork belly and lacked sauce. Wish there was more of the caramelized sauce the waiter described.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The coconut chicken curry noddle soup was delicious. I also ordered the wings and pork belly stew which were both too salty for my liking. They have a Thai tea with Lime juice which is new to me, if you're into lime I'd try it out. Over all the service was great & I would re order the noodle soup however, I'd prefer a more traditional style Thai dinner. 

Still check it out!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: One of a gazillion Thai places in PDX that put out really good food, so nothing special in PDX. More a take-out than eat in.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Slightly overpriced and overhyped but food was good. The house chicken reminded me a lot of rotisserie chicken which was nice..but rather bland considering it was listed as a speciality...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Ahhh I was the most stoked to come visit this place in Portland. We came in early Thursday around 1pm and had a short wait of about 15 minutes. 

First off the location, ambiance and vibe was all amazing and just as I thought it would be. Very Thailand, and most importantly very much lived up to my high expectations.

Food: 

Pok pok special (5 stars): there's no reason not to get this. The signature papaya salad is a must and the sticky rice is incredible. The chicken was so juicy and everything went together so well. I cleaned the plate on this gigantic order of food easily bc it was so great tasting. 

Boars collar (5 stars): super spicy and juicy and delicious! I didn't know what we were expecting when we ordered this but definitely wasn't what we got. I thought it was gonna be dry and gamey, but nope! This is a must order item in my book. 

Ike's fish sauce wings (5 stars): goodness it's just not fair that I can't get these everyday. They are incredible!! The crispy garlic and sticky coating is amazing. I've tried to make these at home and they haven't come out quite the same. These wings are addictive! 

I truly admire Andy Ricker and his passion for Thailand. He's always been high up on my list of favorite chefs, so I definitely was expecting the best and this restaurant delivered. This should be on every Portland travelers list of must-try places to eat.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: How this place ranks at the top of the list boggles my mind. It's less than okay. Kinda gross sitting next to people who do not have knives to use, sucking on chicken bones, slurping and licking next to you, does not make for an amazing dining experience. I can appreciate steamed rice, but having it delivered in a saran wrapped package plopped next to your plate does not make me want to come back for more. I just think this is a classic case of the Emperor's New Clothes.Expensive for what you get. Not worth it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Best meal we had in portland.  I don't need to write a long review, others have covered this place very thoroughly.  If you live in, or visit, Portland, you really should go to this place.  Simply amazing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Talked into meeting my son and his girlfriend here, didn't think there would be anything on the menu I would like. I was pleasantly surprised, I will go there again. Usually a 10-15 minute wait for a table. Worth the wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: All I can say is that the wings did not disappoint! The other food we ordered was good but not 5 star worthy. GET THE WINGS!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We stopped in when visiting a friend in portland. ..the boar is amazing and unlike anything I've ever had. The pork belly melts in you're mouth and the wings are unbelieveable. The menu sounds very eclectic and adventurous but I believe even the pickiest eater would be pleased with anything they got.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Mind blowing food! Prepare to wait to eat on busy nights because this place is POPULAR. Drinks and bartenders are definitely up to par, along with the incredible fusion food. Don't skip their famous chicken wings, but honestly their entire menu appears to be outstanding. A Portland, OR must-indulge-in dinner out.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I get that it's "cool" and "cute" but for gross tasting water, tiny little portions and a giant wait time at least they could charge a bit less. This place is the epitome of a trendy, over-hyped Portland fad. When my friends and I are looking for new places to eat we tease each other that "well if we want to stay hungry and spend a lot of money we could always go to Pok Pok".
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Not much of a variety and pricey for my taste. No pun intended.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Best wings around, phenomenal. Great sticky rice and papaya salad. There's always a wait, so plan around it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Located in an area with plenty of places to walk around and take a stroll. Many restaurants all together, you are most likely going to end up parking in the streets. Overall if you are coming on the weekends, you can probably expect a 1 hour rate on average but we totally lucked out that they had an open table for big groups outside.

It was a bit confusing as we literally had 2 waiters come by to tell us the exact same thing and take our orders. It happens. servers were nice and the food came out fast for the most part. the highlight is def the chicken wings, get it with some heat, the mild ones are too restraint and you do not get the full flavor. i love the chicken wings, just don't love the price especially if you are coming from an Asian town like SGV in LA, California. the price is a bit inflated for value but i get it's a novelty out here.

Other noticeable mentions, papaya salad, really really hot but it burns so good. Pork belly was pretty good over rice. The most not worth it would probably be the cat fish, small portions and was whatevers.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I've heard nothing but rave reviews of this place. And while the food was not bad, it wasnt particularly spectacular either. The two dishes I tried seemed a bit bland, and the waiter was a bit surly (though I do know everyone has bad days....)
There's other thai places in town that are better in my opinion, but i'd go back if I was in the neighborhood.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Expect a crowd on nice nights. There were a few people waiting and the hostess asked right away if we wanted cocktails while we waited. Yay! I had a tasty Gin Rickey. 

We waited a bit longer for an outside table and had some smoky good pork ribs with dipping sauce and amazing fish sauce chicken wings. I'll definitely be back to try more!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I love Pok Pok. Not because it is wildly popular and cool, but because the service is bright, knowledgeable, friendly and on point. Every time. Third round of guests with me here was a hit... Just like the other two visits. I am comfortable and confident when I bring out of towners here that they will be a part of the best of Portland dining. 

There is something for everyone... I don't yet have a favorite dinner... The wings are not my thing but I can tell they are super-good if you like sweet and crunchy. (I only like buffalo style)

Atmosphere is lively and comfortable. We can go in jeans, shorts or skirt/slacks.

Perfect, fellas. Really, really perfect.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I love Thai food so I tend to gravitate towards my (Americanized) favorites like pad kee mao or pineapple fried rice. Pok pok's menu is different and to my knowledge seems authentic. We were greeted with chili lime peanuts which were super delicious!! I got the coconut milk corn on the cob and omg it was creamy and savory. I got the papaya pok pok which was spicier than expected but the tomato and green beans bring down the heat. For the entre, I ordered Khao Soi with tofu and it was hands down the best dish I had in a Thai restaurant! It was creamy but not too heavy. The crispy crackers on top provided interesting texture! And the noodles were were cooked perfectly!! I was pretty happy with the meal. I was way too full for dessert.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: this place is yummy. the papaya salad is really good. i had also the vietnamese chicken wings, they were delicious but i found them a little too salty for both me and my mom. if it were a little less salty, i'd order them again.  but the papaya salad was awesome, though. you should also try the vinegar drinks. sounds weird, but they have a certain vinegary/sweet appealing taste to them... comes in all kind of fruit flavors.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Stayed in Thailand for a while, can't say authentic Thai food but i would say highly recommended and good fusion food! Must try the wings even if you don't eat wings! After the meal cross the road and go have ice cream at salt and straw best in Portland!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Having worked in a few mid and low end restaurants, I know most of the tricks restaurants use to scrape pennies off each customer. I was fairly disappointed to see Pok Pok pull every one out of the book, but also sacrifice the experience. 

Our server did not know what to recommend and provided little to no guidance on the menu. They served a side salad with one of the meat dishes that was a chunk of red cabbage with core intact, and a few branches of mint and rotting pea shoots. You'd think a $15 dish would at least offer sliced cabbage. Ordered a Tsing Tao which ran a cool +$5, which I don't think I've ever paid more than $3 for. You don't pay microbrewery prices on Bud Light quality beer. Ordered a side of sticky rice, which was a cup of sticky rice in a plastic bag served in a bamboo cup. The sticky rice is pre-packaged in plastic bags and kept warm in a rice cooker next to the bathroom, next to about a few dozen other bags. The rice was very dry despite being in bags, which makes me wonder how long those bags have been sitting in the cooker for. The Ike's chicken wings were good, but as other customers have described, were very sweet and slightly undercooked.

I can see why Pok Pok is closing down their LA location. It's honestly strange the NY branch got a Michelin star - I wonder what they do differently out there. But what I can say for sure is these are clear remnants of a sold out chain sacrificing the customer for their best interests.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
My friend and I came to Portland for the weekend, so of course Saturday night we came to pok pok. We got here around 8 and it was packed. Luckily enough the side table has two seats open. We tried the wings and the shrimp with rice noodle, they were all very good. Note, the high light was actually the Brussels sprouts, so good. We both like it so much that we came back on Sunday night again! Knowing that to be seated will take forever we decided to order to go. 

We got here around 6pm and it wasn't that busy. When we said we want to ordered to go, the chef asked us if we want to order from the dinner menu! (This place has a special to go menu with only a few items on it). So we end up ordering the things we want from the whole menu. This place is amazing. I would say if you don't want to wait, order it to go and ask the chef if you can choose the items from the full menu.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is killer. I will come here every single time I'm in Portland. The wings are to die for and there's an amazing selection of drinks! Don't skip out on the coconut rice either!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Best Thai food I've ever had.  I'm glad it was recommended by so many people.  The staff was very helpful with the menu and made great suggestions.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Well, I am now a die-hard fish sauce wings fan. I never would have thunk it, as the name "fish sauce wings" kind of turns my stomach. Trust me - you do not taste the fish, all you taste is delicious, fried, sweet goodness.

Also, best water EVER.

Another also, the cocktails are super good.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I can finally say I ate at Pok Pok and it was worth the wait! We arrived on a Sunday evening around 8:00 and waited for 30 minutes. We were prepared for this to be our most expensive meal of the vacation and ordered away! My husband had 2 beers, and I had two cocktails, all of which were excellent. We shared the fish sauce wings, boar collar and papaya salad with sticky rice. Before tip, our bill was a measly $82. 
The wings were all they are cracked up to be, salty, sweet, and spicy with a deep flavor that you can only accomplish with a balanced amount of fish sauce. Too much and it tastes fishy, too little and it has not flavor at all. They were spot on. The boar collar was incredibly spicy (the waitress warned us), but paired well with the sticky rice and the cooling mustard greens served along side. I also had a mango and coconut cocktail that helped soothed my palate while enjoying the boar collar. The star of the show for me was the papaya salad. It was so well balanced and the added crunch to our meal really married everything together. The music and ambiance of this restaurant really transports you to another country. I am so incredibly pleased with this experience and cannot recommend it enough.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Came up and thought it would be a long wait with the amount of people standing around. We got seated right away since we choose the bar option, if not it was a 20 min wait. However when we were inside & seated, we saw lots of empty tables (again like the last time I visited). The spicy chicken was good but slightly under cook since I saw blood on my wings. The Laap Pet Isaan was ok, definitely spicy. I thought the duck liver and etc was too finely chopped to taste the full flavors of it. All I could taste was the lemongrass and spicy chilies. I didn't quite get the plate of veggies that came with it. Probably would have been better if I got rice papers to make spring rolls out of it. Kaeng hung leh was good. Can taste the coconut curry flavors, more of a brothy dish with minimal pork belly, almost was like soup. Only got one pork while the other was basically a cube of fat.

pics on Instagram @ amanda.n_
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Interesting experience. 2.5 hour wait we did bar hop a bit while waiting. Thank goodness for knowledgable server or we would of been lost. All was really good except for sausage tasted like cleanser. Good selection of beers. Not sure if I would choose to return unless we going because someone were with really wants to go and weather is good. The whole area was very busy on a Saturday night. Had to park a significant distance away.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The fact that you can smell a hint of fish sauce in the air gets your tummy excited! The lemon grass infused in their water is also refreshing. Avoid sitting under the corrugated roof on a hot summer day. The piping hot meal can make the heat more intense!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
First I must say that I am no culinary expert nor am I well educated when it comes to the food of Thailand. What I can say is that I have been to Pok Pok several times and have yet to be disappointed. My last visit I took some Pok Pok virgin friends along with my husband and toddler. We made a reservation the same day and all they had available was rather late, but they did fit us in at the end of the night. 

The food is detailed and interesting. Several times our conversation turned to the food because it begged to be talked about. I highly recommend the sticky rice and if you are a nerd like me, you'll want to eat everything with your fingers.

Our server (who I'll refer to as "asian glasses guy" ;) was great in helping us choose menu items, he made us feel welcome adjusting for our toddlers tastes and wiggles, and didn't put any pressure on us to leave even long after they had closed. He even recommended some other great restaurants for us to check out in our other food pursuits.

My friends raved at the quality and flavor of the food and everyone left with a nice warm heat on our tongues and full bellies. If you can handle spice and have an appreciation for complex flavors and a dining atmosphere that lets you slow down from the faster pace of the outside world this is worth trying hands down. There is nothing you can eat or experience here that doesn't have a great deal of thought and execution behind it and it shows.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Excellent food and good service.  As authentic as Thai gets in Portland.
However, the space is crammed, it is not really kid friendly, and it is way too popular (and full).
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I really don't see what the fuss is about this place. Andy Ricker did not invent Thai food. Yes, the flavors and dishes are more than what you get at your usual hometown pad thai palace. But something is still lost in translation here between the kitchen and your table. Some of it is the immediacy in the way food is served. If it hangs around on the pass in the kitchen and is not blazing hot when it's in front of you, the flavor suffers.  If you've ever had street food in Thailand, you know what I"m talking about...it goes from fire to your face in about a second..and the cook is handing it right to you.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Absolutely delicious! Ordered the khao soi khan (a curry noodle soup) and a Thai tea made with evaporated milk. The curry was flavorful. The chicken I ordered witH it fell off the bone into the soup, so tender and juicy. Customer service was impressionable in a good way, very genuine. I also saw many other guests order the fish sauce wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I can't remember when I waited over an hour for a restaurant table (OK it was 6:30 on a Friday, but...) and then been so underwhelmed with the food, especially compared to the Yelp hype. 

It wasn't that the food was bad, it was all satisfactory.  We had the super-hyped wings (non-spicy version), pork belly, shrimp and ribs.  The ribs were dry, the shrimp was in the shell, the wings were not so much different from an off the shelf BBQ sauce and the pork belly sauce was probably the best of all four.  The noodles with the shrimp were good.  

Service was adequate but just.  Noise level was high. There are many Portland restaurants I'll go back to before this one.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This is fun.
I'd say it's a do, maybe a do now and then,
but at some point for me, Thai food is, well, just kind of boring, just Thai food... you can only sweeten and lemongrass and spice up peanuts and noodles and sweeten chicken wings so many times and ways... I went to Thailand though, and wasn't really wowed here either, so maybe it's me?
So have the wings, and the lamb stew, and a funky salad, and some vinegar chili sauce,
and maybe choose an off time and night because like other hot spots, for me it isn't worth the 'scene'.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: May 4,2012. after seeing this restaurant on Diners, Drive Inn, and Dives, had to go there. HUGE mistake, wings just ok, ribs with hardly any meat, pay for rice, just nothing to get excited about and it is NOT cheap. Save your money, MUCH better options available. HUGE disappointment.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
was visiting Portland for work and had a meal to myself.  The wait was about 1-2 hours if you were 2+ but luckily i went solo and sat down in 1 minute at the bar.  David the bar tender was awesome and gave me recommendations on the wine and food.  First off, Pinot in Portland is 5 stars, and that's coming from a bay area guy.  I had the chicken wings which were practically a meal in themselves, i didn't finish one (rare for me).  It had good tang, only negative was it was a bit salty.  I had a spicey mango duck with rice and it was super awesome.  

I live in the bay area which has a variety of thai restaurnats, but not this style of vietnamese thai.  Most thai food i've seen is pad thai, curry style.  This is more fresh ingrediants, balanced flavors.  

If you're visiting, come here, if you live here, then great!  SE Division also has a ton of other places for you to go drink, eat, walk around as well.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Wings. 
Wings. 
Wings. 

WINGS. 

WIIIIIIIINGS!

Don't be that person who doesn't get them because they're messy. The fish sauce wings here are goddamn delicious and among the best wings I've ever eaten. They even come with wet wipes for you to get back in pristine form once you're done pigging out. 

The rest of the menu is also pretty good--and it might still pale in comparison with those wings (yes, I may be obsessed). My friend and I got a great Burmese pork belly curry where the meat melted in my mouth, as well as an eggplant-based dish whose name eludes me. 

Needless to say, we rolled out of the restaurant bursting to the seams. 10/10 would devour again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Food was good. Service was sh*t.

To the white server lady with glasses.  If you have to get SO VISIBLY annoyed of Asians, STOP WORKING AT A THAI RESTAURANT.  MAYBE it was our first time in the restaurant and the menu is hard as hell to read.  MAYBE there wasn't a separate SECTION for noodles so I couldn't tell off-hand that there were noodle dishes and the restaurant has been around for 14 years and ALWAYS had noodles.  I lived in Portland for 25 years of my life and sure as hell didn't hear about your noodles. And don't get smart about your "no-refill" policy.  There are a MILLION other MORE POLITE ways to say "I'm sorry, we don't do refills".  Seriously? No RC COLA refills? 

Luckily, there is a location in LA where I can go, which is far, FAR away from this bad experience.  I'm kind of unsure though if I will go back, because I now associate fish sauce wings with rude service.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I expected this place to be good given all the buzz, but it wasn't good...it was excellent! Every single dish was amazing, especially the chicken wings. Their Thai iced tea was also the best I've ever had. I live in Seattle but would do the three hour drive to Portland just to eat here again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: If you have been to Thailand, you might be disappointed in the food here. Wasn't a fan of the chicken wings, although the pickled vegetable relish was good. Other dishes were okay. The Khao Soi was served lukewarm so It wasn't as good as it should have been. The ambience is cool though - you feel like you are in a restaurant/bar in Thailand. And the service was very good.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'll make this quick... Since you have 242 other reviews to check out. Sheesh!

Fun cocktail list. I've heard the drinking vinegars are really good--one of them has made it into a cocktail (raspberry vinegar, soda and... was it gin?) but I was lured by the home-made bitters in the tamarind whiskey sour.

Portions... not as big as you'd like.

Menu... almost nothing in common with other Thai restaurants--a nice departure.

Food... intensely seasoned. Sometimes kinda hot, and often on the salty side, to my taste. I LOVE the stringy slow-cooked pork with coconut rice. The pork / pork belly curry was rich, decadent and delicious--and not like other curries. The seafood curry was very brothy, very tasty--a generous amount of shellfish swimming around in there....

The traditionally steamed sticky rice, wrapped in plastic wrap & tucked in a little woven basket: hhmmnnnnn, I'm not sure about heating up plastic wrap on my food. Has plastic wrap got the Bad Stuff in it? Gotta look into that....

Dessert--we shared the ice cream sandwich: 2 or 3 scoops of Coconut Jackfruit ice cream served in a regular bun, rather like a hot dog bun. With sticky rice. Chocolate sauce. Grated coconut too, I think. According to the menu, this is ubiquitous from street vendors in Thailand. Well. I prefer my ice cream without bread, it turns out. 

We were an unwieldy group of 10. They squeezed us next to another table that was not so happy to see us come & take over--It was tighter than an airline seat for a few folks at their table & ours, until we succeeded in running them out of the joint.... But the service was pretty good and friendly enough. We got out of there for $25 each, but I'm sure I'd like to spend $50--a couple cocktails and leave stuffed. Yeah.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The wings are good, and there are some unique dishes.  This restaurant is a little pricey.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: As a vegetarian who also is allergic to wheat my options are limited. and  my partner is vegetarian. We've tried Pok Pok 2x and we don't get it. The vegetarian food just doesn't deliver. Perhaps their meat and fish dishes are awesome but not worth the wait if you're vegetarian.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: My fiancé and I went to Pok Pok today while visiting in Portland. We had high hopes, however once we sat down and looked at the menus we were instantly rethinking things. Our server came over and asked if he could get us drinks then seemed put off that we were happy with water ( which had a fowl taste as it will with cheap metal drinking glasses). He offered no insight on what to get nor any friendly banter. We decided on some type of "spicy" flank salad, sticky rice, and shrimp chips. The best part was the shrimp chimps. The flank salad was anything but spicy, and the sticky rice could induce vomiting alone. Take precaution if you come here, and if you do...beware of the douche bad waiter (shaved head, black thick rimmed glasses, and 8 red pens in his pocket). If the food doesn't turn your stomach, his lack luster personality will!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I was really excited to go to Portland and experience the food scene out there. Even though Pok Pok just opened a NY location, I needed to try the original and see what all the hype was about. We got there around 1pm on a Saturday afternoon and only had to wait about 10 minutes. For such a popular place, this was already a win in my book.

Another win was the fish sauce wings, ordered spicy. They were lathered in an almost Korean-style wet sauce with spices and red chili flakes. The meat was tender and juicy in their slightly crispy outer skin. Unfortunately, this was the only real high point for me.

The charcoal rotisserie roasted game hen was good but not enough to impress. The marinade added a lot of different flavors to the subtly smokey meat. However, the meat could have been juicier; and whenever there are extra dipping sauces on the side, I feel like it takes away from true taste of the meat. Good meat and seasoning should be able to stand by themselves.

Everything else we tried was just OK. The grilled boar collar had a citrus-y garnish. The grilled baby back ribs were small and lacking in meat. They tasted almost exactly like Chinese spare ribs, so there was nothing unique to me about the dish.

I would come back to have some more wings and try some other dishes, but my overall reaction for my first time at Pok Pok was just OK. Until next time.

http://knockrz.wordpress.com/
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
http://adorablydeliciouslp.blogspot.com/

when in doubt eat at pok pok. pok pok is my absolute favorite restaurant in portland and now that i think about it, the world. i have never ordered an item that i didn't like. the mushroom salad, papaya salad, cha ka, and wings are my personal faves. cha ka is probably my favorite dish of all time. it would no doubt be my last meal on this earth if i had a choice.

 i've driven 600 miles just to get some cha ka (the catfish dish with mint, cilantro, rice noodles, etc) and enjoy it with good friends and vinegar sodas. i will get the cha ka any chance i get but i'm not a huge vinegar soda fan. they're just to vinegar-y for my palette.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Portland's staple but IMO it is overrated. 
Overhyped but again it is just my opinion. 
From reading reviews they're known for their fried chicken. 

Fried chicken = salty!! and more like a soy sauce fried chicken. As for the rest of the dishes spicy or not really a fan. I did enjoy the vermicelli dish with catfish. Don't get me wrong service was great. We were a party of 9 and dishes kept coming out. 

Thanks again Pok Pok.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I was really enamored by all the great reviews for Pok Pok. The past five years I've heard a lot about this restaurant. Heard about the chef. About the great recipes. About the innovative flavors and Vietnamese food. I have to say that I was a bit disappointed. I don't believe it was a one time occurrence. While the drinks were good, every single review talks about the chicken wings. What you don't realize is across the street at the whiskey bar are the same chicken wings, the same app menu, from the same kitchen and it's owned by Pok Pok.   I recommend that if you're interested in trying this, just go across the street.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Ugh! Why does this place get such great reviews?! Flavorless food that has too much heat. Complete waste of money.  Service is fine enough. Space is small.  But the food...I can't understand why it gets raves. Less than mediocre. And way too much hype.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok. The Portland culinary institution created by Chef Andy Ricker. There is a lot of hype swirling around this place and rightfully so. This joint is like no other Thai restaurant I have ever been to. In fact, it is difficult for me to properly describe my experience here. And an experience it was. On this night, I witnessed herds of people arriving from each side of the street, cars dropping of guests to reserve tables and even folks paragliding in from the sky. Well, maybe not that last one but you get the drift. They then give you the option to either wait outside or wait for your table at the Whiskey Soda Lounge across the street. At the lounge, you can enjoy a kick ass tamarind whiskey sour until they page your server for you to be sat at Pok Pok where the ambiance is boisterous, hip and eclectic-similar to a Thai street food truck? Possibly. The flavor erupting from our dishes on the menu were unique, delectably mouth watering, and spicy.  I am confident in saying that every Asian fare loving individual in Portland should try this place out at least once.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So delicious!! Hands down one of my favorite Thai food places. This place will make you reconsider everything you know about Thai food. There's so much more than just pad Thai and the standard stuff you see at other Thai places. The food and flavors are so authentic. 
I will definitely be going back when I'm back in the area.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I lived in Portland 5 years before trying Pok Pok. What was I thinking?!?! Sometimes I rebel against trying places with a lot of hype. THAT WAS A HUGE MISTAKE. The wings. The wings! I actually had food dreams about them the first time I tried them. The are worth the $14, I promise you! Honestly, I can't remember what else I ordered here. I remember the meal being good and spicy but everything was overshadowed by the EPIC goodness of the wings! So, if you've been rebelling against the hype like I did, I'm telling you GET OVER IT AND GO. Go now. Get the wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
i wasnt expecting anything when my friends brought me to pokpok for dinner. i mean, a thai restaurant? there are at least 4 within a five minute drive from my house down in california. so, i had no expectations, but i think it says something when our entire table got extremely quiet and didnt talk because we were too busy eating!

what i ate:
- ikes vietnamese fish sauce wings: these were incredibly addicting. well spiced, flavorful. the chicken was tender and juicy. the sauce was finger licking good. i cant even describe it. i think i would be willing to visit again and order two plates of this to eat all by myself. 
- muu sateh (pork satay): the pork was tender, the satay sauce peanuty. while very good, it wasnt the most knock your socks off dish. 
- jin hoom neua (beef stew): deep flavor. it tasted like it had been simmering all day. spicy, the kind that hits the back of your throat and makes you pause, but you still feel compelled to take in more spoonfuls. the beef was good, but it was the broth that kept me coming back
- kaeng hung leh (pork belly): this was my second favorite dish of the night (after the wings). i LOVE pork belly. that layer of fat, that tender pork. the flavor was savory, garlicy, i loved the sauce so much i was pouring it over my sticky rice for a flavor bomb boost
- passionfruit drinking vinegar: delicious, refreshing
- sticky rice: good

pros:
- FOOD! if anything, just come for the fish sauce wings. trust me. 
- price: all the dishes were around $12-15. nothing was outrageously expensive, everything was reasonably priced

cons:
- wait: my friends and i were incredibly lucky i think. we went during the week on the early side, and we were able to get a table on the patio. but my friends warned me how long the wait could be for dinner. so bad, that the owner opened up a bar across the street to satiate those who were waiting for table (what a genius idea! getting your customers money twice, once at the bar for beer, once again at the restaurant for dinner!)
- pretentious: our server, while very adept, he wasnt very friendly and had an air of pretension around him. i wish he had smiled every now and again. but honestly, im just being nitpicky at this point. who gives a crap about the pretentious server (it seems like a common theme for most portland servers)? come for the food!

would i come again? for the wings? YES! :)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Their food was awesome and the restaurant was very cute! I'd say the only cons were that the wait is kinda long (It's not their fault the foods that delicious), and that all guest on the party need to be there to be seated.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm a big fan of Northern Thai (Issan, Chiang Mai) food PLUS I grew up eating Burmese food whose namesake country borders Northern Thailand.  Overall, I was a bit disappointed in the food here, minus the fish sauce chicken wings and sticky rice.

Like everyone says, the fish sauce chicken wings are a MUST.  These chicken drumstick and wing pieces are marinated in fish sauce, deep fried, then coated in more caramelized fish sauce.  You can't go wrong.  It is a little saltier to eat as a stand alone item so it's nice that they provide some light veggies on the side.  I would actually get sticky rice to eat with this as well.  One sticky rice portion is small, literally enough for one person, so get more.

Next up was the Muu Paa Kham Waan which is boar collar meat with an extremely pungent sauce with crushed up goodies on top.  You wrap this in the mustard greens they provide on the side and use the crushed ice to cleanse your palette.  The menu says that this is drinking food so I think beer would've lessened the intensity or made it more eatable.  The meat itself was a little on the tough side and I've noticed this when ordering this dish even at other places.  I won't accept it though; I know they can do better!

Khao Soi is a coconut chicken curry noodle soup but this was the biggest disappointment for me.  The Burmese version is thick and creamy--true comfort food.  This was watery and flavorless.  They do give you a lot of tender chicken pieces but that didn't make up for it.  Also, it needs a lot more of the condiments (lime, chili flakes, shallots, pickled mustard greens) to make up for the lack of flavor.  

Bloody Mary is $9 for a 12 oz. cup, didn't have enough tomato juice, and is on the lighter side.  Not a must get.  I like the hut style restaurant which is nostalgic of some of the indoor/outdoor combo restaurants I've been at in Thailand.  Food is a bit hyped though.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Loooove this place. Food is amazing! Been here a few times and food is consistently very tasty. Fish sauce wings are a must! I remember being hesitant on ordering the papaya salad because a. It might be too bland in satisfying this Asian girl's heavy palate or b. it just wouldn't be good (too sweet, sour, fishy...) which is common at Thai places, but I was pleasantly surprised by how refreshing it was. I usually don't use that word when describing papaya salad. I'm Mien (look it up because I know you're wondering) and I love my papaya salad a perfect balance of spicy, fishy, sour, and sometimes crabby and with pahddet (a highly acquired taste).  While this wasn't usually the way I eat my papaya salad it was so damn good. A hint of fish sauce, and a nice balance of sour and spicy. Even my boyfriend loved it! The boar collar is also a must! Really tender and moist. The pepper sauce on it is what makes it though. Perfect with steak or pork and just like at home. 

Bottom line: Pok pok takes southeast Asian comfort food and transforms it into another level that manages to please everyone, from the picky to the adventurous. Get there early!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Best Vietnamese restaurant I've ever been to. The chicken salad was extremely flavorful. Family style dining lets you try a bunch of items on the menu in one sitting. I will definitely come back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Flavors, folks.  It's an art form.  And textures.  You smokers have no clue what you are missing.  It's almost worth quitting smoking and getting your taste buds back to experience this brilliant food.  Yes, the portions are small and a little pricey. This is how people are supposed to eat.

Mmmmmm....Carlton Farms pork loin skewers marinated in coconut milk and turmeric, grilled over charcoal and served with peanut sauce, cucumber relish and grilled bread. Coconut rice. Thai iced tea with lime juice, a refreshing alternative to the milky sweet version at other Thai joints.  

Ike's Vietnamese chicken wings:  My God.  I had to close my eyes while chewing.  I ate each wing slower than the last.  You will want to lick and nibble every morsel of chicken off of each wing, and then you will want to caress each leftover bone.
