text: For the short and sweet: Worth the wait and oh so amazing!  Just go!  I don't know if I'd order the duck again, but everything else exceeded my expectations, and with four of us, we had seven dishes, plus apps at the bar before dinner!  We left stuffed and happy.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This restaurant is a must-visit if you're in Portland! The food was amazing--we got the smoked eggplant, the tuna salad, and a shrimp dish; all disparate flavors that complimented each other exquisitely. I got a delicious cocktail involving grape fruit juice and tequila--simply divine!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So what's with all the excitement about those famous wings? Hmmmmmmm you are not missing out much;(.
The first wing was good, then the more you eat it, the more saltiness it becomes and the less you want to eat it. Other dishes such as the namtok beef salad was really nothing special (typical), and caramelized prawns with glass noodles was just alright. Good thing we tried on our first trip to Portland, but do I want to try it again in the future? Not really, not worth it. 

Next, the Service was ok because our server (whom claimed that he is full Thai ), he only took our orders then never came around to check on how we were doing. The only time we interacted with him was asking for our check. Now, if he' were expecting good tips from that'? Well expect the least. Dude, what you get is what you put out on your effort to providing good customer service . I would had walked out without tipping , but the hubby was too nice!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Meh, just meh.  I continue to be underwhelmed by the food and service at Pok Pok.  To be fair, I'm a vegetarian and I think they are known more for their meat dishes.  I had the coconut curry soup and while it tasted ok, it was rather dull.  I've also had the Thai herb salad a few times and it wasn't anything all that spectacular.  Even though the food was "ok', I don't think I'll go back just because the service has been horrible each time.  On this last visit, I waited 30 minutes for a drinking vinegar and it was just kind of tossed on the table with no apology for the wait. The soup came out fairly cold and then soup bowls, spoons, and chopsticks weren't delivered until ten minutes after we received our food.  On each occasion, the servers have been abrupt and indifferent (not at all representative of the outstanding service I've come accustomed to in Portland).  I asked for a variation on the drinking vinegar and I swear my waiter rolled his eyes while replying with a snarky "soooorrry, but no."  If you're a meat eater or here from out of town and want to experience Pok Pok . . I  say go for it and you'll probably be happy.  Their drinking vinegars are lovely and I do recommend trying them out if you go.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Get the chicken wings. Everything else is great, but dear god, do yourself a favor and get the chicken wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: A must try if you want to try something new or if you like Thai food. The staff was great and the food was great. It got packed pretty quickly at lunch, so try to get there when they open.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Try Muu Paa Khan Waan and the Khao Soi. Honestly the best thai food I've had ever. Amazing service and the drinks were so good as well, the old fashioned was perfect!! Definitely gonna come back next time I'm in town.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Every dish was very delish! Tried four options and all had a very unique and authentic taste. Will definitely revisit when in town.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
If you're looking for pad Thai keep going; but if you are looking to eat the best REAL Thai food of your life this is the place to stop!
Try the hotwings!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
[Note, I was eating here with some kind of laryngitis. So some of my observations are tainted by this. I.E. the noise made it hard to talk to my dining mate, and I couldn't really judge the spiciness of the food accurately.]

We ate: 
Cha Ca La Vong (catfish) was spot on. Excellent balanced flavors. 

Tam Kai Yaang (chicken salad) I liked this a lot due to the diff. kinds of greens, but it was way spicy for my current state. 

Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings were tasty but came to us lukewarm, which meant by the time we came to picking up the last wing, it was stuck to the plate. Not attractive. 

We couldn't stop staring at the other tables and what people were ordering, especially the whole catfish special they had that night. The whole menu looks mouthwatering. Portionwise, 3 dishes was just right for the two of us, but I think the larger the group you have, the smaller the portions will seem, especially since it's family style. The drinks menu looked awesome, but sadly, I couldn't partake. 

This place looks fantastic (decor, design-wise) though eating inside might make you yearn for a little ventilation or air circulation. Noise levels were quite loud for such a small space. 

Service was fine, but not as attentive as other Portland spots I've been to. 

Pricewise, my friend and I ordered no drinks, 3 dishes and the bill w/ tip came out to around $22 each. A splurge for someone with my finances but definitely proportionate to the quality of food I think. 

Authentic or not, Pok Pok definitely worth a meal or two or more.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place was very good. The reservation process was a little confusing but, we figured it out. The food was great and the staff helped us when we had questions. My family all ordered different items and ate family style.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The chicken I had was plain and average. My friend had the catfish and she couldn't even eat it, the flavors were so strong it wasn't enjoyable. The service was below average.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
It was an interesting one of a kind dining experience, that's for sure. Unfortunately, I don't think I'll be going back- at least any time soon. 

When we first sat down, we were greeted by an absolutely repulsing smell that left us gagging and almost got us to leave. We ordered drinks when we first sat down that didn't arrive until the end of our meal.

On a happy note, I loved the voice of their menu and their coconut rice was SOOO good.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I went here on Valentine's Day at 8pm: the wait was 2 hours. I didn't wait. Came back a month later 30 minutes after it opened and still had to wait 20 minutes for a table. The point: You're going to have to wait. Luckily, they have a Whiskey Soda Lounge across the street you can wait at.

The food was good. I definitely wouldn't wait 2 hours for the food, but 20 minutes I can bear. Nothing to drool over but reasonably priced for what it is. HOWEVER, one thing I felt very gypped at was the sticky rice. Seriously a little lump of rice in a small weaved basket for $2.50. ARE YOU KIDDING ME! It should have automatically come with the meal. Skip the sticky rice, not needed, even if the waiter says so. Repeating previous Yelpers: chicken wings gooood. And if you ask for the Papaya Salad to be very spicy, they will not skimp on the spice.  Go, try, enjoy. Don't expect too much, but it's worth a visit - drinks were great too.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Over priced for the size of the portions but excellent food.
Not worth a 45 minute wait-simply too many great Thai restaurants in Portland, but still a really excellent place to eat!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Excellent. Once a food cart, this place renovated to a shack location (perhaps paying homage to their roots?), but it still has a really unique feel. It feels like a much more authentic luau vibe with excellent food. The wings were large, crispy, and tangy. The thai iced tea was large, sweet, and delicious. The pork skewers were covered with a yellow curry that I could eat on my own, and had the fatty bits of pork that were delicious. I would definitely come here again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Not sure if We just had a bad batch but the wings were overly salty. We were visiting Portland for the weekend. Read all the raving reviews on the chicken wings so thought although they are overpriced ($14+ for 6wings) we're on holiday so why not. Mom's Vietnamese fish sauce wings are 100x better. Pok Pok's were nicely cooked but so so salty...we had to order some sticky rice to help tame the saltiness...$2.50 for a handful of rice..Overall, cute place, but not worth the money in my opinion.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I was here years ago and just went last week, the fish sauce wings are still as amazing as they always were...which are basically mind blowing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Finally!! This was my first stop for yesterday's arrival into Portland.

I love how the restaurant itself is like a traditional Thai hut surrounded by trees, plants, etc. the music is Thai too which gives off a great vibe. The service is quick, efficient and friendly.

I went straight to Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings!! It's a half dozen set of sticky glazed large wings. Each bite was fantastic, I just had to close my eyes in between. The scent and texture is out of this world. I can't get enough of it! I ordered it spicy too, to provide some kick. The sauce is key and is one of my favorite sauce recipes on wings. The hype is real and is a must try! For $15 they should provide a small bowl of rice along with it! 

I didn't get to truth Thai teas or their vinegar soda so I do recommend people trying them!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Don't mess around. Get Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings. Thank me later. Some of the best wings that you'll get in the country. Hands down. The Khao Soi Neua was outstanding too. But don't play yourself. Get the wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We have been here twice before.  We look forward to coming here whenever we are visiting Portland. They open at 11:30 am and the place is already filling up.  Their fish sauce wings is our favorite.  It is so delicious!! ! We decided to try the pok pok chicken special and the papaya salad that came with it is so spicy but compliments well with the sweet and salty flavor of the chicken.  I had the khao soi curry noodles with chicken.  Since I have gluten intolerance, they substituted the egg noodle with rice noodle.  I enjoyed the noodles and wish I had it all on my own.  My hubby and I shared the dishes and were very satiated.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
When we asked people, "where would you recommend to eat?!" during our first visit to portland, Pok pok was a common answer. Sooo, we swung by on a Saturday night and there was a 1.5-2 hour wait for 2 ppl!  Thank the Thai gods for the take out window (15 min wait) :) 

You gotta try Ike's Vietnamese fish sauce wings!!! This was our favorite dish. We also tried the pok pok special - chicken was basic, sticky rice was good, and papaya salad was deceptively spicy (like jalapeno type of spice?), and the khao soi beef curry noodle soup- too sweet for me due to the coconut milk. 

Will definitely come back if I'm ever in Portland again bc of their extensive menu of so many things I know I would like!! -__-
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is SOOOOOOOOOOOO hyped up. I think of it more like a "look at me I'm cool bc I'm eating at Pok Pok" than a "I'm eating at Pok Pok  because it's so wonderful"  Overpriced as well.  I love SE and there are too many good places to drop $40-60 on rather than Pok Pok.  It's really, really, loud too and you actually have to scream to even talk.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Two words. Pokin' awesome. My second visit here and it was better than the first. We were smart to show up for Sunday lunch as it was easy to get in without a wait. The chicken wings, roasted chicken, porkbelly curry, shrimp vermicelli and beef curry noodle soup were all spectacular.  (I'm giving American terminology here as I wouldn't be able to remember the actual dish's native name on the menu!) ask your waiter to order you the top items and you'll be fine. I'll definitely be back when I'm back in Portland. I Pok'in heart this place. You will too.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Impressive. I was worried when my friend wanted to eat here that I wasn't going to enjoy my meal. i'm the type that worries about trying cuisines outside of my comfort zone. We shared a few dishes and I truly enjoyed myself.

Those Fish Sauce wings were absolutely amazing. That is what this place is popular for and it's so worth ordering. I wish I just had one order for myself. We tried 2 other things that I kind of force fed, but still liked. We also had the neua naam tok, it was on the spicy side, which was really hard for me! It's suggested to eat with an order of sticky rice. It is definitely easier to eat with the sticky rice. 

Enough about the food, I want to talk about the customer service. I was so satisfied on how we were treated. Initially we didn't make any type of reservation but the hostess told us it was a 15 minute wait, and we were seated earlier. That's a plus! Then when our server was here, he was so knowledgeable about the menu and the food. He made awesome suggestions, he told us what his favorites were, and he communicated really well. He warned me about the spices, he made me aware of what pairs well. It was a great experience!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I was really disappointed with my meal here. It was mediocre tasting and really expensive, plus there is always a wait. There is great Thai all over Portland. Don't blow your budget at this over-hyped restaurant.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Sometimes I am such a lazy Yelper.  It is also sad, because it makes me look like I am on a bandwagon instead of the trendsetter.  

I have been coming to Pok Pok since 2010 or 2011, all I know is that it was a while ago, but after I moved from Portland to the Bay Area.  One on the signature dishes is the Khao Man Som Tam.  A slow simmered pork butt in soy sauces with palm sugar.  It is served over coconut rice with a side of green papaya salad.  It was this dish that redefined the way I think of Thai food.  It was the reason I bought Andy's book.  It has also been replicated at home for a variety of friends and family, with each one being blown away by this dish. 

I am not sure there is anything more that I can add to the exist 5000+ reviews.  His Thai food empire stands on its own merit.  

What did I learn today?  I should reviewers them a long time ago well before there was even 1000 reviews.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Some of the best Thai I've had in Portland, I came here with the girlfriend after hearing a great deal about the quality of the food and was not disappointed. It is expensive, but I feel like I got what I paid for. I had the pork larb with a Lagavulin scotch, not a pairing I ever expected to have, but damn. It's open air and oddly reminiscent of the actual restaurants in Thailand, from the christmas lights to the warm water, my only (and minor) complaint.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: All I can say is if the line is out the door and down the sidewalk it is a good lace to eat and Pok Pok is definitely a good place to eat. The food is amazing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok was one of those restaurants that I had read about and looked forward to trying, but was disappointed after my meal. Ordering dishes people raved about on Yelp, I had to conclude that maybe people in Portlandia, who have a Thai restaurant on every corner, have a different idea of Thai food. Here's the run down:

Complimentary peanuts flavored with fried kefir lime leaves - my favorite
Fish Sauce Wings - salty
Sticky Rice - good
Pork Belly/Pork Shoulder Stew - not melt in your mouth; c'mon I could do better
Boar Collar - disappointing, spicy and too dry; comes with greens under ice to cool your mouth

There were other items that I could have ordered and I wish I had because the meal I had was disappointing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Confession:  I had no idea what Thai food was beyond pad thai and curry.  I'm sure that's the equivalent, in my world, of spaghetti and meatballs and chicken alfredo (which doesn't actually exist in Italy).  But Pok Pok, thank you for opening my eyes to a breadth of genuine flavors and dishes from this delicious country!  If this is what it really is, sign me up!

However, I am still, very clearly, a complete novice and therefore do not pretend to understand the complexities of this cuisine.  Thus, my commentary will be, probably to the relief of some, limited.  :)  I'll do the best I can, but hopefully the pictures of this beautiful food will be enough to make your mouth water.

I think this first one was my fave.  Prawns and pork belly baked in clay pot with bean thread noodles and a bunch of other delicious salty stuff.  Mmmmm... sticky and rich.
 
It was so good I made my photographer get a shot of the sticky stuff on the bottom.  I went in for the scrap.  I probably shouldn't have; I was bloated for 2 days.  Nah... it was worth it.
 
The Vietnamese fish sauce chicken wings are a house specialty.  Marinated in a fish sauce concoction, deep fried then tossed in said fish sauce concoction with garlic.  Um, ok.  I'd take these at a bar with a beer any day.
 
Charcoal grilled prawns with a spicy lime/garlic/cilantro root dipping sauce.  I managed to miss tasting this one but wasn't disappointed about it.  If I had to miss one, this was it because it was the most understandable to me.  I like to get my hands in the weird stuff.
 
Weird stuff like this: grilled boar collar meat.  Marinated and sauced.  Served with chilled mustard greens that were to be used as a chaser.  I'm not exactly sure what the whole concept is there.  I guess I could see it if it were more spicy but it wasn't super hot.  Maybe it's just tradition?  Regardless, the meat was wonderful.
 
Sauteed water spinach with garlic.  I always go for the greens.  They were simple, fresh and light.  Nothin' too special... just good, yummy greens.
 
Bean thread noodles' competition:  Braised pork shoulder and belly curry with a bunch of crazy stuff like tamarind, palm sugar, turmeric, Burmese curry powder (whatever that is) and pickled garlic.  It was suggested that we eat this one with coconut rice (unpictured).  Good suggestion.
 
Clearly the place is very casual.  Here's the specials board.  Notice the 'drinking vinegars' in the bottom left corner.  They're mixed into some wonderfully interesting cocktails.  They also have a massive list of whiskeys.  Thailand, I think you and I are going to get along just fine...
 
Apparently the place started as just a little shack with very few menu items, including the rotisserie chicken.  It's been expanding little by little.  There's lots of cool, sectioned patio spaces in which to eat and drink.  The indoor space is teensy... like, I could have rested my head on the lady sitting at the table behind me.
 
As for the service, it was pretty slow.  It seemed like the staff was so laid back (maybe that's just a Portland thing) and they all know that they have such a great reputation that everyone will just wait.  And we did.  Our server was very knowledgable and quite helpful, though.  We couldn't have done it without him.  Plus, he's the one that suggested the bean thread noodles so he's good in my book!
 
The Short Version (Out of 10)...
Food:  9
Service:  7
Ambiance:  8
Overall impression:  9
Would I go back?
For sure!  And I'd try all new things.  I'm pretty sure everything they do here is interesting and wonderful.
*Full review with photos on my blog.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Ok this place is insane busy.  We were tourists.  My friend managed to book a dinner reservation but its crazy how often the store manager called to confirmed that we would show up.  Even though he would charge a fee on my friend's credit card if we didn't show up. 

Anyway the foods were different than the usual Thai dishes I have had.  They were good and tasty.  Service was good.  The place was crowded but its a bit less noisy upstairs.  

Overall I don't know if its worth the wait or effort.  The foods are good but without a reservation I won't bother waiting in line for hours.  There are many good restaurants out there.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Not more I can say that hasn't already been said about Pok Pok. The wings are next level out of this world f*ck you up good. No question, you must get them "spicy". They're not at all too hot but the chili flakes add a depth of flavor you'd be literally insane to avoid. As far as the rest of the menu: impossible to go wrong. We had the pork belly curry, jasmine rice and the cod salad that comes with a beautiful side of herbs to eat with the fish salad. The menu is full of annotations that help those of us least versed in authentic Thai - the staff is always great for recommendations which they offer with a genuine and resigned kindness (I wanted to apologize and ask our very friendly server "how many white girls have mispronounced this same menu item to your face today?" but abstained). Love it. Would go every visit to Portland if not for the wait but, who can blame them for killing it so hard everyone wants to go all the time?
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I wish famous BBQed fish-sauce TOFU was an authentic thai specialty. this place would probably be my favorite restaurant if i ate meat.

but i do eat fish, so i have to recommend the catfish entree i got. it rocked. the Papaya Salad was THE BEST ive ever had. my partner LOVED the sauteed beef salad with lemongrass and mint. 

this place completely rocks because they press their own coconut milk and sugar cane juice (for the drinks) - which by the way are wonderful too. 

i love the ambiance. like others have said, it seems like a real Chiang Mai market in the evening - except nicer. somehow the decor does seem to take you to a place far away. 

some reviewers seemed to think there was too much attitude - i think whatever they have going on is PERFECT - i dont think it would have the appeal if the wait staff was up in your business like a fancy French restaurant. the laid-back, non-chalant vibe of the servers completely makes this place.

i dont need to say more about it - since it won one of the top 10 best restaurants of 2007 in portland monthly magazine. 

i cant wait to go back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Very overrated. The food was good but lacked vegetables and spices. If my parents took me to Pok Pok when I was a kid and only liked very bland meat and rice, I probably would have though this was the best restaurant ever. I was expecting much more. Long waits, very noisy, lukewarm food, and pretty pricey for what you get. Next time I'm in the area I'm going to try the Thai restaurant across the street.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok was one of the places I was most looking to check out while in Portland ... unfortunately, it turned out to be the most disappointing.

To be fair, I'd say the execution of the dishes was quite good ... I just clearly ordered the wrong things.  While the flavoring of the Ike's Vietnamese fish sauce wings was quite nice, I feel like top places in SF that serve similar Asian-style chicken are just as good.  Prefer the small bite size wing-size portions elsewhere rather than the whole wing that they serve here.

The Sii Khrong Muu Yaang (baby back ribs) did not look appetizing at all to me as the ribs were cut in pieces so that you see a cross-section of what you're eating (bones, meat, fat, and what looked like fur (?!).

By default, my favorite was the Phat Si Ew which honestly, Ive had better elsewhere.

It was nice that there was absolutely no line on a Sat afternoon ... but not sure that I'd come back, especially if there is typically a long wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: You can get whatever Thai food anywhere or you can get Pok Pok. It is Thailand, Portland, quality, enjoyability, and affordability. If you are not good with the cold, sit inside, but make sure you can get a seat otherwise you will wait outside anyway and you might as well eat.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Waited here for 70 min to get in...only because we had driven from Seattle for a weekend trip and we wouldn't be back soon..Had their boar collar meat dish which I found to be the tastiest dish there...it was nice and spicy. The roast chicken was alright along with clay pot with shrimp and pork belly...The food was average and nothing stood out for except for the long wait....also, the dishes were expensive and they seemed almost like small plates instead of entrees...and the price of rice was outrageous for this Asian girl...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I lived in Thailand for several years, and came back to the States before there were two dozen Thai restaurants in every city: so I took the time starting right then to learn to cook the food. My standards are very, very high. I love Thai food. I have Thai family that cook the old fashioned way that I cook and eat with.  A few weeks ago, I had an opportunity to go to Portland on business. We were celebrating at work, Pok Pok catered. The food was good. That night I met up with a favorite cousin and we went there for dinner: the food was *outstanding*. (For the record, we had Ike's Wings, the Papaya with salted crab, the Yam Makheua Yao, the duck Laab, and the Kaeng Hang Leh.) I may be as passionate about this food as Chef Ricker -- I'll say it again: outstanding. Thank you, Andy, for what you do. Keep exploring!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I'm sorry but this place is overrated.  The only good food here is their very pricey chicken wings.  Don't come here hungry and expect a big portions of food.  The portions was so small we had to order same dish twice.  The two star is for the wonderful service.  I've tasted better Thai food here in the Bay Area for much cheaper price.  Expect to pay an arm and a leg to eat here.  Take public transit because the area is busy.  For a party of 8 our bill was $250.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Overrated.
Sure, there's a wait but that's not the problem.
Sure, it's in a sweet neighborhood, but that doesn't make it any better.
The food is NOT good. I have friends raving about this place....I have tried multiple times to like it but it's just overpriced with Portlanders that think they're "hit" and they don't even realize what they are missing- real thai food. Actually, they are all missing good thai food period. Go elsewhere. Don't bother getting ripped off.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I went here thinking Thai food, lots of pasts right... nope.  I was surprised by the menu and delighted with everything that we ordered.  I went with a few other people and we shared everything.  I really enjoyed the green curry crab special.  They change up there menu, but you will always find something really good to eat.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I came here with a large group last week. Food was ok, but it's one of those restaurants you have to visit if you're in town. Two friends recommended this place, I'm still wondering why. 
Food was too salty. The wings are too salty and heavily seasoned with fish sauce. Larb was also too salty. Papaya salad was just ok.
Service was a little rude. The guy who took our order seemed a little annoyed but that's understandable. My hearing is pretty bad so I had a hard time making out what he was trying to say. The waiter who brought out our food was a jerk. He brought out wings and I asked if it was the spicy one or not since our table had ordered three plates. The waiter paused and says "this is the wings... this is the hot wings..." Finally the bus boy had the table hand down the dirty plates. My friend made a comment that we're not going to order desserts so they can clean the table after we leave. His rebuttal was to get a head start. However we were the last table of the night... I was concerned that with all the dirty plates being passed down that there was a good chance that something might spill. And it did onto me and my white pants, luckily it was just a cup of water. I won't recommend this restaurant to friends. There are better thai restaurants where we are from.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
OH. MY. STARS.

I think this is maybe my 3rd 5-star review? Yea. This place is amazing.

Drinks were good and strong. Food was so good. We got the fish sauce wings, fried egg salad, and stuffed game hen. Then the coconut ice cream sandwich dessert. We ate every last crumb. The wait might be crazy at times, but it wasn't too bad when we were there. I think we probably ended up waiting for 30 min on a late Saturday afternoon (maybe 2:30, labor day weekend) but we got some drinks while we were waiting and the weather was perfect.

The place itself was super cute with seating inside and outside. The outside part feels more like a street food park and the inside feels like a trendier restaurant. I don't know, this description sucks.

TL;DR - Get the wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Service was great! Thai iced tea with milk worth a try. I got the pork skewers with coconut rice which I would get again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Expensive, but worthed! Chicken wings!!!! I can eat those every day
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I was in there yesterday and this young punk took my order. I could just tell that he has a problem in life. This punk had the audacity, to ID me when I ordered my drink. I'm 55, for Pete's sake. 

Their food? Less than okay. I ordered some chicken and expected it to taste like chicken, but coincidentally it did not. I could not believe how dry it was. It tasted like someone took a leather boot and served it to me with a side of catcher's mitt. 

The ambiance? Racist. I just want to be a little honest here. 

The drink? Bitter.

Next time, I'll just go across the street and have a delicious meal at Whiskey Soda Lounge and I recommend that you do the same.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
As many people know, this place is super popular.  it has been featured on many television specials so it's garnered a big following.  My husband and another couple were in town for an exhibit and decided to go see what the "hype" was about.  The other couple had been there before but they were down.  The place is small but the vibe is pretty cool.  Some semi outdoor seating for the large groups and about 10 tables inside.  The inside portion feels a little cramped but it works.  I ordered a fried egg salad (I thought it might be some sort of sandwich) and my husband ordered a pork belly and pork shoulder stew.  The other couple shared the skewers (chicken I believe) and a bean salad.  We additionally ordered the spicy pok pok wings and a non-spicy version.  Since this is the popular menu item, I definitely wanted to try the wings.  

The dishes are mostly for sharing and not a full entree.  My husband was greatly disappointed in that but...Overall, the food was just ok for me.  The spicy wings were not spicy and we got hot sauce for them.  My salad was pretty good with the vinaigrette but not amazing.  My husband's dish was good but he just thought it was standard.  He ordered some coconut rice to make it a fuller dish but he still wasn't impressed.  My salted plum cocktail was really good but this was not enough for me to go back for another experience.  How is Pok Pok so popular?  I don't know.  For me, it was more of a forgettable experience.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Overrated is the first word that comes to mind, second is dry.  dry boring meat with good sauces.  The wings were great but that was about it.  and the waiter was a bit annoying.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I've heard so much about this restaurant that I had to try it, finally. Disappointed.
This is Bar food. Small plates (tapas style), mostly spicy, would go well with the alcoholic concotions here. But if you're not drinking to while away a two-hour dinner wait (really), you might opt for take-out, as we did. However, without the libations, the bill might smart a bit more, and your food will taste more like a neighborhood Thai joint, only less yummy, imo, than like the award-winning restaurant we had looked forward to. So-so, not bad. Drinking a fair amount would help.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I think I would have enjoyed the food more if I didn't eat vegetarian. Oh well. The biggest letdown was the fella got a big metal staple in one of his bites. Luckily he wasn't hurt, but when we let the waiter know, his response was a hurried "Oh sorry, yeah it happens". They took it off the bill, but it was just super weird that they didn't think a sharp object in our food was a big deal...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Stopped by for lunch and, since I was alone, I sat at the counter just inside the entrance. The waitperson came by shortly thereafter and I ordered a draft beer, which took a little longer to arrive than expected but was welcoming and ice cold when it arrived, served with spicy roasted peanuts. I ordered the chicken sate (or whatever it was called here - it was broiled chicken skewers with peanut sauce at any rate) with a side of steamed jasmine rice. It was served with a cucumber/green pepper/onion salad so infused with jalapeno that I literally couldn't eat it for the heat. I have no quibble with the meal, as it was perfectly tasty for what it was, but the price for a lunch-sized entree that seemed more like an appetizer, plus a pint of beer, came to over $20.00 before tip! Not what I would call an affordable lunch option! 

While getting up to leave, I turned around and noticed a blackboard above the tables behind me advertising the daily specials. Y'know, some of them looked pretty good. Don't you think it would have been nice if my server had pointed them out to me before I ordered? Yeah, I think so too. 

Overall, I'd be OK with trying this place again with a large group so we could share entrees and thoughts about them, since I suspect that's the real intention here. And it is a very cool set-up with the tents and the open air and the metal roof. But, as a single diner, I would have been far better off for lunch at a family owned strip mall Thai or Indian restaurant, where I would have been served pretty much the same thing for easily half the price. I come to a restaurant more for the food than the ambiance and in this case, sorry, it fell pretty short.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Be prepared to wait in line during dinner hours!

[WAIT TIME]
This place doesn't take reservations for parties under 6, so expect to wait a while to be seated. I'm assuming this place is even more popular than it once was because it was featured on Food Network. When I arrived around 6:30PM on a Friday night, the wait was about 30 minutes. When I walked past the entrance to use the restroom, I heard that the wait time was around 1 hour.

[SERVICE]
Our server asked if it was our first time and broke down the menu for us since there's so much going on. He gave us the recommended dishes along with the most popular items on the menu. Once we were ready to order and the food came out, he recommended how we should eat the food to enhance our dining experience and continued to check up on us throughout the meal. Five stars for service!

[FOOD]
- Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings - (5/5) These wings were a must try because they were featured on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives! We ordered one order spicy and the other order non-spicy. The spicy ones were definitely my favorite item on the menu! A great blend of sweet and spicy, and the perfect seasoning! 

- Muu Paa Kham Waan - (4/5) Boar collar meat, something I've never had before! This is an incredibly spicy dish, so eat with caution! Our server recommended pairing this with sticky rice. Because this dish is so spicy it comes with chilled vegetables for you to cleanse your palate. Very tender and full of flavor!

- Kaang Hang Leh - (4.5/5) Sweet pork belly and pork shoulder curry. This dish is exactly like a Taiwanese braised pork belly dish, but with different flavors and seasoning. I enjoyed this dish a lot with rice. The curry was a little runny and the dish was very sweet for a savory dish, but still incredibly delicious!

*Note: These dishes did not come with rice, so be sure to get some rice along with your order. 

Not sure if I can call this an authentic Thai restaurant, but it's an interesting dining experience and I would definitely recommend it to anyone visiting Portland!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Man did we have a feast here! We were ready for a long wait but were seated after about 10-15 mins. 

My friend and I shared an order of their famous spicy fish sauce wings, the khao soi with chicken and the pork belly curry (Kaeng Hang Leh). I was honestly impressed with everything! My mouth was just bursting with flavor! The pork belly curry and the khao soi are both wonderful rainy day choices.  The pork belly was so tender and such a wonderful mix of flavors and spices. The curry seemed slightly more like a stew, to be honest, but that's not necessarily a problem.  The khao soi was more subtle in flavor but very satisfying; so soothing and comforting!

Our favorite by far were the Spicy Viet Fish Sauce Wings.  So perfectly made! Beautifully crispy without being too fried. And so tender and juicy.  I will say that our wings were not spicy in the least! Both my friend and I love spicy food so we were definitely expecting more kick to them. They did bring some chili paste. But it wasn't that spicy either; we had to keep asking for more! This wasn't the biggest deal as everything was still delicious, but maybe there should be some levels of spice?

Definitely one of our favorite meals from our Portland trip!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Arrived here on a Tuesday around 4pm. There was no wait and we were seated immediately. I give service 4/5 stars for this experience but 2/5 for the food. 

Chicken wings $16 
For six wings and a side of chopped cabbage/carrots. Since it was the highlight of most Yelp reviews, it was a must try. However it was a big disappointment. Whomever was the chef that day added an extreme amount of fish sauce. I split this plate with a friend and we tried to finish since it was pretty pricey but could not because it was so salty. 

Papaya salad
This plate was average compared to prior experience from 3 stars Thai restaurants. It was quite small since there was an entire half cabbage when you get to the bottom. 

Overall, this place is just a hyped up business. Many locals claim that the quality of food decreased over time since they are riding on their reputation and have been putting less effort in making great food. Unfortunately I should have listened to the locals and I would not visit this place again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
It is impossible to overpraise my experience at Pok Pok.  Yes, yes, the wait is long, and the crowds trendy.  But who cares?  It's the food that matters, and Pok Pok delivers.  The dishes we shared were creative and unpredictable and delicious.  The famous wings are a must have, of course, but do try to delve a little deeper into the menu - you'll be gratified.  

The service was excellent as well and the atmosphere fitting to a restaurant serving a twist on asian street food.  

If you really can't wait, go kitty-corner across the street to the Whisky Soda Lounge to enjoy some of the smaller items on Pok Pok's menu.  And have a vietnamese coffee.  They're amazing.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This restaurant is extremely popular and we had to wait 90 minutes to be seated so for that reason alone I am giving it 4 stars. However, the service was excellent and the food was great. I ordered the baby back ribs and a Thai dish with coconut rice and steak. The Thai dish was a little spicy, but still tasty.  One of my friends is vegan and another one is gluten free and the waitress was very accommodating and great about suggesting dishes that fit within their dietary restrictions. Everyone was happy with their meal so all in all I would recommend this restaurant for groups with diverse tastes.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: They refuse to take reservations for the same day of service. And don't even try to call and ask if they can make an exception. Reservations cannot be made over the phone. Perhaps they are popular enough to set the terms on which they provide good service, but that attitude really rubs me the wrong way.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Everyone who cares about food in Portland has heard of this place and knows it's fantastic.  As a Pok Pok fan and someone who has been there multiple times, I would like to share what I feel are by far the best dishes on the menu.  

If you haven't been or haven't tried these dishes please let me recommend the following:

Papaya Pok Pok (their signature salad, crunchy, refreshing, flavorful and wicked spicy)

Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings (spicy, sweet, amazing, everyone loves them including me who dislikes basically all other chicken wing preparations)

Kuung Op Wun Sen (clay pot with pork belly on the bottom, noodles and prawns, very flavorful and comforting - probably my favorite dish)

Muu Paa Kham Waan (spicy boar collar, so hot and so tasty, my friends and i usually use sticky rice to wipe up every bit of sauce after the boar is done)

None of the above dishes will steer you wrong, I've eaten them with multiple people over several years and they've always been crowd pleasers. The cocktails here are also amazing the salted plum collins (sweet, salty and citrusy) and the thai bloody mary (spicy with thai basil) are my two favorites, but I think all of them would be worth a try.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place was simply the best food experience I have had in Portland and that is saying a lot!  I love the food in Portland.  I love it so much that I will name 50lbs of my total body weight after this city.

Pok Pok is the best Thai food I have ever had and I have traveled the world as a foodie for the Air Force.

The chicken wing appetizer was insanely good.  I ate a bite and the skys opened up and God reached down to try a bite.

The service was awesome and there was no line as we ate there at around 11:30 on a Friday lunch.

The other meals names escape me but all were just so amazing and so many flavors that my instinct was to get another meal to go for that night's dinner! 

I crave it now like a hobo craves a 40 oz of cheap booze....
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I think what I enjoyed most about Pok Pok was not that they serve dishes that are different and unlike dishes that I have had many times at other Asian restaurants near and far but rather the flavor profiles of their selections were different and unique making Pok Pok stand out. My cocktail "Hunny" created with fresh grapefruit juice with lime, Som honey drinking vinegar and tequila served up was just great!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place takes a while to get in. You wait in line for about 45min till they call your name.  
Once in.  The food took a while to come out at this point my little gut was going to eat the big gut. .  When the food arrived the wings were salty and full of MSG my fingers started to swell.  The papaya salad .  I've had better elsewhere and at this point i would have gave Taco Bell a better rating. 

Ps: I don't eat Taco Bell or fast food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We went with a group and allowed our server to order for us and it was unbelievably good.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Consistently good Thai food and great wings. This place is always busy and can get quite crowded every night of the week. Get there early.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: this place lives up to the hype - incredible thai-fusion small plates (and some fullsize entrees).  pricey, but worth it.  do prepare to be crowded like sardines and unless it's miserable out, you'll likely wait for awhile to be seated.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm not one to wait but, if I must, I would wait for a table at Pok Pok at least once a year. Exceptional cuisine, decent-knowledgeable service, reasonable pricing. The main drawback is THE WAIT and they do not take reservations. 
Sure you can eat their delicious chicken wings and drink a tasty gourmet vinegar mixed refreshment and rack up your tab before the main meal event (kind of the point of their Whiskey Lounge annex across the street) but some of us just want to get down to business. 
Also, be forewarned: Only the cool kids eat here. You must dress and act the part.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I came with three of my girlfriends for a night out and this place was pretty good! I'd say the service was good- our waiter was attentive to us and didn't keep us waiting too long. We ordered four dishes with two sides of rice and we felt a bit hungry still afterwards which isn't the best feeling to have after eating dinner. Truth be told, the waiter did suggest we order five dishes but the dishes are on the pricier side so that made it a little difficult for us to order another dish. We ordered the famous chicken wings which were really good but a little salty for all of us. I would recommend the pork shoulder and pork belly dish though!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The fish sauce chicken wangs knocked my socks off!!! Prob the best Thai food I've had since I was last in Chiangmai. I shall be back! With stretchy pants!! 

This was totally unexpected during our last trip to Portland. Seriously, hats off to the chef here!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I would give this place a 4 for the food, a 2 1/2 for the service, so I concluded a 3 sounded fair. I had the lunch special here. The chicken was yummy, LOVED the green papaya salad and the sticky rice. They also had some spicy sauces to accompany--Hooray!
We came here on a week day for lunch. It was super busy, so we expected a wait. It took quite a bit longer than the hostess quoted, with several other parties being seated before us. Finally were seated on the "porch" on the second floor. The waiter was friendly, but I think we were a bit out of the way. Everyone enjoyed their food though.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Food was ok. We had the chicken curry soup & one of the specials. Authentic but everything tasted a bit bland. Don't order the house red wine! It tasted more like watered down cranberry juice then wine.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I brought my parents here for dinner, we asked the waiter gave us some advice. With his help, we ordered 4 dishes, 3 of them were all chicken. I think most of places' waiters would kindly remind their costumes that they already had such as chicken or beef. And he just stopped once for asking. 

Chicken wings were just alright, ours still having red spots near the bones; chicken curry soup, it looks better than tastes; half chicken special dish, chicken itself not worth 20 bucks, the side dish is even worse; the wrapping pork is pretty tasty.

All in all, it was a horrible experience.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Came here on a weekday right when it opened for lunch. No line!

The wings were delicious as expected but I probably wouldn't have waited over an hour for it. The vibe and decor definitely reminds me of Thailand.....but then you step outside on SE Division street, see Salt and Straw nearby, and you snap back to reality.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I finally got to go here, after about 10 years of anticipation. It lived up to everything!  All the food was great, and we had a wonderful waiter who really made it an even better experience. If you go at an odd time - like 8:30 Sunday evening - it's not that long a wait.  We barely had time to finish our drinks across the street before we were called.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Heard great things about Pok Pok from many friends and coworkers, and this place did not disappoint. The only downside is the wait time since they don't take reservations, which was 150-180 minutes once we arrived. We were set on going so we headed over to the Whiskey Soda Lounge (sister restaurant/bar).

Based on reviews, we had to try as much as possible to get our Thai fix. The spicy wings (we ordered both the original and spicy) were the absolute best wings I've had. I considered getting them for a main dish as well. They were that good. The wings alone are worth the wait and the hype you've heard.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We were a group of 5 on a Friday night. The wait time was not too bad. We had a 15 minute wait time when we walked in by 9.30 ish. The food here was really good and the service too. I am a vegetarian and I had the khao soi. It was a tofu noodle soup. The broth in the soup tasted really good. Overall a nice place.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: HOLY CRAP! Delicious!! Every bite I said "WOW!" So tasty! Love the small intimate setting! Service was exceptional! Thank you!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Generally, I liked my experience at Pok Pok but I probably feel more positively towards it since I didn't have to wait at all (around 2:30pm on a rainy Sunday afternoon). Our party of 3 was seated right away. We asked for recommendations from our waiter and took him up on the fish sauce wings (very good, crispy, and flavorful) and the shrimp/pork noodle dish (rather bland and disappointing). Our waiter sold us on two orders of sticky rice as well which weren't that helpful to quell the spicyness from the ultra spicy papaya salad. We also ordered the steak salad and mushroom salad not realizing they were going to have the exact same flavor except one mushroom, one steak. They were a tad too vinegary for my taste and really expensive (~$16) for what turned out to be very small dishes. I don't know that I'd be back to Pok Pok but it was nice to try. I'd reorder the wings and surprisingly delightful pineapple som (drinking vinegar).
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place lives up to the hype.  I was afraid the chicken wings would be over-rated, but they actually exceeded my expectations.  Next time, I will have to order it spicy.  It goes perfectly with a side of coconut rice.

The papaya salad was the best I have ever had.  Fresh, lots of flavor and complex.  Even the Thai iced tea was unique.  They use two different teas to give it a subtle herbal undertone.  

Perhaps I am not as disgruntled as other Yelpers b/c we went during off-peak hours and didn't have to wait at all.  If I had to wait 1-3 hrs for a seat, I don't think I'd be giving this place 5 stars.  For now, I plan to stop by this place any time I am in Portland, and I'll plan to go off-peak for sure.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
After many missed opportunities, I was finally able to try Pok Pok's fusion style Thai cuisine for myself. On this humid weeknight, there was over an hour wait so we headed across the street to wait at their sister bar, Whiskey Soda Lounge. I love the neighbourhood with tons of surrounding restaurant, bars, and homes. The restaurant itself is a converted house with an intimate bar, dining area, and outdoor patio lounge.

Onto Ike's vietnamese fish sauce chicken wings marinated nicely and available spicy (or regular). I've heard mixed things recently but enjoyed the wings satisfyingly, despite a little saltiness. I see what all the hubbub is about yet still couldn't help feeling slightly underwhelmed.

We ordered a host of other dishes including Kaeng Hang Leh (Northern Thai sweet pork belly/shoulder with ginger, palm sugar, and turmeric), Kung Op Wun Sen (prawns baked in a clay pot over charcoal with pork belly, lao jiin, soy ginger, and noodles), and Pet Pha Lo (Thai style stewed duck leg in five spice soy broth). All were fairly solid and an interesting Thai/Pan-Asian fusion style mix with western influences. 

We washed everything down with some Vietnamese coffees, cha yen (Thai iced tea with condensed milk), and whiskey soda float.

I was more than satisfied with the overall dining experience and family style dinner at Pok Pok. The service was great and the menu selection was eclectic and tasty. Everything was enjoyed with a trio of rices flavours, coconut, jasmine, and sticky. Pok, pok.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Top notch joint. Was in Portland for business. Wanted to get something a bit left of center. Pok Pok 100% delivered. Roasted game hen for a starter, fish sauce wings & boar collar for entrees. The boar and the wings were outstanding. Both were very spicy.

Would definitely return.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: More like a 3.5 star. Of course visiting Portland for the first time, and staying so close, I had to check it out. And I'm Thai. I ordered the classic -- Grilled Chicken with somtum and sticky rice. I was impressed with the chicken. Usually, I find most Thai restaurants have a problem with the chicken being too dry. Pok Pok go the chicken part right. The somtum was also not bad. It's hard to please every palate where the somtum is concern because everyone has their own preference. In Thailand, if you order somtum, the person making it usually will ask you how you like it. So, each somtum is customized to the individual. For example, you might say 2 or 3 chilis, not too sweet nor too sour, etc. The papaya could have been pounded a bit more though. You want to sort of smash the strands down and get all the seasonings to blend in well together. But overall not bad. I don't know if it was worth the major hype, but it was not bad. Unfortunately, since I was by myself I couldn't order other dishes that I was interested in. I liked the atmosphere of the place. Reminded me of hole in the wall places in Thailand. I thought it was funny that most of the wait staff were all 'farang' (white westerners). I'm use to most Thai restaurants having Thai wait staff. Not necessarily a bad thing. Just noting the difference from what I'm use to seeing ..... and also this seems to be a Portland thing. I went into a Japanese place down the street on a different night, and also the staff -- cooks, waiters etc. -- were all farangs too!!  And they were yelling out the Welcome in Japanese at all the people entering the place!  (This is messing with my head yo! Lol!)  And this being Portland, I also noted the vinegar drink on the board and craft brews. Even in a Thai place, you're still getting that Portland twist to it. (This town is so endearing.)  If you don't have to wait long, go try it for sure. Why not. I didn't have to wait at all as I was by myself.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
If you like chicken, you will LOVE the Ike's Wings.  The brussel sprout dish was really good, but I was not so impressed with the ribs.  We also ordered the sausage dish with sticky rice, and it was a different flavor but definitely tasty and unique.  The waiter provided good recommendations on the popular dishes, and we also went off of what we had enjoyed at other places.  

There was a group of 6 adults, and 3 kids (21mos, 8yr, 10yr) and the older kids enjoyed it, but it seemed to be more of a place for adult groups, large or small.  We were seated outside in the heated tent and it was ambient but also hard to read the menu, thank goodness for cell phone lights.  

Overall, if a friend of mine was asking me if they should go, I would recommend to call in the order for take out (if they allow it) because the slowwwww service and not so accommodating service just made the whole experience less "Wow" which was what we were expecting.  The food, is very authentic and tasty from what I had.  Call ahead and make reservations, and plan to take your time dining, or get it to go.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Our 4-top included the wife and our 2 college-age children. Waitstaff quickly synopsized the dining custom of the restaurant as family style and recommended we order 4-5 dishes. The standout dish definitely was the vermicelli with pork belly and shrimp, which we all wished there was more. The surprise was the papaya salad, which we were forewarned would be hot, and it was, delightfully so.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I haven't ventured much beyond their most popular dishes (fish sauce chicken wings, delicious mango sour & this smashed & spiced beef thing w/ sticky rice), but this place is absolutely tops! I've actually eaten more at sister bar Whiskey Soda because of the long waits at Pok Pok. Regardless the food & drinks are excellent!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Mmmm one of the best thai restaurants that I've ever been to! It's not like the Thai restaurants in Cali, it's better! I don't remember exactly what the names were for the foods that I ordered, but they were all very yummy! The chicken wings were kind of salty but as long as you order some rice with it, it should be fine! My favorite was the papaya salad and the boar collar(?). Sooooo delicious! 

I heard it gets pretty packed and people wait for up to 2 hours to eat here... Luckily I got here at 3 and there was no wait!! So, if you're ever planning on eating here, definitely go at 3. We left at around 4:30 and it was packed... Not sure if there was a line but there sure weren't any empty seats.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: VIETNAMESE CHICKEN WINGS! Yaaaaaas! I love it! I am Vietnamese so I am proud that these wings are sooo good! Love em! This is all I get here and this is all I want to get here! One other things I really enjoy here is the free water! It is one of the best free waters in the game of restaurants. There is a hint of coconut flavor in the water. One of the must place to go when your in Portland!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
If you're planning on going to Pok Pok, give yourself a good hour to wait for a table. I'd even recommending going in an hour early and putting yourself on the list before doing some other pre-planned activity until a table is ready. Pretty much the biggest downside of this place.

Once you're in, you'll find it's worth the wait. After taking a few bites of the eggplant dish and vegetarian soup, I began wondering why other Thai restaurants don't season food as effectively. It's a new experience if you're used to the pad thai and yellow curry of most Thai restaurants, at least that's my experience. I was happy with the service once I got inside, but man I hate waiting in line!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Overrated and expensive. 

I recently visited Portland and had so many people who recommended this place so my sister and I decided to give it a try. 
|Food|
We went ahead and ordered the Ike's Vietnamese Fish as everyone had good things to say about it. We also ordered a bowl of jasmine rice and a papaya salad.

Food came out really fast. The papaya salad was good and pretty authentic. We got spicy and it wasn't that spicy. And on to the wings... It was SO salty. Do the chefs not know it's so salty? It seems like all the reviews i've read have mentioned about the wings being too salty. It's definitely too salty to enjoy in my opinion.  The flavor was ok. I do taste the fish sauce and it is mild and not overpowering, but just toooooooooooo salty. Also with the spice levels, it was not spicy at all. I do believe the "spicy" tolerance of people around here are different. The wings are so overrated in my opinion and SOOO overpriced. Six wings for $15.75.. are you serious? What makes these wings worth this much? It was so disappointed. My sister and I were not able to enjoy the food nor was able to finish it. 

I seriously believe the wings are placed at a higher price point because of the attention it gets. No matter how high the price will be, curious people like myself will still try it because of the hype. Please save yourself $16.

|Service|
Eh. We were ignored most of the times during dinner. I get that it was getting busy when we were there, but the server literally made eye contact with me and walked away. 

|Parking|
Street parking only.

|Overall|
I do not recommend.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I was expecting quite a bit from Pok Pok after the 1+ hour wait, but we were disappointed due to the following:
1) Indoor seating was a 2 hour wait, so we opted for outdoor seating which was not very warm, even with heat lamps. They were running low on gas so they were trying to ration our heat...not ideal unless you like shivering while eating your wings!
2) They charge you for rice and the rice portions are super small...the sticky rice portion for $2 could fit in the palm of my hand
3) The highlight was Ike's chicken wings, but the other 5 dishes we ordered were ho-hum. Nothing we would be willing to stand in line for and freeze for again.
4) On a positive note, the flavors were different than your average SE Asian restaurant and the offerings were not run-of-the-mill. (That said, we will be opting for the traditional Thai offerings at other locations from now on!)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The best thing about our day in Portland, hands down! The food, drink and service were all top notch!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Amazing food. Totally different from your usual menu of pad thai or pad seew with their mixes of curries, soups, salads and other dishes.
Fish sauce wings are a must try.
Unique, flavorful, if you are a fan of southeast Asian food this is a must try.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Good food, good service.  The coconut flavored water was weird, but overall a good experience.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
there it was.  the moment and a chance to eat at pok pok, and not have to wait in line.   there was no one there, lots of tables open, and that chance?   ruined.

is this place huge in the back?  is there another dining room that is so packed that they can't handle?  or is it that they have only three tables seated, from what I can see, and many clean tables set and ready to go, and yet I have to wait?   Do you TRY to cause a line so that you look super busy?  I dunno.   but I work in a restaurant, and am a hostess, and this is not the kind of behavior I would portray on ANY day.  IF I were busy?  I wouldn't mind seating a deuce, cause they move so quickly.  either way?   seems to me?  no one here, and you don't want to serve us.   fact is?  you make many people stand in line.   and yet?  there are plenty of tables open.   

we looked at the menu.   we looked at the prices, and we looked at each other.   In a city with as many thai and vietnamese?   why am I waiting to get into a place where no one is eating?    there.   I said it.   

we waited for a brief moment, long enough to realize that there are other places to go.   down the street we went, to another, and got served immediately and had a wonderful experience.

I found out later I can go across the street to whiskey soda, and order to go, and avoid all this.   I might.  but I'm not going to hold my breath.

I just want you to know, you came recommended  by a customer of mine, and I live in new orleans.   when I asked where to go in pdx, my ex hometown?  he recommended you.    you disappoint.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The food is ridiculous.  Amazing flavors.  No Pad Thai here.  Well worth the wait.  Get on the list and have a drink next door at the Whisky Soda Lounge.  They'll call you when your table is ready.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I am picky about going to Thai places because to me, the only place to get great Thai food is at home. 

When we first arrived, we were told that it was a 2 and a half hour wait for 2 people. I then asked about the bar and counter space and that shortened the wait to 5 minutes. 

I typically judge a place by how well they make their Som Tum (papaya salad). IT WAS AWESOME! It's not as hot as I've had it at home, but it was done just right. I was ready to order a second dish, but was already stuffed with our other items. Might just get that one by itself the next time!

Our second dish was the broken crepe. Now it said it was "street cart food" that you'd find in Thailand. I don't recall seeing anything like it while in Thailand, but then again, I haven't tried every street cart. It was really good. I loved the bean sprouts and meat with it.

The third dish was a pork belly and pork shoulder curry. There were about 4 pieces of meat in there, 1 was nothing but pure fat. This was our least favorite and we'll probably order something else next time.

On a different note, if you like pickled relish, beware... they add thai chili to it and man did it just burn my mouth! This was way hotter than the Som Tum! 

We will be back, this is now my second favorite Thai place.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
+:  This spot never disappoints me and I always forward to eating here.  When friends visit from out of town, Pok Pok and Pix is always on the itinerary!  
-:  Rice needs to be free.
!:  Try the Thai iced tea with lime, it's amazing on a hot summers day!
?:  Rice needs to be free.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Just up the street from our home this 5 star restaurant should be on everyones list to try. Not to miss: The Wings!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I have been to Pok Pok's a number of times,it is by far one of the best restaurants in Portland!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Overpriced and underwhelmed.  I think I had such high expectations from the yelp reviews and the hype about the wings. The wings were wings. Salty, a bit spicy and tasted like fish sauce.  Since I was solo, the small plates were not recommended to me by my server so I went with Khanom Jiin Naam Phrik since it looked creatively tasty.  The prawn "gravy" was heavy and only had a mild prawn flavor.  The noodles over cooked and gummy that I didn't even want more than a few bites. Super disappointed and for the price, would not come back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The food is good but it's not worth the 2 hour wait or what these other reviews hype it up to be. Their fried chicken wings are nothing special, you can get it at any other Vietnamese restaurant (same taste if not better at Butterfly Belly). I also ordered there Isaan papaya salad that's supposedly super spicy... not lol I was super prepared to guzzle down a gallon of water, but it was not spicy whatsoever. More sour than anything else... Honestly was disappointed that I didn't go to the Crawfish place across the street instead :)

Nothing special about this place! Trust me!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: If you want to go here you need to make a reservation 3+ days in advance. Which is not Possible when you are visting out of town
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Having been to northern Thailand; Chiang Mail, I could tell PP's food and decor was very much inspired by the region. They have these adorable, colorful stringed lights hung on the wooden beams when sitting alfresco or indoors. 
Considering the fact that you don't get this type of Thai food very many other places...much less combined with the trendy scene, PP impresses. We went during a weird 3pm time and they still had an hour wait so do expect a wait...always.
As for the food:
Loooooved their scrumptious chicken wings. They were sticky, sweet and spicy and not your typical flyers :)
Oh and their drinks are also super yum - both proof and no proof!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Went on a Tuesday during President's day week around 2pm. I'm guessing its an off time because there was no line! Had to order the wings!!! Yes, they lived up to the hype! My boyfriend and I also ordered the crepe, which had a good amount of seafood in it and the claypot with porkbelly and vermicelli noodles. Everything was so full of flavor and not overly greasy. Had to stop ourselves from ordering another plate of the wings. 

Great experience. So many other things on the menu that I wanted to try. If I am ever in Portland again, I would definitely get the boar collar.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Overrated and overpriced!!! Not a fan of this over-hyped place at all. 

We came in around 6 pm on a Thursday night and surprisingly no wait! We got seated right away but didn't notice that they didn't have AC. We sat miserably throughout our meal in the scorching 90 degree weather. Although we were uncomfortable, we figure the food has to be worth it. Wrong on so many levels! 

We ordered their famous wings...although I dunno how they possibly could be famous for anything. The were so salty it tasted like I was swimming in the ocean. Yuck! It tasted dry and stale. Then we ordered the pork belly stew. The amount of meat in this dish was so pathetic. The dish cost almost $20 for a big pot with little meat. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great either. It had more flavor than the wings but that's about it. 

Save your money and go elsewhere! Way better places to eat at in PDX!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Food was incredible and the wait staff were knowledgeable and attentive. The flavors of each dish were amazing. Be sure to show up early because the line gets long. They take reservations for 5 or more.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I don`t have a good reason why Pok-pok shouldn't share a part of their profits with us since we recommend and sometimes force everyone we know to go there . Its a pretty popular place around town and well , there are no surprises as to why . Some very unique flavors and dishes , different from the traditional Thai food yet if you want to stick to convention there is always something for everyone. Their service is good and they take care if you have any allergies or want some modifications. Must try if you are in Portland !
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: First stop in Portland we stop by here for lunch, It's a very unique place. My friend and I order the Thai ice tea, it was okay the milk was overly powering the tea. We had couple questions on the menu, our server was very knowledgeable about the food items. So we started out with the most popular dish the chicken wings it was good, but a bit salty and a fishy smell from the sauce. We also order other dishes like the papaya salad, beef salad, and the Pad See Ew. Overall the dishes were good, but a bit spicy for my taste buds.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Briefs:  I'm beginning to suspect that good Thai restaurants don't serve pad thai.  The menu is offers a collection of dishes that you'll never see at most Americanized Thai restaurants.  Pok Pok succeeds at imitating that neighborhood dining shack of Thailand. Order from the take out counter or ask to sit outside to complete the your experience. It's probably the second greatest discovery (second to Voodoo Donuts) in all of Portland.    [Original Visit: December 19, 2010]
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I took a solo trip to Portland which I enjoyed having some alone time wandering the streets and curling up with at book at Powell's Books. The biggest negative about solo traveling is you can't order everything you want. I came to Pok Pok and wanted to order EVERYTHING. Literally everything. I sat at the bar and ordered their "Vietnamese Coffee Grown Up Style" and spent 10 minutes deciding what I wanted. It was a cold and very raining night in Portland so I settled on the Khao Soi.
