It's a Northern Thai mild curry egg noodle soup and it hit the spot. Everything went so well together. They serve it with a side of picked vegetables which gives the dish a nice tang. Add some fish sauce; it help really ramp up the savoriness of the dish. They definitely didn't skimp on the large pieces of beef. Next time I'm in town, I'm coming back with more people and ordering...everything.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Out of this world, untraditional Thai cuisine. Best Thai flavors my taste buds have ever had the pleasure of meeting. I'd mention certain dishes in particular, but we had a number of them last night and they were all over the top tasty.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Delicious and authentic. Fusion of wonderful spices and tastes. Good and happy service too. A real find.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is just alright. After years of hype maybe it's lost the integrity in there food because people are willing to line up and pay. The wings sounded like the star of the show but they where not shining today. We ordered them spicy but they had no hint of spice at all. The prawn gravy noodle dish was just bland. I felt like I was eating a dish at Olive Garden between the sauce and consistency. It also seems so silly to be spending $15 plus for the main dishes and having to pay for rice separately. As for the service it was spotty. It seems like with all the walkie talkie action they have they would been on there game but I guess they where just to busy talking to each other to check on there guests. I would not come back personally but 3 stars because it wasn't terrible food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We patiently waited for 2.5 hours as we had visitors who really wanted pok pok. When our turn finally came, they tried to sit us OUTSIDE (and to be very clear- we are not talking about the covered patio, this area was completely outside) in a 28 degree weather, on one of the coldest days in Portland. The hostess shrugged us off saying we could wait for another 45 mins for a seat inside. At that point, we were extremely cold, hungry and disappointed. 

If it wasn't for the manager, who stepped in and found us a seat in 15 mins, I probably would have sworn off Pok Pok for good after this experience.  We really appreciated the manager's professionalism and desire to make it right.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Fish sauce wings.  Sounds kind of questionable, but just trust me on this one.  Cute little place to go for lunch, and the dishes we ordered had a great mix of sweet and salty.  The Thai iced tea was too sweet for my liking, but otherwise I don't have any complaints.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: A friend suggested a couple new restaurants for me to try while in Portland and Pok Pok was one of them. I've heard the wait time to get a seat can be extremely long however this was not the case when I went. My party of 3 was seated within 10 minutes. The server gave us a few suggestions on what to try (we ordered 3 out of the 4 he recommended) Everything was absolutely amazing. Our food arrived at the table cooked to perfection and all at the same time (no waiting for someone to get their food while the others started eating). The meals were flavorful and the sauces that went with each dish were perfect. All of the wait staff at Pok Pok were amazing! I was a little worried at first as the restaurant is undercover but open to the outside (like tent dining). I will definitely visit Pok Pok again. If I happen to have a longer wait to be seated on my next visit I can assure you it is absolutely worth the wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great Thai street food.  Staff are helpful to educate for decision making and accommodating for needs.  The food was great!  Worth the visit!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
LOVE. deliciousness on a plate. get the wings (duh!) and avoid the scary wait by getting them to go. 

Everything else on the menu is pretty unmemorable. Sorry Andy Ricker.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The best chicken wings I have ever had. The spicy isn't overly spicy.  Delicious! Be sure to make reservations during prime time.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Can I say spicy orgasmic explosion of delight in my mouth?
I think so!
Pok Pok is just simply some of the best food on the planet. If your looking for an incredible flavor trip, this is the place to go. The soups are so spicy hot that they will keep you warm for hours. The BBQed pork, coconut rice, and fish soup are to die for. Beware, get your name on the waiting list when you go to this hollowed out house, because there will be a line.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Two words: Chicken Wangs!

Okay, it's "Wings" but you know what i'm saying. I came here a while back so this review is a bit outdated. However, when I think of Portland .... I think of Pok Pok. I love how the restaurant is build inside of a home, and there are a variety of seatings from outdoor patio (literally sitting in the backyard of the house) to inside of the home. 

I came here with my friend and we waited appx 1 hour for a table for 2. Its located inside of a residual area so you don't get much option to "explore" around the neighborhood. However, I did accidentally walked inside of an adult toy store thinking it was a pet's store (don't even ask!) which is located directly across the street. So for those with children... it is NOT a pet store. 

The chicken wings are absolutely amazing! the spicy, tangy and sweet flavor will explode in your mouth and will not leave you disappointed. My friend is vegetarian, and sometimes my stomach only let me eat like a rabbit, so I didn't get to try other dishes. 

As for drinks, I got the tamarind mojito (?) and it was different.  It definitely had a strong kick though because I recall getting a bit buzzed half way through. I did wished it had more of the tamarind flavor. 

I can't wait to go back to Portland .. and to you, Pok Pok.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Love this food!!! The sticky rice is the best and the chicken love the kids meal!!! Would always get on weekends they have great locations and the take out is very quick and convenient!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: God. This place is not worthy going! Went there three times, worse and worse experience. Dishes are not my favorite; waiter is slow; too crowded seats.

text:
Just lucky I guess....

Went here for lunch today about 12:30...lucky no wait...well, maybe 5 minutes for a table inside.  Food was fantastic.  Stuck with the standard "safe" choices, what most people like or order...the pok pok combo, the wings and some sliced beef salad. gotta holla at the thai iced tea made with lime juice...really really good. never had it like that.   

I'll be back..and back...and back.

text: Recently went here and had a good experience although one dish was under prepared. They did make a new one and corrected the situation. Would go back!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
After hearing so much about how amazing Pok Pok was, I took my fella there for dinner. We waited 15 minutes or so right behind another couple for a table and were seated in less time than they had projected. That's where the good news stops.

After being seated we were completely ignored by the staff for the next 15 minutes. I am not exaggerating (the table sat directly before us had food on their table before we were able to order).15 minutes until our waitress finally graced us with her presence to help us with our food selections. We knew we wanted the signature dish, the lemongrass stuffed game hen, but weren't sure what else to order. I wanted something a little spicy, but not too spicy, and communicated clearly. What we ended up with was a beef dish so spicy i took one bite and was thrown into coughing fits. I took another bite with plenty of rice and it was still too spicy. My dining partner loves spicy food, but no. it was too spicy for him as well. As for the game hen, I didn't know you could make a game hen that dry without trying. 

I don't expect waitstaff to bend over backwards for me. I've been in the food service industry for the past 17 years. I understand that when it's busy it's busy and you can't always get to a table right away.. forgiven. no big deal. However, never in my life have I left a restaurant so hungry that I had to get pizza afterward. 

The carefully packed up leftovers made their way to my refrigerator where my drunken room mate found the beef dish and ate it in it's entirety only to immediately regret it, and then regret it some more over the next few days. He described it as "a fire ball from my throat to my intestines"..
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Just love the wings.  It is a little salty but it is pretty tasty.  They have a food stand at PDX airport.  I bought a bucket of wings and took it on the airplane.  Ate the wings for lunch AND for dinner and the people sitting around me were so envious!  Even the flight attendant made a comment when he walked by at how delicious those wings looked, and asked where I got them.  I like their vinegar drinks too!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
When I saw that this place was a thai/viet restaurant, I was imagining the typical thai (pad thai) & viet (pho) foods that I've eaten before. But boy was I so wrong... I haven't been to Thailand or Vietnam, but I imagine that they would serve foods like this there. This was probably one of the most authenic asian restaurants that I've been to. 

When I first walked in, I noticed that it had a very chill vibe. There were indoor seating, but also had a few tables in a tent like space with heating lamps above us (thank god cause it was pretty chilly). We got seated fairly quickly and the waiter came to us with water (which tasted like rice infused water). Then he proceeded to explain each of the foods and told us about the family sharing style of eating that they endorse when we told him that we've never been here. The waiter here were so informative about the foods that they serve and answered all our questions (cause that menu is so extensive!)

We heeded his advice and got the wings to share. We opted for the mild options, which had a fish sauce taste. It was crispy on the outside and just the right texture on the inside. It was great. 

Next, my friend and I shared the kung op wun sen (which is a claypot with pork belly, noodles, shrimp and much more). It was pretty filling for its size and we both enjoyed it. It was definitely a unique experience and so different from foods I tried in the past, so I'm glad that I gave this place a chance.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: best wings on the west coast. salted plum vodka collins is very refreshing
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese

text:
We drank the coconut flavored kool-aid and found ourselves toasting under the multicolored lit patio of pok pok. Come on - it's the first time my Thai family comes to PDX. They have to see if it lives up to the test. Turns out, they're opening one in Vegas too so I guess they didn't have to go so far. But we made it to the OG restaurant to see if it lives up to all the hype.

And well it certainly did. And so did the price! Almost $200.00 for 5 people yikes! But we eat a lot. That's what families do. We ordered 2 wing sets which were much bigger than I thought they would be. The flavor is what makes this place great. They keep it authentic. No spice level changes. Just straight up good food. It was a nice fish sauce flavor on crispy tender wings. We were hooked. The Chang beer was flowing and this was the best introduction to our vacation in the PNW. 

We also ordered the skirt steak salad. (This was a bit dry. They didn't have a lot of fat on it) The papaya salad had a good balance of flavor. We got some Thai sausage that was amazingly cooked. And plenty of sticky rice (aka sleepy rice for me). My brother of course had to get some pork belly too - his favorite. 

Overall Pok Pok was impressive but it's great for a one offer, special occasion type of me. It's hard when the prices are high for something you wish you can make at home. But they've got some secret flavors in the sauce that'll make you wish you can come back sooner rather than later.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Honestly I go to this place just to have their khao soi with tofu. It's best coconut based curry I have had in any Thai place. Although I'm a vegetarian I have heard lot of my friends tell so many good things about other dishes here as well. 
They usually have a long wait time,but it's definitely worth it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Over-rated. Don't get mixed up with the Michelin star swarded branch in NYC. Wings are salty and kao Soi chicken was ok. Coconut rice was good but not the best I have had.

text:
some of the best wings you will eat!  My team and I routinely talk about how much we love this place and crave their wings.

The rest of the menu is on the "different" side - very flavorful, but has been a bit surprising to some of my more food-conservative friends.

Favorites: wings.  definitely the wings.

text: Not worth the 2 hour wait. Food is average and service was excellent. I would recommend the chicken other than that nothing out of the ordinary.

name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm a fan! Everyone comes here for the wings (which were delish btw), but you have to open your mind and try some of the other stuff too!

For our visit, we arrived on a Sunday around 6:45 PM. Our table was ready by 7:20 PM, which I didn't think was too bad. Love the texting when table's ready all of these Portland restaurants have btw, SF needs this!!

For dinner, we ordered:

1. Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings - $15.50
I'm not going to talk about this too much since every other review talks about it. My opinion was that this was too flavorful. The tangy-ness sort of killed the roof of my mouth...it was weird and I can't quite put my finger on what it is exactly. 

1. Muu Paa Kham Waan (boar collar meat) - $15.50
This dish comes spicy, sauce over the boar meat, but I'm a wimp when it comes to spiciness so we had it on the side (offered by our server who was super nice!). The meat was tender and it comes with iced mustard greens to neutralize your palette after the spicy sauce. I thought it was a gimmick, but it really worked!! This was my favorite dish.

2. Yam Makheua Yao (charcoal grilled eggplant) - $14.50
This also comes spicy so we requested to have the Thai chilies on the side. This dish is really flavorful, but not to the point where it's overpowering. The eggplants are cooked just right and really soak in all the flavors of the dish.

3. Hoi Thawt (crispy broken crepe) - $13.50
This was a tasty snack, but I could skip next time. I felt like there was too much egg and not enough mussels in the dish. As described on the menu, this is definitely a night market food.

Overall, a yummy meal and I would definite revisit next time I'm in Portland!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I'm sorry, maybe it's an acquired taste but I just couldn't handle the fishy chicken.  I smelled like fish and tasted fish all day, it wasn't for me, sorry guys...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So there are tons of reviews on this place and came to Portland with friends and decided to give this place a chance. Not really surprised when we went during prime dinner time it would be a 45-60 min wait. 

The restaurant was part indoor and outdoor seating in what looked like two houses turned restaurant. I prayed we wouldn't sit outdoors since it was freezing even with the heaters (and I'm not a stranger to cold since I come from SF). The decorations were cute, with lights strung outside and going for that thai/viet theme. 

So those chicken wings were the whole reason why most reviewers go to this place and it wasn't spectacular to my friends and I. It's not any San Tung chicken (SF local) but if you order spicy it has a kick to it that just messed it up for us. The fish sauce was obviously used but I would cut down on the fish sauce. 
The Glass noodles were yummy though and my favorite dish in the whole night!! It was flavored just right but the downside is that with the size of the clay pot you would expect to be getting more noodles. I would get it again but would have to order 2 to have enough for 3 people. 
The last thing we and was steak salad which I have to say is decent but on the sour side. I get that most thai larb salads are like that but Ive also been to places that can balance the sour salad dressing just right to not make it overwhelming. Which is where the steaky rice was recommended for this dish and was what helped with the dressing. The steak was cooked and seasoned just right at a medium rare and as a meat lover was my favorite part of this dish.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: One of my favorites, kind of a limited menu in my opinion.  And impossible to get a walk in table, Just order at the walk up window.  My favorite is nothing more than their chicken wings.  Don't know if it's just fish sauce or what but their magical. Just go across the street to Whisky Soda Lounge, order 2 orders  and their good drinks with vinegar.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok was definitely on my food list for my trip to Portland after reading all the raving reviews. I came on Monday around 6:30 PM and there was no wait, which was a plus! I ordered the famous Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce wings with Papaya Pok Pok Salad. The wings were sweet and tangy! Very delicious, slightly on the salty end. The papaya salad added a nice crisp crunch and a spicy kick to balance out the sweetness. I enjoyed my meal overall, but chicken wings in general does not satisfy my hunger.. I don't know what it is.. but after about 4 wings in.. I felt content, but not fully satisfied. I nibbled off of my friends Chicken Khao Soi, which was PACKED with flavor! Very comforting! If you're in Portland, give it a try :)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Great little Thai place with AMAZING food! My boyfriend and I decided to try this place out after hearing a friend rave about the Fish Sauce Wings. We arrived just before 6pm, and were seated promptly. Our waiter was very friendly and attentive. Brian & I shared the fish sauce wings and another dish called Muu Paa Kham Waan... both did not disappoint. The wings definitely lived up to their reputation, and the pork dish was delicious!! 

Go early though, the line when we left wrapped down the block.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So freaking good. You might wait for a while.... who cares? the food in this place is incredible! Like no other thai restaurant in the world. I used to live in Thai town (Hollywood) and in comparison to Pok Pok, their food is like Mickey D's.
Pok Pok is an incredible cozy spot with fantastic customer service. I can't wait to go there again.
ps: AWESOME MOJITOS!!!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I had a very positive experience at Pok Pok, unlike a lot of people. Call it luck of the draw, but we had no lines to deal with. We went on a Sunday around 1 when it was raining. That definitely would deter people from going so it's probably because I didn't go during the most ideal of conditions. 

We were sat inside away from the rain and cold. We were greeted promptly by our waitress and asked if we'd like anything to drink and were given time to look at the menu. The menu is not like a typical Thai restaurant, and probably where all of the appeal lies. It was hard for me to choose since everything was so foreign to me, but I settled on the Khanom jiin naam phrik with coconut rice. I can say right now that I do not regret my decision whatsoever. The main dish had some cabbage that added some crunch to the food and the noodles and vegetables blended in well. It had some pureed shrimp in it which you could taste and added some thickness to the soup. Just a forewarning, the dish comes with a super spicy sauce that you should use in moderation, so just be careful when eating it along with your meal. The coconut rice is a must since the change of pace from traditional white rice is always nice. I only wish I could visit this place more to try all of their different dishes, but I would say this place is a definite must for those who are adventurous eaters that are in the Portland area.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: So the food here is very good. Definitely some of the best non-traditional (American traditional that is) Thai food I've ever had. Love the setting and the atmosphere and all. I felt the portions were very small for the price. It didn't live up to the hype in that sense. I was still hungry after my dinner even though it was quite good. I like innovative hipster takes on ethnic restaurants, but not when they make it look fancy and raise the price with smaller portions just to capitalize on their image. So over all good but worth the hype...maybe just once
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Had to try because of DD&D and weren't disappointed, but not the best I've ever had. The Papaya Pok Pok was from the depths of hell though, it was soo spicy, it almost hindered us from enjoying our food. Yes, the waitress told us it was gonna be spicy, but we didn't expect that lasting burn to linger on our tongues for minutes after, it's a good thing they have a huge pitcher of water at each table, even if it was room temperature. Still, we enjoyed our food. We had the Kai Yanng, which was ok, just a roasted chicken with a thai dipping sauce. The star of the show as the Kung Op Won Sen, a noodle dish in a clay pot with pork belly and shrimp, the dish was very flavorful and we almost licked the pot. The place was a little expensive for the little amount of food we got, but it was good tasting, which is why we'd go again if ever in town again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We were in town visiting for fun and thought we would try this. We were seated in the front patio. It was warm enough and with the great music playing, both me and my husband felt very nostalgic. Thumbs up! We came with our son and it was the middle of the day so it was perfect and not busy. We ordered the Pok Pok Special, Papaya Pok Pok, and Muu Paa Kham Waan. It was delicious and authentic even down to the presentation.

We had a craving for it a few days in, realizing it was about to close in 30 mins I made sure we put our order in and prayed we made the drive to downtown in time! We won't ever drive that fast again, lol. This time I wanted to try a restaurant's version of the fish sauce wings so we ordered Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings and another round of Pok Pok Special. Tasty! I'm sad realizing they had one opened in LA but no longer the case. :(
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The noodle soup with the chicken was to die for!!!!! And the mango coconut milk drink was amazing! the pok pok was also very good and started a fire in my mouth!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok! This is not your average Thai food. 

The place is small so plan on waiting for a table. When I went at 5:30 on a Sunday, we still had a half hour wait time. But no fear, Pok Pok owns the bar across the street, Whiskey Soda Lounge so head over there to get started. 

At the bar, we were able to order the famed Tasting Vinegars and Fish Sauce Wings. They both lived up to the hype. The wings were salty, sweet and delicious. The vinegars were so unique: sweet with a vinegar kick at the end. 

For dinner we had the Wingbean Special Salad, the Boar Collar, and the Cornish Game Hen. Everything was amazing. The wingbean and boar collar were stand outs. The wingbean had a great peanut sauce. The boar collar was tender, spicy, and a little gamey. It was served with mustard leaf to cut the heat. The cornish game hen was good too, but much more plain than the other two dishes. 

The menu here is exotic. This is not your traditional pad thai and green curry type of establishment. This is real Thai street food. But, the food goes well beyond being exotic. It's effing tasty. 

Service was okay. Ambience was okay. Total came to about $30/person (no alcohol). Portions were on the small side, but the food was so rich we were not want for more. Go for the food. Ignore everything else.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Forever craving their fish sauce wings, papaya salad & my true love - pineapple drinking vinegar.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We all know that eating should be an experience. 

(If you are one of the lucky ones who gets to eat regularly...rejoice, be grateful, and always treat a meal with reverence.)

I love food experiences. Cheeky and informed servers. Good vibes. Thoughtful decor that parallels the food offerings. Bar tenders who understand the care of cocktails. Clean plating. All the stuff that makes the food, when delivered, taste even better. 

Unless it's Pok Pok. 

They could serve me their food, in an alley, on a trash can lid, with a feral cat as my dinner companion and I'd STILL give it 5 stars. 

I've eaten here numerous times and am heading back in November. My mouth is already watering. Many of the dishes are served as shares...family style. Andy was named best NW Chef. I own the Pok Pok cookbook. Best Thai in the country. No joke. 

So, I'm gonna keep this simple. Here are a few of the things I love at Pok Pok. 

Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings. I feel that everyone should have a taste of these before they die. 

Yam Samun Phrai. It is nothing short of a party in your mouth. If I were you I'd make sure you are firmly seated when taking the first bite. 

Laap Pet Isaan. Laap is one of my fav Thai dishes. I always get it, when available, at Thai restaurants. It's fun to see how each one prepares it. Pok Pok takes it to a whole other level with duck, duck skin (have mercy) and duck livers. Bursting with a medley of well layered flavors.

Pork Belly. Anything they serve with pork belly is worth eating. Especially if it's cooked for two days and served in a little crock. 

Vegetarians, relax, lots of wonderful dishes available for you too!

I have had their cocktails, 
Bloody Mary- really good with the wings. 
Hunny - grapefruit juice with lime, honey drinking vinegar and tequila. Everything fresh squeezed. 

Never had desert, not enough room. Stuffed.

So take a walk, let it digest and the head to Salt and Straw (artisan ice cream) right down the street.

Pok Pok and S&S are two of my fav places to eat in the Northwest. Or anywhere for that matter.

Even in an alley.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Seriously delicious food. Read about this joint in Sunset. My girlfriend lives in Portland and when I came for a visit I insisted we go. The fish sauce chicken wings are to die for. Can't recall the name of the soup ( there was only one) but it was a little bowl of heaven with noodley goodness. Still talking and yelping about the dinner. Just lovely!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Service was really friendly and quick even though it was really busy.  I went with a group of people and I was the only vegan.  I really loved the noodle soup I got and I felt there were enough vegan options.  Everyone I was with liked everything and said it all had a great amount of spice.  The salted plum cocktail was delicious.  I'd go back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I tried eating here on Sunday and unfortunately experienced the worse service I have had in a long time. Waited about 10 mins before getting seated even though there was tons of open tables, and then was given water and never to be seen again by anyone. They actively ignored our table. Serving around us but not acknowledging us. After 20 mins we left and I informed the manager of my experience. Looking at me all doughy eyed he said: huh? Sorry, there are now too many good places to eat in Portland with better service.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We came here on a Thursday for a late lunch. We were seated within 10 minutes and given some roasted chilies and lime leaf peanuts and pandan-flavored water. Between the two of us, we ordered Ike's Vietnamese fish sauce wings, kung op wun sen, papaya Pok Pok, and jasmine rice. Overall, everything tasted good, but I would've preferred a little more heat from the food and for it to be less salty. Getting rice is a must, especially with the chicken wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Mmm.. I expected more. It's a very hyped up place so you'll expect long lines. Nothing here really blew me away to be honest for the level of popularity it has. Khao Soi was good, chicken wings good but too salty. Nothing else was too memorable.

I didn't like the service we received from one waiter. When I returned the sticky rice for it being too undercooked, he looked at the rice and commented: "Really? I checked the rice this morning and it was fine! Also...you can't bring me back so little and expect us to give you a new bowl."

Seriously? It's rice. How much can it possibly be worth to you. By the way, it was undercooked and we received a complimentary jasmine rice for noting it to them. 

It left me pretty disgusted that he wouldn't just check the rice and bring us a new bowl. Really soured my experience here.

Expect long lines, decent food, a cool space, but I would go elsewhere. 

If you have friends who are vegetarians or hate spices, go elsewhere. It will be painful how many yummy dishes you'll have to compromise to accommodate their palates.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I appreciate the Thai street food served at Pok Pok. The food is simple and delicious and the ambiance makes you feel like you're in Southeast Asia. The only thing I don't dig is the rice water. The pok pok wings are well seasoned and very crispy, just the way I like it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Came in today. Rude hostess (girl wearing glasses, around 3-4 pm). Told me my wait was going to be ten minutes, I walked across the street, came back in five minutes and the hostess said "we called you a long time ago" don't give me an appx ten minutes when it's less than five minutes. She then proceeds to tell me i was already called, and now I have to wait about 20 mins now and asked if I'd like a text for when the Table was ready. Why didn't she ask for my number earlier? She put me on a waiting list without asking for my number, then skips me and tells me to wait another 20 mins THEN asks for my number ? I asked her why she didn't ask for my number the first round, she was unapologetic and basically said "oops". Now I do realize the whiskey soda and lounge is owned by the same owner, BUT nonetheless, the bartender/server at whiskey and soda obviously has better service. Didn't catch her name but she was great.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Sticking to the facts. 
The food is tasty. Lots of flavor. No doubt about that. 
This is a great place if you are on weight watchers.
The portions are small. Seriously. 
Order two entree's  per person, if you are actually hungry. 
My party of four ordered four entrees, and then had additional desert someplace else, and appetizers before hand.   A couple seated next to us ordered Six entrees for the two of them, if I had only known... 

The wait staff was busy, so I won't knock them for forgetting to serve water. 

This is not a "typical" thai restaurante.  
Call if Fusion, Call it Thai inspired, call it any thing but a Thai restaurant. 

The clients... wow, I've never been anywhere else in Portland where people stared at other people this much. The customers were so... appearance conscious, it definitely did not feel like portland.  It is one thing to "people-watch", but this was a whole other level of self concious... oogling. Very disturbing. 

This place is way overhyped.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: It's decent Thai food but over rated and not really worth a long wait time.  It has Issan (North Thailand) food which is somewhat rare to find.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Waited 3 hours to eat here...well worth the wait! Had the chicken wings in both the spicy and regular. Both amazing! I also had the bore collar and the beef clay pot dish. Both also excellent. I'm not from Portland, but if I came back to visit, this would definitely be a stop I would make.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I knew before I got here that I had to try the Fish Sauce wings. The papaya salad and side of sticky rice were the perfect compliments. The wings I have heard can be a little salty but I thought they were perfect with the papaya salad and side of rice. The bartender recommended getting the wings non-spicy since the papaya salad is spicy and that was definitely the right move. 

The wait was about 45 minutes but the bar is open seating with full menu as well. I actually enjoyed the experience at the bar because the bar tender was interactive with us and gave us ordering/eating tips. I.e. If you order the side of sticky rice, don't take the entire chunk out at once because it will dry out/harden really quickly. So leave it in the bamboo container so that it will stay warm/moist. 

I would definitely like the chance to come back and try more items on their menu. You know you had a great experience when you are done dining and already full; and while walking out you see dishes on other tables that you didn't order and still say to yourself "that looks amazing".
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I called them, waited 10 rings for automated phone system to pick up, pressed '1' and waited a few more rings for someone to pick up who then put me on hold for about one minute to wait for someone to take my takeout order.  I asked for pad Thai, which I assumed was standard fare at any Thai restaurant.  Okay, turns out I'm ignorant, no problem, right?  Except, no, the staff had to use a stern tone of voice to condescend me in his explanation that they don't have pad Thai.  He then asked, "did you even look at the menu?" Me, "yes I looked at the menu, but it was pretty big, do you have a dish with rice noodles, shrimp and vegetables".  Him, again in a stern tone of voice, "well we have Kuung Op Wun Sen, but you really need to look at the menu".  I was rather frustrated that he questioned my having looked at the menu a second time after I told him that I had already looked at the menu, so I just said, "no thanks" and hung up.  It's a reasonable request to suggest looking at the menu, but in such a rude demeanor, I don't think I'll be patronizing them any time soon.  If he had been friendly about it, I gladly would have called back with a decision. For a moment, I thought I had called Dorsia.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The thing to ask yourself about Pok Pok isn't whether or not the food and booze is good. It is. However, every time I've been there the eating and drinking part of the experience seems to lose ground to the hassle factor. The waits are horrendous, it's a zoo, and to be honest, after you've eaten there a few times, the food isn't all that mind blowing anymore. Last time I went was on a Sunday with some out of town visitors. A solid 1:15 minute wait on a Sunday is a pain in the ass. I realize that not taking reservations keeps your bar hopping across the street but sometimes I don't need to spend 3+ hours at "pre dinner" and dinner combined. The food is very good though, I can't take that away from them, but in my mind, at least, it used to be better.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I don't think this is the best Thai food I ever had, but it definitely is delicious. It's Thai influenced by Vietnamese flavors. 

The water is soaked or cooked in Pandan leaves. I didn't ask any of the servers this, but I know that it's Pandan leaves because a lot of Vietnamese people drink water the same way, and I can just smell it! Lol.

Also, I think it's so funny that people talk so highly of the Fish Sauce Wings, but I grew up eating Fish Sauce Wings! Vietnamese people put fish sauce on everything! And it's good, but nothing I never had before. 

Service was great and the ice cream dessert was delicious!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So... like my other posts, I am a chicken wing connoisseur. I visited Portland and for sure my #1 "have-to" checkout place to eat was Pok Pok for the famous wings! For me, they weren't life changing, nor would i come back for the wings again... they were too salty and fishy in my opinion. However, the other dishes were really good if you love spicy food. And I'm talking Thai chili spicy! My husband loved it, but I'm just a lil weeny when it comes to that asian spice. Service was great, the ambiance was like walking into my Tita's kitchen with the plastic floral table cloth and floral plates. I think Pok Pok should get more credit on other foods, but not the wings. 

Brussel Sprouts with Pork Belly (very small slices)
Papaya Salad
Boar meat with chili peppers **my favorite dish** wrap it in the mustard greens, paired with sticky rice- yum!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I am busting out reviews tonight and I need to plug in my laptop.  This will be a short and dirty review of Pok Pok for those reasons as well as this place as a TON of other reviews already that are 5 stars.

Good food, good service - a bit spendy.  We only dined here once and do plan to go back and give it another go round with some family and friends due to the face that we did enjoy it.  I ordered some chick crack wings that ended up being more than I thought they would be (I should have read the menu better but my stomach was rolling ove4r on itself I was so hungry and the place smelled so delish!) and they were yummy but man the bones were a pain to eat around.  I will be skipping that meal the next go round.

My drink was a bit on the small side but the bar service was stellar.

Our wait was nill, we were seated instantly which was great!  They were busy but found us a quaint little table in the bar.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Came here on a Sunday night before labor day Monday. We waited for three hours(party of three) expecting 5 stars food and hoping it worth our wait. However, the food was not as great as we thought and most of the food are too salty. I had better Thai chichen at other places and I was expecting it to be as good as my other experiences but the overall experience was just disappointing. I will give it a higher rating if the wait was shorter, three hours for what we got was just wasting my time. Period.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok's adventurous menu distinguishes it from the many other Thai restaurants in the Portland.  If you seek comfort in phad Thai and three or four colors of curry to put on chicken, shrimp or tofu, then do not go to Pok Pok. 

On March 6, 2010, other diners beat us to Pok Pok, so the sweet young woman directing traffic offered us appetizers and drinks across the street at their Wiskey Soda Lounge to wait the estimated 1 hour.  There, the firey Chinese fungus forced me to gulp Thai iced tea to restore order to my taste buds.  The other two appetizers we shared were more within my tolerance.  There are no asterisks or red peppers on the menu to warn diners; you should ask how spicy.  The music was a little too loud & intense, with bad sound quality, which distracted diners rather than enhanced the venue.  Maybe at 11:00 p.m., when people are louder and drunk, the music would be less dominant.

Back at Pok Pok, we all found something we wanted, plus sticky rice and coconut rice.  The authentic sticky rice, alone, is almost worth the trip to Pok Pok. Off the top of my head, I can't think of other restaurants in Portland that make sticky rice as well.  The other items were pretty good.  The Asian music here was much better than at the ante restaurant, and did, in fact, evoke a return to Thailand. 

Some creative drinks, and pleasant servers.

Good dining experience and good food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Went by myself at the bar. It's my very first time I asked the bartender his recommendation he told me to get the chicken wings. doesn't come with Rice so that's another extra 3 to 4 dollars a bowl. But the meal was amazing finger licking good the service was excellent everybody was very very friendly.... most definitely would recommend anybody friends or family to come to this restaurant!!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Spicy Pok Pok wings are must!! The tamarind whiskey sour was just about the best whiskey sour I've ever had! Pok Pok isn't just a hype the food is authentic and full of bold flavors!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Love this place.  First time here.  I can neither spell nor pronounce what we had, but it was delicious.  A sweet pork dish, a spicy pork belly and shoulder dish, and a spicy steak dish, each with a different kind of rice.  Will be back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The wait wasn't too bad, maybe less than ten minutes. Would've liked a table outside but instead was seated inside by the bar where it was claustrophobic and loud with the music blaring. Service was friendly but pretty slow. Yep, as someone else states, the coconut rice extra was the best part of our meal. The half roasted chicken was okay, six pieces mixed white and dark meat with two dipping sauces, one too salty fish sauce and our fav, the red sweet and spicy one. The deep fried catfish served on a bed of noodles was pretty good. The vermicelli dish with Chinese sausage and dried shrimp was too runny. I think I'm over this place.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Delicious wings! I have not been to their location, but tried their signature wings at St. Josef's Winery in Canby and was pleasantly surprised given I am not a "wing person."
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I don't really have a whole lot left to say about Pok Pok that hasn't already been said. It's an amazing restaurant and you should go. That's really all there is to it. 

Why is it amazing? Just throw "Pok Pok" or "Andy Ricker" into Google really quickly and read comment after comment that gushes over the restaurant and its world class chef.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Omg.  Why did I come here directly after a disgustingly large brunch?  Oh, probably because it was nearby, I was visiting from out of town and relying on public transpo, and I'd heard about the infamous chicken wings.  And boy, did I ever stagger out clutching my stomach like I was super preggo and ready to deliver.  The Pok Pok wings live up to all the hype, but don't discount their daily drink menu, the coconut and jackfruit ice cream dessert sandwich, or the super friendly staff.  My only regret is that there isn't a Pok Pok even remotely close by to me so I can gorge myself daily on those wings...
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Wow! Food is so good!!! Today was my first time trying this dish! I was blown mind by the taste!!! So delicious!! Who would thought I would be eating something different! Hahahahaha
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
First time at Pok Pok.  I've lived in PDX ever since Pok Pok opened in 2005.  I've always hesitated to patronize Pok Pok because of reports of really long lines and wait times (due to its popularity).

Today, I finally made it.  Turns out, Pok Pok has no lines during their weekday lunch service.

We ordered the Kai Yang Chicken - Charcoal toasted stuffed with herbs and spices- chicken was moist, but blander tasting than I expected (expectation based on the description).  The 2 sauces were good and made the bites of chicken taste distinctly different depending on which sauce the chicken was dipped into.

Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings was clearly the star of the meal.  Great flavor and crunch.  The 6 wing portion is equivalent to 12 wings compared to the typical chicken wing service since each wing included the drumette and the wing part.

I brought a couple of the wings home to pair with the Pok Pok Rhubarb Shandy that I had in my refrigerator- the Shandy paired really well with the wings.

I enjoyed the Kung Op Wun Sen - Prawns baked in a clay pot with clear noodles very much.  The chef used caramelized onions to create a great taste experience.

I recommend the sticky rice over the jasmine rice to go with the chicken wings while the jasmine rice was a better pairing for the Kai Yang Chicken.

I'm traveling to Thailand soon and I'm looking forward to trying the street food in Bangkok.

I'll update the review with an after Thailand perspective.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The famous wings was too salty for my taste. But the pork belly was perfect with sticky rice. And papaya salad was a great diffuser of the saltiness of the wings.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I'm at a Convention this week and when lunch time rolled around, the choices were pretty much limited to "captive" cafes, a nearby Burgerville, and a few other casual places within an easy walk. On a whim, I decided to go to Pok Pok for Lunch. On the Trimet, it's a simple "jump to the left" (#70 Bus), then a "step to the right" (#4). And as much as watching people is fun regarding my fellow sometimes nerdy professionals, being on a Portlandia Bus is even better. My favourite overhead conversation today was a lady asking the bus driver if he could extend his route an extra hour so that she could get home more conveniently.

Pok Pok is a popular place and I had been previously advised that going for lunch during the week might better assure a seat at the table or bar. That was certainly true today, although by the time I left, the place was full both inside and outside.

The service could have been better than today's "A-OK". My waiter had the expected friendly and casual Portland personality. However, he was a bit detached, slow in taking my order, short on menu choice explanations, and maybe a tiny bit flip on top of that. I've seen stronger versions of that behaviour before at well regarded restaurants that let all the praise they receive go to their head. But in the end, I let it go and decided to just enjoy the space, the energetic mid-day vibe, and of course my meal.

The food was simply fabulous. I ordered the Phat Si Ew (a woked pork, vegetables, and rice noodles dish) and am still marvelling at the rich variety of flavours that came rushing in and around my pallet at every bite. Gayle would call this a "kick ass" meal of which every last drop would be "licked" clean from the plate. I'd love to bring her back here and give Pok Pok a more robust work out.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I tried so hard to like this place, but we were unfortunately 2/4 on the dishes we ordered even after taking 15 minutes to consult the very knowledgeable, friendly server and customizing our order. The fried chicken that the restaurant is famous for was suffocatingly salty. Nice decor and service couldn't overcome the disappointment we felt about the food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This was the restaurant that everyone recommended. I haven't been able to find Northern Thai food ever since I left Chiang Mai so I had to give it a shot. The food made it all worth it. Had tuna, wingbean salad and pork belly& shoulder and they were phenomenal. One detail that bothered me was how many empty tables were around us when we were seated after 2.5hr wait. There were at least two empty tables constantly -at one point there were 6 for about 15 minutes. And that was just a small portion of the restaurant. It blew my mind that this busy restaurant  couldnt have an efficient system to handle the wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
During my last trip to Portland, we stumbled upon this place after a quick yelp search for somewhere close we could go nearby for dinner since the original place we wanted to go to was closed for the day. 

For a Thai/Vietnamese place with such high reviews, it was very disappointing. It's definitely more catered for the American palate and less authentic to other restaurants I've been to and maybe 2-3 times for expensive.

We ordered the following items to share:
- Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings
- Khao Soi - Thai mild curry noodle soup
- Hoi Thawt - Crispy broken crepe with steamed fresh mussel
- 2 servings of the coconut rice

Overall, I wasn't really a fan of any of the dishes. I think I would have had more luck finding better dinner options at the food carts downtown.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This is a Portland institution and is well worth the wait for a very authentic experience. We even sat out in a little patio shack with overhead heaters in December. The waiter was very helpful in ordering since we were new to the menu. We ended up getting a sausage appetizer, a pork belly "curry" that was more like a stew (to be eaten with the sticky rice), and a chicken coconut noodle soup.   the portions were small compared to what I'm used to, but everything was freshly prepared and very flavorful. It's a little pricy too; our meal was $50 with no drinks and we ate all the food with no leftovers. But definitely a must try for the experience!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So good I bought a shirt.

1205 reviews?! well this one probably won't move the average but i agree with most of the people before me,.. this place is great.

Smallish portions but packed with flavour, the hype is worth it DESPITE sitting outside in November in a heated tent...

For some reason the waiter dissuaded us from the wings which everyone says are amazing,... but I'm not complaining, everything from the vinegar drinks to the stewed pork dish pleased us to no end.   Prices worth it (and reasonable to begin with).

The shirt? Brown with light blue letters.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place came as a recommendation so my family and I went around 5pm to beat the dinner rush. I guess there's a couple different dining areas and we got sat outside. Good thing there are heat lamps outside otherwise I would be freezing my butt off. 

The staff is friendly and knowledgeable and suggested their favorites. I took a look at the menu and found it to be too cluttered so I just whipped out my phone and looked at pictures. Here's what I ordered (I have no idea what the name of the dishes I ordered were but here we go:

Chicken wings - everyone was getting these so we decided to. Wings are a pretty decent size and very flavorful

Braised pork belly/pork shoulder curry - my favorite dish of the evening. Goes well with coconut rice

Trout with fish sauce over greens and noodles- also a great dish. The noddles are vermicelli and the fish is cut into bite size pieces with no bones. 

Minced pork salad - I love that the dish is so meaty and it's got this crunch to it. It also comes with a side of leafy greens such as mint, basil and cabbage

Glass noodle with prawn - this was okay. Nice size prawns but you have to peel them. 

Overall I loved this restaurant. If I have more time on this trip, I would definitely come back to try the other dishes.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Worth the 2 hour wait. Pork belly curry is worth it every time.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We went at 10pm on a Thursday  and sat at the bar. Ordered the wings and Thai curry noodles. Really neat place and delicious food. Reasonable prices and great drinks.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Amazing spot to eat. Wings are the best! Will definitely be coming back often. Love the various locations
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Very delicious. A bit over priced. Nice ambiance. A good choice when on Division. Just be ready to wait and to pay good money for great food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Gosh, I'm not even sure how to start this review. I was really excited to try this place out because of the great yelp reviews and recommendation from several friends but after trying it out, I'm sad to say it does not live up to the great reviews and should not be recommended.

The prices are more expensive than your typical Thai/Vietnamese restaurant.  Dishes ranged around $15-$18 per dish. When I saw the prices were in that range, I assumed that the portions should have been decent enough to share but no, they were super meager.  Everything we ordered was so salty! I inhaled 2 glasses of water after my meal because it was so salty.

I'm a nursing mother with a big appetite. I came here eager to eat and left still hungry disappointed.  

I'm not sure why this place received so many great reviews because it doesn't deserve it! Why the extra star? Well, our server was super sweet and provided us with superb service.  Oh and I also liked the hibiscus tea here.

Would I come back? Would I recommend this place? Hell to the no.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Finally!  I got a chance to try Pok Pok!  Yaay

Think you've been eating Thai food for all these years at one of your favorite local thai spots?  Think again!  Of course I recognized a lot of things on the menu and their ingredients but Pok Pok takes them all to another level.  I was pleasantly surprised!  I like varying levels of spiciness in foods and they can accomodate all of them.  

I'd give them five stars but who (server or runner) forgets the rice and makes you wait forever to check on things.  The sticky rice was pretty darn good though and presented well!

I'd go back again.  Be prepared to wait if you prefer indoor seating!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok is a Portland staple. The wings are iconic, definitely try them, but allow for exploration as the rest of the menu is equally delicious. The Boar collar, the Som Tum, the drinking vinegars are all worth trying. You'll be glad you were adventurous, I've never had an unpleasant dining experience here.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Sorry but I don't get the big hub-ub about this place. It has definite charm with its outdoor Christmas lights and funky seating. I reserved a table for six ahead of time and my table was promptly ready. The space for such tables, however, is sort of average and feels like an after thought. This place really is not welcoming to vegans as their one curry noodle dish I'm pretty sure I could get tastier from a food cart over on Alder. I also think their alcoholic drinks are pretty weak. My friends got the chicken wings and just raved, those seem to be worth the hype.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Love love love Pok Pok wings!! Had a good amount for the money charged. They really know how to put ingredients together to make great tasting food
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: You haven't been here? You need to! Some of the best chicken you will have especially if you like Asian fusion! We got to try some amazing wings, noodles, and pork belly! We tried their catfish marinated in turmeric with rice vermicelli noodles with peanuts, mint, cilantro, and mam nem. If you know what this is then you should know it's delicious! If you don't it's worth trying. The chef checked in on us to make sure we were enjoying our food (we were), our waiter gave us great advise based on what we were in the mood for, and there was plenty of indoor and outdoor seating. Definitely recommend coming to eat some yummy food or drinks.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Huge Pok Pok fan! This is one of our choices for out of town guests, great experience every time.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I really wanted to love this place...buuut I just didn't like it. I waited for 1.5 hours for service that made me feel rushed. The place is packed and full of hipsters eating chicken wings. The Khao Soi was meh and the whole fried tilapia was $24 garbage. It wasn't hot when it was brought out and was basically soggy. I might give it another change with the take out window, but I doubt it. They should only take reservations or something. Maybe then it wouldn't be so rushed.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Yes, they are well regarded here in Portland. It is justifiable. The food is somehow just different from what you would get at most any Thai restaurant. It sounds cliche, but the best way I can describe Pok Pok is that eating there is a transcendental experience. Something you will remember. Out of the ordinary, special, unique, unforgettable. 

It is pricey, though, so don't come expecting a cheap Thai meal. So if you go, do it right. Be prepared to spend a bit more than you normally do. But if you can afford it, it is DEFINITELY worth it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Beware! There are many locations that use the name Pok Pok; be sure you're visiting the original location on Division. After reading many reviews, we anticipated a long wait and mentally prepared to be waiting for at least an hour. To our surprise, we were seated immediately (granted it was around 1730). We were seated at a cozy corner booth by the bar and appeared to have the bartender waiting on us. He was quick, efficient and provided us good info about the menu and options available. 

We wondered about the hype of the food and came with some skepticism. The food did not disappoint! My partner had Ike;s Fish Sauce Wings and Papaya Salad (which he usually makes at home). Both dishes seemed to live up to the hype and he truly enjoyed them both - flavorful and the right amount of spice. I had the Khao Soi which reminds me of a yellow curry I've had in the past. It was super flavorful, rich and decadent. I would suggest removing the crunchy fried noodles on top so they don't get soggy. It gave the dish a nice complexity and different textures to entertain the palate. Five stars for food & service! If we're ever back in the Portland area, we will be back and we would wait for their food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The best vietnamese wings! You have to try. As someone who's dating a vietnamese guy, his mom makes bomb vietnamese wings for dinner every now and then. This place nails it. And I haven't found a place that makes good vietnamese wings so far. We also had the Papaya salad. It was good too! These 2 are a must to order.

They also offered to serve it with Thai sticky rice in a bamboo box. We took it because we didn't wanna miss any of the experience. We were a little flustered because we usually just eat with white rice. It's a little more Thai than we're used to LOL, but it was delicious. 

We noticed that every single table had ordered the wings. That's how popular it is! We also noticed that some tables were ordering one plate per person and eating it like American wings, with nothing else. What we normally do is eat it with rice. But hey that goes to show that everyone like it in every way they can eat it!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The wings were decent, thanks to guy fietti.  Besides that it missed the mark.  The soup had no flavor, the beef salad was salty, and it was small portions and expensive.

The crowd next to us was also rowdy and kept bothering us.

The waiter comp'd the soup and allowed us to get out of there.  Don't believe the hype, Guy's reviews are bogus!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Delicious Fried Chicken Wings? Check.
Awesome tasty prawns? Check
Friendly and helpful service? Double check.

I would say the overall experience at Pok Pok is as rumored to be, AWESOME. Since this was our first time there with out of town guests, we thought we would try something new. We were not disappointed. 
The server explained how each dish should be eaten and what type of rice we should order to complement the individual dishes. He was incredibly helpful. 

Everything we ordered, Steak Salad, Chicken Wings, Tuna Salad and the stir fry prawns (sorry I don't remember their exact names) were all very good. I can't wait to go back and try more items on their extensive menu.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:

text: Great and tasty chicken wings just like everyone else say about them. Pair it with the coconut rice, and its a great flavour combo! Service is also

text:
A little overrated. 

I was really excited to check this place out- not sure if it lives up to the hype.  Although flavorful, the portions were rather small for price.  The most stand out dish was the fish sauce wings.  We also ordered a few other items on the menu (including the half bird) which were not spectacular. 

On the plus side, the waiter was very knowledgeable in providing recommendations and the overall ambiance is unique and a little funky.  It would probably take a few visits to Pok Pok to figure out which dishes we would like the best but deciphering the menu was an entire job in itself!

text: Overhyped and salty. And reserve a seat or you will have to wait 45 mins on a Saturday night.

name: Pok Pok

text:
a lil' different,
than the average Thai food
too hyped up for me
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I heard this place gets really busy.  First time I came here, I called the morning of to make reservations.  A few rings and I get an unpersonalized answering machine, strange, but I didn't think much of it, so I left a message "Hi, this is Sophia, I'd like to make reservations for tonight at 6:30pm, my call back number is ... Thanks!"  A little while later I get a missed call and a voicemail.  So apparently I must've misdialed the number thinking it was Pok Pok's number!  A nice lady left me a message saying that I called the wrong number and she called Pok Pok for me to make reservations but she didn't know how many were in my party.  WOW!  I called her back and thanked her, she said she gets those calls a lot and to try to chicken wings. =)

I eventually dialed the right number and the hostess suggested that I didn't need reservations for 2.  But to tell you the truth, I wish I made reservations for 2 because we still had to wait and the only seats open were the bar seats and the ones outside next to the rice cookers.  The set up of this place is pretty wicked.  There's an indoor area that's tightly packed and then outdoor areas that are covered and then an area in between where a few people can sit for a quick meal.  

I've been here a couple of times, I highly recommend the chicken wings.  I tend to avoid the spicy ones, but the spicy level isn't spicy at all.  The menu gets kind of confusing with all the mixed up flavors, but the servers are helpful and make suggestions if you tell them what you like.  Also, listen in for the food and drink specials!  If I'm ever back in the area, I'd definitely try their cocktails.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We tried Pok Pok on a recent visit.  The wait was a bit long but it was too be expected.  Our group ordered a few orders of their wings at different spice levels - all were great.  A few of us ordered beverages and all were great and refreshing but its funny because although the drinks we ordered were delicious our group couldn't stop talking about the complimentary water that was flavored with pandan.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Get the wings.  You want the wings.  And the wings want you.  Order a lychee vinegar with it.  DO IT.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Ah, Pok Pok: this is regarded as one of the best food experiences in Portland and just maybe in Oregon. The only reason I heard about this place was from my friend who is from Portland and after that, I started seeing the name "Pok Pok" EVERYWHERE.

Apparently, Pok Pok is only found in Portland and New York. It's a Northern Thai restaurant, meaning that they won't have your typical curry dishes or your pad thai (both of which are more central Thailand food). The only dish that actually has coconut in it (since it's scare in Northern Thailand) is their Tom Kha. 

So what's great about this place? EVERYTHING! We had the opportunity to try out a number of their dishes. A lot of the waitresses and waiters will keep reiterating that Pok Pok is meant for a shared food experience, and I also echo that. Order a number of dishes and eat it family style. The portion sizes are a bit small for each dish and so it's meant to distribute around the table. If I recall correctly, we got their fish sauce wings, the boar meat, waterfall beef tom kha, the pok pok papaya salad, and cat fish noodles. 

First of all, the fish sauce wings were amazeballs. There are a number of places in the US that are known for amazing chicken wings (such as San Tung's garlic wings in SF), and Pok Pok's wings definitely rank up there. The sauce wasn't too overwhelming and the wings were cooked perfectly. It's a nice dish to try and I highly recommend it.

Second, the Tom Kha was probably one of my favorite parts of our meal. It isn't hard to make a coconut curry soup, but they added the perfect blend of coconut milk and curry in there. The soup was flavorful, not too creamy, and overall delicious. This is another one of those items that you need to share with other people.

Third, the waterfall beef and wild boar were tender and SO JUICY. They both taste a bit different and the sauces that are used have some distinctions, but you really do need to try each. We got extra leaves and ice to use with the wild boar because it was apparently spicy - it wasn't. Portion size is small so please be aware of that!

The curry catfish was another great dish. It's pretty much vermicelli noodles and catfish in an oily, curry sauce. It comes in a small bowl and works well with a salad or piece of lettuce on the side.

Last, we tried the pok pok papaya salad. The menu warns that htis dish is very spicy, but it really isn't if you have any experience with spicy food. Again, portion size is small but very delicious regardless!

Don't forget the drinks though! The waitress recommended the non-alcoholic ginger/vinegar drinks and they were splendid. I ordered the black pepper one and it tasted unique with a bit of a kick to it.

Overall, Pok Pok is a perfect experience with fine Thai dining. You really don't get many opportunities to try Northern Thai food unless you are actually in Thailand (Chang Mai). The only reason why I give this place 4 stars is because the portion sizes are a bit TOO small for me for the price. Though we ordered a lot, we ended up paying about $30 a person, and I feel like that is a bit much for Thai food.

However, you need to check this place out...

Eat well and prosper,
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: So Pok Pok is like a little village consisting of "huts" that people dine in which is suppose to resemble street food in Thailand (minus the bugs but including the $15 per dish prices).  I found the menu at Pok Pok to be super confusing and would have appreciated some suggestions/input from the waitress.  We were obviously baffled by the selections and ended up getting a coconut curry noodle dish as well as the eggplant dish with coconut rice.  The coconut rice didn't taste like coconut and the eggplant was cold which I wasn't happy with since it was 40 degrees outside and I needed warmth.  The noodle dish was good.  Their drink menu is very exotic and extensive so I recommend taking advantage of that as well.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great wings. Love coming here for a date night or bringing family from out of town.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Expected a long wait and still go there. Yes we waited for more than an hour for 2 persons to eat their chicken. Their fried chicken is the bomb. It is soft, juicy and tasty. We also tried Pork Curry. It is authentic asian taste and very closed to Burmese Pork Curry. I'm born and raised in Myanmar (Burma). This is very close to burmese curry taste that i can find in U.S. Not even some of my relatives home cook curry taste like this because they use indian spice. The third one we got was Boar Salad. Its sour and spicy sauce is very thai authentic. Must go.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We went out of our way to visit this place because of all their rave reviews and being featured on food network.   We weren't disappointed! I like how they made the place look like you're actually in Thailand.   We ordered the famous fish sauce wings and I, surprisingly, really liked it. I don't tend to eat salty food and this was pretty salty, but somehow, the combination of flavors worked! You get a hint of sweet and spicy, and it's absolutely perfect with the sticky rice! We also ordered pork belly in Burmese curry and chicken satay for the kids, and both turned out really good too.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Such amazing food! We had the chicken wings, which are huge and packed with flavor, and the catfish vermicelli on the recommendation of our server, and we were so surprised with how delicious yet light it was. Yum!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: We tried this location for the first time.  I've been to the other location and came to this location this time. The chicken wings were amazing.  Everything else that we tried was just okay.  We'll definitely try some other things next time we come.  Come and get the chicken wings!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: On a recent road trip from Seattle to SD, I had to make a stop at Pok Pok in Portland. I had the pleasure of dinning here with years ago. I almost could not find this place as so many of the surrounding architecture and landscape had changed. This casual and quaint 'shack' transports me back to Thailand! As expected, service was very professional and friendly. Considering it was a Sunday evening, they were packed and therefore, the kitchen was slow in serving our order. Their famous chicken wings were not as crisp and explosive as I remember them to be; but it was definitely very good. The grilled Halibut collar special was a large portion and spectacular. Enjoyed out cocktail drinks very much and definitely recommend trying the yuzu rum daiquiri! The authentic touch on this place has been slightly abandoned, but compared to most Thai restaurants, this is the very best I have had in the Pacific Northwest!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
My fiance has family in Seattle and we decided to take a trip out and go do things for a week or so. I knew that would be put us very close to Portland. I realized we had a free day so I insisted we rent a car and drive from Seattle to Portland to get Pok Pok. 

I am so glad we made the decision to venture out to here. The owner Andy Ricker is rather famous and all the awards and acclaim he has gotten don't do him justice! The man is clearly a genius with an unmatched culinary vision.

I had to have the Fish Sauce Wings.. and I did have them and they were oh my god so amazing! I cant explain the sweet savory and delicious flavor that was going on with these wings. The little sticky bits of garlic with the savory flavor from the fish sauce is literally mind blowing!

Everything else we had was great too , the pork belly was delicious the Brussel Sprouts were delicious and I could go on and on about how much I love Pok Pok! 

If you are within 100 miles I'd say drive here and try the food. If you have to fly all the way from Texas .. well you wont regret it I know I didn't!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
When my friends heard I was going to Portland, several of them recommended to me Pok Pok. I had never heard of it and had assumed it was a food truck...turns out it's pretty much the opposite of what you'd expect from a food truck (except for the atmosphere).

I think Valerie L sums it up best by saying "this isn't the best Thai food I ever had, but it definitely is delicious." None of the dishes we had would be considered Thai - maybe Pok Pok is better described as "Southeast Asian Fusion." And that's a culinary style I would love to see more of because it is amazing. But what I think is ultimately preventing me from shelling out the 5 stars with abandon is the price and the overly hyped Fish Sauce Chicken Wings. I could faintly taste the difference in chicken quality compared to what I usually get in Chinatowns or Costcos in California (i.e., hormone-pumped goodness), but the sauce and flavor of the chicken wings themselves were really nothing special. Because of the price ($14?!), it's not something I would order again next time I visit.

What I did love was literally everything else. We ordered the catfish vermicelli with herbs and the Burmese-inspired pork belly stew (both $15 each). We were in heaven. The vermicelli was quite possibly the best I ever had and helped offset the oils from the catfish.
