The catfish was cooked to perfection, not a single bite tasted rubbery, and the peanuts worked seamlessly with the herbs to enhance the fish. The pork belly stew was nothing novel for me, but the tenderness of the meat really blew my mind. Every bite was perfect and the curry was rich with flavor and fat. I highly recommend ordering a bowl of rice if you're going to eat this dish. All and all, a great dining experience. Even now, as I write this review MONTHS after this meal, I feel like I can relive the whole thing. The flavors of these dishes are very vivid, and they stay with you long after you've digested!

I'm also a huge fan of Pok Pok's drinking vinegars. I ordered the ginger flavor and highly recommend it. We were too stuffed to even try a dessert, but I noticed people opted to get their sugar cravings satisfied at the nearby Salt & Straw.

On a random note, I love how Pok Pok deals with its popularity - you can put your name on a waitlist and then you'll be directed to right across the street to the Whiskey Soda Lounge, a bar with one of the most extravagant selections of whiskeys I've ever seen. Once your table is ready, the host or your waiter at Whiskey Soda Lounge will notify you. Genius business move on the part of the owners of Pok Pok, but also great for customers too because it's a fantastic way to kill time. The Whiskey Soda Lounge also has some noms (like the chicken wings, not that I'd recommend them) and even the drinking vinegars that I am now obsessed with. 

And in case you are wondering, yes you will definitely have to wait, unless you arrive very early for lunch. Don't worry - it's worth it!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Always a favorite ! The wings were on point last night! We took guests from Dallas and they were blown away, could not stop raving about it !
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The hype is real. Was excited to try this place but was disappointed that this place was just a hype.

The famous Ike's wings were way salty and expensive. I have had much better and cheaper back home in California.

The pork belly curry was great. However they only gave 4 pieces of pork belly. Curry was very spicy FYI. Combination of the curry and coconut rice was recommended which was what we got but I thought that the rice was too overpowering.

The waiters were rude to everyone. I sat outside on the bar so I could see everything going on. After waiting a good 10 minutes for someone to take our order, we finally waved someone over only to have him shut us down and to tell us to talk to our server. And then as time goes on I see him be equally as rude to others who were standing on the sidewalk waiting to be seated - people were confused by the chaos and naturally had questions. The last thing I heard him say was "do you have a reservation?" "no? Wait over there." they were all really busy and I could see all the waiters hustling but as a customer I expected to be treated as a paying customer. They all looked like they hated their job- just an observation.

I highly recommend getting a reservation. Line was long and people were given an 1.5 hrs to 2 hours waiting time. I personally won't be coming here again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Me and my husband went down to visit this place all the way from Seattle for our 1 year wedding anniversary. The food was delicious and our waiter was kind. However the reason why I am rating this place so low was due to the racism that we experienced when we first walked in. Which is shocking because it is a Asian restaurant and we are Asian American. There were 2 other families in the whole restaurant and they sat us side by side the only other East Asian looking couple. I asked to be moved to another table because their tables are so close and their were about 10 other open tables. The host said no, they all have reservations. I didn't think much of it until after going to the bathroom to wash my hands I over heard the other waitress talking to another guest. She was so shocked that because of The corona virus 2/3 of their reservations were canceled! I felt rude to interrupt but I insisted for another table and this hostess was happy to accommodate. To the restaurant I ask that you educate your staff to please be aware of micro aggressions. #Iamnotavirus
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
When I walked into Pok Pok my nose thanked me. It smells delicious in there.

Then Don B and I indulged in a serious meat fest for dinner, which was when my taste buds and stomach thanked me.

We ordered ribs, boar collar, steak "salad," and of course the wings - and to balance it all out a side of sticky rice. Everything tasted fantastic, but I'd have to say my favorite was the wings. And almost all of our choices were spicy which led to lots of sniffles and drinks. The drink in question for me was a plum wine cocktail, which turned out to be refreshing and not too sweet as plum wine can be. 

The atmosphere here is super cute since the restaurant is housed in a house. We sat on the deck upstairs on the front of the building. They do have heaters out there if it gets too cold and festive Christmas lights to brighten up the area at night. And the finishing touches to our awesome evening was the server - she was super friendly and professional. Pok Pok, I have a feeling I'll be seeing you again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: People say its overrated, but I guess all the things I ate hit the sweet spot. I had their famous Ikes Chicken Wings with Fish Sauce + sticky rice and their homemade durian ice cream. Love love loved the salty-ness and crispiness of the wings together with the sticky rice (= although the sticky rice could've been made better). The durian ice cream was amazing! Super fresh and creamy, the taste of durian was pretty strong but that made it even better. Will be back on my next Portland trip!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Didn't live up to it's billing ... my order of wings had no crunch at all and were overly salty (and I'm aware they're made with fish sauce ... I like fish sauce).  They just weren't very well balanced, and weren't crispy at all.

My husband's roasted hen wasn't as good as he had hoped -- it was a bit dry.

Perhaps they were having an off day -- as we've only eaten here once.  However, I don't think we'll be back.

We arrived before they opened for lunch and by opening time there was a pretty good line on a weekday.  

Service was okay; not great (had to find someone to ask for water) as our server disappeared.  Atmosphere is festive.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Restaurants come and go in PDX. Food carts come and go in PDX. Pok Pok remains. We've been here many times. 
I hate trying to find parking. I hate the wait. I hate that there's no reservations.  But it's all SO SO worth it for the food. So worth it. The food is incredible. So despite the things I don't like, I have to tackle them so I can eat Pok Pok. 
I must eat Pok Pok!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
What hasn't been said about Pok Pok that hasn't been said before?  This is indeed a must-visit when in Portland -- hands down our best meal during our Pacific NW road trip!

Location and ambience:
This is right in the heart of the hip SE Division strip.  (Warning: make time to find parking, and good luck!)  Very quaint ambience -- the restaurant is an addition to an old home and evokes a rustic homey feel, with simple wooden furniture, ceiling fans, and tiny kitchen quarters with big cauldrons on stilts. 

Service:
Knowledgeable and accommodating staff who are genuinely proud of their restaurant and their hugely popular chef.  There was a surprisingly short line when we arrived, and the hostess was nice enough to give us some extra time while the hubby scoured for parking.

Food:
James Beard award winner Andy Ricker definitely knows how to put up a meal that would keep you coming back from more -- I'm getting hungry just remembering these.  

Papaya Pok Pok - perfectly tangy papaya salad with their signature chili lime dressing 

Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce wings - seriously finger-lickin' good!

Kai Yaang - stuffed rotisserie roasted game hen, with tamarind sauce -- yes!

Khao Soi - coconut milk based soup with mushroom and tofu - kid-approved!

Kaeng Hang Leh - sweet pork belly and pork shoulder curry - tender and savory meat

Muu Paa Kham Waan - grilled wild boar collar meat rubbed with coriander root, garlic and pepper, and glazed with soy and sugar -- my fave!

We loved everything that we ordered and seriously considered going back again the next day before heading out of Portland.  I guess we'll just have to come back again soon!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
The second time around was not as good... not sure why.

Ordered papaya salad, two orders of boar collars and an order of wings to share between four people.  Decent amount for appetizers, but an order of the boar collar is simply not enough.  Make sure you really understand how SMALL the portion is for the boar collar... (which was why we ordered two plates to start).

I loved that they offered mustard leaves to help you cool down your mouth and cleanse your palate between bites.  I honestly remembered the boar being better when I came here the first time.  Now I think it's over drenched in sauce.

The spiciest thing we had that day was the papaya salad, and we didn't even get it SUPER spicy!  It was, however, very refreshing for a hot day (despite it being very spicy...)  We chugged our water really quick, thank goodness the California drought hasn't hit us in Portland yet.

The wings were sweet, spicy and sticky as expected, but the meat was tender and you pretty much have to lick your fingers afterward. 

I'll probably only come back here when my out-of-town friends visit.  To me, it's not worth suffering through the wait to come eat here.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
This place is AMAZING.  Seriously.  If you want to eat delicious and "not your standard Thai restaurant Thai food", then do your tastebuds a favor and hit up Pok Pok!

My group of 4 showed up an hour before close, and they gave us a 45 minute wait time.  We headed across the street to Whiskey Soda Lounge (run by the same people), and had a drink to pass the time.  When we got the call (they text you when your table is ready), we headed over and were seated. The menu looks daunting, but it really isn't.  Most everything on the menu is very detailed, but the staff seems more than willing to answer questions about dishes.  My group tried 4 different things, and each was absolutely delightful.

Some of the reviews complain about the price versus portion size... If you want more quantity and less quality, then I suggest you try a more Americanized version of Thai food.  Perhaps there are some establishments in Beaverton you might be interested in?  Others complain about the wait... Hmm... Let's see.... As of this writing, over 3000 reviews and a 4 star rating.  Gee... I wonder why there's a wait for such a clearly "under visited" restaurant.  Get real.  The food is hands down, the best Thai food I've ever experienced.

I even saw one review that complained that there were "too many words" on the menu!  If you're having a hard time reading the menu, and want them to "take out all the words and put some pictures on it", I say this:  GO BACK TO CALIFORNIA.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: One word: Addicted.  The number 6 and wings are a staple in our household. We order take-out almost once a week from our Pok Pok Noi.  Bad ass food and cool people.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
As everyone else has stated, get the wings. So good! I am not a big wing fan either but have definitely been back multiple times for these wings.

I have had the catfish too and its also good.  The wild boar is good but beyond spicy. I can usually handle spicy too but this was beyond so be prepared.

If the line is long, go get it togo. They have a togo window!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: No pad thai.  No panang curry.  No Massaman curry.  I mean, what's going on?  Service was good.  What we did order was simply okay.  Maybe all the hype was too much to live up to?  Patio was hot and humid.  Felt like Thailand, so I guess they delivered on authenticity there.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Came here for lunch during a recent trip to Portland/Seattle and had a great meal. The décor of the restaurant is rustic, but the ambiance is cozy.

The menu can seem intimidating with a lot of unfamiliar food and ingredients, but our service was patient enough to walk us through the popular dishes for each section. Eventually, my fiance and I ordered the Papaya Pok Pok ($9.50), Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings ($15.50) and the Sii Khrong Muu Yaang ($15.50) baby back ribs. 

The food was quite delicious. The wings were bursting in flavor, but can get a bit salty after a couple. The baby back ribs had a good marinade with a variety of thai spices. The meat was also tender and juicy! Really enjoyed what we ordered! We went on a Saturday 10 minutes before it opened and did not have to wait.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is super delicious! Great vibe and the servers are helpful and friendly. The fish sauce wings are out of this world good, def recommend! I also recommend eating in because the experience is awesome, super authentic and a great place to hang out with friends, you won't be disappointed.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I showed up to the restaurant at 6:45 PM on a Tuesday and it was 35 minutes to get a seat at a table, but I was able to be seated right away at the bar. The spicy fish sauce wings were delicious, the meat was tender, the flavor was good, but I was disappointed that the wings were not spicy at all. The beef salad was also good. The sauce was a bit sweet than I would prefer, but it did have an overall good flavor and there was some spice to this dish. Service at the bar was fine, and it was an overall good experience. I wasn't blown out of the water by anything, but I wasn't disappointed with anything either.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Went in with a party of 6. Our table was upstairs and it was in a pretty cramped room. The menu looks pretty intimidating but the server was nice and helpful. Pork kabob things was decent but the peanut sauce brings it to another one. The chickens wings were too salty. Papaya salad tasted like home though. Would come back for the salad and peanut sauce.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Great service even in their peak hour and a wonderful place if you have a big family visiting from out of town. My main tip would be to make sure you get a reservation if you have a big party or prepare to wait!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Great concept. Mediocre execution. In bad need of someone in the kitchen who understands the idea of balance: 'Spicy' dishes can come out at nuclear level, inedible to someone who doesn't have tolerance. Other dishes can come out greasy and underseasoned, bland and boring.

Papaya salad and fish sauce wings, when they're done well, are fantastic, and everything I wish I could import from SEA. 

Portions are not really 'dinner sized'... this is more of a place for drinks and snacks than a dinner spot.

Frustrating place. I really like the idea of what they're doing. Hard to recommend it to anyone though. Too much can go wrong... easiest place in town to have 'worst meal ever' at.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: That's a quite unique place around Portland! The location is great, service is outstanding and food is delicious. I confess it was quite hard to choose what I wanted from the menu and also a good combination. But the waiter helped us and were great exotic choices! I also love the beach-like ambiance. The only down side if the long waitlist, but there are lots of things to do around while you wait. I would go back when I get a chance to visit Portland again.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Sooooooo dang gooood! Walk in smell the fish sauce fill the room, chicken wings so delicious! Papaya salad spicy clean done correctly. Curry's are great as well! You really can't go wrong with any choice on this menu! The drinks are well done as well. Just listen to the hype go early lines are usually long. But beat the hipsters go little
Before 6 and you get right in and go on a weekday. But even the wait is worth it and they get your food out real quick! Enjoy the experience!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Dishes are overly priced. Service was poor. Not worth it. 

This was my first time coming here and I'm disappointed in the dining experience. We came here around 3PM and the restaurant was practically empty yet we still had to wait 20 minutes for a table. We ordered their infamous chicken wing and a steak salad, both which were SO SALTY that they were practically inedible without rice. The chicken wings were fairly ordinary, didn't necessarily knock our socks off. We couldn't finish the steak salad because it was overpowered with fish sauce, lime and basil. For whatever reason, our server gave other tables better service. We weren't given peanuts to start with, we weren't told specials of the day - just a few small things I noticed.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
While in Portland, we definitely had to stop by Pok Pok to try their Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings. We arrived on a Saturday around lunch time and luckily there was no wait. My jaw literally dropped when I saw the prices on the menu. $15.50 for WINGS?! These better be some amazingly delicious wings! Since most of the dishes were meant to be served family style, we settled for the fish sauce wings and Neua Naam Tok (steak salad). I ordered a side of their coconut rice.

The wings were definitely flavorful.. maybe a little too flavorful.. to the point that it was salty. The chicken was cooked perfectly though and we still enjoyed it. After tasting the wings, my boyfriend decided he did need a side of rice to go with his meal. The wings weren't as overbearing when eaten with rice.

 The real winner though was the steak salad! It was seasoned just right and the beef really soaked in all the flavors and was tender. It's probably the best beef salad I've ever had! Their coconut rice was also delicious, it had just a the right hint of coconut flavor.

I would definitely recommend trying this place out if you're in Portland, not for the wings but for their Neua Naam Tok (steak salad). I'm still thinking about it as I type this review..
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
First review of 2019!!!

Save for a semi-rude encounter at the door (not Pok Pok's fault) - I enjoyed every bit of my dining experience at the famous Pok Pok in PDX!

Reservations were super easy to make online. I even realized I made a slip up (forgot 2 ppl in my reservation...oops) day of and they were able to accommodate the larger party.

Pok Pok is located inside of what looks like a home. We were seated inside the house (upstairs so a little tough for those with difficulty...would recco you request seating downstairs next to the bar area). The decor was kitschy and the music was loud, but the food was phenomenal. 

Our waiter was the typical PDX hipster, not super enthusiastic but got the job done and checked on us multiple times as well as refilled our waters/our special request for hot water. As a group of 8 we ordered doubles of the following:

- Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings: So good!!!! Worth all the hype and MORE. Tender, sticky, with just the right amt of sweetness. Loved this!

- Kai Yaang Tuua (whole roasted chicken): It's the whole chicken so some of the pieces tend to be drier than others. Comes with a bunch of dipping sauces, so that helped. Other than that, decent but unmemorable. 

- Kaeng Hang Leh (Northern Thai sweet pork belly and pork shoulder curry): A Chiang Mai classic! Everyone kept pouring the curry sauce over their rice - it was THAT good!

- Kung Op Wun Sen (prawn and pork belly casserole): prawns were seriously large and it was served with vermicelli which sopped up allllll dat sauce! 

Topped it off with a few Thai iced teas and a Pilsner (beer...when in PDX!) and we were all happy and full! Super exciting especially when you consider I was traveling with family and their palates tend to be all over the place (i.e., Chinese specific). This was unique enough to win them over. Thanks, Pok Pok!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I love street food but this is mediocre Street food gone overpriced! I suspect part of Oregon's "keep Portland weird" tradition is to upvote mediocre restaurants to mess with people. This is a sit down street food establishment that is priced as  high as a upscale restaurant but the deliciousness of the food is not as high as street food. We tried the wings, the prawn clay pot and the crepe. All okay but nothing earth shattering. We interacted with three or four servers, all appeared to be overworked and have life sucked out of them. The drink was okay. Ambience was okay. Very okay experience except the wait time. The 45 minutes wait was 45 minutes too long.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: As good as it gets..WOW...From Chicago and heard about this place from a friend. So had to go try and UNBELIVEABLE . Boar was spicy but soooooooooo good and the wings..."to die for" ..
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Well worth the hour wait. Michael our server was very good and described and recommended all the dishes we tried. Im not going to knock off the star because of the light that was out. We ended up sitting in near darkness. That's why my pictures did not come out so well. The waitress had mentioned that it had been out for a while and was not sure when they would get it repaired. My tip is if they sit you in a dark corner ask for another table. We would have moved although that wold have added to our long wait. Fried Chicken is perfect, the Boar collar amazing and the shrimp and noodles in the hot pot were excellent. We will be back soon.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: this place isn't good for the food, the chicken is aight. the wait was an hour and not worth. you come here to get and drink beers with the bois
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Wings on wings on wings on wings on wings!

Their dishes are made to share, so bring your friends!

I've never been to Portland before and would never have thought this type of delicacy had graced this great land. 

All these reviews talk about the wings and there's a reason for it. The skin had a slight crunch to it, while keeping the meat at a juicy, tender level. Their wings were sooo tasty. They were sweet and packed a little bit of heat. The group and I ordered a couple orders of these at first, then added about 3 more orders. WORTH IT!

We let our waiter recommend and pick the rest of our entrees so we could see what else this popular spot had to offer. There was way too much food for all of us. 

I don't remember what each dish was, but all of them were delicious. Their pork belly that came out in a stone pot had to be my second favorite. I'm sure if you describe it, they will know what you're talking about. 

Check this place out.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I came here because my friends wanted to try to their famous fish sauce chicken wings. My review is solely based on having tried only this one dish. To my dismay, the wings were on the saltier side. It was a good blend of seasoning but I just wished it wasn't so loaded on sodium. I've had Vietnamese fish sauce wings in little Saigon Orange County that are not as loaded with sodium and still tasted really good. I'd highly recommend you order a side of sticky rice or jasmine rice to pair with the chicken wings unless you have a high tolerance for lots of salt. The amount of salt in this dish alone may exacerbate your blood pressure and heart failure lol. 

We came at 3:45pm on a Friday and still had to wait as a party of 6 for 30 minutes with no one else in front of us which is surprising. I could only imagine how horrendous the wait would be if we came during peak hours. In my opinion, the chicken wings alone are not a worthy dish to wait for. Now, I have not tried the rest of their menu so I am not sure if the other dishes are worth the wait. But given that the wings is the most popular dish, I am not impressed by this establishment so far. Coming from LA/OC in SoCal, I guess my standards for good Asian food are high....
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Although you have to wait a while to get a table, it's well worth it. Food is excellent and authentic. My 3 year old wouldn't eat it. My 5 year old said it was her favorite food ever.  We tried 5 entrees family style and I thought it was absolutely delicious.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The hype about this place is real. The staff is super friendly and there are very authentic Thai options to choose from. One of my favorite parts is that the water that is served has Pandan flavor in it so even the water is super refreshing. The fish sauce chicken wings is what everyone talks about so I naturally ordered those. And yes they were amazing and fun to eat. Went here 4 times in a span of two months and every time was an good time. Would highly recommend coming here if you come to Portland.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We waited over two hours to be seated as a party of 2 on a Saturday night around 6:30pm, after being given an estimated wait time of 80 minutes. Once we *were* seated, it was in a semi-covered outdoor space that was partially heated with a heat lamp. Now, this would've been a-okay if it weren't for the fact that it was a chilly 40 degrees out that night and this restaurant doesn't offer complimentary hot tea (it was $4 a cup), and they only had herbal or early grey tea, which is weird and does not go with your Thai street-food meal). Anyway, it all just felt super anticlimactic given the long wait and the hype around this place, and I did not enjoy the fact that my hands were near-frozen all night.

The food was decent, but honestly didn't match the hype of the place. Perhaps it was because all the food so quickly turned cold. Okay, maybe I'm holding a grudge now. #shrug

We ordered Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings which were underwhelmingly flavored and not at all spicy. We also ordered the Cha Ca "La Vong", which we had tried in Vietnam. There were I think 4 small pieces of battered fried cod in the whole dish, which was very disappointing and felt cheap.

The service felt a bit cold as well (harhar), which didn't help the situation. My personal suggestion: order to go or only stop by when there's no line.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Too much hype! 

We've heard about this place all the way in LA. Every foodie friend we had recommended it. And when the wife and I came here one morning for lunch and saw that there was no line, we thought we were in heaven!

Alas, this was not so. We ordered the wing bean salad, the (spicy) fish sauce chicken wings, and the boar collar. The wing beans were good- a nice touch of coconut cream offset the garlic and sour spices and the prawns really gave the whole dish some nice heft.

However, the wings and the boar collar were disappointing. The first two wings were a little salty, but tasty. But after that, MSG coma set in. The taste seemed to dull with each passing wing until my wife and I were trying to convince each other to have the last one ("oh dear, PLEASE have the last bite!"). The boar collar really inconsistent- sour and puckering for one bite, white-hot for another bite. The meat itself was bleh- I would have preferred a nice ox tongue.

Overall, we felt very underwhelmed. And when the check came, we felt even more sad. . .
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: My favorite restaurant hands down. The flavors are just mind blowing good. They don't hold back. Their tamarind whiskey sours are perfection and so is everything I've eaten here. Boar collar is SPICY but so damn addicting. Neua Naam Tok (spicy flank steak) is my favorite dish I've tried. This place made me fall in love with Thai food. Can't recommend enough!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Amazing chicken wings!!! Go! Also great service.  One my favorite restaurants in the world.  The peanuts are delicious.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: The food didn't disappoint. I love their fish sauce chicken wings. It is flavorful and it's good to eat it with rice. The serving is good for 2-3 persons (not bad for $16). The employees are friendly and nice too except for the lady who processed our payment. Our bill was only around $50 so we put a $100 bill and she was like "Do you need change?!" in a very rude tone. Lol. I think that's very rude and inapproriate to ask. We will still come back for the food though.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: 土曜夜、18時半の時点で待ち時間ゼロだったのに残りの友達5人が到着した19時には待ち時間2時間に‥仕方なく近くの店でテキストされるまでパティオでウイスキーソーダを飲む。コールド&ハングリー。21時過ぎに呼び出され、再び外の席で寒すぎ。水がスティッキーライス味。これって普通なのかどうかで論争する。レモンとかバジルとからキュウリならわかるけど‥意図されたものか聞いたらなんと意図してるとのこと。ワンプレートのポクポクスペシャルを頼む。ローストチキンにバジルのタイソース、パパイヤサラダにスティッキーライス。美味しいけど普通。２時間待つ意味は全くない。サービスの人はいい人だった。
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
It was delicious. 

I've heard mixed reviews, but happy to report that my experience was great. I mean, it was a 2-hour wait, but it was fine. Gave us time to walk up and down the street and into the local shops. Who knows, maybe that's part of the plan, which would be smart to keep local business alive. 

The service was good. Staff was friendly and knowledgeable about the dishes, and gave honest recos.

There was 4 of us, so we were able to order several dishes to share. Everything was flavorful and delicious. The famous wings were fantastic. I personally, loved them. The braised pork belly was also a fave, as well as the glass noodle dish.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Love this place in SE Hawthorne. The food is really good. Great environment. Outdoor heaters.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: super yummy! i need to go and get more soon! I lived in Asia for a number of years and these are truly a great flavor product, regardless of what your past experiences.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
and yelp does it again - this place was on our list for two reasons 
1. yelp
2. everyone who ever comes to portland is like you gotta stop by pok pok

So we did and we were not disappointed but we were still left with that "hey it could have been better". the service is quick and there usually is a wait to get in so head over to the Whiskey Soda Lounge as its the other half of this empire to get some great drinks. and this place is crowed so chances are you square foot to move around is pretty much limited to exactly you arms reaching to grab the food right in front of you. 

the drinks were the same as WSL and I got the pok Pok beer which was alright and not like something i was wow'ed by so I wish I had picked something else off the menu. 

The roasted peanuts though -- COME HERE FOR THE PEANUTS! 10/10 nailed it and i even got a bag to go so i guess there was some winning here!

the food - so the ike's wings are the #1 go to dish to order and i have to say it was really salty and for the two of us we couldn't even get past 1 each for ourselves. so maybe if you are an explorer and tread not with the crowd i'd say get the ribs instead and boy oh boy were those boooommmbbbb!!!

also underrated item the eggplant - its not vegan but i think you can ask to make it vegan since it has pork and egg bits in it but it was sour and soooo melty in your mouth. might just come back for that! 

this menu is really crowded as well and might be overwhelming so i suggest asking for suggestions. we got the ribs, wings and coconut rice and then we though maybe one other thing off the menu. wrong decision and wrong choice on the sausage. it was one long piece cut into small bites and it was like why'd i get this. but it would go really well in fried rice together but on its own, not so much. 

overall come for the experience and the yelp hype but ask before you order.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Came here whilst on a trip with some friends because we had heard about their chicken! 

I highly recommend the Brussels sprouts and of course the fried chicken. All the meals here and meant to be shared with others so we ended up with about 4 dishes between 5 people. Pricing was decent for what it was and everything had an authentic taste to it. 

While our meal was amazing, the only thing that knocked it down two stars was the fact that foreigners had to have to their passports checked if they wanted to consume alcohol. And this is absolutely something unheard of as we were visiting from Vancouver, BC, Canada and our regular IDs were not accepted. 

Great food but a really weird policy. Have your passport ready!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
YUM.  I had heard great things about Pok Pok and was so glad I got around to eating here during my recent Portland visit.  We arrived around 8:15pm and were surprised to see that Pok Pok still had lots of people waiting around on a drizzly, cold Saturday night.  Luckily, my boyfriend convinced me to be patient and wait for an hour and a half - something that would usually deter me to go somewhere else immediately.  We left our phone number with the hostess, who told us we'd receive a call/text when our table was ready.  

We ended up driving to Target nearby to grab some snacks and kill time, and headed back around 9:45pm.  I approached the hostess, concerned that we may not be seated since the restaurant hours state closing at 10pm, and she said our table was ready and we could be seated inside!  (I didn't even realize there was inside seating, but it was definitely preferred since it was chilly outside.)

Our waitress greeted us warmly, and I noticed a few other tables being seating around the same time as us.  Business seemed to go on as usual despite the fact that they were technically closed!  Not sure when they close off allowing people to dine-in.  

We ordered the famous fish sauce wings and a curry noodle dish, with a side of sticky rice to share.  The food didn't take too long to arrive, and we had complimentary peanuts to snack on in the meantime.  I'm glad we held back when it came to ordering; the two dishes for us was plenty!  We even had a couple of wings and a little rice leftover.  While the curry noodle soup was warm and filling, I definitely think that the accompaniments helped dial up the flavors - squeezing in some lemon and adding some chili made the dish even more enjoyable.  The wings, on the other hand, were amazing from beginning to end to the next day when we reheated them for lunch.  We LOVED the wings and I would visit Pok Pok a million times just to order wings each time.  They definitely lived up to any expectation I had for them.  Yes, they were a little salty, but I thought it worked well with bites of rice and the pickled carrots, daikon, and cucumber that come with the dish.

All in all, I was really pleased with our visit to Pok Pok and can say that it was worth the wait.  Patience pays off!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
It was a Friday afternoon, I was up earlier than I like to be, navigated two airports on crutches, spent more time than was needed renting a car and we were starving.  When asked if I had any ideas where to stop for lunch, all I could think of was Pok Pok because every person I told about my trip to Portland all said the same thing...."go to Pok Pok or you'll be sorry."  

I wasn't sure if that was a threat, or they meant they just really liked it....but I wasn't taking any chances.  Before we even stopped at our hotel, we were on our way.

This isn't your usual Thai fare and I was pleased to see that and excited to try some things I've never had before.  So here is what we stuffed our tired faces with:

Ikes Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings:  First of all these aren't tiny little wings, they're big and you get 6 of them.  I shared, but I could have kept them all to myself.  They are worthy of the praise they are given.  They're marinated in sugar and fish sauce, deep fried and tossed in garlic and caramelized fish sauce and served with a refreshing side of pickled daikon and carrots.  They were tender, juicy and bursting with flavor....it was heaven.  

Papaya Pok Pok Salad:  Well balanced, refreshing, sweet, spicy, tangy, crunchy papaya, a little bit of chewiness from the dried shrimp.  It was everything a papaya salad should be.....wish I had tried it Isaan style (with extra spicy dried chili) though.  

Hoi Thawt:  Crispy broken crepe with mussels, egg, garlic, chives and bean sprouts served with sriracha.  Lots of mussels and good rich flavor but not overwhelmingly so thanks to the bean sprouts.  

Cha Ca "La Vong":  Catfish medallions fried in turmeric oil with scallions and dill served over rice vermicelli.  They don't skimp on the fish, there is plenty of it and it is GOOD.  The dill added a really nice touch and much needed brightness to the dish.  Make sure you pour the sauce over and mix well so it gets on the noodles!  

I NEEDED a cocktail and so I turned to their specials board and asked the waitress what she suggested.  She said the Gin Rummy (gin, rum, lemon juice and thai basil ) was really different and though it sounded a bit boring to me, I decided to trust her and I'm glad I did.  I didn't expect it to be as good as it was and it really complimented the food perfectly.  

So, bottom line, if anyone tells me they're going to Porland, I too will now threaten "go to Pok Pok or you'll be sorry!!!" though I will add "and please bring home some chicken wings for me."
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Where do I begin? Don't waste your time or money here. Food is MEH. The hostess is super rude and though it was "unconcventional" to get a drink as we waited for our table. In fact, we were told it was a 10-15 minute wait for outside seating while we waited 40 minutes and there were at least 8 outside seats available right in front of our eyes. The food was mediocre. The wings are over seasoned and very salted. The hostess followed us and wanted to know if we were going to sit at the bar because it was unconventional to get a drink before eating and we were not allowed to sit and wait at the 6 empty chairs at the bar. Lastly, we were overcharged for items we didn't order and had to wait for our bill to be corrected. Like is said, don't waste your time or money here. Lots of better options in this city.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Food is good, but this place is over rated for what it is. The papaya salad was way too salty. The entrees we had we're both good, but didn't feel like it was worth the wait
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
After traveling throughout Thailand and eating A LOT of street food there, I gotta say this was pretty good. I was surprised that they had a dish with cured pork sausage (Sunny Tam Wun Sen Chao). I've rarely had it in a dish but it was quite tasty with the glass noodles. 
The other dish I had was the Pok Special which was a half roasted chicken with papaya salad, cabbage, and sticky rice. The chicken was juicy and flavorful, and the papaya salad had an excellent balance of sweet, salty, and spice. The dipping sauces were also pretty good as well. 
Overall this was a nice place. Everything on the menu looked delicious and I definitely will be back to try the other dishes. The decor was nice inside and outside. Service was superb.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I didn't enjoy it. 

Mainly because the food wasn't good, and there are a few dozen Thai places in town that do this same exact thing, just way better.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
So overrated...  The seating was completely terrible as they tried to seat my 80 year old grandmother out in the cold and up a flight of stairs in the dead of winter.

When you wait for 2 hours to eat and then get treated like a stray dog being served scraps off of the front porch, it is pretty insulting.   

The manager on duty did get us a seat inside (albeit, with a snarky attitude of a studio 54 bouncer) but it was so crammed and busy that it really wasn't much better.   

I have been to Thailand a number of times and about the only thing they got right was the uncomfortable seats!  :D  

Everything else was completely bastardized and overpriced.  My fiancee and I both got sick after eating here and ended up paying double for the portions we get at any other Thai food in PDX.  

I would much rather support real Thai people and get better food for a lower price.   This restaurant is exactly what is wrong with Portland.  All hype and leaving you feel like you made a "tourist trap mistake" you only need to make once.

If you love waiting for mediocrity stop at Voodoo donuts first and then waste even more of your day here.   You will be out of time, money and even have a rumble in your stomach from poor food quality.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Got the wings, of course. I had high expectations and they were honestly met. I really enjoy the unique and spicy flavors of Northern Thai cuisine and Pok Pok delivers. Tried 3 other waiter-recommended dishes as well. Everything was super flavorful and awesome. The noodle dish with prawns and pork belly was also amazing. We went on a Friday night at 7pm and only had to wait 10 mins. This was a bucket list restaurant for me and I'm pretty excited to have experienced it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok is amazing. 'nuff said. Their food is so unique. It's a cross between asian, thai, grilling, and awesomeness.  I recommend making a reservation or going later in the evening because they get pretty busy.  And definitely try the wings!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Really one of the must visit eatery/restaurant if you are in Portland. Ike's Vietnamese Chicken wing is arguably the star of the show here. They have other items in the menu too which are good like Boar Collar stripes grilled and served in a hot sauce. Good Service. It takes sometime to get the items to your table as it's all made fresh. 

Wait times can be longer, but it's really worth it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Ike's chicken was amazing and the coconut rice was delicous!! Definitely coming back next time we are in town.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: It's everything you would expect it to be if you have been to Thailand, but if PadThai is your jam, this place is not your spot.  Real in every way it's food you will love.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Good food, 2 hour wait, waiter was a total jerk. Would go again-- with a reservation and another waiter.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Went to Pok Pok for the first time last weekend and I have to say I don't understand the hype.  The wings were great, but not any better or much different than those I can get a some food carts.  The dishes my wife and I had were supposed to be curry but were nearly flavorless.  You have to do a really poor job to make a flavorless curry dish.  The noodles were on the soggy side in my dish, which should not happen at a place pike this.  Not the highest quality ingredients either.  For the prices I would expect much higher quality.  Pok Pok is an "okay" restaurant with decent service and mediocre to decent food, but it is not worth standing in line for and definitely not worth the prices they charge.  Seems like nothing more than just another over-hyped Portland fad.  I love this city and all the food options, but we do have a tendency to popularize places like this and extend the hype for far too long.  save your money and go someplace else just down the street.  Just about every other restaurant in the area is likely a better choice - better food, better service, shorter lines for less $.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Yum yum yum! What an authentic place to get some Thai and Vietnamese food. Once I was brought to my seat and smelled the fish sauce I knew this was going to be good. They do not take reservations so be mindful of that.

You definitely have to get the wings at some point and have some sticky rice to go with it. I loved the papaya salad which was just the right spice level for me and I also had their Khao Soi. Can't wait to come back and try more delicious food.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Definitely a MUST, when visiting Portland, OR. So glad we came for early dinner, just past 5pm, parked right in front of the place. The Wings?!?!?! Scrumptious! Then I had the flank steak, spicy, cooked medium, with basil and shallots; my husband ordered the Baby back ribs. Everything was Delish! It's not about the decor! It's about the FOOD!!! Service was awesome! We had no room for dessert!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This Pok Pok is insane and worth the wait. The one in NW Portland doesn't have a lot of the same stuff on the menu so I would definitely stick to this one. This one is also a lot cuter inside. The wings really are as good as everyone makes them out to be. Get them spicy, because even when you get them spicy they still could use some more spice. I don't know what they put on the corn but get that too. A perfect meal if you get it with the Thai Iced Tea. Also their water has something in it that makes it taste really good. Cucumber maybe? Just a really good experience and worth the wait that they almost always have.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Came here during our trip after hearing good things about pok pok but honestly... it's overhyped.

The fish sauce wings are on the unique side with nice caramelized skin, but they're just.. ok. 
They ran out of pork belly so we didn't get to try that, don't go late if you expect to order it.

We tried a steak dish instead which was very overwhelming with saltiness. 

Don't expect the portions here to be generous either. 

Overall I wouldn't come back. I'm glad it wasn't super crowded. It's an okay experience, sadly.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Had high expectations for this place because it's a "top place" to try in Portland but was really disappointed with the long wait (at least 45 min), terribly small portions, and steep price. 

I came here with two friends and we had just ordered a charcuterie board and wine flight down the street at Urban Winery & Wine Bar while we waited so we weren't too hungry. We ordered the Muu Paa Kham Waan (boar collar meat), Kai Yaang (half bird chicken) and sticky rice. The food was good, but the plates were literally for ants. This all cost about $32.50 (which wasn't too bad since we split it among 3 people) but definitely not worth.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Not good for gluten free people. 

I'm celiac and they said they would be able to take care of me but I've been glutened both times I ate there. I made sure to call ahead and ask if they could accommodate me. I asked the waiter to check with the kitchen about what was easiest for them. 

If they'd said they couldn't keep things separated and I went ahead, that would be on me. (I had another Thai place basically yell at me over the phone that they put gluten in everything and I wasn't offended. At least I know where they stand) 

Food was delicious, but I was badly sick.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: There's a reason why there's always such a long line at this place. The food here is outstanding. The first time I came here everyone said, you have to try the wings. I'm generally not a fan of wings. However, these wings held up to the hype. I get them every time I come back. The flavor of the fish sauce is amazing. Other items that I would recommend are Kung Op Wun Sen, and the Laap Pet Isaan. The drinks leave something to be desired. It would be nice if there was some alcohol in them. I never like paying $10.00 for juice. However, the food is always so good, it's still deserving of 5 stars.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Asian people are their harshest critics. 

For example, when Jeremy Lin got his championship with the Raptors, instead of saying cool bro what a journey, a lot of Asian Americans were like what an asterisk without taking into account how hard it is to be on an NBA roster. Also, I recently went to a dim sum place in SF that was "not authentic" and some of my friends commented that the place was "overpriced" or "Americanized".  

Let me pause here and say, can't we just celebrate and enjoy things for what they are if they are good? Freaking haters yo.  

I bookmarked Pok Pok because it is one of the most reviewed places in Portland. The wife and I pulled the plug for over a decade so my wife did not know the chef, Andy Ricker, was Caucasian. When I found out, I kept that part a secret to see how she would react. Guess what? She was surprised in a good way when I told her because the food was delicious. I think if you go into Pok Pok with preconceived biases or try to compare it to your nana's cooking, then you should just stay home because no one can compete with nana. Na-na-na. However, if you want to try food that is fresh, vibrant, and tasty, then book that reservation now. 

Pok Pok is the Thai onomatopoeia for the sound of wooden pestles hitting mortars to make papaya salads. I found out from a Filipino friend that pok-pok is slang for a prostitute in Tagalog lol. I guess I am a pok-pok for Pok Pok? Moreover, imagine if the "o" in Pok Pok were an "e", Pinays would be laughing all day. Although, some people might say Pok Pok smells like P*k P*k because of all the fish sauce ROFL. 

Fish sauce. 

I guess you either hate it or love it. I'm Korean so we have some funky smelly foods and a lot of people use fish sauce in kimchi so I don't mind it at all. But if you are not used to it, it's probably a sensory overload. And, Pok Pok's famous wings are marinated with a fish sauce marinade. We loved the wings which were super tasty and legit.  

Sidenote: I wondered why the wings were called Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings. I was like who the heck is Ike? Turns out Ike is the nickname for Mr. Ich "Ike" Truong who was Pok Pok's first employee (and still employed) when Pok Pok was just a street cart and the recipe is his family recipe from Vietnam.  

Since the restaurant is named Pok Pok, we had to get the papaya salad. It had the right amount of tang and zest and wasn't too spicy which I did not mind at all.  Another tasty dish that we got was the clay pot noodle dish with prawns called kung op wun sen. Very good. The coconut rice was good, but not worth $3.75. Maybe if they threw in some mangos? I would suggest just getting the regular jasmine rice. 

At the end of the day, I recommend that you Pick Pick Pok Pok if you are visiting Portland or if you just want some really tasty Southeast Asian food that tastes legit. 

Pok Pok has a dog-friendly patio, which is why it's 5 stars in my book! Hard to find dog-friendly restaurants that taste good and have great service. The struggle is real. 

* Hey Trailblazers, as of August 5, 2019, Jeremy Lin remains a free agent. Dude would be a perfect fit!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: There was a 45 minute wait but thankfully you get texted when the table is ready. Our server was very nice and answered all our questions. I had the infamous chicken wings which were delicious. I wish it came with a side of rice since it was on the saltier side. If no rice, than a lower price would be more fitting. Otherwise i would come back to try the other menu items.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok's atmosphere is unassuming, but it's food tastes complex and rich. Vegetarian items are marked clearly on the menu, and the wait staff was proactive in asking if our party had any dietary restrictions. Upon learning I'm vegan, the waiter pointed out which vegetarian dishes were suitable, which were almost all of them. I had the spicy mushroom salad, and I've never had anything else quite like it. For non-vegans, my companion said the wings were some of the best he ever had. Also for non-vegans? Try the spicy mushroom salad, it's unique. I would confidently recommend Pok Pok to just about anyone.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Hype. 

I only remember eating the wings and the rest were whatevs...
The wings were good but not amazing. I don't know why this place is so raved about. It was good but nothing amazing. I know for a fact that it was quite expensive.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: This place is worth however long they tell you to wait. And please don;t miss the wings. They are epic. Also, if you don;t drink alcohol have the bartender make you a mocktail of drinking vinegar and seltzer. Delish!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Love love love this place! The chicken wings is worth waiting in line for a long time!!! And the curry pork belly, is yumm Their cocktails are great too! It's all family style serving. Overall it's amazing experience. Yummy for my tummy!!!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: I wanted to try this place for some time based on the hype.  Quite honestly, I expected so much more...  For starters, the place is a shack with one unisex bathroom right next to the not so clean kitchen.  Service was fairly good but food was marginal at best.  Three of us shared the wings (gross), papaya salad (good), pork tenderloin skewers (zero flavor without the peanut sauce), ribs (gross) & 1/2 chicken (very good).  My lime aid was great!  Glad I can check this place off the list.  Next!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Puddles of Pok Pok grease vomit floating in the toilet --- yes, that's right, I barfed.  

Actually, I should clarify.  I didn't barf, but my partner did, all night long.  Basically the mediocre catfish dish did her in.  It's some kind of pan seared and under-seasoned catfish (apparently the server's fav...God knows why) resting on rice noodles which are swimming in grease.  The noodles kind of resembled baby food.  Once you put them in your mouth you were dually fighting both the gritty mushy crumbling of over cooked rice along with the bubble of grease that was sloshing around in their and then eventually coating your stomach.  Fortunately for me, I took one bite of the noodles and then let them be.  Later, I survived the evening with merely gas, bloating and general indigestion.  My partner, who was not so lucky, had more than a few bites.  The revelation of the grease as we were eating told us that perhaps this was not the much talked about cuisine we were expecting.  We explained the grease situation to the waitress (who had previously been quite nice to us) and were confronted with a curt "It's supposed to be like that.  Would you like your check?"  Well, yes, I guess we would...thanks.

The next day, we called the manager to explain the bout with food poisoning that was endured.  He tactfully gave us the run around by saying there was no way he could know if we were food poisoned by his restaurant because of blah blah blah.  He then suggested we call some kind of food and health thingy to assess what exactly gave us food poisoning.  I explained that she barfed up little puddles of Pok Pok grease (literally...they were floating around in the toilet), but he remained unconvinced.  Oh well.

In addition to the food poisoning, overall everything we had was highly unimpressive.  The chicken wings, also recommended by our server, were ridiculously overflavoured.  I felt like I was eating a brown sugared lollipop of a chicken wing.  The sweetness was overwhelming.  We also had the soup, which did not have an offensive flavor profile by any means, but it was just boring and also overly greasy.

Did I mention the drinks?  We both had lime infused vodka and gin drinks and both agreed it was like sucking on the rind of a lime the whole time.  

So, 70 dollars and one sleepless night later, I imagine you've guessed...I won't be going back.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
My recent Pok Pok discoveries:

1. There's no wait on the Monday night of Thanksgiving week.
2. Ike's Fish Sauce Wings can and should be ordered "spicy"
3. The Pork Belly/Shoulder with curry is BOMB
4. They should provide more than one wet-nap to anyone who orders Ike's Fish Sauce Wings
5. They now have a mushroom (veg) version of the spicy beef salad - YUM!
6. I can't afford to eat at Pok Pok very often (but I wish I could)

Upping it to a solid 5-star culinary experience, with flavors that take me back to Thailand.

If you're looking for lots of food for a good value, or standard phad thai, go elsewhere.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
I give 3-stars because 1) it's not owned by Thai people and culinarily-speaking, especially with Thai and Asian food, this factor makes a HUGE difference to the taste as there are alot of nuances in flavoring of the food; and 2) too much hype surrounds it - more than it deserves.

However, with this said I give them KUDOS for their efforts. They are trying to recreate the ambience (and food) of Northern Thailand which is admirable but Thai BBQ Chicken is NEVER made with Cornish Game Hens. The bird just isn't part of the everyday fare. Cucumber Relish, Peanut Sauce, Shrimp Chips which are SO SO inexpensive are  usually served as complimentary side dishes at no extra charge. This kind of stuff plus the professionally bottled vinegar/Thai sauce gives me pause.

I agree it's 'cool', innovative and has a fun vibe but what I truly value is the quality of the food and for me, it misses the mark esp compared to other Thai restaurants in PDX that is more deserving of our patronage. PokPok is more of a venture in marketing and branding than a commitment to good food. Sorry, PokPok but that's how I see it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Being a huge fan of Thai food, I had to visit Pok Pok when I visited Portland.  It's got quite the following and boasted many glowing reviews before I stepped thru the door.  It serves mainly northern Thai dishes, so don't expect to see any Pad Thai or yellow chicken curry on their menu.  I let the waitress suggest some dishes and my family and I were not disappointed, it is however, not your average Thai restaurant.  The bar was heavy on whiskeys, some coming from as far as Japan, and the bartenders were all very adept mixologists providing excellent service, as did our waitress and server.  

Would I go again? probably not, my palate leans towards the southern Thai dishes, but I'm not sorry I tried it out, it was an overall wonderful evening for me and my family and reasonably priced, with excellent service.  We did come on a rainy weekday night, I hear getting a table on a weekend can be a bit of a wait, and if I was going to wait, I'd rather wait for a table at Red Onion.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Had high expectations that were not met.  Food was OK but nothing exceptional.  Service was not as friendly as other local restaurants.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
We came here for my sister's birthday because she had been before but hadn't been in ages. I was hesitant because this place gets so much hype that I figured it would just be a tourist trap. Honestly, now that I've actually been here I'm ashamed as a Portland-born human that I put it off for so long. 

We didn't have to wait long on a Saturday afternoon- probably 20 minutes tops. I ordered the thai tea with fresh lime- lovely. Our waitress explained that you order a few things and then share them- basically family style. We got the spicy fish sauce wings (I'm not huge on spicy food but trust me, they're not overly spicy at all), kung op wun sen, muu paa kham waan, jasmine rice, and coconut rice. Our favorite main dishes were the kung op wun sen and the fish sauce wings. The muu paa kham waan was also good, but we all agreed that when we go again we'd order the other two things and try something new for the third. We loved the coconut rice. My mom was hesitant about it which is why we also got jasmine rice. I'm glad we got both though because I love rice and they were both great. 

We mentioned it was my sister's birthday casually and at the end of the meal our waitress brought our mango sticky rice (which we ordered and paid for, just to be clear) with a little candle. So thoughtful and sweet! Our waitress was super nice and patient with us- we had no idea what to order and she guided us in the right direction. They were also so nice when we were leaving- the restaurant had also emptied out considerably so I think a late lunch here might be a good idea! This is another random note, and a little odd, but also the water here is so good (in my opinion, my mom wasn't a huge fan). We asked the waitress and she said the secret was pandan leaf. 

It did take a long time to eat our meal- I'd say it took probably an hour and a half start to finish, so don't come here if you don't have time to wait a bit!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Pok Pok is where you go on a pilgrimage for both great wings and fabulous Thai food. Andy Ricker is a master at bringing the best of Thailand back here to us on the PNW. Thank you Chef!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Everything was good here! Wings were my favorite. Didn't realize how authentic everything was until i saw a documentary about them a few months after i went. They make everything themselves. Down to the coconut milk used in their recipes
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
When my husband and I were planning a trip to the Northwest  we just had to try out some of the places from Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives. 

Pok Pok (saying that makes me LOL since pok pok in Filipino means hoe ) wasn't just recommended by DDD, but also from a lot of our friends. This Thai restaurant is COMPLETELY different from any Thai restaurants I know. Don't be expecting Pad Thai, Pad See Ew or Pineapple fried rice in their menu just FYI. 

Location & Parking: 3/5
Since the Pok Pok is located in the downtown area, parking can be a little hard to find. We had to park in one of the residential streets and walk down to the restaurant... in the rain 

Atmosphere & Ambience: 3/5
With how busy and small it is, they had to make do with whatever room they had. We ended up sitting in their "outside area" during winter, which was covered with a patio tarp and an overhead heater which helped with the cold.  

Service: 4/5 
The waiter was pretty nice and helpful with us first timers. He tried to explain the many to us, since the menu was kind of confusing to me. 

Food & Drinks: 4/5
Spicy Fish Sauce Wings (5/5) Definitely a must when going to Pok Pok. Highly recommend getting spicy only since the regular has less of a taste. The spicy isn't even that spicy for those of you who don't like spicy. 
Sii Khrong Muu Yaang (3/5) Their version of baby back ribs wasn't bad tasting, but just really just too dry for me. The ribs weren't meaty and just not worth over $10
Sunny's Yan Wun Sen (4/5) Glass noodles served in a clay pot, tasted like the Filipino dish called "sotanghon" to me. Don't forget to add some of the citrus sauce on the side to the dish, it really makes a difference.

Overall Experience: 3.5/5
Truthfully, the only thing I'll probably order from here are the wings. They really are as good as everyone says they are. Other than the wings, I don't really think anything else (that I've tasted so far) is worth it.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: Good food, but plan on making reservations or waiting for hours.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: 6 wings for 16 dollars. Honestly wasn't worth the hype. The wings weren't incredible and it certainly just cost too much for what you get. They tasted good, don't get me wrong. The fish sauce note really makes for a more complex flavor journey, but for 16 dollars? Not coming back. And waiting forever to get 6 wings for 16 dollars? And, to touch on a common theme: customer service was definitely not a priority. So here I am, paying for overpriced chicken wings, and also paying to be treated like a peasant. Meh. Coming from a customer service field, was definitely let down.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Although we had to wait over an hour for our table even though we noticed open tables (I think they just forgot to text us), I still give this place a 5 star review!! The service here was great, the food was great. Honestly, the only bad thing was that the portions are so small. 

If you're looking for authentic Thai food, I would say this place is as close as you can get. Not only did the tables look like the ones in Thailand, but the plates were the same too!! The food was pretty spot on to what I tasted in Thailand, which surprised me. I just say, the Khao Soi was so delicious that I wanted to order a whole bowl just for myself. This place is family style, so it is recommend to order as many dishes as there is people, however, I would recommend to order maybe 1-2 more dishes since they are pretty small. 

If you're ordering the famous fish sauce wings, they only come with 6 so take that into account when counting the number of dishes.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
(Pre-Covid) I waited on this review for a while, but I can't seem to stop thinking about how disappointed Pok Pok left me every time I go out to eat Thai food. 

Being from Thailand, I can definitely say the most authentic part about this restaurant is the portions. For those of you that don't know, Thai portions are tiny (anything from half to a quarter the size of regular American portions). And yet the price, like the food, is pretty Americanized.

They definitely serve food that most other Thai restaurant don't (because most other Thai restaurants have to cater to western tastes to survive), and you definitely get more "Northern" dishes. Common in America? Hmm not really, but you can definitely find other places in Portland with similar dishes. Authentic? Ehhhh kinda? Good? Hmmm... not by any means, especially for the price. 100% overhyped. 

Honestly me and my Southeast Asian friends bond over how disappointed we were with the place. Would really appreciate it if people stop recommending me this place as an authentic and amazing experience.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Ah, the aroma of this place is divine. I was skeptical, as I have had traditional thai cuisine in mom and pop shops, but Pok Pok definitely delivered. The wait was nearly 2 hours at around 7pm. There are plenty of bars around, though, to kill time before they call you when your table is ready.

Ambiance has a funky yet homey charm to it. Service was also wonderful, always polite, attentive, and personable. 

Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings: marinated in fish sauce and palm sugar. Delightfully crispy, salty, sticky, and spicy. 
Muu Paa Kham Waan- boar collar meat served with chilled mustard greens. Garlicky and spicy. Best with eaten together. 
Cha Ca La Vong- catfish marinated in turmeric. So melt in your mouth. 
Sticky rice- a staple to pair each of these dishes with. It balances out some of the flavors and do eat the greens as it helps tone down the saltiness in these dishes. And don't be afraid to eat with your hands, it's recommended and fun and not to mention easier to combine the flavors together with the pinch of your fingers. 

I enjoyed Pok Pok, out of all my Portland eats. Because it was not your typical pad thai, pad see ew, it felt authentic. It's worth a try if you visit Portland, there's a wide variety on the menu sure to appeal you.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok was incredible! It was a truly a wonderful experience!

We were visiting Portland for the first time and some friends of ours that had previously visited said Pok Pok is a must-do food spot for our trip. 

Everything we ordered had great flavor and was filling! The Pok Pok staple is their chicken wings. The thought of fish sauce wings was a little weird at first, but they were seriously the best wings we've ever had! We honestly thought about ordering some for dessert lol. 

Dining at Pok Pok will be one of the first things we do whenever we visit Portland!
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Food 5/5: You have to get the fish sauce chicken wings, they were amazing! 

Price 4/5: 6 chicken wings (which include the mini drumstick) for $16.25. Other items on the menu generally ran from $13-$20, but the portions are large and many people do family style. 

Service 5/5: Complementary seasoned peanuts and an Asian lady came by the table to describe the popular dishes in detail. She was very adorable

The aesthetic of the place is just perfect! The outside reminds me of a tiki hut decorated with Christmas lights! Upon entering, the whole place smells like fish sauce, some hate it, but I loved it
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Exterior = 5/5
From the outside it felt like something I would see more in like the woods. Canopy tent, hanging lights, open concept, at least from the outside look. I know they have an interior area where people can sit and the bar is located. Waiting area is out in the open so you just stand there or you can put your name down then go across and hang out at the Whiskey Soda Lounge, which I found out is owned by Pok Pok. They notify you via text, and through Whiskey Soda Lounge, when your table is ready (which I really liked).

Interior = 4/5
There is a mixture of inside seating in a actual building and outside seating in what looked like a canopy tent. If it gets cold I can see people preferring the inside one - which concerns me a bit since there seemed to be more outside seating than inside. We went at dinner and were seated in the canopy tent and it was fine. The atmosphere outside felt like camp, inside (since I went to go look for the bathroom) was a bit more like a bar feel.

Service = 5/5
The servers were attentive and would check on us often. Food came out pretty quick. So there was no complaints on our side.

Order = 4/5

Fish sauce wings: 5/5
Usually I am afraid of fish sauce because of two things: 1) super salty and 2) irritates my lips. However both were not the case for when we ate these wings. They were salty but not unbearable. They had a nice sticky yet crunchy exterior, and still juicy interior. The size of the wings were also good not like other wing places which seem to find wings from tiny chickens.

Thai tea with evaporated milk: 3/5
I like my Thai tea more on the heavy creamy side (similar to how pho restaurants make it), so this wasn't a big hit with me. I can see it for people who like less heavy cream and more on the tea flavor.

Papaya salad: 4/5
This was my boyfriend's request and he really enjoyed it. It came with a fish sauce dressing that complemented the salad well. The salad itself had strips of papaya in it. Overall it was refreshing and fresh which balanced out the fried aspects of the wings we ordered.

Overall = 4/5
The place had a nice set up with Whiskey Soda Lounge so it made waiting so much easier. Also I kind of enjoyed the outside seating in the canopy so that was a different kind of experience. The food was yummy, different, and had me looking at fish sauce in a whole new way.

Hint = hang out at Whiskey Soda Lounge across the street so you don't have to just hang around in front of Pok Pok (and yes they had a big wait)
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text: My husband and I were very disappointed.  We had 3 entrees and were told to order 2-4 because they are small servings meant to share family style. The pork belly was over 50% fat and the sauce was also very greasy.  Our check was $47, no drinks, just water. The service was good, but felt the restaurant was highly overrated.
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Pan Asian, Thai, Filipino, Chicken Wings, Vietnamese
name: Pok Pok

text:
Pok Pok in Tagalog is...not a nice reference to a person...

Good thing that Pok Pok is Thai-ish food, right?? 

After carousing about the town with Clover, we decided to head over to Pok Pok and sit outside so we could enjoy the weather. 

It's so boring to say it, but it's true. Ike's Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings are rad. Man, they are SO good. I have 3 different kinds of fish sauce in my house at any given moment so I'm a big fan. The wings have a softer breading--due to the generous tossing in the fish sauce...sauce. 

The half chicken is a good size and was easily shared between the two of us; it was tender and moist, but was made even bettah by the dipping sauces (tamarind and something else.) 

I wasn't a real fan of their Thai tea. I was glad that it wasn't crushingly sweet, but the vinegar they add...I wasn't keen on.

I really liked the Pet Pha Lo: Duck leg in brothy richness, including a duck egg. It's reminiscent of hot clay pot. I had it with coconut rice--which is great here. The sticky rice, however, is not how I like sticky rice. I couldn't tolerate the plastic bag taste from the rice being steamed in the plastic bag: Could I get my rice ziploc-taste free, por favor?
